Preface to the Second Edition
In this new edition, the author has made mainly the following revisions
to the ﬁrst edition, in addition to some minor changes and corrections of
minor errors:
(1) A relatively great expansion of Chapter 1 with some rewriting.
(2) A little expansion of Chapters 5, 6 and 8.
(3) Two subjects, which were missing in the ﬁrst edition, are added: occu-
pation number representations (Sections 2.10, 5.8 and 6.10) and Haag’s
theorem (Section 8.14). The latter is important in understanding the
mathematical structure of quantum ﬁeld theory.
(4) In view of the importance of the concept of spontaneous symmetry
breaking in modern quantum physics, a new chapter, Chapter 15, is
added as an introduction to this subject.
(4) The bibliography in the ﬁrst edition is also revised but not intended to
be complete.
The author thanks readers for their comments and remarks on the ﬁrst
edition.
Asao Arai
Sapporo
October 2023

Preface to the First Edition
The notion of a quantum ﬁeld was introduced in physics in the later part of
the 1920s to unify the particle and wave pictures of quantum particles, such
as electrons and photons, which have the so-called wave–particle duality.
After pioneering work on quantization of wave functions (the so-called “sec-
ond quantization”) by Dirac (1927), Jordan & Klein (1927), Jordan (1927)
and Jordan & Wigner (1928), Heisenberg and Pauli (1929, 1930)1 presented
a general theory of quantum ﬁelds which uniﬁes the foregoing theories,
where a quantum ﬁeld is “deﬁned” by the “canonical quantization” of a
classical wave ﬁeld.
A basic class of quantum ﬁelds is called free quantum ﬁelds, which
describe free (non-interacting) elementary particles. As far as free quantum
ﬁelds are concerned, the quantum ﬁeld theory (QFT) by Heisenberg and
Pauli was successful in unifying the wave and particle pictures of elemen-
tary particles with a general theoretical framework for quantum systems,
in which the number of elementary particles may change. However, if one
applies the formalism of QFT to an interacting system of quantum ﬁelds
and calculates the physical quantities of interest in an approximate way
(formal perturbation theory), then one encounters divergent integrals and
hence meaningless results. This is the so-called “diﬃculty of divergence”
in QFT.2
Later, in the 1940s, a prescription to avoid the diﬃculty of divergence
and to obtain meaningful results which can be compared with experiments
1Heisenberg, W. and Pauli, W. Zur Quantendynamik der Wellenfelder I. Z. Phys. 56:
1–61; ibid. II, Z. Phys. 59: 168–190.
2There are two kinds of divergences: ultraviolet and infrared. The former (resp., latter)
is a divergence with respect to large momenta (resp., small momenta in the case of
massless quantum particles).
vii
viii
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
was invented by Feynman, Schwinger and Tomonaga. The prescription
is called “renormalization theory,” with which QFT as a physical theory
revived. In particular, quantum electrodynamics (QED), a QFT describ-
ing the interaction of electrons (the quantum electron ﬁeld) and photons
(the quantum radiation ﬁeld), explains experimental results with surpris-
ingly high precision.3 From a mathematically rigorous point of view, how-
ever, the diﬃculty of divergence in QFT remains unsolved; it was unclear
what kind of mathematics can justify QFT with renormalization theory.4
In these situations, mathematically rigorous investigations of QFT were
started in the 1950s to give it a sound mathematical basis. Since then,
mathematical studies on quantum ﬁelds have formed a major stream of
research in modern mathematical physics. Many interesting mathematical
theories have been born from studies on mathematical problems in QFT and
are still developing in various directions, having close relations mutually.
These developments show the richness of mathematics that the concept of
quantum ﬁeld has in itself and suggest that QFT may have something to
do with almost all areas in mathematics, explicitly or implicitly. Quantum
ﬁelds are so fascinating but not so easy to understand in their totality.
The purpose of this book is to describe and explain to beginners the basic
aspects of the mathematical theory of quantum ﬁelds.
In mathematical studies on QFT, there are basically two approaches: an
axiomatic one and a constructive one. The former assumes a set of axioms
that a quantum ﬁeld should obey and investigates what results can be
derived from the axioms. This approach is useful in the analysis of general
aspects of QFT which are independent of individual quantum ﬁeld models.
QFT based on this approach is called axiomatic QFT. On the other hand,
the latter approach is concerned with showing the mathematical existence
of concrete models in QFT and deriving their properties in a mathemat-
ically rigorous way. This kind of QFT is called constructive QFT.5 But
this classiﬁcation of QFT is just for convenience; these two approaches are,
3See, for example, Kinoshita, T. (ed.) (1990). Quantum Electrodynamics. Singapore:
World Scientiﬁc. The three physicists mentioned above were awarded the Nobel Prize
for physics in 1965 for their contributions to the construction of QED with the renor-
malization theory (Nobel Lectures, Physics Vol. 4, 1972, Elsevier Publishing Company,
Amsterdam New York).
4At present (as of April 10, 2024), this problem is not solved yet for QFT in four-
dimensional space-time.
5Originally, the name “constructive QFT” was used for mathematical approaches con-
structing concretely relativistic interacting quantum ﬁeld models. However, here, we use
the word in a wider sense.
Preface to the First Edition
ix
in fact, complementary. Rather, by employing these two approaches, one
may arrive at a deeper, higher and wider cognition of the nature of the
microscopic world described by quantum ﬁelds.
This book consists of two parts. Part I, which is from Chapter 1 to
Chapter 7, is devoted to giving a detailed description of the theory of Fock
spaces, which are basic spaces in the mathematical theory of quantum ﬁelds.
From a purely mathematical point of view, a Fock space is a general and
natural type of Hilbert space in the sense that it is deﬁned as the inﬁnite
direct sum of tensor products of a Hilbert space (see Chapters 4–6 for
details), i.e., in a Fock space, the concept of sum is incorporated with the
concept of product in a general and natural form in terms of a Hilbert
space with the concept of inﬁnity (recall that “sum” and “product” are
fundamental concepts which appear in almost all places in the mathematical
world, taking various forms). Historically, as its name suggests, the ﬁrst
concrete forms of Fock spaces were presented by Fock6 in 1932 in relation
to the aforementioned “second quantization.” In the context of QFT, a Fock
space is used to describe the state vectors of a quantum system in which
inﬁnitely many elementary particles may exist. It is well known that there
are two kinds of families of elementary particles, i.e., bosons and fermions.
Corresponding to this fact, there are three types of Fock spaces. A Fock
space describing the state vectors of a quantum system consisting of the
same kind of bosons (resp., fermions) is called a boson (resp., fermion) Fock
space, and a Fock space describing the state vectors of a quantum system
consisting of the same kinds of bosons and fermions is called a boson–
fermion Fock space.7 In fact, a boson Fock space (resp., a fermion Fock
space) is identiﬁed with a closed subspace of a larger Hilbert space, called
a full Fock space. From this point of view, in this book, a description of the
theory of Fock spaces begins with a full Fock space in Chapter 4. The theory
of boson Fock space (resp., fermion Fock space and boson–fermion Fock
space) is discussed in Chapter 5 (resp., Chapters 6 and 7). In particular,
in Chapter 7, a theory of inﬁnite-dimensional Dirac-type operators on a
boson–fermion Fock space, which is a new theory developed by the author
of this book in connection with supersymmetric QFT, is described in detail.
As far as the author knows, this is the ﬁrst time that the theory has been
presented as part of a book.
6Fock, V. Konﬁgurationsraum und zweite Quantelung. Z. Phys. 75: 622–647.
7There is another type of Fock space, called a q-Fock space, which interpolates a boson
Fock space and a fermion Fock space. But, in this book, we do not discuss it.
x
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
In Part II, which is from Chapter 8 to Chapter 14, QFT is described
as an application of the mathematical theories in Part I. Except in
Chapter 8, in which the general theories of QFT including axiomatic QFT
are described, concrete quantum ﬁeld models and their basic properties
are discussed. In Chapters 9–12, we construct four kinds of free quan-
tum ﬁelds: (i) de Broglie ﬁeld: a non-relativistic matter ﬁeld (Chapter 9);
(ii) Klein-Gordon ﬁeld: a relativistic scalar ﬁeld (Chapter 10); (iii) radi-
ation ﬁeld (Chapter 11); and (iv) Dirac ﬁeld: a relativistic spinor ﬁeld
(Chapter‘12). Free quantum ﬁelds do not describe interacting elementary
particles. In Chapter 13, we treat a simple interacting quantum ﬁeld model,
called the van Hove model, or the van Hove–Miyatake (vHM) model. This
model is a prototype for interacting quantum ﬁeld models and has been
extensively studied. In this book, an abstract version of the model is deﬁned
and analyzed in detail. This approach makes clear the general structures
behind the concrete vHM model. It is shown how the problems of ultra-
violet divergence and infrared divergence are solved in the abstract vHM
model. In the last chapter, we present a list of interacting quantum ﬁeld
models, which are more complex and/or realistic than the vHM model, and
give a short description of each model. To make the book as self-contained
as possible, appendices are added.
This book is based on the author’s books Fock Spaces and Quantum
Fields I and II (2000, Nippon-Hyoron-Sha, Tokyo) written in Japanese, but
it is not just an English translation of them: in this English edition, expan-
sions as well as alterations have been made (e.g., Chapter 1 is newly added
and Chapter 0 (heuristic arguments on QFT in physics) in the Japanese
edition is not included). This book is primarily intended to be an introduc-
tory textbook, not a monograph, as are the Japanese editions. Hence, the
bibliography in the book is partial and far from complete. It also includes
textbooks and monographs written in Japanese, some of which are cited
in the Japanese editions. They may be helpful for readers who can read
Japanese. The author thanks the readers of the Japanese editions for their
comments, remarks and questions, which have been useful in writing this
revised and enlarged edition.
Asao Arai
Sapporo
January 2017
Preface to the First Edition
xi
Reader’s Guide
Chapter 1 is a preliminary chapter which is devoted to the description of
elements of the theory of linear operators (in particular, unbounded self-
adjoint operators) on Hilbert spaces. Those who are familiar with these
topics can skip Chapter 1 and start reading from Chapter 2. In this book,
Chapter 7 is not necessarily needed to read Chapters 8–14. Therefore, for
the ﬁrst reading, one can skip Chapter 7.

About the Author
Asao Arai has been an Emeritus Professor at Hokkaido University since
2017. He graduated with a B.S. in physics at Chiba University in 1976,
got a master’s degree in science from the University of Tokyo in 1979 and
received his Ph.D. in science from Gakushuin University in 1986. The author
worked as an Assistant Professor of mathematics at Tokyo Institute of
Technology from 1980 to 1986 and then moved to Hokkaido University to
work as a Lecturer (1986–1992) and an Associate Professor (1992–1995) of
mathematics. He was a professor of mathematics at Hokkaido University
from 1995 to 2017. The author has been working on the mathematical
foundations of quantum ﬁeld theory and published many mathematics and
mathematical physics papers on quantum ﬁeld theory and related topics.
He published also a number of books in mathematics and mathematical
physics (many of them are written in Japanese).

PART I

Chapter 1
Theory of Linear Operators
This chapter is devoted to mathematical preliminaries: the fundamentals
of the theory of linear operators on Banach and Hilbert spaces are reviewed within
the scope of the following chapters. We assume that the reader is familiar with
the elements of Banach space theory as well as those of Hilbert space theory.
1.1
Linear Operators on Vector Space
Throughout this book, the symbol K denotes R (the set of real numbers)
or C (the set of complex numbers). An element of K is called a scalar.
1.1.1
Deﬁnitions
Let X and Y be vector spaces over K. Recall that a non-empty subset
D of X is called a subspace of X if, for all Ψ, Φ ∈D and α, β ∈K,
αΨ + βΦ ∈D. A linear operator T from X to Y is a mapping from a
subspace D of X to Y (i.e., T : D →Y ) such that, for all Ψ, Φ ∈D and
α, β ∈K,
T (αΨ + βΦ) = αT (Ψ) + βT (Φ)
(linearity).
The subspace D is called the domain of T and denoted as D = D(T ).
We also write T (Ψ) = T Ψ. If D(T ) = X , then T is said to be every-
where deﬁned. A linear operator from X to Y is also called a linear
transformation from X to Y .
We sometimes simply say “operator” instead of “linear operator.”
3
4
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
It follows from the deﬁnition of a linear operator that, for all n ∈N

We denote the set of linear operators from X to Y by L(X , Y ). In
the case where X = Y , we use the following symbol:
L(X ) := L(X , X ).
As a convention, an element T in L(X ) is said to be a linear operator on
X even if it is not everywhere deﬁned.
We denote by IX the identity operator (or the identity) on X :
IX (Ψ) := Ψ, Ψ ∈X .
Remark 1.1. In the case where X and Y are complex vector spaces, there
is another class of mappings from the subspaces of X to Y which makes a
contrast with L(X , Y ). Let D be a subspace of X . A mapping A : D →Y
is said to be anti-linear if
A(αΨ + βΦ) = α∗A(Ψ) + β∗A(Φ),
Ψ, Φ ∈D, α, β ∈C,
where α∗is the complex conjugate of α. In this case, A is called an anti-
linear operator from X to Y with domain D(A) := D.
For T ∈L(X , Y ), the set
Ran(T ) := {T Ψ | Ψ ∈D(T )}
is called the range of T , or the image of T . It is easy to see that Ran(T )
is a subspace of Y . We sometimes write Ran(T ) = RanT .
The direct sum of the vector spaces X and Y is the vector space
deﬁned by
X ⊕Y := {(Ψ, Φ)|Ψ ∈X , Φ ∈Y }
with addition (Ψ, Φ) + (Ψ ′, Φ′) := (Ψ + Ψ ′, Φ + Φ′) and scalar multiplication
α(Ψ, Φ) := (αΨ, αΦ) (Ψ, Ψ ′ ∈X , Φ, Φ′ ∈Y , α ∈K).
For a linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ), the subset
G (T ) := {(Ψ, T Ψ) ∈X ⊕Y |Ψ ∈D(T )}
(1.1)
of X ⊕Y becomes a subspace of X ⊕Y . This subspace is called the graph
of T .
Theory of Linear Operators
5
For a subset D ⊂D(T ), a subset of Y is deﬁned as follows:
T D := T (D) := {T Ψ|Ψ ∈D}.
If T ∈L(X ) and D ⊂D(T ) is a subspace of X such that T D ⊂D, then
one says that T leaves D invariant. In this case, D is called an invariant
subspace of T .
Two linear operators S, T ∈L(X , Y ) are said to be equal if D(T ) =
D(S) and T Ψ = SΨ, Ψ ∈D(T ). In this case, we write T = S. This type of
equality on operators is called operator equality.
If there exists a subspace D ⊂D(S) ∩D(T ) such that, for all Ψ ∈D,
SΨ = T Ψ, then we say that S is equal to T on D; in this case, we write
as “S = T on D.” Note that this notion of equality on operators is weaker
than that of operator equality.
A linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ) is said to be injective, or one to one,
if Ψ1 ̸= Ψ2 (Ψ1, Ψ2 ∈D(T )), then T Ψ1 ̸= T Ψ2 (this is equivalent to that, if
T Ψ1 = T Ψ2 (Ψ1, Ψ2 ∈D(T )), then Ψ1 = Ψ2). In this case, one can deﬁne a
linear operator T −1 ∈L(Y , X ) as follows:
D(T −1) := Ran(T ),
T −1Φ := Ψ, Φ ∈D(T −1),
where Ψ ∈D(T ) is the unique vector satisfying T Ψ = Φ. The operator T −1
is called the inverse of T , or the inverse operator of T . It follows that
T −1T = ID(T ),
T T −1 = IRan(T ).
If Ran(T ) = Y , then T is said to be surjective.
If T is injective and surjective, then T is said to be bijective and is
called a bijection.
It is easy to see that T is injective if and only if the kernel
ker T := {Ψ ∈D(T ) | T Ψ = 0}
of T is equal to {0}.
1.1.2
Eigenvalues
Let T ∈L(X ). In this case, there is a structure which relates T to numbers.
A number λ ∈K is called an eigenvalue of T if there exists a non-zero
vector Ψ ∈D(T ) such that T Ψ = λΨ. Such a vector Ψ is called an eigen-
vector of T with eigenvalue λ. The subspace spanned by all eigenvectors
of T with eigenvalue λ is called the eigenspace of T with eigenvalue λ.
We denote the set of eigenvalues of T by σp(T ) and call it the point
spectrum of T .
6
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
It is obvious that Ψ is an eigenvector of T with eigenvalue λ if and only
if Ψ ∈ker(T −λ)\{0} (T −λ := T −λIX ).1 Hence, the eigenspace of T
with eigenvalue λ is equal to ker(T −λ).
For a vector space V , we denote its dimension by dim V ∈N ∪{∞}.
The dimension dim ker(T −λ) of the eigenspace ker(T −λ) is called the
multiplicity of the eigenvalue λ. If dim ker(T −λ) = 1 (resp., dim ker(T −
λ) ≥2), then the eigenvalue λ is said to be simple (resp., degenerate).

power T n of T is deﬁned as follows: T 0 := IX and, for n ≥1, T n := T · · · T
(the n-fold product of T ). We have T 1 = T .
1.1.4
A partial ordering in linear operators
A linear operator S ∈L(X , Y ) is said to be an extension of a linear
operator T ∈L(X , Y ) if D(T ) ⊂D(S) and T Ψ = SΨ, Ψ ∈D(T ). This
relation is written as T ⊂S, or S ⊃T .
Note that S = T if and only if S ⊂T and T ⊂S.

X|x ̸∈B}, the complement of B.

Let T ∈L(X , Y ) and D ⊂D(T ) be a subspace. Then, one can deﬁne
a linear operator T ↾D by
D(T ↾D) := D,
(T ↾D)Ψ := T Ψ,
Ψ ∈D.
The operator T ↾D is called the restriction of T to D. It is obvious that
T ↾D ⊂T .
The relation ⊂in L(X , Y ) is a partial ordering.
The partial ordering ⊂in L(X , Y ) is preserved for product operations
of linear operators.
Proposition 1.1. Let S, T ∈L(X , Y ) such that T ⊂S. Let W and Z be
vector spaces over K. Then, for all Q ∈L(W , X ) and R ∈L(Y , Z ),
T Q ⊂SQ,
RT ⊂RS.
Proof. An easy exercise (Problem 2).

1.1.5
Commutator
For S, T ∈L(X ), the commutator [S, T ] ∈L(X ) is deﬁned by
[S, T ] := ST −T S.
By the deﬁnition of the sum of linear operators, one has
D([S, T ]) = D(ST ) ∩D(T S).
It follows that
[S, T ] = −[T, S]
(anti-symmetry).
The operators S and T are said to commute if, for all Ψ ∈D([S, T ]),
[S, T ]Ψ = 0. In this case, one says that S commutes with T .
If there exists a subspace D ⊂D([S, T ]) such that [S, T ] = 0 on D, then
we say that S and T commute on D.
The notion of commutator yields a notion of diﬀerential in the space
L(X ) described as follows. For each A ∈L(X ), one can deﬁne a mapping
δA : L(X ) →L(X ) by
δA(X) := [A, X],
X ∈L(X ).
It is easy to see that, for all X, Y ∈L(X ) and α, β ∈K,
δA(αX + βY ) ⊃αδA(X) + βδA(Y ).
(1.2)

In particular, if D(A) = X and D(X) = X = D(Y ), then the operator
equality δA(αX + βY ) = αδA(X) + βδA(Y ) holds. By direct computations,
one can show that, for all X, Y ∈L(X ),
δA(XY ) = δA(X)Y + XδA(Y )
(Leibniz rule)
(1.3)
on D([A, X]Y )∩D(X[A, Y ]). Note that δA(X) and Y (resp., X and δA(Y ))
do not necessarily commute. Formulae (1.2) and (1.3) mean that δA is, in
a sense, a “diﬀerential” mapping on L(X ). The mapping δA is called the
derivation on L(X ) with respect to A.

1.2
Linear Operators on Banach Space
We assume that the reader is familiar with the elements of Banach space
theory. We next consider the case where the vector spaces X and Y are
Theory of Linear Operators

Banach spaces over K with norm ∥·∥X and ∥·∥Y , respectively.2 A Banach
space over C (resp., R) is called a complex (resp., real ) Banach space. In
what follows, we sometimes use the term “Banach space” to mean “Banach
space over K.”
We recall that a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in a Banach space X is said to
converge to a vector Ψ ∈X if limn→∞∥Ψn −Ψ∥X = 0. In this case, one
writes limn→∞Ψn = Ψ.
For a subset D ⊂X , the set
D :=

Ψ ∈X | ∃Ψn ∈D (n ∈N) such that lim
n→∞Ψn = Ψ

is called the closure of D. If D = X , then D is said to be dense in X .
1.2.1
Continuous mappings
Let D be a non-empty subset of X . A mapping f : D →Y is said to be
continuous at Ψ0 ∈D if, for any ε > 0, there exists a constant δ > 0 such
that, for all Ψ ∈D satisfying ∥Ψ −Ψ0∥X < δ, ∥f(Ψ) −f(Ψ0)∥Y < ε. If f is
continuous at every vector in D, then f is said to be continuous on D.
1.2.2
Bounded linear operators
A linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ) is said to be bounded if there exists a
constant C ≥0 such that ∥T Ψ∥Y ≤C∥Ψ∥X , Ψ ∈D(T ). In this case, the
ﬁnite quantity
∥T ∥:=
sup
Ψ∈D(T )\{0}
∥T Ψ∥Y
∥Ψ∥X
,
the supremum of {∥T Ψ∥Y /∥Ψ∥X |Ψ ∈D(T )\{0}}, is called the operator
norm (or simply norm) of T . It follows that
∥T Ψ∥Y ≤∥T ∥∥Ψ∥X ,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
(1.5)
Remark 1.2. For an anti-linear operator T from X to Y , the boundedness
and operator norm of T are deﬁned in the same form as above.
For a subspace D of X , we denote by B(D, Y ) the set of bounded
linear operators T ∈L(X , Y ) with D(T ) = D:
B(D, Y ) := {T ∈L(X , Y )|T is bounded}.
(1.6)
2We sometimes omit the subscript X in the norm ∥· ∥X if there is no danger of
confusion.

It is easy to see that B(D, Y ) is a vector space and the following hold:
(i) ∥T ∥= 0 (T ∈B(D, Y )) ⇐⇒T = 0D (the zero operator from D to Y ).
(ii) ∥αT ∥= |α| ∥T ∥,
α ∈K, T ∈B(D, Y ).
(iii) (triangle inequality) ∥T + S∥≤∥T ∥+ ∥S∥, T, S ∈B(D, Y ).
Hence, the operator norm ∥· ∥: B(D, Y ) →K is certainly a norm.
Property (iii) above implies the following inequality:
| ∥T ∥−∥S∥| ≤∥T −S∥.
(1.7)
A bounded linear operator is continuous on its domain.
Proposition 1.2. Let T ∈L(X , Y ) be bounded. Then, for every sequence
{Ψn}∞
n=1 in D(T ) (Ψn ∈D(T ), n ∈N) such that limn→∞Ψn = Ψ ∈D(T ),
limn→∞T Ψn = T Ψ.
Proof. We have ∥T Ψn −T Ψ∥Y = ∥T (Ψn −Ψ)∥Y ≤∥T ∥∥Ψn −Ψ∥X (by
(1.5)) →0 (n →∞).
□
Proposition 1.2 implies that a bounded linear operator is continuous at
the origin 0 ∈X in particular. In fact, the converse is true, as shown in
the following.
Proposition 1.3. If T ∈L(X , Y ) is continuous at the origin, then T is
bounded.
Proof. Based on the present assumption, for any ε > 0, there exists a con-
stant δ > 0 such that, for all Φ ∈D(T ) satisfying ∥Φ∥X < δ, ∥T Φ)∥Y < ε.
Let Ψ ∈D(T )\{0} and Θ := δ(1 + δ)−1Ψ/∥Ψ∥X . Then, Θ ∈D(T ) and
∥Θ∥X < δ. Hence, ∥T Θ∥Y < ε, which gives ∥T Ψ∥Y ≤C∥Ψ∥X with
C := ε(1 + δ)/δ, including the case Ψ = 0. Hence, T is bounded.
□
It is easy to see that a linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ) is continuous at
the origin if and only if T is continuous on D(T ). Thus, Propositions 1.2
and 1.3 show that the boundedness of a linear operator from one Banach
space to another is equivalent to its continuity.
The following theorem shows that every element in B(X , Y ) (the case
of D = X in B(D, Y )) is uniquely determined by its operation on a dense
subspace of X .
Theorem 1.1. Let T, S ∈B(X , Y ). Suppose that there exists a dense
subspace D of X such that T = S on D. Then, T = S.
Theory of Linear Operators

Proof. Since D is dense in X , for each vector Ψ ∈X , there exists a
sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in D (Ψn ∈D, n ∈N) such that limn→∞Ψn = Ψ. Based
on the present assumption, we have T Ψn = SΨn, n ∈N. Since T and S
are bounded, it follows from Proposition 1.2 that limn→∞T Ψn = T Ψ and
limn→∞SΨn = SΨ. Hence, T Ψ = SΨ, ∀Ψ ∈X . Thus, T = S.
□

We say that T ∈L(X , Y ) is densely deﬁned if D(T ) is dense in X .
The following theorem is a basic one on a densely deﬁned, bounded linear
operator.
Theorem 1.3 (Extension theorem). Let T
∈
L(X , Y ) be densely
deﬁned and bounded. Then, there exists a unique bounded linear operator
T ∈B(X , Y ) such that T ⊂T. Moreover, ∥T∥= ∥T ∥.
Proof. For each Ψ ∈X , there exists a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in D(T ) such that
limn→∞Ψn = Ψ. Then, it follows from the boundedness of T that {T Ψn}∞
n=1
is a Cauchy sequence in Y . Hence, the limit TΨ := limn→∞T Ψn exists in
Y . It is easy to show that the limit is independent of the choice of {Ψn}∞
n=1.
Therefore, the operator T is well deﬁned with D( T ) = X . It is obvious
that TΨ = T Ψ, ∀Ψ ∈D(T ) (take Ψn = Ψ, ∀n ∈N). Hence, T ⊂T. We have
∥TΨ∥= limn→∞∥T Ψn∥≤∥T ∥∥Ψ∥. Hence, T is bounded with ∥T∥≤∥T ∥.
On the other hand, for all Ψ ∈D(T ), ∥T Ψ∥= ∥TΨ∥≤∥T∥∥Ψ∥, implying
that ∥T ∥≤∥T∥. Therefore, ∥T∥= ∥T ∥. The uniqueness of T follows from

1.2.3
Closed operators
A linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ) is said to be closed if, for every sequence
{Ψn}∞
n=1 in D(T ) (i.e., Ψn ∈D(T ), n ∈N)3 such that limn→∞Ψn = Ψ ∈X
and limn→∞T Ψn = Φ ∈Y , it holds that Ψ ∈D(T ) and Φ = T Ψ.
Proposition 1.4. Every element in B(X , Y ) is closed.
Proof. An easy exercise (Problem 4).
□
In what follows, a closed linear operator is simply called a closed
operator.
For T ∈L(X , Y ), we deﬁne
∥Ψ∥T := ∥Ψ∥X + ∥T Ψ∥Y ,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
It follows that the mapping ∥· ∥T : D(T ) →[0, ∞) is a norm. Let
∥(Ψ, T Ψ)∥G(T ) := ∥Ψ∥T ,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
Then, ∥· ∥G (T ) is a norm of the graph G (T ) of T and G (T ) becomes a
normed space with the norm ∥· ∥G (T ). The norm ∥· ∥G (T ) (or ∥· ∥T ) is
called the graph norm of T .
The domain D(T ) is a normed space with norm ∥· ∥T. It is easy to see
that the normed space (D(T ), ∥· ∥T ) is a Banach space if and only if T is
closed.
The importance of the concept of closed operator is shown in the fol-
lowing theorem.
Theorem 1.4 (Closed graph theorem). Let
T
∈
L(X , Y )
with
D(T ) = X . Then, T is bounded if and only if T is closed.
Proof. See, for example, Reed and Simon (1972), Theorem III.12.
□
An important application of the closed graph theorem is as follows.
Theorem 1.5. Let T ∈L(X , Y ) be closed and bijective. Then, T −1 ∈
B(Y , X ).
Proof. Based on the present assumption, we have T −1 ∈L(Y , X ) and
D(T −1) = Y . According to the closed graph theorem, we need only to

A linear operator T ∈L(X , Y ) is said to be closable if it has a
closed extension (i.e., there exists a closed operator S ∈L(X , Y ) such
that T ⊂S). It is obvious that every closed operator is closable. In what
follows, a closable linear operator is simply called a closable operator.
Proposition 1.5. Let T ∈L(X , Y ). Then, the following are equivalent:
(i) T is closable.
(ii) If
a

that T ⊂S. Let {Ψn}∞
n=1 be the sequence assumed in (ii). Then, SΨn →Φ
(n →∞). Since S is closed, it follows that Φ = S0 = 0.
Assume (ii). We deﬁne an operator T as follows:
D(T ) := {Ψ ∈X | ∃Ψn ∈D(T ) (n ∈N) such that lim

and ∃lim

Based on the assumed condition (ii), the limit limn→∞T Ψn is independent
of the choice of {Ψn}∞
n=1 and hence T is well deﬁned. For each Ψ ∈D(T ),
one can take Ψn to be equal to Ψ. Then, Ψ ∈D(T ) and TΨ = T Ψ. Hence,
T ⊂T. It is not so diﬃcult to prove that T is closed. Thus, (i) holds.
□
According to Proposition 1.5 and its proof, each closable operator
T ∈L(X , Y ) has the closed extension T deﬁned by (1.9) and (1.10). The
operator T is called the closure of T . It follows that T is the smallest closed
extension of T (i.e., for all closed extensions S of T , T ⊂S). In particular,
if T is closed, then T = T .
It is easy to see that, for two closable operators S, T ∈L(X , Y ), the
following holds:
T ⊂S =⇒T ⊂S.
(1.11)

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
This means that the closure operation T →T for the closable operator T
preserves the partial ordering of linear operators.
For an operator T ∈L(X , Y ), a subspace D ⊂D(T ) is called a core
of T if, for each Ψ ∈D(T ), there exists a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in D such that
limn→∞Ψn = Ψ and limn→∞T Ψn = T Ψ.
It follows that, in the case where T is closed, a subspace D ⊂D(T ) is a
core of T if and only if T ↾D = T .
The following theorem gives a necessary and suﬃcient condition for the
sum A + B of two closed operators A, B ∈L(X , Y ) to be closed.
Theorem 1.6. Let A and B be closed operators from X to Y . Then, A+B
is closed if and only if there exists a constant C > 0 such that
∥AΨ∥+ ∥BΨ∥≤C(∥(A + B)Ψ∥+ ∥Ψ∥), Ψ ∈D(A) ∩D(B).
(1.12)
Proof. Suppose that A + B is closed. Then, as remarked above, D(A + B)
is a Banach space with the norm ∥· ∥A+B. We deﬁne a linear operator
J : (D(A + B), ∥· ∥A+B) →(D(A), ∥· ∥A) by JΨ := Ψ, Ψ ∈D(A + B).
Then, it is easy to show that J is closed. Hence, according to the closed
graph theorem, J is bounded. Therefore, there exists a constant C1 > 0
such that ∥Ψ∥A ≤C1∥Ψ∥A+B, Ψ ∈D(A + B). This implies that ∥AΨ∥Y ≤
C1(∥Ψ∥X +∥(A+B)Ψ∥Y ), Ψ ∈D(A+B). Similarly, there exists a constant
C2 > 0 such that ∥BΨ∥Y ≤C2(∥Ψ∥X + ∥(A + B)Ψ∥Y ), Ψ ∈D(A + B).
Thus, (1.12) holds with C = C1 + C2. Conversely, it is easy to show that
(1.12) implies the closedness of A + B.
□
Remark 1.4. Theorem 1.6 is sometimes useful in perturbation theory.
1.2.4
Resolvent set and spectra of linear operator
Let X be a complex Banach space. Let T ∈L(X ). The subset of C
ρ(T ) := {λ ∈C|Ran(T −λ) = X , T −λ is injective and
(T −λ)−1 is bounded}
is called the resolvent set of T . For each λ ∈ρ(T ), the bounded operator
(T −λ)−1 is called the resolvent of T at λ.

The complement of ρ(T )
σ(T ) := C\ρ(T )
is called the spectrum of T . One can also consider the following subsets
of σ(T ):
σr(T ) := {λ ∈C | T −λ is injective and Ran(T −λ) ̸= X },
σc(T ) := {λ ∈C | Ran(T −λ) = X , T −λ is injective and
(T −λ)−1 is unbounded},
which are called, respectively (Fig. 1.1), the residual spectrum and and
continuous spectrum of T .
The four sets ρ(T ), σr(T ), σc(T ) and σp(T ) are mutually disjoint, and
C = ρ(T ) ∪σr(T ) ∪σc(T ) ∪σp(T ),
σ(T ) = σr(T ) ∪σc(T ) ∪σp(T ).
(1.13)
An eigenvalue λ of T is called a discrete eigenvalue of T if the multi-
plicity of λ is ﬁnite and λ is an isolated point of σ(T ). The set of all discrete
eigenvalues of T is called the discrete spectrum of T and denoted by
σd(T ). Obviously, σd(T ) ⊂σp(T ).
A basic theorem on the spectrum of a linear operator is the following.
Theorem 1.7. For all T ∈B(X ), σ(T ) is a non-empty bounded closed
subset in C with σ(T ) ⊂{λ ∈C | |λ| ≤∥T ∥}.
Proof. See, for example, Reed and Simon (1972), p. 191, Corollary.
□
Proposition 1.6. Let T be closable. Then:
(i) ρ(T ) = ρ(T) and σ(T ) = σ(T ).
(ii) For all λ ∈ρ(T ), (T −λ)−1 = (T −λ)−1.
(iii) ρ(T ) is an open set in C and σ(T ) is a closed set in C.

Proof. See, for example, Arai and Ezawa (1999a), Proposition 2.18 and
Theorem 2.20 and Yosida (1965), p. 211, Theorem 1.
□
In the case of closed operators, one has the following simple criterion to
identify ρ(T ).
Proposition 1.7. Let T be closed. Then, λ ∈ρ(T ) if and only if T −λ is
bijective.
Proof. Let λ ∈ρ(T ). Then, Ran(T −λ) = X and T −λ is injective,
with (T −λ)−1 being bounded. Using the closedness of T −λ and the
boundedness of (T −λ)−1, one can show that Ran(T −λ) = Ran(T −λ).
Hence, Ran(T −λ) = X . Thus, T −λ is a bijection.
Conversely, suppose that T −λ is bijection. It is easy to see that T −λ
is closed. Hence, according to Theorem 1.5, (T −λ)−1 is bounded. Thus,
λ ∈ρ(T ).
□
1.2.5
Compact operators
There is an important class of bounded linear operators from the Banach
space X
to the Banach space Y . An operator T
∈L(X , Y ) with
D(T ) = X is said to be compact, or completely continuous, if, for
every bounded sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in X (i.e., Ψn ∈X , ∥Ψn∥X ≤M, n ∈N,
for some constant M > 0), there exists a subsequence {Ψnk}∞
k=1 such that
{T Ψnk}∞
k=1 converges. It follows that a compact operator is bounded. More-
over, T ∈L(X , Y ), with D(T ) = X , is compact if and only if T maps
every bounded set in X to a pre-compact set in Y .
The fundamental properties of a compact operator can be found in
most textbooks on functional analysis. Here, we only recall a basic spectral
property of a compact operator.
Lemma 1.2. Let T be a compact operator on the Banach space X . Then,
σ(T )\{0} consists of only discrete eigenvalues of T , and if σ(T )\{0} is an
inﬁnite set {λn}∞
n=1, then limn→∞λn = 0.
1.3
Linear Operators on Hilbert Space
Let H be an inner product space (pre-Hilbert space) over K.4 We denote
its inner product and norm by ⟨, ⟩H (anti-linear, or conjugate linear, in
4We assume that the reader is familiar with the elements of inner product space and
Hilbert space theory.
Theory of Linear Operators
17
the ﬁrst variable and linear in the second variable in the case K = C) and
∥· ∥H , respectively. But we sometimes omit the subscript H if there is
no danger of confusion in the context under consideration. Recall that a
Hilbert space is a complete inner product space and is hence a Banach
space. Therefore, we can apply the theory of linear operators on a Banach
space to linear operators on a Hilbert space.
1.3.1
Dual spaces
Let H be a Hilbert space over K. Then, an element in
H ∗:= B(H , K)
is called a bounded (or continuous) linear functional on H . The set
H ∗is called the dual space of H . The following theorem is important.
Theorem 1.8 (Riesz’s representation theorem). For each F ∈H ∗,
there exists a unique vector ΦF ∈H such that F(Ψ) = ⟨ΦF , Ψ⟩, Ψ ∈H .
Moreover, ∥F∥= ∥ΦF ∥H .
Proof. See textbooks on Hilbert space theory.5
□
1.3.2
Adjoint operators
Let H1 and H2 be Hilbert spaces over K. For a densely deﬁned linear
operator T ∈L(H1, H2), a linear operator T ∗∈L(H2, H1), called the
adjoint of T , is deﬁned as follows:
D(T ∗) := {Φ ∈H2|∃ΘΦ ∈H1 such that ∀Ψ ∈D(T ), ⟨Φ, T Ψ⟩= ⟨ΘΦ, Ψ⟩},
T ∗Φ := ΘΦ, Φ ∈D(T ∗).
If T ∗is densely deﬁned, we denote its adjoint by T ∗∗, i.e., T ∗∗:= (T ∗)∗.
Let T, S ∈L(H1, H2) be densely deﬁned. Then, the following is easily
proved:
T ⊂S =⇒S∗⊂T ∗.
(1.14)
Proposition 1.8. Let T ∈L(H1, H2) be densely deﬁned. Then:
(i) T ∗is closed.
(ii) T is closable if and only if T ∗is densely deﬁned. In that case, T
∗= T ∗
and T = T ∗∗.

On the adjoint of an everywhere deﬁned, bounded linear operator, one
has the following.
Proposition 1.9. For all T ∈B(H1, H2), T ∗∈B(H2, H1) and
∥T ∥= ∥T ∗∥,
T ∈B(H1, H2).
Moreover, T = T ∗∗.
Proof. See, for example, Reed and Simon (1972), Theorem VI.3, or Arai
(1997a, 2014a), Proposition 2.15.
□
Proposition 1.10. If T
∈L(H1, H2) is a densely deﬁned, closable
unbounded operator, then T ∗is unbounded.
Proof. According to Proposition 1.8, T ∗is densely deﬁned and closed.
Suppose that T ∗is bounded. Then, T ∗∈B(H2, H1). Then, by Proposi-
tion 1.8(ii), T = (T ∗)∗∈B(H1, H2). But this is a contradiction. Thus, T ∗
is unbounded.
□
With regard to the adjoint of the sum (resp., product) of two densely
deﬁned linear operators, one has the following.
Proposition 1.11. Let T, S ∈L(H1, H2) and R ∈L(H2, H3) (H3 is a
Hilbert space) be densely deﬁned.
(i) Suppose that T + S is densely deﬁned. Then, (T + S)∗⊃T ∗+ S∗. In
particular, if T is bounded with D(T ) = H1, then (T + S)∗= T ∗+ S∗.
(ii) Suppose that RT ∈L(H1, H3) is densely deﬁned. Then, (RT )∗⊃
T ∗R∗. In particular, if R is bounded with D(R) = H2, then (RT )∗=
T ∗R∗.
Proof. See, for example, Arai (1997a, 2014b), Proposition 2.16, and
Schm¨udgen (2012), Propositions 1.6 and 1.7.
□
1.3.3
Topologies of convergence of bounded linear operators
There are three kinds of concepts on convergence for sequences in
B(H1, H2).
Theory of Linear Operators
19
Let {Tn}∞
n=1 be a sequence in B(H1, H2) and T ∈B(H1, H2).
(C.1) {Tn}∞
n=1 is said to converge to T uniformly or in opera-
tor norm as n →∞if limn→∞∥Tn −T ∥= 0. In this case, we write
u- limn→∞Tn = T , and T is called the uniform limit of {Tn}∞
n=1.
(C.2) {Tn}∞
n=1 is said to converge strongly to T as n →∞if, for all
Ψ ∈H1, limn→∞∥TnΨ −T Ψ∥H2 = 0. In this case, we write s- limn→∞Tn =
T , and T is called the strong limit of {Tn}∞
n=1.
(C.3) {Tn}∞
n=1 is said to converge weakly to T as n →∞if, for all
Ψ ∈H1 and Φ ∈H2, limn→∞⟨Φ, TnΨ⟩H2 = ⟨Φ, T Ψ⟩H2. In this case, we
write w- limn→∞Tn = T , and T is called the weak limit of {Tn}∞
n=1.
Remark 1.5. The above deﬁnitions also apply to the case where {Tn}∞
n=1
is replaced by a subset {Tλ}λ∈Λ of B(H1, H2) indexed by an open set Λ of
Rd (d ∈N).6 In that case, “n →∞” is replaced by “λ →a” (a ∈Rd). See
also Remark 1.6 in the following.
The logical relations shown in Fig. 1.2 hold.
Remark 1.6. The space B(H1, H2) possesses three kinds of topologies:
(i) (standard one) For each δ > 0 and T ∈B(H1, H2), the set Uδ(T ) :=
{S ∈B(H1, H2)| ∥S −T ∥< δ} is called a δ-neighborhood of T , or
an open ball of radius δ with center T . A subset O of B(H1, H2)
is called an open set if, for each T ∈O, there exists a δ > 0 such
that Uδ(T ) ⊂O. The set of all open sets in B(H1, H2) is called the
uniform operator topology, or the operator-norm topology, on
B(H1, H2). The space B(H1, H2) is a Banach space in this topology.
The convergence in operator norm deﬁned in (C.1) above is due to this
topology.
(ii) For each Ψ ∈H1, a mapping EΨ : B(H1, H2) →H2 is deﬁned by
EΨ(T ) := T Ψ, T ∈B(H1, H2). The strong operator topology on
B(H1, H2) is deﬁned as the weakest topology on B(H1, H2) such that,
for all Ψ ∈H1, EΨ is continuous. In this topology, a net7 {Tλ}λ∈Λ in
uniform convergence =⇒strong convergence =⇒weak convergence

(iii) For each pair (Ψ, Φ) ∈H1 × H2, a mapping EΨ,Φ : B(H1, H2) →C
is deﬁned by EΨ,Φ(T ) := ⟨Φ, T Ψ⟩, T ∈B(H1, H2). The weak topol-

(written Tλ
w→T ). In this case, we say that {Tλ}λ∈Λ converges to
T weakly. The weak convergence of a sequence deﬁned in (C.3) is a
special case of this convergence.

Proof. By (1.7), we have | ∥Tn∥−∥T ∥| ≤∥Tn −T ∥→0 (n →∞). Hence,
the desired result follows.

1.3.4
Graph and core
It is easy to see that, for two linear operators S and T in L(H1, H2), T = S
if and only if G (S) = G (T ), where, for a linear operator L, G (L) denotes
the graph of L (see (1.1)).
22
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
For each A ∈L(H1, H2), the graph G (A) of A is an inner product space
with the inner product of the direct sum Hilbert space H1 ⊕H2.9 It follows
that the inner product space G (A) is closed (hence a Hilbert space) if and
only if T is closed.
For a subset D of a Hilbert space H , we denote by D⊥the orthogonal
complement of D in H :
D⊥:= {Ψ ∈H | ⟨Ψ, Φ⟩H = 0, Φ ∈D}.
It follows that D⊥is a closed subspace of H and D⊥= (D)⊥.
Proposition 1.15. Let T be closed and D ⊂D(T ) be a subspace. Then,
D is a core of T if and only if G (T ↾D)⊥∩G (T ) = {0}.
Proof. Let D be a core of T , and let (Ψ, T Ψ) ∈G (T ↾D)⊥∩G (T ). Then,
for all Φ ∈D, ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩+ ⟨T Φ, T Ψ⟩= 0. Since D is a core of T , there exists a
sequence {Φn}∞
n=1 in D such that Φn →Ψ, T Φn →T Ψ (n →∞). Letting
Φ = Φn in the above equation and taking the limit n →∞, we obtain
∥Ψ∥2 + ∥T Ψ∥2 = 0. Hence, Ψ = 0, T Ψ = 0. Thus, G (T ↾D)⊥∩G (T ) = {0}.
Conversely, let G (T
↾D)⊥∩G (T ) = {0}. Then, G (T
↾D) is
dense in G (T ). Hence, for each (Ψ, T Ψ) ∈G (T ), there exists a sequence
{(Ψn, T Ψn)}∞
n=1 in G (T ↾D) such that (Ψn, T Ψn) →(Ψ, T Ψ) (n →∞) in
G (T ). Hence, Ψn ∈D, n ≥1 and Ψn →Ψ, T Ψn →T Ψ (n →∞). Thus, D
is a core of T .
□
The following proposition is often used to identify a smaller core of a
closed operator.
Proposition 1.16. Let T ∈L(H1, H2) be closed and D ⊂D(T ) be a core
of T . Let F ⊂D be a subspace of H1 such that, for each Ψ ∈D, there
exists a sequence {Ψn}n in F satisfying Ψn →Ψ and T Ψn →T Ψ (n →∞).
Then, F is a core of T .
Proof. Let (Φ, T Φ) ∈G (T ↾F)⊥∩G (T ). Then, for all Ψ ∈F,
⟨Φ, Ψ⟩+ ⟨T Φ, T Ψ⟩= 0.
By the property of F assumed and a limiting argument, this equation
extends to all Ψ ∈D, implying that (Φ, T Φ) ∈G (T ↾D)⊥∩G (T ). Hence,
by Proposition 1.15, (Φ, T Φ) = 0. Thus, G (T ↾F)⊥∩G (T ) = {0}. By
Proposition 1.15 again, F is a core of T .
□
9The inner product of (Ψ1, Ψ2) ∈H1 ⊕H2 and (Φ1, Φ2) ∈H1 ⊕H2 is deﬁned by
⟨(Ψ1, Ψ2), (Φ1, Φ2)⟩:= ⟨Ψ1, Φ1⟩+ ⟨Ψ2, Φ2⟩.

1.3.5
Unitary equivalence
An operator U ∈B(H1, H2) is said to be unitary if Ran(U) = H2 and
⟨UΨ, UΦ⟩H2 = ⟨Ψ, Φ⟩H1 , Ψ, Φ ∈H1.
It is shown that an operator U ∈B(H1, H2) is unitary if and only if
U ∗U = IH1 and UU ∗= IH2.
A unitary operator is also called a unitary transformation.
Let A ∈L(H1) and B ∈L(H2). Then, A and B are said to be unitarily
equivalent (or A is said to be unitarily equivalent to B) if there exists a
unitary operator U : H1 →H2 satisfying
B = UAU −1.
(1.19)
In this case, one says that B is a unitary transform of A by U.
Proposition 1.17. Suppose that A ∈L(H1) is densely deﬁned and U ∈
B(H1, H2) be a unitary operator. Deﬁne B ∈L(H2) by (1.19). Then, B
is densely deﬁned and B∗= UA∗U −1.
Proof. An exercise (Problem 5).
□
The
spectra
of
a
linear
operator
are
invariant
under
unitary
transformations.
Theorem 1.9 (Unitary invariance of spectra). Let H1 and H2 be
complex Hilbert spaces (i.e., Hilbert spaces over C). Suppose that A ∈L(H1)
and B ∈L(H2) are unitarily equivalent. Then, the following (i)–(iv) hold:
(i) σ(A) = σ(B).
(ii) σp(A) = σp(B) and, for all λ ∈σp(A), dim ker(A −λ) = dim
ker(B −λ).
(iii) σr(A) = σr(B).
(iv) σc(A) = σc(B).
Proof. Under the present assumption, there exists a unitary operator U :
H1 →H2 such that UAU −1 = B. Hence, for all λ ∈C, U(A −λ)U −1 =
B −λ. The facts (i)–(iv) follow from this operator equality.
□
The following proposition is useful for proving the unitary equivalence
between two closed operators.
Proposition 1.18. Let A and B be closed operators on Hilbert spaces
H1 and H2, respectively. Suppose that there exist a unitary operator
24
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
U : H1 →H2 and a core F ⊂H2 of B such that U −1F is a core of
A and
UAU −1 = B
on F.
(1.20)
Then, the operator equality
UAU −1 = B
(1.21)
holds.
Proof. The operator UAU −1 is closed. Hence, (1.20) implies that B ⊂
UAU −1. Relation (1.20) also gives A = U −1BU on U −1F. Since U −1(F)
is a core of A, it follows that A ⊂U −1BU. Hence, by Proposition 1.1,
UAU −1 ⊂B. Thus, (1.21) holds.
□
1.3.6
A decomposition theorem
The following theorem is very useful.
Theorem 1.10. Let T be a closed operator from a Hilbert space H to a
Hilbert space K . Then:
(i) The kernel of T , ker T , is closed.
(ii) If D(T ) is dense in addition, then
H = ker T ⊕Ran(T ∗).
(1.22)
Proof. Part (i) is easy to prove. By (i), we have the orthogonal decompo-
sition H = ker T ⊕(ker T )⊥. It is easy to show that Ran(T ∗)⊥= ker T (use
Proposition 1.8) and hence (ker T )⊥= (Ran(T ∗)⊥)⊥= Ran(T ∗). Hence,
we obtain (1.22).
□
We call (1.22) the natural orthogonal decomposition of H with
respect to T .
1.3.7
Relative boundedness
Let S and T be linear operators from a Hilbert space H to a Hilbert space
K such that D(T ) ⊂D(S) and there exist constants a, b ≥0 such that
∥SΨ∥≤a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥,
Ψ ∈D(T ),
where we omit the subscripts H and K in the norms ∥· ∥H and ∥· ∥K .
Then, S is said to be T -bounded, or relatively bounded with respect
Theory of Linear Operators
25
to T . In this case, the constant a is called a relative bound of S with
respect to T . The inﬁmum of the relative bounds of S with respect to T is
called the relative bound of S with respect to T , or simply the T -bound
of S.
If a > 0 can be taken arbitrarily small (b may depend on a) (i.e., the
T -bound of S is zero), then S is said to be inﬁnitesimally small with
respect to T .
Theorem 1.11. Let T be closed and S be closable. Suppose that D(T ) ⊂
D(S) and there exist a constant a ∈[0, 1) (i.e., 0 ≤a < 1) and a constant
b ≥0 such that
∥SΨ∥≤a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
(1.23)
Then, T + S is closed, and any core of T is a core of T + S.
Proof. By (1.23), for all Ψ ∈D(T ),
∥T Ψ∥≤∥(T + S)Ψ∥+ ∥SΨ∥≤∥(T + S)Ψ∥+ a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥.
Hence,
∥T Ψ∥≤
1
1 −a(∥(T + S)Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥).
(1.24)
Now, let Ψn ∈D(T + S) = D(T ), Ψn →Ψ ∈H and (T + S)Ψn →Φ ∈H
as n →∞. Then, by (1.24), {T Ψn}n is a Cauchy sequence. Hence, by the
closedness of T , Ψ ∈D(T ) = D(T + S) and T Ψ = limn→∞T Ψn. Hence,
limn→∞SΨn = Φ −T Ψ, which means that SΨ = Φ −T Ψ. However, since
D(T ) ⊂D(S) ⊂D(S), it follows that SΨ = Φ −T Ψ, i.e., (T + S)Ψ = Φ.
Thus, T + S is closed.
Let D be any core of T . Then, for each Ψ ∈D(T ), there exists a sequence
{Ψn}n in D such that Ψn →Ψ and T Ψn →T Ψ as n →∞. Then, by (1.23),
SΨn →SΨ (n →∞). Hence, (T + S)Ψn →(T + S)Ψ. Thus, D is a core of
T + S.
□
The following proposition describes an extension of an inequality on
relative boundedness.
Proposition 1.19. Let T be closed and S be closable. Suppose that there
exist a subspace D ⊂D(T )∩D(S) and non-negative constants a, b such that
D is a core of T and
∥SΨ∥≤a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥,
Ψ ∈D.
(1.25)

Then, D(T ) ⊂D(S) and
∥SΨ∥≤a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
(1.26)
Proof. Let Ψ ∈D(T ). Then, there exists a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1, with Ψn ∈D,
such that Ψn →Ψ and T Ψn →T Ψ as n →∞. By (1.25), we have

(1.27)
and

1.3.8
Hermitian, symmetric and self-adjoint operators
Let H be a Hilbert space over K.
A linear operator T on H is said to be Hermitian if, for all Ψ, Φ ∈
D(T ), ⟨Ψ, T Φ⟩= ⟨T Ψ, Φ⟩(Hermitian property).
A densely deﬁned Hermitian operator T on H is called a symmetric
operator. Hence, T is symmetric if and only if D(T ) is dense and T ⊂T ∗.
A densely deﬁned linear operator T on H is said to be self-adjoint if
T = T ∗.
By Proposition 1.8(i), a self-adjoint operator is closed.
Remark 1.7. Some authors use the term “Hermitian operator” to mean
“symmetric operator,” and vice versa. In many books and articles on phys-
ical quantum theory, little attention is given to distinguish among the three
kinds of operators deﬁned above and their domains (Fig. 1.3). It is obvious
that a self-adjoint operator is a closed symmetric operator. But it has to
be emphasized that the converse is not true, i.e., a closed symmetric opera-
tor is not necessarily self-adjoint if the Hilbert space under consideration is
inﬁnite-dimensional. Also, the following theorem should be kept in mind.
Theorem 1.12 (The Hellinger–Toeplitz theorem).
An everywhere deﬁned symmetric operator on a Hilbert space is bounded
(hence, it is a bounded self-adjoint operator).
{self-adjoint operators} ⊂{symmetric operators}
⊂{Hermitian operators}
Fig. 1.3
A hierarchy in linear operators in inﬁnite-dimensional Hilbert spaces.
Theory of Linear Operators
27
Proof. This follows from an application of the closed graph theorem (Theo-
rem 1.4). Let T be an everywhere deﬁned symmetric operator on a Hilbert
space H . Let {Ψn}∞
n=1 be a sequence in H such that Ψn →Ψ ∈H
and T Ψn →η ∈H as n →∞. By the Hermitian property of T , for all
Φ ∈H , ⟨Φ, T Ψn⟩= ⟨T Φ, Ψn⟩. Hence, taking the limit n →∞, we obtain
⟨Φ, η⟩= ⟨T Φ, Ψ⟩= ⟨Φ, T Ψ⟩. Hence, η = T Ψ. Therefore, T is closed. Thus,
according to the closed graph theorem, T is bounded.
□
This theorem implies that an unbounded symmetric operator is not
everywhere deﬁned.
Hermiteness (resp., symmetricity, self-adjointness) of a linear operator
is a unitarily invariant property.
Proposition 1.20. Let H and K be Hilbert spaces over K and U : H →
K be a unitary operator. Let A ∈L(H ) and B := UAU −1. Then:
(i) If A is Hermitian, then B is Hermitian.
(ii) If A is symmetric, then B is symmetric.
(iii) If A is self-adjoint, then B is self-adjoint.
Proof. (i) Let A be Hermitian. Then, for all Φ, Ψ ∈D(B), ⟨Φ, BΨ⟩=

U −1Φ, AU −1Ψ

=

AU −1Φ, U −1Ψ

= ⟨BΦ, Ψ⟩. Hence, B is Hermitian.
(ii) Let A be symmetric. Then, A is densely deﬁned and A ⊂A∗. Hence,
by Proposition 1.1, B ⊂UA∗U −1. By Proposition 1.17, UA∗U −1 = B∗.
Therefore, B ⊂B∗. Thus, B is symmetric.
(iii) This follows from Proposition 1.17.
□
A linear operator S on H is called a symmetric extension of a linear
operator T on H if S is symmetric and S is an extension of T : T ⊂S.
A basic property of a self-adjoint operator is as follows.
Theorem 1.13. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space H and
S be a symmetric extension of T . Then, S = T .
Proof. Under the present assumption, we have T ⊂S. Hence, by (1.14),
S∗⊂T ∗= T . Therefore, S∗⊂T ⊂S. But S ⊂S∗since S is symmetric.
Thus, S∗= T = S.
□
Theorem 1.13 is rephrased as “a self-adjoint operator has no non-trivial
symmetric extension.”
It follows from Proposition 1.8(ii) that a symmetric operator is closable.
A symmetric operator S is said to be essentially self-adjoint if the closure
S is self-adjoint.
28
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
The expression “essentially self-adjoint” is justiﬁed by the following
proposition.
Proposition 1.21. Suppose that a symmetric operator S is essentially self-
adjoint. Then, S is the unique self-adjoint extension of S.
Proof. Let T be any self-adjoint extension of S: S ⊂T . Then, by (1.11)
and the closedness of T , S ⊂T . Since S is self-adjoint, it has no non-trivial
symmetric extension (Theorem 1.13). Hence, S = T .
□
Let T be a Hermitian operator on H . Then, for all Ψ ∈D(T ), ⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩is
a real number. If there exists a constant γ ∈R such that, for all Ψ ∈D(T ),
⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩≥γ∥Ψ∥2, then T is said to be bounded from below, or, simply,
bounded below. In this case, we write T ≥γ, or γ ≤T . In particular, if
γ > 0 (resp., γ = 0), then T is said to be strictly positive (resp., positive,
or non-negative).
If −T is bounded from below with −T ≥−b (b ∈R), then T is said
to be bounded from above. In this case, we write T ≤b, or b ≥T . In
particular, if b < 0 (resp., b = 0), then T is said to be strictly negative
(resp., negative, or non-positive).
If T is bounded from below or bounded from above, then T is said to
be semi-bounded.
A non-negative Hermitian operator has the following good property.
Proposition 1.22. Let T be a non-negative Hermitian operator. Then, for
all Ψ ∈D(T ) and a > 0,
∥(T + a)Ψ∥2 ≥∥T Ψ∥2 + a2∥Ψ∥2.
(1.28)
Proof. This follows from the expansion ∥(T + a)Ψ∥2
=
∥T Ψ∥2 +
2aRe ⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩+ a2∥Ψ∥2 and ⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩≥0.
□
If T and S are Hermitian operators on H satisfying D(T ) ⊂D(S) and
⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩≤⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩, Ψ ∈D(T ), then we write S ≤T . This is equivalent to
(T −S) ↾D(T ) ≥0.
The relation ≤in the set of symmetric operators is a partial ordering.
Proposition 1.23. Let H be a complex Hilbert space (i.e., a Hilbert space
over C) and T be a Hermitian operator on H . Then, for all z ∈C\R, A−z
is injective and (A −z)−1 is bounded with
∥(A −z)−1∥≤
1
|Im z|,
(1.29)
where Im z denotes the imaginary part of z.
Theory of Linear Operators
29
Proof. Let Ψ ∈D(A) and z ∈C. Then, using the Hermiteness of A, one
can show that ∥(A −z)Ψ∥2 = ∥(A −Re z)Ψ∥2 + |Im z|2∥Ψ∥2, where Re z
denotes the real part of z. Hence, ∥(A −z)Ψ∥2 ≥|Im z|2∥Ψ∥2. This implies
that if Imz ̸= 0, then A −z is injective and (A −z)−1 is bounded with

The following theorem states the basic spectral properties of a self-
adjoint operator.
Theorem 1.14. Let H be a complex Hilbert space and T be a self-adjoint
operator on H .
(i) The spectrum σ(T ) is a non-empty closed subset of R. In particular,
C\R ⊂ρ(T ).
(ii) The residual spectrum σr(T ) is empty (Problem 9) and hence
σ(T ) = σp(T ) ∪σc(T ).
(iii) Let λ ∈R. Then, λ ∈σ(T ) if and only if there exists a sequence
{Ψn}∞
n=1 of unit vectors in D(T ) (∥Ψn∥= 1, n ≥1) such that
limn→∞∥(T −λ)Ψn∥= 0.
(iv) If T ≥γ for some γ ∈R, then σ(T ) ⊂[γ, ∞).
Proof. See, for example, Reed and Simon (1975), Theorem X.1, or Arai
(1997a, 2014b), Theorems 2.30 and 2.31.
□

1.3.10

of vectors ΨM ∈M and ΨM ⊥∈M ⊥such that
Ψ = ΨM + ΨM ⊥.

D(PM ) = H ,

PM . It is obvious that Ran(PM ) = M . The operator PM is called the
orthogonal projection onto M .

1.3.11
Weak commutator
There is a weak form of the commutation relation. Let H be a Hilbert
space and A, B ∈L(H ) be densely deﬁned. If there exist a dense subspace
D of H and an operator C ∈L(H ) such that D ⊂D(A)∩D(A∗)∩D(B)∩
D(B∗) ∩D(C) and
⟨A∗Φ, BΨ⟩−⟨B∗Φ, AΨ⟩= ⟨Φ, CΨ⟩,
Φ, Ψ ∈D,
then we say that (A, B) has a weak commutator C on D. Since D is
dense, C is uniquely determined on D. Based on this fact, we write
C ↾D = [A, B]D
w .
Hence,
⟨A∗Φ, BΨ⟩−⟨B∗Φ, AΨ⟩=

Φ, [A, B]D
w Ψ

,
Φ, Ψ ∈D.
(1.32)
If D ⊂D(AB) ∩D(BA), then it follows that
[A, B]D
w = [A, B] ↾D.
In this sense, the weak commutator of two linear operators is regarded as
a weak version of the commutator of two linear operators.

1.5
Self-Adjoint Operators and Related Subjects
In what follows, we mean by a Hilbert space a complex Hilbert space unless
otherwise stated.
In this section, we present facts on self-adjoint operators and related
subjects which are used later in this book.
1.5.1
Criteria on (essential) self-adjointness for symmetric
operators
In this section, we summarize criteria for a symmetric operator to be (essen-
tially) self-adjoint. As usual, we denote by i the imaginary unit.
Proposition 1.28. Let T be a symmetric operator on a Hilbert space H .
Then, the following are equivalent:
(i) T is self-adjoint.
(ii) T is closed and ker(T ∗± i) = {0}.
(iii) Ran(T ± i) = H .
Proof. See, for example, Reed and Simon (1972), Theorem VIII.3, or Arai
(1997a, 2014b), Theorem 4.1.
□
A simple application of Proposition 1.28 is given as follows.
Theorem 1.16. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H . Then, for all
n ∈N, T n is self-adjoint.
Proof. Let αk := eiπ/2ne2πik/n, k = 0, . . . , n −1, so that αn
k = i, k = 0,
. . . , n −1. Then, T n −i = n−1
k=0(T −αk). Each αk is not real. Hence αk
and α∗
k are in ρ(T ). Therefore, A := (T −αn−1)−1 · · · (T −α0)−1 is in
B(H ) and A∗= (T −α∗
0)−1 · · · (T −α∗
n−1)−1, which is injective. Hence,
using the natural orthogonal decomposition of H with respect to A∗(see
(1.22) or a general fact (Problem 7), Ran(A) is dense in H . But Ran(A) ⊂
D(T n). Hence, D(T n) is dense. It follows that T n is symmetric. For all
Theory of Linear Operators
35
Φ ∈H , we have (T n −i)AΦ = Φ. Hence, Ran(T n −i) = H . Similarly,
one can show that Ran(T n + i) = H . Thus, by Proposition 1.28, T n is
self-adjoint.
□
In the case of a non-negative symmetric operator T , one has simpler
criteria for T to be self-adjoint.
Proposition 1.29. Let T be a non-negative symmetric operator on a
Hilbert space H . Then, the following are equivalent:
(i) T is self-adjoint.
(ii) T is closed, and ker(T ∗+ 1) = {0}.
(iii) Ran(T + 1) = H .
Proof. (i) =⇒(ii). Assume (i). Then, T is closed. Let Ψ ∈ker(T ∗+ 1).
Then, by (i), (T + 1)Ψ = 0. Hence, T Ψ = −Ψ. Therefore, ⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩=
−∥Ψ∥2 ≤0. But the left-hand side is non-negative due to the non-negativity
of T . Hence, ∥Ψ∥2 = 0, implying Ψ = 0. Thus, ker(T ∗+ 1) = {0}.
(ii) =⇒(iii). Assume (ii). Then, by the natural orthogonal decomposi-
tion H = ker(T ∗+ 1) ⊕Ran(T + 1) with respect to T ∗+ 1 (see (1.22)),
we have H = Ran(T + 1). By inequality (1.28), we have ∥(T + 1)Ψ∥≥
∥Ψ∥, Ψ ∈D(T ). Using this inequality and the closedness of T , one can
show that Ran(T + 1) is closed. Hence, (iii) holds.
(iii) =⇒(i). Assume (iii). Since D(T ) ⊂D(T ∗) by the symmetry of T ,
we need only to show that D(T ∗) ⊂D(T ). Let Ψ ∈D(T ∗). Then, there
exists a vector Φ ∈D(T ) such that (T + 1)Φ = (T ∗+ 1)Ψ. Hence, (T ∗+ 1)
(Ψ −Φ) = 0. On the other hand, by the natural orthogonal decomposition
of H with respect to T ∗+ 1, we have ker(T ∗+ 1) = {0}. Hence, Ψ = Φ.
Hence, Φ ∈D(T ). Therefore, D(T ∗) ⊂D(T ).
□
We also need criteria for a symmetric operator to be essentially self-
adjoint.
Proposition 1.30. Let T be a symmetric operator on a Hilbert space H .
Then, the following are equivalent:
(i) T is essentially self-adjoint.
(ii) ker(T ∗± i) = {0}.
(iii) Ran(T ± i) are dense in H .
Proof. This follows from Proposition 1.28.
□
36
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Proposition 1.31. Let T be a non-negative symmetric operator on a
Hilbert space H . Then, the following are equivalent:
(i) T is essentially self-adjoint.
(ii) ker(T ∗+ 1) = {0}.
(iii) Ran(T + 1) is dense in H .
Proof. This follows from Proposition 1.29
□
A symmetric operator T is said to be essentially self-adjoint on a dense
subspace D ⊂D(T ) if T ↾D (the restriction of T to D) is essentially
self-adjoint. In this case, one has T = T ↾D.
Proposition 1.32. Let T be a self-adjoint operator and D be a dense sub-
space such that D ⊂D(T ). Then, D is a core of T if and only if T is
essentially self-adjoint on D.
Proof. The “if part” is obvious. Let D be a core of T . Then, by Proposition
1.28(iii), for each Φ ∈H , there exists a vector Ψ ∈D(T ) such that (T +
i)Ψ = Φ. Since D is a core of T , there exists a sequence {Ψn}n in D such
that Ψn →Ψ and T Ψn →T Ψ as n →∞. Hence, (T + i)Ψn →(T + i)Ψ = Φ
as n →∞. This means that Ran((T + i) ↾D) is dense in H . Similarly,
one can show that Ran((T −i) ↾D) is dense in H . Thus, by Proposition
1.30(iii), T is essentially self-adjoint on D.
□
The following proposition may be useful to prove the essential self-
adjointness of a symmetric operator on a suitable subspace.
Proposition 1.33. Let H and K be Hilbert spaces and D be a dense
subspace of K . Let T and S be symmetric operators on H and K , respec-
tively, satisfying the following (i) and (ii):
(i) S is essentially self-adjoint on D.
(ii) There exists a unitary transformation U : H →K such that U −1D ⊂
D(T ) and, for all Ψ ∈D, UT U −1Ψ = SΨ.
Then, T is essentially self-adjoint on U −1D, and the operator equality
UTU −1 = S holds.
Proof. By (ii), we have (S ±i)D = U(T ±i)U −1D. By (i) and Proposition
1.30, (S ± i)D are dense in K . Hence, U(T ± i)U −1D are dense in K .
Since a unitary operator maps a dense subspace to a dense subspace, it
follows that (T ±i)U −1D are dense in H . Thus, by Proposition 1.30 again,
T is essentially self-adjoint on U −1D. We have UTU −1 ⊃S ↾D. Hence,
Theory of Linear Operators
37
UTU −1 ⊃S. Since both sides are self-adjoint and a self-adjoint operator
has no non-trivial self-adjoint extension, the operator equality UTU −1 = S
holds.
□
1.5.2
The Kato–Rellich theorem
We recall a fundamental theorem in perturbation theory of self-adjoint
operators. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space H and S
be a symmetric operator on H . Then, a natural question is: under what
condition is T + S self-adjoint? A basic theorem on this question is given
as follows.
Theorem 1.17 (The Kato–Rellich theorem). Let
T
and
S
be as
above. Suppose that S is T -bounded with a relative bound less than 1, i.e.,
D(T ) ⊂D(S) and there exist constants a ∈[0, 1) and b ≥0 such that
∥SΨ∥≤a∥T Ψ∥+ b∥Ψ∥,
Ψ ∈D(T ).
(1.33)
Then, T + S is self-adjoint and essentially self-adjoint on any core of T .
Moreover, if T is bounded from below with T ≥γ (γ ∈R), then T + S is
bounded from below with
T + S ≥γ −max{b/(1 −a), a|γ| + b}.
(1.34)
Proof. See, for example, Arai (2006b), Theorem 2.7; Kato (1976), p. 287,
Theorem 4.3; or Reed and Simon (1975), Theorem X.12.
□
Corollary 1.1. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H and S be a symmet-
ric operator on H such that D(T ) ⊂D(S).
(i) If S is inﬁnitesimally small with respect to T , then T +S is self-adjoint
and essentially self-adjoint on any core of T .
(ii) If S is bounded, then T + S is self-adjoint and essentially self-adjoint
on any core of T . Moreover, if T ≥γ (γ ∈R), then T + S ≥γ −∥S∥.
Proof. In part (i) (resp., (ii)), one can take a < 1 (resp., a = 0 < 1,
b = ∥S∥) in (1.33). Hence, by Theorem 1.17, one obtains the desired
results.
□

1.5.4
Spectral measures and functional calculus
(A) Spectral measures
Let (X, Σ) be a measurable space and H be a Hilbert space. We denote
by P(H ) be the set of all orthogonal projections on H . A mapping E :
Σ →P(H ); Σ ∋B →E(B) ∈P(H ) (or a family of orthogonal projections
{E(B)|B ∈Σ} on H ) is called a spectral measure on (X, Σ), or a
projection-valued measure on (X, Σ), if the following hold:
(E.1) E(X) = I (the identity on H ).
(E.2) (complete additivity) If {Bn|n ∈N} is a family of mutually disjoint
Σ-measurable sets, i.e., Bn ∈Σ, n ∈N and, for n ̸= m, Bn ∩Bm = ∅
(empty set), then
E(∪∞
n=1Bn) = s- lim
N→∞
N

n=1
E(Bn),
where s-lim means the strong limit.
40
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
We summarize some basic properties of a spectral measure as follows.
Proposition 1.35. Let E be a spectral measure on (X, Σ). Then, the fol-
lowing hold:
(i) E(∅) = 0.
(ii) (ﬁnite additivity) Let Bn ∈Σ (n = 1, . . . , N, N ∈N) such that, for
n ̸= m, Bn ∩Bm = ∅. Then,
E(B1 ∪· · · ∪BN) =
N

n=1
E(Bn).
(1.35)
(iii) (orthogonality) If B, C ∈Σ and B ∩C = ∅, then E(B)E(C) = 0.
(iv) If B ⊂C, B, C ∈Σ, then E(C)E(B) = E(B)E(C) = E(B).
(v) (product property) For all B, C ∈Σ, E(B)E(C) = E(B ∩C).
(vi) (commutativity) For all B, C ∈Σ, E(B)E(C) = E(C)E(B).
(vii) (monotonicity) If B ⊂C, B, C ∈Σ, then E(B) ≤E(C).
Proof. (i) Taking Bn = ∅in (E.2) (n = 1, 2, . . .), we have E(∅) =
s- limN→∞NE(∅), which implies that E(∅) = 0.
(ii) Taking Bn = ∅, n > N in (E.2) and using (i), we obtain (1.35).
(iii) By (1.35) with N = 2, we have E(B ∪C) = E(B) + E(C).
Taking the square of this equation and using E(A)2 = E(A), A ∈Σ,
we have E(B ∪C) = E(B) + E(B)E(C) + E(C)E(B) + E(C). Hence,
E(B)E(C) + E(C)E(B) = 0 · · · (∗). Multiplying both sides by E(B), we
obtain E(B)E(C)E(B) = 0 · · · (∗∗). Multiplying (∗) by E(B) from the left
and using (∗∗), we obtain E(B)E(C) = 0.
(iv) We have C = B + (C\B). Hence, by (ii), E(C) = E(B) + E(C\B).
Multiplying this equation by E(B) from the left (resp., the right) and using
E(B)E(C\B) = 0 = E(C\B)E(B) by (iii), we obtain that E(B)E(C) =
E(B) (resp., E(C)E(B) = E(B)).
(v) We have
B ∪C = (B ∩C) ∪D ∪F,
D := B\C, F := C\B.
Hence, by (ii), E(B ∪C) = E(B ∩C) + E(D) + E(F). Multiplying this
equation by B (resp., C) from the left and using (iv), we obtain
E(B) = E(B ∩C) + E(D),
E(C) = E(B ∩C) + E(F).
Hence, it follows that E(B)E(C) = E(B ∩C).
(vi) This follows from (v).
(vii) We have by (ii) that E(C) = E(B) + E(C\B). Since E(C\B) ≥0,
it follows that E(C) ≥E(B).
□

Proposition 1.35(vi) shows that the set {E(B)|B ∈Σ} is a family of
commuting orthogonal projections on H .

The following proposition may be used to identify supp E.
Proposition 1.36. Let a ∈Rd and, for r > 0,
Br(a) := {x ∈Rd| |x −a| < r},
the d-dimensional open ball with center a and radius r. Then, a ∈supp E
if and only if, for every ε > 0, E(Bε(a)) ̸= 0.
Proof. Suppose that there exists a constant δ > 0 such that E(Bδ(a)) = 0.
Then, E(Bδ(a)c) = I. Since Bδ(a)c is closed, it follows that supp E ⊂
Bδ(a)c. Hence, a ̸∈supp E. Thus, if a ∈supp E, then, for every ε > 0,
E(Bε(a)) ̸= 0.
Suppose that a ̸∈supp E. Then, since (supp E)c is an open set,
there exists a constant δ > 0 such that Bδ(a) ⊂(supp E)c. Since
E((supp E)c) = 0, it follows from (E.4) that E(Bδ(a)) = 0.

For a d-dimensional spectral measure E and a continuous function f on
Rd, the essential range RE(f) is identiﬁed as follows.
Lemma 1.3. Let E be a d-dimensional spectral measure and f ∈C(Rd).
Then,
RE(f) = f(supp E).
(1.44)
Proof. Let λ0 ∈f(supp E) and let ε > 0. Then, there exists a point x0 ∈
supp E such that |f(x0) −λ0| < ε/2. By the continuity of f, there exists a
constant δ > 0 such that, if |x−x0| < δ, x ∈Rd, then |f(x)−f(x0)| < ε/2.
By the triangle inequality, we have, for all x ∈Rd satisfying |x −x0| < δ,
|f(x) −λ0| ≤|f(x) −f(x0)| + |f(x0) −λ0| < ε.
Hence, Bδ(x0) ⊂Vε := {x ∈Rd| |f(x) −λ0| < ε}. Since x0 is in supp E,
it follows that E(Bδ(x0)) ̸= 0. Hence, E(Vε) ̸= 0. Therefore, λ0 ∈RE(f).
Thus, f(supp E) ⊂RE(f).
To prove the converse inclusion relation, we prove (f(supp E))c ⊂
(RE(f))c. So, let λ0 ∈(f(supp E))c. Then, for all suﬃciently small ε > 0,
{x ∈Rd| |f(x) −λ0| < ε} = ∅. Hence, E({x ∈Rd| |f(x) −λ0| < ε}) = 0.
Therefore, λ0 ∈(RE(f))c.
□
Theorem 1.21. Let E be a d-dimensional spectral measure and f ∈C(Rd).
Then,
σ(IE(f)) = f(supp E).
(1.45)
Proof. This follows from Theorem 1.20(i) and (1.44).
□

Remark 1.10. In applications to quantum mechanics, the concept of spec-
tral measure of a self-adjoint operator plays an essential role for the probabil-
ity interpretation of quantum mechanics in the following manner. A state17
of a quantum system, i.e., a quantum mechanical state is represented by
a unit vector in a Hilbert space H and a physical quantity (observable)
of the system is represented by a self-adjoint operator on H . A basic fact
in the quantum mechanical world is that a measurement on a quantum
system is not independent of the object to be measured, i.e., a measure-
ment of a quantum mechanical object in a quantum mechanical state may
change the state to another one with some probability, not deterministi-
cally. Quantum mechanics gives a method to calculate such a probability:
for a physical quantity (a quantum mechanical object) represented by a
self-adjoint operator T on H , the probability that the result of a mea-
surement of T in a state Ψ ∈H lies in a Borel set B ⊂R is given by
∥ET (B)Ψ∥2 (recall that ∥ET (·)Ψ∥2 is a probability measure on (R, B1); see
Section 1.5.4(C)), and the expectation value of T in such measurements
is

R λd∥ET (λ)Ψ∥2 = ⟨Ψ, T Ψ⟩. This forms a basic part of the probability
interpretation of quantum mechanics. In this way, the spectral measure of
a self-adjoint operator is used to give a mathematical foundation to the
probability interpretation of quantum mechanics in a very general setting
(not limited to speciﬁc quantum systems in which the spectra of physical
quantities consist of only eigenvalues).
An important result can be derived from the interpretation above. Let
Φ ∈H be a unit vector representing a quantum mechanical state and PΦ be
the orthogonal projection onto the one-dimensional subspace {αΦ|α ∈C}
generated by Φ. Then, we have
PΦΨ = ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩Φ,
Ψ ∈H .
(1.52)
By Example 1.4, the spectral measure EPΦ of PΦ is given as follows:
EPΦ({1}) = PΦ,
(1.53)
EPΦ({0}) = I −PΦ,
(1.54)
EPΦ(B) = 0,
B ⊂R\{0, 1}, B ∈B1.
(1.55)
Hence, the probability that the result of a measurement of PΦ in a state Ψ
lies in the set {1} is ∥EPΦ({1})Ψ∥2 = | ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩|2 by (1.53) and (1.52). On the
17We mean by “state” a pure state. There is a more general class of states called “mixed
states,” which can be formed from several states through superposition.
52
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
other hand, a measurement of PΦ in a state Ψ is interpreted as a measure-
ment of whether or not the state Φ is found in Ψ. Hence, ∥EPΦ({1})Ψ∥2 is
interpreted as the probability of ﬁnding Φ in Ψ by a measurement. There-
fore, | ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩|2 is interpreted as the probability of ﬁnding Φ in Ψ by a mea-
surement. Since ﬁnding Φ in Ψ by measurement means the transition from
Ψ to Φ, the quantity | ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩|2 is called the transition probability from
Ψ to Φ, while the inner product ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩is called the transition amplitude
from Ψ to Φ.

Proposition 1.39. A real number λ is an eigenvalue of S (i.e., λ ∈σp(S))
if and only if ES({λ}) ̸= 0. In that case, RanES({λ}) = ker(S −λ) and,
for all Ψ ∈ker(S −λ), supp ∥ES(·)Ψ∥2 = {λ}.
Proof. Apply Theorem 1.20(iii), with (X, Σ) = (R, B1), E = ES and
f(λ) = λ, λ ∈R.
□
Proposition 1.40. If λ ∈σ(S) is an isolated point of σ(S), then λ ∈
σp(S).
Proof. We have ES({λ}) + ES(σ(S)\{λ}) = ES(σ(S)) = I (by (1.56)).
Suppose that ES({λ}) = 0. Then, ES(σ(S)\{λ}) = I. By the isolatedness
of λ assumed, σ(S)\{λ} is a closed set. Hence, supp ES ⊂σ(S)\{λ}. But
this contradicts (1.56). Hence, ES({λ}) ̸= 0. Thus, by Proposition 1.39,
λ is an eigenvalue of S.
□

1.5.8
Essential spectrum
The set
σess(S) := σ(S)\σd(S)
is called the essential spectrum of S, where σd(S) is the discrete spectrum
of S (see Section 1.2.4). Hence, we have
σ(S) = σess(S) ∪σd(S),
σess(S) ∩σd(S) = ∅.
(1.57)
It follows that, if dim H < ∞, then σess(S) = ∅. Hence, the concept
of essential spectrum is meaningful only if the Hilbert space H is inﬁnite
dimensional.
For notational simplicity, we sometimes write RanES(·) := Ran(ES(·)).
Proposition 1.41.
(i) The essential spectrum σess(S) is a closed set in R.
(ii) A real number λ is in σess(S) if and only if, for all ε
>
0,
dim RanES((λ −ε, λ + ε)) = ∞.
Proof. (i) Let λn ∈σess(S), n ∈N and limn→∞λn = λ. Suppose that
λ ∈σd(S). Then, σ(S)\{λ} is closed. Note that λn ∈σ(S)\{λ}. Hence,
λ ∈σ(S)\{λ}. But this is a contradiction. Hence, λ ∈σess(S). Thus, σess(S)
is closed.
(ii) “only if” part: Let λ ∈σess(S). Then, the following two cases (a)
and (b) should be considered:
(a) The case where λ is an eigenvalue of S;
(b) The case where λ is not an eigenvalue of S.
The case (a): In this case, the eigenvalue λ is non-isolated or has inﬁ-
nite multiplicity. Suppose that λ is a non-isolated eigenvalue of S ﬁrst.
Then, there exists a sequence {λn}∞
n=1 (λn ̸= λm, n ̸= m) such that
λn ∈σ(S)\{λ}, n ≥1, and limn→∞λn = λ. For each n, there exists an
εn > 0 such that (λn −εn, λn + εn) ∩(λm −εm, λm + εm) = ∅, for n ̸= m.
By Proposition 1.38, dim RanES((λn −εn, λn + εn)) ≥1. For any ε > 0,
there exists an n0 ∈N such that (λ −ε, λ + ε) ⊃∪n≥n0(λn −εn, λn + εn).
Hence, by Proposition 1.27,
dim RanES((λ −ε, λ + ε)) ≥
∞

n=n0
dim RanES((λn −εn, λn + εn)) = ∞.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
f(·) : S(H ) −→L(H ); S(H ) ∋S →f(S) ∈L(H )
Fig. 1.5

We next consider the case where the multiplicity of the eigenvalue λ is
inﬁnite. In this case, for all ε > 0,

The case (b): In this case, λ is not an isolated point of σ(S) by Proposition
1.40. Then, in the same way as in the proof of the ﬁrst case of (a), we can
show that dim RanES((λ −ε, λ + ε)) = ∞.
“if ” part: Suppose that λ ∈σd(S). Then, λ is an isolated point in σ(S)
and the multiplicity m of λ is ﬁnite. Hence, there exists a constant δ > 0
such that (λ −δ, λ + δ) ∩σ(S) = {λ} and dim RanES({λ}) = m. Hence,
dim RanES((λ −δ, λ + δ)) = dim RanES({λ}) < ∞.

1.5.9
Functional calculus
Since the spectral measure ES of the self-adjoint operator S is a one-
dimensional spectral measure, one can apply the general theory of the func-
tional calculus with respect to a spectral measure, as described in Section
1.5.4, to deﬁne an operator-valued functional on MB1(R) (the set of Borel
measurable functions on R):
IES(f) =

R
f(λ)dES(λ),
f ∈MB1(R).
In what follows, we write IES(f) = f(S), i.e.,
f(S) :=

R
f(λ)dES(λ),
f ∈MB1(R).
(1.58)
Note that, for each f ∈MB1(R), the correspondence : S →f(S) gives an
operator-valued function on the set S(H ) of self-adjoint operators on H
(Fig. 1.5). We call the calculus on the operators {f(S)|f ∈MB1(R)} the
functional calculus for the self-adjoint operator S.
Theorem 1.19 implies the following:
Theorem 1.24. Let f and g be Borel measurable functions on R.
(i) For all B ∈B1, ES(B)f(S) ⊂f(S)ES(B).
(ii) If ES({λ ∈R| |f(λ)| = +∞}) = 0, then f(S) is a densely deﬁned
closed operator and f(S)∗= f ∗(S).
Theory of Linear Operators
55
(iii) If f(λ) ∈C, λ ∈R, then f(S) is a densely deﬁned closed operator
and f(S)∗= f ∗(S).
(iv) If f is bounded on supp ES, i.e., Kf := supλ∈supp ES |f(λ)| < ∞,
then f(S) ∈B(H ) and ∥f(S)∥≤Kf.
(v) If |f(λ)| = 1 for all λ ∈supp ES, then f(S) is unitary.
(vi) If f : R →R ∪{±∞} and ES({λ ∈R| |f(λ)| = +∞}) = 0, then
f(S) is self-adjoint. In particular, if f(λ) ∈R, λ ∈R, then f(S) is
self-adjoint.
(vii) If there exists a real number γ such that, for all λ ∈R, γ ≤f(λ) < ∞,
then f(S) is a self-adjoint operator with f(S) ≥γ. In particular,
if 0 ≤f(λ) < ∞, λ ∈R, then f(S) is a non-negative self-adjoint
operator.
(viii) f(S) + g(S) ⊂(f + g)(S). In particular, if g is bounded on supp ES,
then f(S) + g(S) = (f + g)(S).
(ix) D((fg)(S)) ∩D(g(S)) = D(f(S)g(S)) and f(S)g(S) ⊂(fg)(S). In
particular, if g is bounded on supp ES, then f(S)g(S) = (fg)(S).
(x) If fn ∈MB1(R), n ∈N satisfy supn∈N,λ∈supp ES |fn(λ)| < ∞and
limn→∞fn(λ) = f(λ), λ ∈supp ES, then fn(S), f(S) ∈B(H ) and
s- limn→∞fn(S) = f(S).

1.5.10
The spectral measure of a multiplication operator
We consider the multiplication operator MF on L2(X, dμ) in Section 1.5.3

MF is self-adjoint. In view of the spectral theorem, it is natural to ask what
form the spectral measure EMF of MF does take.
It is easy to see that, for all B ∈B1, the operator

(v) Let M be the set on the left-hand side of (1.63). Let Ψ ∈M . Then,

The family {eitS}t∈R is a realization of a general concept deﬁned as
follows.
A family of unitary operators {U(t)}t∈R on a Hilbert space H is called
a strongly continuous one-parameter unitary group if it has the
following properties:
(U.1) (group property) U(t + s) = U(t)U(s), t, s ∈R (then it follows that
U(0) = I and U(t)U(s) = U(s)U(t), t, s ∈R);
(U.2) (strong continuity) s- lims→0 U(t + s) = U(t), t ∈R.
For this object, the following important theorem holds.18
Theorem 1.30 (Stone’s theorem). For each strongly continuous one-
parameter unitary group {U(t)}t∈R, there exists a unique self-adjoint
operator S such that U(t) = eitS, t ∈R.
The self-adjoint operator S in this theorem is called the inﬁnitesimal
generator, or generator, of {U(t)}t∈R. Thus, there exists a one-to-one
correspondence between a self-adjoint operator and a strongly continuous
one-parameter unitary group. The family {eitS}t∈R is called the strongly
continuous one-parameter unitary group generated by S.
The following theorem is sometimes useful to prove the essential self-
adjointness of a given symmetric operator.
Theorem 1.31. Let {U(t)}t∈R be a strongly continuous one-parameter uni-
tary group on a Hilbert space H and T be a symmetric operator on H .

Hilbert space theory, for example, Reed and Simon (1972), Theorem VIII.8, and Arai
(2014b), Theorem 4.6.

⟨Φ, U(t)Ψ⟩, t ∈R. Then, f is diﬀerentiable with f ′(t) = ⟨Φ, iT U(t)Ψ⟩
= i⟨T ∗Φ, U(t)Ψ⟩= −f(t). Hence, f(t) = ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩e−t. Hence, | ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩| =
|f(t)|et ≤∥Φ∥∥Ψ∥et. Letting t →−∞, we obtain ⟨Φ, Ψ⟩= 0. Since D is
dense, it follows that Φ = 0. Hence, ker(T ∗+ i) = {0}. Similarly, one can
show that ker(T ∗−i) = {0}. Thus, T is essentially self-adjoint.

of the heat semi-group. This nomenclature may come from (1.81), which
is called the abstract heat equation in the complex variable.22

There is a relation between the analytic vectors of a symmetric operator
and its essential self-adjointness.
Theorem 1.35 (Analytic vector theorem). Let
A
be a
symmetric
operator on H . Suppose that there exists a subspace D ⊂D(A) such that
D includes a dense subset of analytic vectors of A and AD ⊂D. Then, A
is essentially self-adjoint on D.
For a proof of this theorem, see, for example, Reed and Simon (1975),
p. 203, Corollary 2, or Arai (2006b), Section 2.7. Theorem 1.35 is often
referred to as Nelson’s analytic vector theorem (Nelson, 1959).
1.8
Analysis of Strongly Commuting Self-Adjoint
Operators
1.8.1
Strong commutativity
Let S and T be linear operators on a Hilbert space H . In the case where
S or T is unbounded, the usual notion of commutativity is not so useful
because D([S, T ]) may be very small even if S and T are densely deﬁned.
However, if S and T are self-adjoint, then one can deﬁne another notion of
their commutativity, as follows.
Theory of Linear Operators
73
Deﬁnition 1.2. (i) Two self-adjoint operators S and T on a Hilbert space
H are said to strongly commute, or to be strongly commuting, if the
spectral measures ES and ET commute, i.e., for all Borel sets B, C ∈B1,
[ES(B), ET (C)] = 0.
(ii) An N-tuple (T1, . . . , TN) of self-adjoint operators T1, . . . , TN on H
is said to be strongly commuting if, for every pair (i, j) with i ̸= j
(i, j = 1, . . . , N), Ti and Tj strongly commute.
Proposition 1.47. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on H . Then, the
following are equivalent:
(i) S and T strongly commute.
(ii) For all B ∈B1, ES(B)T ⊂T ES(B).
(iii) For all z ∈ρ(T ) and B ∈B1, [(T −z)−1, ES(B)] = 0.
Proof. (i) =⇒(ii). Assume (i). Then, for all Ψ ∈H and B, C ∈B1,
∥ET (C)ES(B)Ψ∥= ∥ES(B)ET (C)Ψ∥≤∥ET (C)Ψ∥. Hence, for all Ψ ∈
D(T ),

R
λ2d∥ET (λ)ES(B)Ψ∥2 ≤

R
λ2d∥ET (λ)Ψ∥2 < ∞.
Hence, ES(B)Ψ ∈D(T ). Thus, D(ES(B)T ) ⊂D(T ES(B)). Moreover, for
all Φ ∈H ,
⟨Φ, ES(B)T Ψ⟩=

R
λd ⟨ES(B)Φ, ET (λ)Ψ⟩
=

R
λd ⟨Φ, ET (λ)ES(B)Ψ⟩
= ⟨Φ, T ES(B)Ψ⟩.
Hence, ES(B)T Ψ = T ES(B)Ψ. Thus, (ii) holds.
(ii) =⇒(iii). Assume (ii). Then, for all z ∈C, ES(B)(T −z) ⊂(T −z)
ES(B). Hence, by Proposition 1.1, for all z ∈ρ(T ), (T −z)−1ES(B) ⊂
ES(B)(T −z)−1. Hence, (iii) holds.
(iii) =⇒(i). Assume (iii). Using Stone’s formula (1.65), one can show
that, for all ﬁnite intervals J and B ∈B1, ET (J)ES(B) = ES(B)ET (J).
Then, ﬁxing Ψ, Φ ∈H , B ∈B1 arbitrarily and applying Hopf’s extension
theorem to the complex-valued measures μ1(C) := ⟨Φ, ET (C)ES(B)Ψ⟩and
μ2(C) := ⟨Φ, ES(B)ET (C)Ψ⟩, C ∈B1, one sees that μ1(C) = μ2(C),
C ∈B1. Hence, one obtains ET (C)ES(B) = ES(B)ET (C), B, C ∈B1.
Thus, S and T strongly commute.

Proposition 1.48. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on H . Then, the
following are equivalent:
(i) S and T strongly commute.
(ii) For all s ∈R, eisST = T eisS.
(iii) For all s, t ∈R, [eisS, eitT ] = 0.
(iv) For all z ∈ρ(T ) and w ∈ρ(S), [(T −z)−1, (S −w)−1] = 0.
(v) For some z0 ∈ρ(T ) and some w0 ∈ρ(S), [(T −z0)−1, (S −w0)−1] = 0.

implies that, for all s ∈R, eisST ⊂T eisS. Hence, eisST e−isS ⊂T . Since
both sides are self-adjoint, it follows that eisST e−isS = T . Hence, (ii) holds.
(ii) =⇒(iii). Assume (ii). Then, eisST e−isS = T , for all s ∈R. By
applying Theorem 1.32 with U = eisS and f(λ) = eitλ, λ ∈R, we obtain
eisSeitT e−isS = eitT . Hence, (iii) holds.
(iii) =⇒(iv). Assume (iii). According to Theorem 1.14, each z ∈C\R is
in ρ(T ). Moreover, it is not so diﬃcult to show that the following formula
