Theorem 1.36. Let S and T be strongly commuting self-adjoint operators
on H and f, g be Borel measurable functions on R. Then:
(i) If f and g are bounded on σ(S) and σ(T ), respectively, then f(S) and
g(T ) are commuting bounded linear operators on H : f(S), g(T ) ∈
B(H ) and f(S)g(T ) = g(T )f(S).
(ii) If f and g are real-valued, then the self-adjoint operators f(S) and
g(T ) strongly commute.
(iii) For all m, n ∈N, Sm and T n strongly commute.
Proof. (i) The boundedness of f(S) and g(T ) follows from Theorem
1.24(iv). It follows from the functional calculus for S and T that, for all
B ∈B1, ES(B)g(T ) = g(T )ES(B). This implies that, for all Ψ, Φ ∈H ,
⟨Φ, f(S)g(T )Ψ⟩=

R
f(λ)d ⟨Φ, ES(λ)g(T )Ψ⟩=

R
f(λ)d ⟨g(T )∗Φ, ES(λ)Ψ⟩
= ⟨g(T )∗Φ, f(S)Ψ⟩= ⟨Φ, g(T )f(S)Ψ⟩.
Hence, f(S)g(T ) = g(T )f(S).
(ii) According to Theorem 1.27, we have Ef(S)(B) = ES(f −1(B)),
B ∈B1 and Eg(T )(C) = ET (g−1(C)), C ∈B1. Hence, Ef(S) and Eg(T )
commute. Therefore, f(S) and g(T ) strongly commute.
(iii) We need only to apply part (ii) to the case where f(λ) = λm and
g(λ) = λn, λ ∈R.
□
The following proposition tells us that the notion of strong commutativ-
ity of self-adjoint operators is indeed stronger than that of commutativity.
Proposition 1.49. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on H .
(i) If S and T strongly commute, then S and T commute.
(ii) Let S, T ∈B(H ). Then, S and T strongly commute if and only if they
commute.
Proof. (i) Proposition 1.48(iv) is equivalent to [(S −w)(T −z)]−1 =
[(T −z)(S −w)]−1, for all z ∈ρ(T ) and w ∈ρ(S). Hence, (S −w)
(T −z) = (T −z)(S −w). This implies that D(ST ) ∩D(S) ⊂D((S −w)
(T −z)) = D((T −z)(S −w)) and hence, for all Ψ ∈D(ST ) ∩D(S),
Ψ ∈D(T S) and T SΨ = ST Ψ. In particular, for all Ψ ∈D(T S) ∩D(ST ),
[S, T ]Ψ = 0.
76
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(ii) We need only to show that the commutativity of S and T implies
the strong commutativity of S and T . Let ST = T S. Then, it is easy to see
that (T −z)(S −w) = (S −w)(T −z), for all z, w ∈C. Hence, Proposition
1.48(iv) holds. Thus, S and T strongly commute.
□
Remark 1.13. In the case where at least one of S and T is unbounded,
the commutativity of S and T does not imply the strong commutativity of
S and T . One should be careful about this point.
The following proposition is also useful.
Proposition 1.50. Let T ∈B(H ) and S be a self-adjoint operator on H .
Then, T S ⊂ST if and only if T eitS = eitST, t ∈R.
Proof. Suppose that T S ⊂ST . Then, it is easy to see that, for all n ∈N,
T Sn ⊂SnT . Let RN(t) := N
n=0(itS)n/n!, t ∈R, N ∈N. Then, for all
Ψ ∈C∞
0 (S), T RN(t)Ψ = RN(t)T Ψ. We have limN→∞RN(t)Ψ = eitSΨ.
Hence, T eitSΨ = limN→∞RN(t)T Ψ. It is not so diﬃcult to show that, if
limN→∞RN(t)Φ ( Φ ∈C∞(S)) exists, then it is equal to eitSΦ. Hence,
T eitSΨ = eitST Ψ. Since C∞
0 (S) is dense and eitST and T eitS are bounded,
the operator equality eitST = T eitS follows.
Conversely, suppose that T eitS = eitST . Let Ψ ∈D(T S) = D(S). Then,
T eitSΨ = eitST Ψ, t ∈R · · · (∗). The vector-valued function :t →eitSΨ is
strongly diﬀerentiable with the strong derivative (eitSΨ)′ = iSeitSΨ. Since
T is bounded, it follows that T eitSΨ is strongly diﬀerentiable in t, with
(T eitSΨ)′ = iT SeitSΨ. Hence, by (∗), eitST Ψ is strongly diﬀerentiable in t.
Therefore, according to Theorem 1.29(iv), T Ψ ∈D(S) (i.e., Ψ ∈D(ST ))
and (eitST Ψ)′ = iSeitST Ψ. Hence, iT SeitSΨ = iSeitST Ψ. Taking t = 0,
we obtain T SΨ = ST Ψ.
□
1.8.2
Joint spectral measure and joint spectrum
We now consider an N-tuple T = (T1, . . . , TN) of strongly commuting self-
adjoint operators on H .
Theorem 1.37. There exists a unique N-dimensional spectral measure ET
such that
ET (B1 × · · · × BN) = ET1(B1) · · · ETN (BN),
Bj ∈B1, j = 1, . . . , N.
Theory of Linear Operators
77
Moreover,
Tj =

RN λjdET (λ),
j = 1, . . . , N,
where λ = (λ1, . . . , λN) ∈RN.
Proof. See, for example, Schm¨udgen (2012), Theorem 4.10; Arai (1997a),
Theorem 4.12; and Arai (2014b), Theorem 4.13.
□
The N-dimensional spectral measure ET in Theorem 1.37 is called
the joint spectral measure, or the product of the spectral measures,
ET1, . . . , ETN . The support
σJ(T ) := supp ET
of ET is called the joint spectrum of T .
A physical interpretation of the joint spectral measure ET and the
joint spectrum σJ(T ) in the context of quantum mechanics is as follows.
Suppose that each Tj represents a physical quantity (an observable) in
a quantum system. Then, the strong commutativity of T means that
the compatible measurements of T1, . . . , TN are possible. If the quantum
system is in a state represented by a unit vector Ψ ∈H (∥Ψ∥= 1),
then the probability that the result of a compatible measurement of
T lies in a Borel set B ⊂RN is ∥ET (B)Ψ∥2. The closure of the set
{λ ∈RN|λ is a result from the compatible measurement of T } is equal to
σJ(T ). But one should keep in mind that σJ(T ) is not necessarily the direct
product σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN) (see Theorem 1.38 and an example in the
following section).
Theorem 1.38.
σJ(T ) ⊂σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN)
(1.86)
Proof. We have
ET (σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN)) = ET1(σ(T1)) · · · ETN (σ(TN)) = I · · · I = I.
Hence, (1.86) holds.
□
A necessary and suﬃcient condition for the equality in (1.86) to hold is
given in the following theorem.
78
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Theorem 1.39. One has
σJ(T ) = σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN)
(1.87)
if and only if, for each λ ∈σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN) and every ε > 0, ET1((λ1 −
ε, λ1 + ε)) · · · ETN ((λN −ε, λN + ε)) ̸= 0.
Proof. Suppose that (1.87) holds. Then, each λ ∈σ(T1)×· · ·×σ(TN) is in
σJ(T ) = supp ET . Hence, by Proposition 1.36, for all ε > 0, ET (Bε(λ)) ̸= 0.
One has Bε(λ) ⊂(λ1−ε, λ1+ε)×· · ·×(λN −ε, λN +ε). Hence, ET (Bε(λ)) ≤
ET1((λ1 −ε, λ1 + ε)) · · · ETN ((λN −ε, λN + ε)). Hence, ET1((λ1 −ε, λ1 +
ε)) · · · ETN ((λN −ε, λN + ε)) ̸= 0.
Conversely, suppose that, for each λ ∈σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN) and every
ε > 0, ET1((λ1 −ε, λ1 + ε)) · · · ETN ((λN −ε, λN + ε)) ̸= 0. Then, ET ((λ1 −
ε, λ1 + ε) × · · · × (λN −ε, λN + ε)) ̸= 0. One has
(λ1 −ε, λ1 + ε) × · · · × (λN −ε, λN + ε) ⊂B√
Nε(λ).
Hence, ET (B√
Nε(λ)) ̸= 0. Therefore, by Proposition 1.36, λ ∈supp ET =
σJ(T ). Hence, σ(T1) × · · · × σ(TN) ⊂σJ(T ). Thus, (1.87) follows.
□

The following theorem is concerned with a class of cores of LP(T ).

1.8.5
Strongly continuous multi-parameter unitary groups
Let T := (T1, . . . , Tn) (n ∈N) be a set of strongly commuting self-adjoint
operators on H . Then, for each t = (t1, . . . , tn) ∈Rn, one can deﬁne a
unitary operator by
UT (t) := eit1T1 · · · eitnTn.
It is easy to prove the following: (i) UT (0) = I; (ii) (group property)
UT (t + s) = UT (t)UT (s) = UT (s)UT (t), t, s ∈Rn; (iii) (strong continuity)
s- lims→0 UT (t + s) = UT (t), t ∈Rn.
Properties (ii) and (iii) above have an abstraction. A family of uni-
tary operators {U(t)}t∈Rn (n ∈N) on a Hilbert space H
is called a
strongly continuous n-parameter unitary group if it has the following
properties:
(I) (group property) U(t + s) = U(t)U(s), t, s ∈Rn (then it follows that
U(0) = I and U(t)U(s) = U(s)U(t), t, s ∈Rn);
(II) (strong continuity) s- lims→0 U(t + s) = U(t), t ∈Rn.
For a strongly continuous n-parameter unitary group, an extended ver-
sion of Stone’s theorem holds, as follows.
Theorem 1.46 (Extended Stone’s theorem). For each strongly con-
tinuous n-parameter unitary group {U(t)}t∈Rn, there exists a unique
90
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
n-tuple (T1, . . . , Tn) of strongly commuting self-adjoint operators on H
such that
U(t) = eit1T1eit2T2 · · · eitnTn, t = (t1, . . . , tn) ∈Rn.
(1.114)
Proof. Let (ej)n
j=1 be the standard basis of Rn. Then, each t
=
(t1, . . . , tn) ∈Rn is written t = n
j=1 tjej. Hence, by the group property
of {U(t)}t∈Rn, we have U(t) = U(t1e1) · · · U(tnen). For each j = 1, . . . , n,
{U(tej)}t∈R is a strongly continuous one-parameter unitary group. Hence,
according to Stone’s theorem, there exists a unique self-adjoint operator
Tj on H such that U(tej) = eitTj, t ∈R. Therefore, (1.114) holds. For
j, k = 1, . . . , n and tj, tk ∈R, we have U(tjej)U(tkek) = U(tkek)U(tjej).
Hence, Tj and Tk strongly commute. The uniqueness of (T1, . . . , Tn) is easily
proved.
□
The self-adjoint operators T1, . . . , Tn in Theorem 1.46 are called the
inﬁnitesimal generators, or generators, of {U(t)}t∈Rn.
1.9
Reduction of Linear Operators
Let H be a Hilbert space and M be a closed subspace of H . We denote
by PM the orthogonal projection onto M . According to the projection
theorem, H has the orthogonal decomposition
H = M ⊕M ⊥,
(1.115)
where we use the natural identiﬁcation of a vector Ψ = Ψ1 + Ψ2 (Ψ1 =
PM Ψ, Ψ2 = PM ⊥Ψ), with (Ψ1, Ψ2) ∈M ⊕M ⊥.
A linear operator A on H is said to be reduced by M if PM A ⊂APM,
i.e., for all Ψ ∈D(A), PMΨ ∈D(A) and APMΨ = PM AΨ. In this case,
A is reduced by the orthogonal complement M ⊥of M too since I −PM
is the orthogonal projection onto M ⊥and (I −PM )A ⊂A(I −PM ).
Let A be reduced by M . Then, one can deﬁne a linear operator AM on
M as follows:
D(AM ) := D(A) ∩M ,
AMΨ := AΨ,
Ψ ∈D(AM ).
The operator AM is called the reduced part of A to M .
Theory of Linear Operators
91
Proposition 1.51. Let A be reduced by M . Then:
(i) The operator A has the direct sum decomposition
A = AM ⊕AM ⊥
(1.116)
relative to the orthogonal decomposition (1.115).
(ii) σ(A) = σ(AM ) ∪σ(AM ⊥).
(iii) ρ(A) = ρ(AM) ∩ρ(AM ⊥). Moreover, for all z ∈ρ(A), (A −z)−1 is
reduced by M and ((A −z)−1)M = (AM −z)−1.
(iv) Let B be a linear operator on H and reduced by M . Suppose that
A ⊂B. Then, AM ⊂BM.
Proof. (i) According to the projection theorem, each Ψ ∈D(A) has the
orthogonal decomposition Ψ = Ψ1 +Ψ2, with Ψ1 := PMΨ and Ψ2 := PM ⊥Ψ.
From the reducibility of A by M and M ⊥, we have Ψ1 ∈D(A) ∩M , Ψ2 ∈
D(A) ∩M ⊥and AΨ1 = AMΨ1, AΨ2 = AM ⊥Ψ2. Hence, AΨ = AMΨ1 +
AM ⊥Ψ2, implying A ⊂AM ⊕AM ⊥. It is easy to see that AM ⊕AM ⊥⊂A.
Hence, (1.116) holds.
(ii) This is a simple application of Theorem 1.15(ii).
(iii) The ﬁrst half follows from (ii). Let z ∈ρ(A). Then, using the
equality
A −z = (AM −z) ⊕(AM ⊥−z),
z ∈C,
(1.117)
one has
(A −z)−1 = (AM −z)−1 ⊕(AM ⊥−z)−1.
(1.118)
Thus, (A −z)−1 is reduced by M and ((A −z)−1)M = (AM −z)−1.
(iv) An easy exercise (Problem 16).
□
Remark 1.14. If A is reduced by M , then A leaves M and M ⊥invari-
ant in the sense that A(D(A) ∩M ) ⊂M · · · (∗) and A(D(A) ∩M ⊥) ⊂
M ⊥· · · (∗∗), respectively. If A ∈B(H ) (i.e., D(A) = H
and A is
bounded), then (∗) and (∗∗) imply the reducibility of A by M (see Propo-
sition 1.52, as follows). However, in the case where A is unbounded, (∗) and
(∗∗) do not necessarily imply the reducibility of A by M (see Problem 17).
In treating unbounded operators, one should be careful about this point.
Proposition 1.52. Let A ∈B(H ). Then, a necessary and suﬃcient con-
dition for A to be reduced by M is that AM ⊂M and AM ⊥⊂M ⊥.
92
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Proof. The necessity of the condition follows from the deﬁnition of
reducibility.
To prove the suﬃciency of the condition, suppose that AM ⊂M and
AM ⊥⊂M ⊥. Then, for all Ψ ∈H , the identity AΨ = APMΨ + APM ⊥Ψ
gives the orthogonal decomposition of the vector AΨ relative to the orthog-
onal decomposition (1.115). Hence, PMAΨ = APM Ψ, PM ⊥AΨ = APM ⊥Ψ.
Thus, A is reduced by M .
□
Proposition 1.53. Let A and B be linear operators on H
which are
reduced by a closed subspace M ⊂H . Then, A + B is reduced by M
and (A + B)M = AM + BM.
Proof. An easy exercise (Problem 18).
□
Proposition 1.54. Let A be a linear operator on H which is reduced by
a closed subspace M ⊂H . Let K be a Hilbert space and U : H →K
be a unitary transformation. Let N := UM . Then, UM := U ↾M is a
unitary transformation from M to N , and UAU −1 is reduced by N , with
(UAU −1)N = UMAM U −1
M .
Proof. Let P := PM and Q := PN . Based on the present assumption,
PA ⊂AP. It is obvious that UP = QU. Hence, U −1Q = PU −1. Therefore,
(UAU −1)Q = UAPU −1 ⊃UPAU −1 = Q(UAU −1). Hence, UAU −1 is
reduced by N . It is easy to see that (UAU −1)N = UMAM U −1
M .
□
The following theorem summarizes the main properties of the reduced
part of a linear operator to a closed subspace. As is seen, the reduced part
inherits many properties from the original operator.
Theorem 1.47. Let A be a linear operator on H
reduced by a closed
subspace M .
(i) If D(A) is dense in H , then D(AM ) is dense in M .
(ii) If A is injective, then so is AM .
(iii) If A is surjective, then so is AM.
(iv) Suppose that A is closed. Then, AM is closed. Moreover, for any core
D of A, PMD is a core of AM.
(v) Suppose that A is closable. Then, AM is closable. Moreover, A is
reduced by M and (A)M = AM .
(vi) If A is bounded (D(A) is not necessarily equal to H ), then AM is
bounded with ∥AM∥≤∥A∥.
Theory of Linear Operators
93
(vii) If A is symmetric, then so is AM .
(viii) If A is an orthogonal projection, then so is AM .
(ix) Let A be self-adjoint. Then, AM is self-adjoint. Moreover, for each
Borel set J ∈B1, EA(J) (EA is the spectral measure of A) is reduced
by M —in this case, EA is said to be reduced by M — and the reduced
part EA(J)M is equal to EAM (J).
(x) If A is unitary, then so is AM.
(xi) If A is a contraction operator,27 then so is AM .
(xii) Let A be self-adjoint and B be a self-adjoint operator on H which
is reduced by M and strongly commutes with A. Then, AM and BM
strongly commute.
Proof. (i) Let Ψ
∈M . Then, by the density of D(A), there exists
a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in D(A) such that Ψn →Ψ as n →∞. Hence,
PM Ψn →PMΨ = Ψ as n →∞. Since PMΨn ∈D(AM ), it follows that
D(AM ) is dense in M .
(ii) For all Ψ ∈ker AM, AΨ = AMΨ = 0. Hence, under the present
assumption, Ψ = 0. Thus, AM is injective.
(iii) For each Ψ ∈M , there exists a vector Φ ∈D(A) such that AΦ = Ψ.
Hence, PM AΦ = Ψ. The left-hand side is equal to APM Φ = AMPM Φ.
Hence, AM is surjective.
(iv) Let Ψn ∈D(AM ), Ψn →Ψ ∈M , AMΨn →Φ ∈M (n →∞). Then,
Ψn ∈D(A) and AΨn →Φ (n →∞). By the closedness of A, Ψ ∈D(A) and
AΨ = Φ. Hence, Ψ ∈M ∩D(A) = D(AM ) and AMΨ = Φ. Thus, AM is
closed.
Let Ψ ∈D(AM ). Then, Ψ ∈D(A). Hence, there exists a sequence
{Ψn}∞
n=1 in D such that Ψn →Ψ, AΨn →AΨ (n →∞). Hence, letting
Φn = PM Ψn, we see that Φn ∈PM D, Φn →PMΨ = Ψ (n →∞) and
PM AΨn →PM AΨ (n →∞). On the other hand, PM AΨn = APM Ψn =
AΦn, PMAΨ = APM Ψ = AMΨ. Hence, AMΦn →AMΨ (n →∞). Thus,
PM D is a core of AM .
(v) Let Ψn ∈D(AM ), Ψn →0 and AMΨn →Φ ∈M (n →∞). Then,
AΨn →Φ (n →∞). Since A is closable, it follows from Proposition 1.5 that
Φ = 0. Hence, by Proposition 1.5 again, AM is closable.
Let Ψ ∈D(A). Then, there exists a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in D(A) such
that Ψn →Ψ and AΨn →AΨ (n →∞). By the reducibility of A by
M , we have APM Ψn = PMAΨn. By the boundedness of PM , we have

PM Ψn →PM Ψ (n →∞) and APM Ψn = PMAΨn →PM AΨ (n →∞).

Hence, A is reduced by M .
It is obvious that AM ⊂(A)M and hence AM ⊂(A)M. For each

(vi) In this case, for all Ψ ∈D(AM ), ∥AMΨ∥= ∥AΨ∥≤∥A∥∥Ψ∥.

Theorem 1.48. Let A and B be linear operators on H reduced by M .
Then, AB is reduced by M , and
(AB)M = AMBM.
(1.119)
Proof. Let Ψ ∈D(AB). Then, Ψ ∈D(B) and BΨ ∈D(A). The former

PM BΨ ∈D(A) and APM BΨ = PM ABΨ. Hence, BPMΨ ∈D(A) and

= {Ψ ∈D(BM )|BMΨ ∈D(A) ∩M }
= {Ψ ∈D(BM )|BMΨ ∈D(AM )}
= D(AM BM).
Thus, (1.119) follows.

1.10
Convergence of Self-Adjoint Operators
Let Hn (n ∈N) and H be self-adjoint operators on a Hilbert space H .
Then, C\R ⊂ρ(Hn) ∩ρ(H). Hence, for all z ∈C\R, (Hn −z)−1 and
(H −z)−1 are in B(H ).
Deﬁnition 1.3.
(i) (strong resolvent convergence) The sequence {Hn}n of self-adjoint
operators is said to converge to H in the strong resolvent sense
if, for all z ∈C\R,
s- lim
n→∞(Hn −z)−1 = (H −z)−1,
where s- lim means the strong limit (i.e., limn→∞(Hn −z)−1Ψ =
(H −z)−1Ψ, Ψ ∈H ).
(ii) (norm resolvent convergence) The sequence {Hn}n of self-adjoint oper-
ators is said to converge to H in the norm resolvent sense if, for
all z ∈C\R, limn→∞∥(Hn −z)−1 −(H −z)−1∥= 0.
A basic criterion on strong resolvent convergence of a sequence of self-
adjoint operators is given in the following theorem.
Theorem 1.50. Suppose that there exists a core D for H such that
D ⊂∩∞
n=1D(Hn) and limn→∞HnΨ = HΨ, for all Ψ ∈D. Then, {Hn}n
converges to H in the strong resolvent sense.
Proof. Since D is a core for H, for all z ∈C\R, (H −z)D := {(H −z)
Ψ|Ψ ∈D} is dense in H . Let Φ ∈(H −z)D. Then. Ψ := (H −z)−1Φ
is in D. We have
(Hn −z)−1Φ −(H −z)−1Φ = (Hn −z)−1(H −Hn)Ψ.
Hence, using (1.67), we obtain
∥(Hn −z)−1Φ −(H −z)−1Φ∥≤
1
|Im z|∥(H −Hn)Ψ∥.
Hence, limn→∞(Hn −z)−1Φ = (H −z)−1Φ. Since supn∈N ∥(Hn −z)−1∥≤
1/|Im z| and (H −z)D is dense, it follows from Proposition A.3 in
Appendix A that s- limn→∞(Hn −z)−1 = (H −z)−1.
□
Theory of Linear Operators

We next formulate a suﬃcient condition for {Hn}n to converge to H in
the norm resolvent sense. For this purpose, we ﬁrst prove a lemma, which
is useful.
Lemma 1.9. Let A be a closed operator on H such that D(A) ⊃D(H).
Then, for all z ∈ρ(H), A(H −z)−1 is bounded.
Proof. According to the closed graph theorem (Theorem 1.4), it is suﬃ-
cient to show that A(H −z)−1 is closed since D(A(H −z)−1) = H . Let
{Ψn}n be a sequence in H such that Ψn →Ψ ∈H and A(H −z)−1Ψn →
Φ ∈H
as n →∞. Then, (H −z)−1Ψn →(H −z)−1Ψ as n →∞.
Since A is closed, it follows that A(H −z)−1Ψ = Φ. Hence, A(H −z)−1 is
closed.
□
Theorem 1.51. Let A be a closed operator on H such that D(A) ⊃D(H).
Suppose that there exists a core D for H such that D ⊂∩∞
n=1D(Hn) and
∥(Hn −H)Ψ∥≤Cn∥AΨ∥,
Ψ ∈D,
(1.120)
with a sequence {Cn}n of positive numbers satisfying limn→∞Cn = 0.
Then, {Hn}n converges to H in the norm resolvent sense.
Proof. Let z ∈C\R and Φ ∈(H −z)D. Then,
((Hn −z)−1 −(H −z)−1)Φ = (Hn −z)−1(H −Hn)(H −z)−1Φ.
Hence,

□
Important implications of strong resolvent convergence and norm resol-
vent convergence are stated in the following theorem.
98
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Theorem 1.52.
(i) If {Hn}n converges to H in the strong resolvent sense, then, for all
bounded continuous functions f on R, s- limn→∞f(Hn) = f(H).
(ii) If {Hn}n converges to H in the norm resolvent sense, then, for
all bounded continuous functions f
on R vanishing at ∞(i.e.,
lim|x|→∞f(x) = 0), limn→∞∥f(Hn) −f(H)∥= 0.
For a proof of this theorem, see, for example, Reed and Simon (1980),
Theorem VIII.20.
Corollary 1.9.
(i) If {Hn}n converges to H in the strong resolvent sense, then, for all
t ∈R, s- limn→∞e−itHn = e−itH.
(ii) If {Hn}n converges to H in the strong resolvent sense and there exists
a constant γ ∈R such that Hn, H ≥γ, for all n ≥1, then, for all
β ∈R, s- limn→∞e−βHn = e−βH.
(iii) If {Hn}n converges to H in the norm resolvent sense and there exists
a constant γ ∈R such that Hn, H ≥γ, for all n ≥1, then, for all
β > 0, limn→∞∥e−βHn −e−βH∥= 0.
Remark 1.15. In applications, strong and norm resolvent convergences
may also be useful for deriving some spectral properties of the limiting
operator H from those of Hn (n ∈N) (see, for example, Reed and Simon,
1980, Theorems VIII.23 and VIII.24).

Chapter 2
Tensor Product Hilbert Spaces
For a ﬁnite number of Hilbert spaces, a new Hilbert space, called the tensor
product Hilbert space (or the tensor product) of them, is deﬁned. Some funda-
mental properties of tensor product Hilbert spaces are investigated. An important
class of tensor product Hilbert spaces is given by those of L2-spaces. Also dis-
cussed is the tensor product of a Hilbert space and one consisting of Hilbert
space-valued L2-functions. Moreover, symmetric tensor product Hilbert spaces
and anti-symmetric tensor product Hilbert spaces are introduced, which play
important roles in the quantum theory of many identical quantum particles.
2.1
Forms
2.1.1
Bilinear forms
Let V and W be vector spaces over K. A mapping F from the direct product
V ×W := {(ψ, φ)|ψ ∈V , φ ∈W } to K is called a (K-valued) bilinear form
on V ×W if the following equations hold: for all ψ, ψ1, ψ2 ∈V , φ, φ1, φ2 ∈W
and α ∈K,
F(ψ1 + ψ2, φ) = F(ψ1, φ) + F(ψ2, φ),
(2.1)
F(ψ, φ1 + φ2) = F(ψ, φ1) + F(ψ, φ2),
(2.2)
F(αψ, φ) = αF(ψ, φ),
F(ψ, αφ) = αF(ψ, φ).
(2.3)

and ψi ∈V , φj ∈W , αi, βj ∈K (i = 1, . . . , n, j = 1, . . . , m),

Example 2.1. Let V be a real inner product space and T : V →V be
a linear operator on V . Then, the mapping F : V × V →R deﬁned by
F(ψ, φ) := ⟨ψ, T φ⟩V (ψ, φ ∈V ) is a bilinear form on V .
Example 2.2. Let H be a complex inner product space, J : H →H
be an anti-linear mapping (see Remark 1.1) and T : H →H be a linear
operator. Deﬁne F : H × H →C by F(ψ, φ) := ⟨Jψ, T φ⟩H , ψ, φ ∈H .
Then, F is a bilinear form on H .
2.1.2
Sesquilinear forms and a representation theorem
Let V and W be complex vector spaces. A mapping F : V × W →C is

F(αψ, φ) = α∗F(ψ, φ)

A sesquilinear form F on V is said to be symmetric, or Hermitian,
if F(ψ, φ)∗= F(φ, ψ), ψ, φ ∈V . In this case, for all ψ ∈V , F(ψ, ψ) is
a real number. If a symmetric form F on V satisﬁes that, for all ψ ∈V ,
F(ψ, ψ) ≥0, then we say that F is positive or non-negative. A symmetric
form F is said to be positive deﬁnite if F is positive and F(ψ, ψ) = 0
implies ψ = 0. A positive deﬁnite symmetric form on V is nothing but an
inner product of V . On the other hand, a non-negative symmetric form is
called a positive semi-deﬁnite inner product (see Problem 1).

A sesquilinear form on a dense subspace of a Hilbert space may have an
operator representation.
Theorem 2.1. Let H be a complex Hilbert space and D be a dense sub-
space of H . Let F be a sesquilinear form on D such that there exist a bijec-
tive linear operator A on D(A : D →D) and a constant C > 0 satisfying
|F(ψ, φ)| ≤C∥ψ∥∥Aφ∥,
ψ, φ ∈D.
Then, there exists a unique linear operator T on H such that D(T ) = D
and
F(ψ, φ) = ⟨ψ, T φ⟩,
ψ, φ ∈D
(2.7)
and ∥T φ∥≤C∥Aφ∥, φ ∈D. Moreover, if F is symmetric (resp. non-
negative), then T is symmetric (resp. non-negative).
Proof. We ﬁx ψ ∈D and deﬁne ℓ: D →C by
ℓ(φ) := F(ψ, A−1φ),
φ ∈D.
It is easy to see that ℓis a linear functional on D, with |ℓ(φ)| ≤
(C∥ψ∥)∥φ∥, φ ∈D. Hence, ℓis a bounded linear functional on D with
∥ℓ∥≤C∥ψ∥. Therefore, according to the extension theorem, there exists
a unique ℓ∈H ∗such that ℓ⊂ℓand ∥ℓ∥= ∥ℓ∥. Hence, according to
Riesz’s representation theorem (Theorem 1.8), there exists a unique vector
uψ ∈H such that ℓ(φ) = ⟨uψ, φ⟩, φ ∈H and ∥uψ∥= ∥ℓ∥= ∥ℓ∥≤C∥ψ∥.
So, one can deﬁne a mapping L : D →H by Lψ := uψ, ψ ∈D. By the
aforementioned result on uψ, L is a bounded linear operator with ∥Lψ∥≤
C∥ψ∥, ψ ∈D. It follows that, for all ψ, φ ∈D. ⟨Lψ, φ⟩= F(ψ, A−1φ). This
means that F(ψ, φ) = ⟨Lψ, Aφ⟩= ⟨ψ, L∗Aφ⟩,
ψ, φ ∈D, where we have
used the fact that (L)∗= L∗and D(L∗) = H . Hence, letting T := L∗A,
we obtain (2.7) (note that D(T ) = D(L∗A) = D(A) = D). The uniqueness
of T follows from the denseness of D. The last statement in the theorem is
easily proved.
□

The method to deﬁne the tensor product of two Hilbert spaces given above

equations hold: for all (ψ1, . . . , ψN) ∈V1 ×· · ·×VN, φj ∈Vj (j = 1, . . . , N)

2.5
Hilbert Space Isomorphisms
Before developing further the theory of tensor product Hilbert spaces, we
recall here an important concept. Two Hilbert spaces H and K are said to
be isomorphic if there exists a unitary operator U from H to K . In this
case, we say that H is isomorphic to K under U, and we write H
U∼= K ,
or simply H ∼= K , if U is understood.
As is well known, every separable inﬁnite-dimensional complex Hilbert
space H is isomorphic to
ℓ2 :=

a = {an}∞
n=1
n ∈N, an ∈C,
∞

n=1
|an|2 < ∞

,
the Hilbert space of absolutely square summable sequences of complex num-
bers, in such a way that each ψ ∈H corresponds to {an(ψ)}∞
n=1 ∈ℓ2, with
an(ψ) = ⟨ψn, ψ⟩H , where {ψn}∞
n=1 is an arbitrary CONS of H . But this
isomorphism is not so useful because it depends on the choice of the CONS
of H , just giving a coordinate representation of each vector in H . One
may call an isomorphism depending on the choice of CONS a relative
isomorphism. We emphasize that a useful or meaningful Hilbert space
isomorphism may be one which has nothing to do with the CONSs of the
Hilbert spaces under consideration. We say that such an isomorphism is
absolute, or natural. As will be seen later in this book, natural isomor-
phisms play important roles in the theory of tensor product Hilbert spaces.
To establish an isomorphism between two Hilbert spaces, the following
theorem is fundamental.
Theorem 2.4 (Isomorphism theorem). Let H
and K
be Hilbert
spaces over K and {ψα}α∈A and {φα}α∈A be the CONSs of H and K ,
respectively, where A is an index set not necessarily at most countable.
Then, there exists a unique unitary transformation U : H →K such that
Uψα = φα,
α ∈A.
Proof. Existence. For each ψ ∈H , there is an at most countable sub-
set Aψ of A such that 
α∈Aψ | ⟨ψα, ψ⟩H |2 = ∥ψ∥2 < ∞. Hence, accord-
ing to the abstract Riesz–Fischer theorem, 
α∈Aψ ⟨ψα, ψ⟩H φα converges
in K . Therefore, one can deﬁne a mapping U : H
→K
by Uψ :=

α∈Aψ ⟨ψα, ψ⟩H φα. In particular, Uψα = φα. Then, it is easy to see
that U is linear and isometric (i.e., ∥Uψ∥K
= ∥ψ∥H ). To prove the
Tensor Product Hilbert Spaces
117
surjectivity of U, we note that, for each φ ∈K , 
α∈Bφ | ⟨φα, φ⟩K |2 =
∥φ∥2 < ∞, where Bφ is an at most countable subset of A. Hence,
ψ := 
α∈Bφ ⟨φα, φ⟩K ψα converges in H . Hence, Uψ = 
α∈Bφ ⟨φα, φ⟩K
φα = φ, showing that U is surjective. Thus, U is unitary.
Uniqueness. Let V : H →K be a bounded linear operator such that

Remark 2.8. (i) The above-mentioned isomorphism between a separa-

always the case (see, for example, Proposition 2.4). In applications, there
are many cases in which the isomorphism in Theorem 2.4 is in reality an
absolute isomorphism.

2.6
Tensor Product of L2-Spaces
Let (Xj, Σj, μj) (j = 1, . . . , N) be a σ-ﬁnite measure space. Then, using
the theory in Section 2.4, we can consider the tensor product Hilbert space
⊗N
j=1L2(Xj, dμj). But this Hilbert space is an abstract one. Hence, it would
be natural to ask if ⊗N
j=1L2(Xj, dμj) can be identiﬁed with a concrete
Hilbert space. In what follows, we show that the answer is aﬃrmative.
Since each measure space (Xj, Σj, μj) is σ-ﬁnite, the direct product
space X1×· · ·×XN becomes a measure space whose Borel ﬁeld and measure
are the product Borel ﬁeld of Σ1, . . . , ΣN and the product measure μ1 ⊗
· · · ⊗μN, respectively.

Theorem 2.5 shows that the tensor product ⊗N

Example 2.4. Let d ∈N and take Xj = Rd, Σj = Bd (the Borel ﬁeld
of Rd) with μj being the Lebesgue measure on the Borel-measurable space
(Rd, Bd) so that L2(Xj, dμj) = L2(Rd). Then, by Theorem 2.5, we have
⊗NL2(Rd) ∼= L2((Rd)N) = L2(RdN).
This natural isomorphism is very useful in applications to mathematical
theory of quantum many-body systems.
2.7
Tensor Product of an L2-Space and a Hilbert Space
Let (X, Σ, μ) be a measure space and H be a complex Hilbert space. Then,
the tensor product Hilbert space L2(X, dμ) ⊗H
is considered. In this
section, we describe a natural isomorphism of L2(X, dμ)⊗H to a concrete
Hilbert space.
122

Let
H X := {F : X →H },
the set of mappings from X to H . Then, for F, G ∈H X, the pointwise
inner product ⟨F(x), G(x)⟩H (x ∈X) gives a complex-valued function on
X: x →⟨F(x), G(x)⟩H . It may be natural to deﬁne an inner product of F
and G by 
X ⟨F(x), G(x)⟩H dμ(x) if ⟨F(x), G(x)⟩H is Σ-measurable and
integrable with respect to μ. With this heuristic motivation, we introduce
the concept of measurability for the elements of H X.
Deﬁnition
2.2. An
element
F
∈

is

be

valued function : X ∋x →⟨Ψ, F(x)⟩H on X is Σ-measurable. We denote
by M(X, H ) the set of weakly Σ-measurable mappings from X to H .
Remark 2.9. Besides the weak measurability, there are two diﬀerent con-
cepts of measurability for the elements of H X, called strong measura-
bility and Borel measurability, respectively (see, for example, Reed and
Simon, 1980, pp. 115–116). One has the following logical relation (Reed and
Simon, 1980, p. 116, Proposition):
strongly measurable =⇒Borel measurable =⇒weakly measurable
But, it turns out that, in the case where H is separable, these three con-
cepts of measurability are equivalent (Reed and Simon, 1980, Theorem
IV.22). In many cases of applications of the theory on the mapping space
H X to quantum ﬁeld theory, H is separable. Therefore, for the purpose
of this book, it is enough to consider the case where H is separable and
weak measurable functions in H X.
Throughout this section, we assume that H is separable.

Example 2.5. Let d, r ∈N and Cr := {(z1, . . . , zr)|zj ∈C, j = 1, . . . , r},

to quantum mechanics, L2(Rd; Cr) describes a Hilbert space of state vec-
tors of a quantum system consisting of a quantum particle (an elementary
particle, an atom, a molecule, an ion etc.) in Rd with internal degrees of
freedom.2

2In quantum mechanics, a state of a quantum system S is described by a ray [Ψ] :=
{αΨ|α ∈C \ {0}} for a non-zero vector Ψ in a Hilbert space H . A vector in [Ψ] is called
a state vector of the state [Ψ], and H is called a Hilbert space of states for S. It
is obvious that the two states [Ψ] and [Φ] (Φ ∈H ) are identical (i.e., Ψ represents the
same state as that Φ does) if and only there exists a non-zero constant α ∈C such that
Ψ = αΦ.

In applications to quantum physics, it is important to know when a

Deﬁnition 2.4. A mapping A(·) : X →L(H ) is called a self-adjoint

Theorem 2.7. Let A(·) : X →L(H ) be a self-adjoint mapping. Then,
A =
 ⊕
X A(x)dμ(x) is self-adjoint.
Proof. By Lemmas 2.5 and 2.6, C± :=
 ⊕
X (A(x) ± i)−1dμ(x) are bounded
operators on L2(X, dμ; H ). It is easy to see that C± are injective. Since
A(x)(A(x) + i)−1 = 1 −i(A(x) + i)−1,
x ∈X,
A(x)(A(x) + i)−1 is bounded with ∥A(x)(A(x) + i)−1∥≤2, and the
mapping : x →A(x)(A(x) + i)−1 is measurable. For all φ ∈L2(X, dμ; H ),

X
∥A(x)(A(x) + i)−1φ(x)∥2dμ(x) ≤4∥φ∥2 < ∞.
Hence, C+φ ∈D(A). By direct computations, one obtains (A + i)C+φ
= φ. Hence, (A + i)C+ = I. Similarly, one can show that (A −i)C−= I.
Therefore, Ran(A ± i) = L2(X, dμ; H ). It is easy to see that, for all ψ,
φ ∈D(A), ⟨ψ, Aφ⟩= ⟨Aψ, φ⟩. Hence, if D(A) is dense, then it follows from
a basic criterion on self-adjointness (Proposition 1.28) that A is self-adjoint.
To show that D(A) is dense, let φ ∈D(A)⊥. Then, for all ψ ∈D(A),
0 = ⟨φ, ψ⟩= ⟨(A + i)C+φ, ψ⟩= ⟨C+φ, (A −i)ψ⟩. Since Ran(A −i) =
L2(X, dμ; H ), as shown above, C+φ = 0. Since C+ is injective, φ = 0.
Hence, D(A)⊥= {0}, implying that D(A) is dense.
□
2.9
Permutation Operators, Symmetric Tensor Products
and Anti-symmetric Tensor Products
As is well known in quantum mechanics, a system of identical quantum
particles may have symmetries with respect to their permutations. In this
section, we present some concepts to formulate such symmetries.
Tensor Product Hilbert Spaces
129
2.9.1
Permutation operators
Let H be a complex Hilbert space and σ ∈SN (N ∈N). Then, by Propo-
sition 2.4, there exists a unique unitary transformation Uσ on the N-fold
tensor product ⊗NH such that, for all Ψj ∈H (j = 1, . . . , N),
Uσ ⊗N
j=1 Ψj = ⊗N
j=1Ψσ(j).
(2.35)
We call Uσ the permutation operator with respect to σ ∈SN on ⊗NH .
Some of its elementary properties are given in the following proposition.
Proposition 2.9.
(i) For all σ, τ ∈SN,
UτUσ = Uστ.
(2.36)
(Note that the right-hand side is not Uτσ.)
(ii) For all σ ∈SN,
U −1

= Uσ−1.
(2.37)
and
U ∗

(2.38)
where U ∗

Proof. (i) Let Ψj ∈H , j = 1, . . . , N, and Φj := Ψσ(j). Then, by (2.35),
UτUσ ⊗N
j=1 Ψj = Uτ ⊗N

To gain a deeper mathematical meaning of Proposition 2.9, we recall
some concepts from group theory.
2.9.2
Basic elements in group theory
A set G is called a semi-group if there exists a mapping G × G ∋(a, b) →
ab ∈G such that, for all a, b, c ∈G, (ab)c = a(bc) (composition law). The
mapping : (a, b) →ab is called the semi-group operation. If there exists
an element e ∈G such that, for all a ∈G, ae = ea = a, then G is said to
130
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
be unitary and e is called the unit element in G. It is easy to see that e
is unique.
If ab = ba for all a, b ∈G, then G is said to be commutative, or
Abelian.
A subset H of a semi-group G is called a subsemi-group of G if it is
a semi-group with respect to the semi-group operation of G.
A set G is called a group if it is a unitary semi-group with the following
additional property (the existence of inverse element): for each a ∈G, there
exists an element a−1 in G such that aa−1 = a−1a = e. The element a−1
is called the inverse element of a (it is easy to see that a−1 is uniquely
determined). For a group G, the operation : G × G ∋(a, b) →ab is called
the group operation of G.
Example 2.8. The set SN is a group with operation SN ×SN ∋(σ, τ) →
στ ∈SN (σ, τ ∈SN). This group is called the symmetry group of
order N. If N ≥3, then SN is non-commutative.
A subset H of G is called a subgroup of G if it is a group with the
group operation of G.
For each a ∈G and a subset F of G, the subsets aF and Fa of G are
deﬁned by aF := {af|f ∈F} and Fa := {fa|f ∈F}. Also, the subset aFb
(a, b ∈G) is deﬁned by aFb := {afb|f ∈F}.
A subgroup N of G is said to be normal if, for all a ∈G, aNa−1 = N.
For subsets G1, G2 of G, the subset G1G2 of G is deﬁned by
G1G2 := {ab|a ∈G1, b ∈G2}.
Let N be a normal subgroup of G. Then, it is easy to see that, for all
a, b ∈G,
(aN)(bN) = abN.
Hence, it follows that the set
G/N := {aN|a ∈G}
becomes a group with the product operation of subsets. The unit element
of G/N is N and the inverse element of aN is a−1N. This group is called
the residue class group modulo N, the quotient group by N, or the
factor group by N. A subset of the form aN (a ∈G) is called a coset
with respect to N.
Let G and H be groups. A mapping ρ : G →H is called a homomor-
phism if ρ(ab) = ρ(a)ρ(b), a, b ∈G.
Tensor Product Hilbert Spaces
131
Let ρ : G →H be a homomorphism and denote by eG (resp., eH) the
unit element of G (resp., H). Then, ρ(eG)ρ(eG) = ρ(e2
G) = ρ(eG). Hence,
ρ(eG) = eH.
Hence, the subset
N(ρ) := {g ∈G|ρ(g) = eH}
of G contains eG. The set N(ρ) is called the kernel of ρ.
It is easy to see that ρ is injective if and only if N(ρ) = {eG}.
The kernel N(ρ) is a normal subgroup.
A bijective homomorphism ρ : G →H is called an isomorphism. The
groups G and H are said to be isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism
ρ : G →H. In this case, we write G
ρ∼
=H, or simply G ∼= H, if the isomor-
phism is understood. Two isomorphic groups can be regarded as identical
as groups.
It is not so diﬃcult to prove the following theorem, which is a basic one
in group theory.
Theorem 2.8 (Homomorphism theorem). Let ρ
:
G
→
H be a
homomorphism. Then, the mapping ˆρ : G/N(ρ) →ρ(G), deﬁned by
ˆρ(aN(ρ)) := ρ(a), a ∈G, is an isomorphism, i.e., G/N(ρ) ∼= ρ(G). In
particular, if ρ is surjective in addition, then G/N(ρ) ∼= H.
Let V be a vector space over K. Then, the set GL(V ) of bijective linear
mappings on V is a group with the product operation of mappings on V .
The group GL(V ) is called the general linear group on V .
A homomorphism ρ : G →GL(V ) is called a representation of G
on V . In this case, V is called the representation space of G. A repre-
sentation ρ of G on V is sometimes denoted (ρ, V ), or {ρ(g)|g ∈G}.
In the case where G is a topological space and V is ﬁnite dimensional,
ρ is said to be continuous if ρ(g) is continuous in g ∈G in the standard
topology of V .
If ρ is injective, then it is called a faithful representation of G.
A subspace M is called an invariant subspace of ρ if, for all g ∈G,
ρ(g)M ⊂M .
It follows that, for any invariant subspace M of ρ, ρ(g)M = M , g ∈G.
It is obvious that V and {0} ⊂V are invariant subspaces of ρ. But
these are called trivial invariant subspaces.
An invariant subspace M of ρ is said to be non-trivial if M ̸= {0}, V .
132
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
A representation ρ : G →GL(V ) is said to be irreducible if it has no
non-trivial invariant subspace.
If V is a Hilbert space H and ρ(g) is unitary for all g ∈G, then ρ is
called a unitary representation of G on H .
In the case where G is a topological space, a unitary representation
ρ : G →GL(H ) is said to be strongly continuous if, for all Ψ ∈H , the
mapping : G ∋g →ρ(g)Ψ ∈H is continuous.
A group G is called a topological group if G is a topological space
and the mappings G × G ∋(g1, g2) →g1g2 ∈G and G ∋g →g−1 ∈G are
continuous.
Example 2.9. For each n ∈N, Rn is a commutative group with group
operation: Rn × Rn ∋(a, b) →a + b ∈Rn. The space Rn in this sense is
called the n-dimensional translation group. This is a topological group.
Let {U(t)}t∈R be a strongly continuous one-parameter unitary group on a
Hilbert space H . Then, the mapping U : R →GL(H ); R ∋t →U(t) is
a strongly continuous unitary representation of R as the one-dimensional
translation group.
2.9.3
Unitary representation of SN
We now return to Proposition 2.9. One can deﬁne a mapping ρN : SN →
GL(⊗NH ) by
ρN(σ) := Uσ−1,
σ ∈SN.
Then, Proposition 2.9 implies that ρN(σ) is unitary and
ρN(στ) = ρN(σ)ρN(τ),
σ, τ ∈SN.
Hence, ρN is a unitary representation of the symmetry group SN on ⊗NH .
Thus, ⊗NH carries a unitary representation of SN.

We next consider the case of ∧N(H ). For vectors ψ1, . . . , ψN ∈H , we

It follows from Theorem 2.9(v) that ψ1 ∧· · · ∧ψN is anti-symmetric with
respect to permutations of ψ1, . . . , ψN:
ψσ(1) ∧· · · ∧ψσ(N) = sgn(σ)ψ1 ∧· · · ∧ψN,
σ ∈SN.
(2.56)
This property has an important consequence, as follows.
Proposition 2.11. If there exists a pair (i, j) (i ̸= j) such that ψi = ψj,
then
ψ1 ∧· · · ∧ψN = 0.
(2.57)
Proof. Applying (2.56) to the case σ = (i, j), the transposition of i and j,
and using the fact sgn(i, j) = −1, we have
ψ1 ∧· · · ∧ψN = −ψ1 ∧· · · ∧ψN.
Hence, (2.57) holds.
□

2.11
Symmetric and Anti-Symmetric State Functions
in Quantum Mechanics
In this section, we describe elementary applications of the theory given in
the preceding sections to the theory of many-body quantum systems. A
typical one of such quantum systems is a system of N quantum particles
in a d-dimensional Euclidean vector space Rd, with N ≥2 and d ∈N. If
the quantum particles are of mutually diﬀerent kinds, then one can take
L2((Rd)N) = L2(RdN) as a Hilbert space of states for the system. We call
an element of L2(RdN) a state function of the system.
Remark 2.14. In most of the literature on quantum mechanics, a state
function is usually called a “wave function,” although there are exceptions
(e.g., Margenau and Murphy, 1943; Tomonaga, 1952). But it seems that the
5Note that, according to the Pauli principle (see Remark 2.12), the fermions which
occupy ej are at most one.
142
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
name “wave function” may be misleading in understanding properly the
essence of quantum mechanical state because, in the context of quantum
mechanics, an element ψ in L2(RdN) cannot be interpreted as representing
any physical wave, such as an electromagnetic wave. This is already sug-
gested by the fact that an element in L2(RdN) is an equivalence class, not a
function in the usual sense. As is well known, in the Hilbert space formal-
ism of quantum mechanics due to von Neumann (1932), ψ is interpreted
as a probability amplitude: for each Borel set Bj ⊂Rd (j = 1, . . . , N), the
integral

B1×···×BN |ψ(x)|2dx/∥ψ∥2 gives the probability of the event that
the jth particle is found in Bj, j = 1, . . . , N, where Rd is interpreted as the
position space of the quantum particles. The following points should also
be noted: (i) If N ≥2, RdN does not represent the physical (position) space
Rd (d = 1, 2, 3) in which quantum particles are supposed to exist. (ii) In
quantum mechanics, two state vectors ψ and αψ (α ∈C, α ̸= 1) represent
an identical quantum state; however, if ψ were to represent a physical wave,
then they would represent diﬀerent states because the amplitude of ψ is dif-
ferent from that of αψ. To be rigorous in the sense of natural philosophical
cognition, we do not use the word “wave function” for a quantum mechan-
ical state. Of course, from a purely mathematical point of view, it does not
matter which name is used.
For mathematical generality and usefulness for applications, we con-
sider a general measure space (X, Σ, μ) instead of (Rd, Bd, μd
L) (μd
L is the
Lebesgue measure on (Rd, Bd)). Let
XN := {x = (x1, . . . , xN)|xj ∈X, j = 1, . . . , N}
be the N-direct product of X. We denote by μN the N-product measure of
μ on XN. For each element ψ ∈L2(XN, dμN) and a permutation σ ∈SN,
one can deﬁne ψσ ∈L2(X, dμN) by
ψσ(x) := ψ(xσ(1), . . . , xσ(N)),
μN-a.e. x ∈XN.
Then, the mapping uσ : L2(XN, dμN) →L2(XN, dμN), deﬁned by
uσψ := ψσ,

is unitary. For all σ, τ ∈SN,

2.11.1
The Hilbert space of symmetric state functions
A state function ψ ∈L2(XN, dμN) is said to be symmetric if, for each
σ ∈SN,
ψ(xσ(1), . . . , xσ(N)) = ψ(x), μN-a.e. x ∈XN.
This is equivalent to ψσ = ψ, for all σ ∈SN. We denote by L2

space is used as a Hilbert space in the case where each quantum particle
under consideration is identical with a boson (i.e., a quantum particle with
an integer spin).6

particle with a half-integer spin).7

2.13
Notes
A natural extension of the concept of tensor product of ﬁnitely many Hilbert
spaces is the concept of an inﬁnite tensor product Hilbert space,
⊗∞
n=1Hn, constructed from a sequence {Hn}∞
n=1 of Hilbert spaces. It is
a non-trivial task to deﬁne it rigorously, however. For details, see the orig-
inal paper by von Neumann (1939) or Ezawa (1978). A use of inﬁnite ten-
sor product Hilbert space in quantum mathematical physics is found, for
example, in the works of Thirring and Wehrl (1967) and Ezawa (1978). But,
nowadays, inﬁnite tensor product Hilbert spaces are not so often used, at
least in the ﬁeld of quantum mathematical physics.

with the positive semi-deﬁnite inner product space V . Thus, there is a
correspondence from the set of positive semi-deﬁnite inner product spaces

Chapter 3
Tensor Product of
Linear Operators
For each set, (A1, . . . , AN), of densely deﬁned closable linear operators Aj
(j = 1, . . . , N) acting in a Hilbert space, Hj, respectively, a linear operator
⊗N
j=1Aj, called the
tensor product operator, (or
tensor product), of Ajs, is
deﬁned. The fundamental properties of tensor product operators are proven. In
particular, detailed analyses are made on tensor products of self-adjoint operators,
which play important roles in applications to the theory of many-body quantum
systems.
3.1
Algebraic Tensor Product of Linear Operators
In the rest of this book, we mean by “Hilbert space” a “complex Hilbert
space,” unless otherwise stated.

Uniqueness. Suppose that there exists a linear operator T on H ⊗K , with
D(T ) = D(A)ˆ⊗D(B), such that T (Ψ ⊗Φ) = AΨ ⊗BΦ, Ψ ∈D(A), Φ ∈D(B).
Then, T (Ψ ⊗Φ) = Aˆ⊗B(Ψ ⊗Φ), Ψ ∈D(A), Φ ∈D(B). It follows from the
linearity of T and Aˆ⊗B that, for all F ∈D(A)ˆ⊗D(B), T (F) = Aˆ⊗B(F).
Thus, T = Aˆ⊗B.
□
We call the operator Aˆ⊗B the algebraic tensor product of A and B.
Remark 3.1. Let H ′ and K ′ be Hilbert spaces and A (resp., B) be a
linear operator from H (resp., K ) to H ′ (resp., K ′). Then, in quite the
same manner as above, one can prove that there exists a unique linear
operator A⊗B from H ⊗K to H ′ ⊗K ′ such that, for all Ψ ∈D(A) and
Φ ∈D(B), A⊗B(Ψ ⊗Φ) = AΨ ⊗BΦ. The operator A⊗B also is called the
algebraic tensor product of A and B. This concept of algebraic tensor
product of two linear operators is more general.
3.2
Tensor Product of Linear Operators
Let A ∈L(H ) and B ∈L(K ).

Aˆ⊗B is densely deﬁned and closable. Moreover,
A∗ˆ⊗B∗⊂(Aˆ⊗B)∗,

⟨Ψ ′ ⊗Φ′, AΨ ⊗BΦ⟩= ⟨A∗Ψ ′ ⊗B∗Φ′, Ψ ⊗Φ⟩.

(3.6) holds.

By Lemma 3.2, the following deﬁnition is possible.
Deﬁnition 3.1. For densely deﬁned closable operators A and B on H and
K , respectively, the closed operator
A ⊗B := Aˆ⊗B
(3.8)
on H ⊗K is called the tensor product operator, (or the tensor prod-

Remark 3.2. Also, in the case where A (resp., B) is a densely deﬁned
closable operator from H (resp., K ) to a Hilbert space H ′ (resp., K ′),
A ⊗B is deﬁned by (3.8) as a closed operator from H ⊗K to H ′ ⊗K ′
(see Remark 3.1).
Let A ∈L(H ) and B ∈L(K ) be densely deﬁned and closable. Then,
by Lemma 3.2, we have
A ⊗B = A ⊗B.
(3.9)
It is easy to see that, for all α ∈C,
α(A ⊗B) = (αA) ⊗B = A ⊗(αB).
It follows from the deﬁnition of A ⊗B that D(A)ˆ⊗D(B) is a core for
A ⊗B. The following proposition formulates basic facts on A ⊗B.
Proposition 3.1. Let A and B be densely deﬁned closable operators on H
and K , respectively. Then:
Tensor Product of Linear Operators
157
(i) If D ⊂D(A) and F ⊂D(B) are cores for A and B, respectively, then
D ˆ⊗F is a core for A ⊗B.
(ii) A∗⊗B∗⊂(A ⊗B)∗.
(iii) If A and B are symmetric, then A ⊗B is symmetric.
(iv) Ran(A ⊗B) = Ran(A) ⊗Ran(B).
Proof. (i) Let T := (A ⊗B) ↾D ˆ⊗F. Then, it is obvious that T ⊂A ⊗B.
Hence, T ⊂A ⊗B. To prove the converse relation, let Ψ ∈D(A) and Φ ∈
D(B). Then, there exist sequences {Ψn}∞
n=1, with Ψn ∈D, and {Φn}∞
n=1,
with Φn ∈F, such that Ψn →Ψ, AΨn →AΨ, Φn →Φ and BΦn →BΦ
as n →∞. Hence, Ψn ⊗Φn →Ψ ⊗Φ and T (Ψn ⊗Φn) →Aˆ⊗B(Ψ ⊗Φ)
as n →∞. This means that Aˆ⊗B ⊂T. Hence, A ⊗B ⊂T. Therefore,
T = A ⊗B.
(ii) Taking the closure operation on (3.5), we have A∗⊗B∗⊂(Aˆ⊗B)∗.
By Proposition 1.8(ii), (Aˆ⊗B)∗=

Aˆ⊗B
∗
= (A⊗B)∗, Hence, A∗⊗B∗⊂
(A ⊗B)∗.
(iii) Since A ⊂A∗and B ⊂B∗, it follows that Aˆ⊗B ⊂A∗ˆ⊗B∗. Hence,
taking the closure operation, we have A⊗B ⊂A∗⊗B∗. Using part (ii), we
obtain A ⊗B ⊂(A ⊗B)∗. Thus, A ⊗B is symmetric.
(iv) It is obvious that Ran(A)ˆ⊗Ran(B)
⊂
Ran(A ⊗B). Hence,
Ran(A)ˆ⊗Ran(B) ⊂Ran(A ⊗B). To prove the converse inclusion relation,
let Ψ ∈Ran(A ⊗B). Then, there exists a vector Φ ∈D(A ⊗B) such
that Ψ = (A ⊗B)Φ. By the deﬁnition of A ⊗B, there exists a sequence
{Φn}∞
n=1 in D(A)ˆ⊗D(B) such that Φn →Φ and (A⊗B)Φn →(A⊗B)Φ = Ψ
(n →∞). It is easy to see that (A⊗B)Φn is in Ran(A)ˆ⊗Ran(B). Hence, Ψ ∈
Ran(A)ˆ⊗Ran(B). Therefore, Ran(A⊗B) ⊂Ran(Aˆ⊗Ran(B), implying that
Ran(A ⊗B) ⊂Ran(Aˆ⊗Ran(B). Hence, Ran(A)ˆ⊗Ran(B) = Ran(A ⊗B).
By Proposition 2.2, the left-hand side is equal to Ran(A) ⊗Ran(B).
□
Remark 3.3. In Proposition 3.1(ii), the following equality holds: A∗⊗
B∗= (A ⊗B)∗. For a proof of this fact, see, for example, Schm¨udgen
(2012), Proposition 7.26.
In applications, operators of the form A ⊗I + I ⊗B, with A and B
being densely deﬁned closable operators, are also fundamental.
Proposition 3.2. Let A and B be densely deﬁned closable operators on H
and K , respectively. Let
S(A, B) := A ⊗I + I ⊗B,
S0(A, B) := S ↾D(A)ˆ⊗D(B).

Then:
(i) S(A, B) and S0(A, B) are densely deﬁned, closable and
S(A∗, B∗) ⊂S(A, B)∗,
(3.10)
S0(A∗, B∗) ⊂S0(A, B)∗.
(3.11)
(ii) If D ⊂D(A) and F ⊂D(B) are cores for A and B, respectively, then
D ˆ⊗F is a core for S0(A, B). In particular,
S0(A, B) = S0(A, B).
(3.12)
(iii) If A and B are symmetric, then S(A, B) and S0(A, B) are symmetric.
Proof. (i) It is obvious that D(A)ˆ⊗D(B) ⊂D(S(A, B)). Hence, S(A, B)
is densely deﬁned and S(A, B)∗⊃(A⊗I)∗+ (I ⊗B)∗⊃S(A∗, B∗). Hence,
D(S(A, B)∗) is dense, and (3.10) holds. Thus, S(A, B) is closable.
Since D(S0(A, B)) = D(A)ˆ⊗D(B) is dense in H ⊗K , S0(A, B) is
densely deﬁned. It is obvious that S0(A, B) ⊂S(A, B) ⊂S(A, B). Hence,
S0(A, B) is closable. By direct computations, one can show that, for all Ψ ∈
D(S0(A∗, B∗)) = D(A∗)ˆ⊗D(B∗) and Φ ∈D(S0(A, B)) = D(A)ˆ⊗D(B),
⟨Ψ, S0(A, B)Φ⟩= ⟨(A∗⊗I + I ⊗B∗)Ψ, Φ⟩= ⟨S0(A∗, B∗)Ψ, Φ⟩. Hence, Ψ ∈
D(S0(A, B)∗) and S0(A, B)∗Ψ = S0(A∗, B∗)Ψ. Hence, (3.11) holds.
(ii) Let S00 := S0(A, B) ↾D ˆ⊗F. Then, S00 ⊂S0(A, B), and hence
S00 ⊂S0(A, B). In the same way as in the proof of Proposition 3.1(i),
one can show that S0(A, B) ⊂S00. Hence, S0(A, B) ⊂S00. Therefore,
S00 = S0(A, B). Thus, D ˆ⊗F is a core for S0(A, B). Formula (3.12) is
proved by an application of the preceding result to the case where A and
B are replaced by A and B, respectively, and D = D(A), F = D(B).
(iii) Under the present assumption, S(A, B)
⊂
S(A∗, B∗) and
S0(A, B) ⊂S0(A∗.B∗). These relations and (i) imply that S(A, B) and
S0(A, B) are symmetric.
□
We conclude this section with a theorem on the unitary equivalence of
tensor product operators.
Theorem 3.1. Let A and B be densely deﬁned closable operators on H
and K , respectively. Let U : H ⊗K →K ⊗H be the natural isomorphism
(see Proposition 2.4), i.e., U is the unitary transformation from H ⊗K to
K ⊗H such that, for all Ψ ∈H and Φ ∈K , U(Ψ ⊗Φ) = Φ ⊗Ψ. Then,
U(A ⊗B)U −1 = B ⊗A.
(3.13)
Tensor Product of Linear Operators
159
Proof. It is easy to see that, for all Ψ ∈D(A) and Φ ∈D(B),
U(A ⊗B)U −1Φ ⊗Ψ = (B ⊗A)Φ ⊗Ψ.
Hence, U(A ⊗B)U −1 = B ⊗A on D(B)ˆ⊗D(A). This fact and a simple
limiting argument give that U(A⊗B)U −1 ⊂B ⊗A. By symmetry, we have
U −1(B ⊗A)U ⊂A ⊗B, which implies that B ⊗A ⊂U(A ⊗B)U −1. Thus,
(3.13) holds.
□
Formula (3.13) shows that A ⊗B is unitarily equivalent to B ⊗A under
the natural isomorphism U. This is a nice property. For example, the spec-
tral properties of B ⊗A are similar to those of A ⊗B. Moreover, (3.13)
makes it possible to derive the properties of B ⊗A from those of A ⊗B.
3.3
Tensor Product of Bounded Linear Operators
In this section, as a basic step for analysis of tensor product operators, we
consider the tensor products of bounded linear operators.
For a Hilbert space X , we denote the identity on X by IX (or simply
I if there would be no danger of confusion).

The following proposition is concerned with the convergence properties

Bn = A ⊗B.
(iii) If w-limn→∞An = A and w- limn→∞Bn = B, then w- limn→∞An ⊗
Bn = A ⊗B.

3.4
Reduction of Tensor Product Operators
In this section, we prove some basic facts on the reductions of tensor product
operators (see Section 1.9 for the concept of reduction of a linear operator).
Proposition 3.4. Let A and B be densely deﬁned closable operators on
H and K , respectively. Suppose that A (resp., B) is reduced by a closed
subspace M ⊂H (resp., N ⊂K ).
(i) The operator A ⊗B is reduced by M ⊗N , and
(A ⊗B)M⊗N = AM ⊗BN .
(3.19)
(ii) The operator A ⊗I + I ⊗B is reduced by M ⊗N , and
(A ⊗I + I ⊗B)M⊗N = AM ⊗IN + IM ⊗BN .
(3.20)
Proof. Let P (resp., Q) be the orthogonal projection onto M (resp., N ).
Then, by the assumption, PA ⊂AP · · · (∗) and QB ⊂BQ · · · (∗∗). By
Theorem 3.2(vii), the orthogonal projection onto M ⊗N is P ⊗Q.
(i) Let Ψ ∈D(A ⊗B). Then, there exists a sequence {Ψn}∞
n=1 in
D(A)⊗D(B) such that Ψn →Ψ and (A⊗B)Ψn →(A⊗B)Ψ (n →∞). By (∗)
and (∗∗) mentioned above, we have (P ⊗Q)(A⊗B)Ψn = (A⊗B)(P ⊗Q)Ψn.
Hence, (A ⊗B)(P ⊗Q)Ψn
→(P ⊗Q)(A ⊗B)Ψ (n →∞). Also,
(P ⊗Q)Ψn →(P ⊗Q)Ψ (n →∞). Since A ⊗B is closed, it follows that
(P ⊗Q)Ψ ∈D(A ⊗B) and (A ⊗B)(P ⊗Q)Ψ = (P ⊗Q)(A ⊗B)Ψ. Hence,
(A ⊗B)(P ⊗Q) ⊂(P ⊗Q)(A ⊗B). Thus, A ⊗B is reduced by M ⊗N .
It is obvious that (A ⊗B)M⊗N = AM ⊗BN on D(AM )⊗D(BN ).
Hence, it follows that AM ⊗BM ⊂(A ⊗B)M⊗N .
Tensor Product of Linear Operators
163
Conversely, let Ψ ∈D((A ⊗B)M⊗N ). Then, there exists a sequence
{Φn}∞
n=1 in D(A⊗B) such that Φn →Ψ and (A ⊗B)Φn →(A ⊗B)Ψ
(n →∞). Hence, letting Ψn := (P ⊗Q)Φn, we have Ψn ∈D(AM )⊗D(BN )
and limn→∞Ψn = (P ⊗Q)Ψ = Ψ. Moreover, (AM ⊗BN )Ψn = (P ⊗
Q)(A ⊗B)Φn →(P ⊗Q)(A ⊗B)Ψ = (A ⊗B)M⊗N Ψ (n →∞). Hence,
Ψ ∈D(AM ⊗BN ) and (AM ⊗BN )Ψ = (A ⊗B)M⊗N Ψ. Thus, (3.19)
holds.
(ii) By a simple application of (i), A ⊗I and I ⊗B are reduced by
M ⊗N , with (A ⊗I)M⊗N = AM ⊗IN and (I ⊗B)M⊗N = IM ⊗BN .
Hence, by Proposition 1.53, A ⊗I + I ⊗B is reduced by M ⊗N . Hence,
by Theorem 1.47(v), A ⊗I + I ⊗B is reduced by M ⊗N and

A ⊗I + I ⊗B

M⊗N = (A ⊗I + I ⊗B)M⊗N .
By Proposition 1.53 and the above mentioned facts, one obtains (3.20). □
3.5
Basic Properties of Simple Tensor Product Operators
Let A be a densely deﬁned closable operator on H or K . Then, the corre-
spondence A →A⊗I, or I ⊗A, gives an extension of A to a closed operator
on H ⊗K . We show that some properties of A are preserved under these
extensions. By Theorem 3.1, U(A ⊗I)U −1 = I ⊗A, where U is the natural
isomorphism from H ⊗K to K ⊗H . Hence, the properties of I ⊗A can
be derived from those of A ⊗I.1 Therefore it is suﬃcient to consider A ⊗I.

tensor product operator I ⊗I ⊗· · · ⊗Aj ⊗I ⊗· · · ⊗I on ⊗N

3.5.2
Spectral properties of A ⊗I
In what follows, we take it for granted that H ̸= {0} and K ̸= {0}.
Lemma 3.3. Let A be a densely deﬁned closed operator on H .
(i)
ker(A ⊗I) = ker A ⊗K .
(3.25)
(ii) A is injective if and only if A ⊗I is injective.
(iii) Ran(A) is dense in H if and only if Ran(A ⊗I) is dense in H ⊗K .
(iv) A is bijective if and only if A ⊗I is bijective. In that case, (A ⊗I)−1
and A−1 are bounded, and
(A ⊗I)−1 = A−1 ⊗I.
(3.26)
Proof. (i) According to the decomposition theorem with respect to A
(Theorem 1.10(ii)), we have H = ker A ⊕Ran A∗. Hence,
H ⊗K = (ker A ⊗K ) ⊕(Ran A∗⊗K ).
For all Ψ ∈ker A ⊗I, ψ ∈D(A∗) and φ ∈K , we have
0 = ⟨(A ⊗I)Ψ, ψ ⊗φ⟩= ⟨Ψ, A∗ψ ⊗φ⟩.
Hence, Ψ ∈(Ran A∗ˆ⊗K )⊥, which implies that Ψ ∈(Ran A∗⊗K )⊥. Hence,
ker(A ⊗I) ⊂ker A ⊗K . To prove the converse inclusion relation, we ﬁrst
note that ker Aˆ⊗K
⊂ker(A ⊗I). Taking the closure of this inclusion
relation, we obtain ker A ⊗K ⊂ker(A ⊗I). Thus, (3.25) holds.
(ii) This follows from (i).
(iii) Suppose that Ran(A) is dense on H . It is obvious that
Ran(A)ˆ⊗K ⊂Ran(A⊗I). It follows from the assumption that Ran(A)ˆ⊗K
is dense in H ⊗K . Hence, Ran(A ⊗I) is dense in H ⊗K .
Conversely, assume that Ran(A ⊗I) is dense in H ⊗K . Suppose that
Ran(A) were not dense in H . Since H
= ker A∗⊕Ran(A) (Theorem
1.10(ii)), there exists a non-zero vector ψ ∈ker A∗. Then, for all φ ∈K
and Ψ ∈D(A ⊗I),
⟨ψ ⊗φ, (A ⊗I)Ψ⟩= ⟨A∗ψ ⊗φ, Ψ⟩= 0.
Hence, Ran(A ⊗I) is not dense. But this is a contradiction. Thus, Ran(A)
is dense in H .
Tensor Product of Linear Operators
167
(iv) Let A be bijective. Then, by (ii) and (iii), A ⊗I is injective and
Ran(A ⊗I) is dense in H ⊗K . By the present assumption and Theorem
1.5, A−1 is bounded. Hence,
(A ⊗I)(A−1 ⊗I) = I,
(A−1 ⊗I)(A ⊗I) ⊂I.
This means that A ⊗I is bijective, and (3.26) holds.
Conversely, let A ⊗I be bijective. Then, according to Theorem 1.5,
(A ⊗I)−1 is bounded, and by (ii) and (iii), A is injective and Ran(A) is
dense. We have, for all ψ ∈D(A−1) and φ ∈K ,
A−1ψ ⊗φ = (A ⊗I)−1ψ ⊗φ.
Suppose that A−1 were not bounded. Then, there exists a sequence {ψn}n
in D(A−1) such that ∥ψn∥= 1, n ∈N and ∥A−1ψn∥→∞(n →∞). Let
φ ∈K be a unit vector. Then, ∥ψn ⊗φ∥= 1, and from the equation given
above, we have
∥(A ⊗I)−1ψn ⊗φ∥= ∥A−1ψn∥→∞(n →∞).
This shows that (A⊗I)−1 is unbounded. But this is a contradiction. Hence,
A−1 is bounded. This fact and the closedness of A imply that Ran(A) is
closed. Hence, Ran(A) = H .
□
We can now identify the spectra of A ⊗I.
Theorem 3.3. Let A be a densely deﬁned closed operator on H . Then,
σ(A ⊗I) = σ(A).
(3.27)
Proof. Equation (3.27) is equivalent to ρ(A ⊗I) = ρ(A). Let us prove
this. Let λ ∈ρ(A). Then, the closed operator A −λ is bijective. Hence, by
Lemma 3.3(iv), (A −λ) ⊗I is bijective. It is easy to see that
A ⊗I −λ = (A −λ) ⊗I.
(3.28)
Hence, A ⊗I −λ is bijective. Therefore, by Proposition 1.7, λ ∈ρ(A ⊗I).
Thus, ρ(A) ⊂ρ(A ⊗I).
Conversely, let λ ∈ρ(A ⊗I). Then, (A −λ) ⊗I is bijective. Hence,
by Lemma 3.3(iv), A −λ is bijective. Therefore, by Proposition 1.7 again,
λ ∈ρ(A). Thus, ρ(A ⊗I) ⊂ρ(A).
□
168
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Theorem 3.4. For all λ ∈C,
ker(A ⊗I −λ) = ker(A −λ) ⊗K .
(3.29)
In particular,
σp(A ⊗I) = σp(A),
(3.30)
and for each λ ∈σp(A),
dim ker(A ⊗I −λ) = dim ker(A −λ) · dim K .
(3.31)
Proof. Equation (3.29) is just an application of Lemma 3.3(i), with A
replaced by A −λ (use also (3.28)). Properties (3.30) and (3.31) follow
from (3.29).
□
Remark 3.7. Formula (3.31) shows that, if K
is inﬁnite dimensional,
then the multiplicity of the eigenvalue λ ∈σp(A ⊗I) is inﬁnite even if the
multiplicity of λ ∈σp(A) is ﬁnite.
3.6
Eigenvalues of Tensor Product Operators
Proposition 3.7. Let A and B be densely deﬁned closable operators on H
and K , respectively. Then,
{λμ|λ ∈σp(A), μ ∈σp(B)} ⊂σp(A ⊗B).
(3.32)
{λ + μ|λ ∈σp(A), μ ∈σp(B)} ⊂σp(A ⊗I + I ⊗B).
(3.33)
Proof. Let λ ∈σp(A) and μ ∈σp(B). There exist non-zero vectors Ψ ∈
D(A) and Φ ∈D(B) such that AΨ = λΨ and BΦ = μΦ. Hence, Ψ ⊗Φ ∈
D(A ⊗B) ∩D(A ⊗I + I ⊗B) and
A ⊗B(Ψ ⊗Φ) = λμ(Ψ ⊗Φ), (A ⊗I + I ⊗B)Ψ ⊗Φ = (λ + μ)Ψ ⊗Φ.
Since Ψ ⊗Φ is not zero, λμ ∈σp(A ⊗B) and λ + μ ∈σp(A ⊗I + I ⊗B).
Thus, (3.32) and (3.33) hold.
□

Point Spectra of Tensor Product of Self-Adjoint

Let Aj (j = 1, . . . , N) be a self-adjoint operator on Hj and SA1,...,AN
be deﬁned by (3.43). Then, by Theorem 3.8(i), the closure SA1,...,AN of
SA1,...,AN is self-adjoint, and its spectrum is given by (3.44). In this section,
we identify the point spectrum of SA1,...,AN. For this purpose, we recall
the multiplication operator form of the spectral theorem of a self-adjoint
operator.
Theorem 3.12. Let H be a separable Hilbert space and T be a self-adjoint
operator on H . Then, there exist a ﬁnite measure space (X, Σ, μ), a real-
valued Σ-measurable function F on X which is a.e. ﬁnite with respect to μ,
and a unitary transformation U : H →L2(X, dμ) such that UT U −1 = F
(the multiplication operator by the function F).
Proof. See, for example, Theorem VIII.4 in Reed and Simon (1980).
□

Proof. (i) It is suﬃcient to show (3.52) in the case of N = 2 because (3.52)

relation.

(U1 ⊗U2)(I ⊗A2)(U1 ⊗U2)−1 = I ⊗F2.
Let W : L2(X1, dμ1) ⊗L2(X2, dμ2) →L2(X1 × X2, d(μ1 ⊗μ2)) be the
natural isomorphism. Then, U := WU1 ⊗U2 is a unitary transformation
from H1 ⊗H2 to L2(X1 × X2, d(μ1 ⊗μ2)), and the operator equality

We can also clarify the structures of the eigenspaces of SA1,...,AN and
⊗N
j=1Aj. To state them, we introduce some symbols.
For a self-adjoint operator A on a Hilbert space H , we deﬁne the fol-
lowing two closed subspaces:
Hp(A) := Ran EA(σp(A)),
Hc(A) := Ran EA(σc(A)),
(3.56)
where EA is the spectral measure of A and σp(A) (resp., σc(A)) is the
point (resp., continuous) spectrum of A. If H is separable, then σp(A) is
at most countable, and hence Hp(A) is the closed subspace generated by
linear combinations of the eigenvectors of A (see Proposition 1.39).
Since the residual spectrum of A is empty (see Theorem 1.14(ii)), it
follows that
σ(A) = σp(A) ∪σc(A),
and hence
H = Hp(A) ⊕Hc(A).
(3.57)
The operator A is reduced by Hp(A) (resp., Hc(A)). We denote the
reduced part of A to Hp(A) (resp., Hc(A)) by Ap (resp., Ac). Hence, we
have the direct sum decomposition
A = Ap ⊕Ac
(3.58)
relative to (3.57).
Theorem 3.14. Assume that each Hj (j = 1, . . . , N) is separable.
(i)
Hp(SA1,...,AN) = ⊗N
j=1Hp(Aj)
and

SA1,...,AN

p = SA1p,...,ANp,
where Ajp is the reduced part of Aj to Hp(Aj).
(ii) If each Aj (j = 1, . . . , N) is injective, then

Chapter 4
Full Fock Spaces and Second
Quantization Operators
For a Hilbert space H , the inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert space ⊕∞
n=0 ⊗n H of the
n-fold tensor product ⊗nH (n ≥0) with ⊗0H := C is called the full Fock
space over H . This Hilbert space is the main subject of this chapter. There
is a fundamental class of linear operators acting in the full Fock space, called
second quantization operators. Their basic properties are investigated. The full
Fock space is a basis for the mathematical theories of quantum ﬁelds.
4.1
Inﬁnite Direct Sum Hilbert Spaces
From this chapter, we develop the theory of Fock spaces, which is one of
the main subjects in this book. This theory can be viewed as the theory
of inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert spaces of certain types. Therefore, to clearly
understand the nature of Fock spaces, it would be better to develop in
advance a general theory of inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert spaces. Thus, we
ﬁrst present the elements of a general theory of inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert
spaces.

4.4
Diagonal and Non-Diagonal Operators on H
Let H be as in (4.2) and, for each n ≥0, Pn be the orthogonal projection
onto the closed subspace Hn of H. We say that a linear operator T on H is
Full Fock Spaces and Second Quantization Operators
207
diagonal if T is reduced by each Hn, i.e., for each n ≥0, PnT ⊂T Pn. In
that case, for all Ψ ∈D(T ) and n ≥0, PnΨ ∈D(T ) and T PnΨ = PnT Ψ.
Hence, (T Ψ)(n) = PnT Ψ = T Ψ (n) = TnΨ (n), where Tn is the reduced part
of T to Hn. Therefore. we have
T = ⊕∞
n=0Tn.
Hence, T is an inﬁnite direct sum operator on H. Conversely, all inﬁnite
direct sum operators on H are diagonal, as is easily seen.
Of course, there exist non-diagonal operators on H, which should also be
studied. In this section, we introduce a basic class of non-diagonal operators
on H, which has applications to mathematical theory of quantum ﬁelds, and
a generalization of it.

Theorem 4.7. Let p ≥2 and An = (An1, . . . , Anp) (n ≥0) be a p-tuple of

we have
EA(B1 × · · · × Bp) = ⊕∞
n=0EAn(B1 × · · · × Bp).
Then, by a standard argument using Hopf’s extension theorem, one obtains
(4.36).
To prove (4.37), let

n=0Sn.

EA(Bδ(λ)) = 0. Therefore, by (4.36), EAn(Bδ(λ)) = 0, for all n ≥0.
This means that Bδ(λ) ⊂Sc

4.6
Full Fock Spaces
We have so far considered a general theory of inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert
spaces. We now introduce a special class of inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert
spaces, which plays a basic role in mathematical quantum ﬁeld theory.
Let {Hn}∞
n=1 be a sequence of Hilbert spaces. Then, one can deﬁne the
inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert space

j=1Hj


We call it the Fock space associated with {Hn}∞
n=1. The subspace

j=1Hj is called the n-particle Hilbert space of F. In the context
of quantum physics, ⊗n
j=1Hj describes states (state vectors) of n-quantum
particles. The Hilbert space F may be an abstract form which describes
a state space of a quantum system consisting of possibly inﬁnitely many
quantum particles.
In applications to quantum ﬁeld theory, the case where, for all n ≥1,
Hn is equal to a single Hilbert space H appears. In this case, F takes the
form
F(H ) := ⊕∞
n=0 ⊗n H ,
with the convention ⊗0H
:= C. This Hilbert space is called the full
Fock space over H . As is seen, the full Fock space F(H ) is constructed
from the one-particle Hilbert space H with tensor product and direct sum
operations.
An application of Corollary 4.1 gives the following proposition.
Proposition 4.10. If H is separable, then F(H ) is separable.
A vector Ψ = {Ψ (n)}∞
n=0 in F(H ) is called a ﬁnite particle vector
if there exists an n0 ∈N such that, for all n ≥n0, Ψ (n) = 0 (n0 depends

The Fock vacuum ΩH is a unit vector, i.e., ∥ΩH ∥= 1, and sometimes
written as ΩH = {1, 0, 0, . . .}.

In the context of quantum ﬁeld theory, dΓ(T ) may have the following
meaning. Suppose that T is a self-adjoint operator which denotes a physi-
cal quantity in a one-particle quantum system (e.g., the Hamiltonian and
the momentum operator). Then, T (n) represents the same kind of physical
quantity in the corresponding n-particle quantum system. Hence, dΓ(T )
gives the same kind of physical quantity in the corresponding inﬁnite quan-
tum particle system in which any number of quantum particles may exist.
The second quantization operator for the identity I on H ,

(4.47)

that

the scalar multiplication operator by n. Since I is self-adjoint, 

one has

(4.48)
with

n ≥0.
(4.49)

4.8
Ground State
Let T be a non-negative self-adjoint operator on H . Then, by Theorem
4.9(iii), dΓ(T ) is non-negative and the inﬁmum of the spectrum of dΓ(T ) is
equal to 0, which is an eigenvalue of dΓ(T ); an eigenvector belonging to it is
given by the Fock vacuum ΩH (see (4.43)). From a general mathematical
point of view, this structure can be regarded as a concrete realization of a
general concept, which we recall in the following.
Let H be a self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space X , and suppose
that H is bounded from below. Then, by Theorem 1.14(iv), the inﬁmum of
the spectrum of H
E0(H) := inf σ(H)
(4.50)
222
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
is ﬁnite. In the context of quantum physics, where H denotes the Hamilto-
nian of a quantum system, E0(H) is called the lowest energy of H. We
remark that E0(H) is not necessarily an eigenvalue of H. If E0(H) is an
eigenvalue of H, then H is said to have a ground state, and each non-zero
vector Ψ0 in the eigenspace ker(H−E0(H)) (i.e., Ψ0 ∈D(H)\{0} and HΨ0 =
E0(H)Ψ0) is called a ground state of H. In this case, the eigenvalue E0(H)
is called the ground state energy of H. If dim ker(H −E0(H)) = 1, then
the ground state of H is said to be unique.4 If dim ker(H −E0(H)) ≥2,
then the ground state of H is said to be degenerate. In quantum ﬁeld the-
ory, a ground state is sometimes called a vacuum.
The notion “ground state” originally comes from quantum mechanics;
a ground state is an eigenstate (eigenvector) with the minimum eigenvalue
of the Hamiltonian of a quantum system. However, in the deﬁnitions here, H
does not necessarily represent a Hamiltonian; they apply to all self-adjoint
operators bounded from below (an extension is made for the use of terms).
With the deﬁnition above, one can say that ΩH is a ground state of
dΓ(T ), with the ground state energy being zero.
4.9
Γ-Operators
Let K be a Hilbert space and S be a densely deﬁned closable operator
from H to K . Then the n-fold tensor product ⊗nS of S (⊗1S := S) is
a densely deﬁned closed operator from ⊗nH to ⊗nK (see Remark 3.8).
Hence, by Theorem 4.1(i) and (ii), the inﬁnite direct sum operator
Γ(S) := ⊕∞
n=0 ⊗n S
(4.51)
with ⊗0S := 1 : C →C is a densely deﬁned closed operator from F(H )
to F(K ). We call the operator Γ(S) the Γ-operator for S.5 By (3.9), we
have
Γ(S) = Γ(S).
4With regard to the existence and uniqueness of ground states, some general theories
are known. See, for example, Glimm and Jaﬀe (1970), Simon and Hoegh-Krohn (1972),
Farris (1972), Gross (1972) and Miyao (2010). Textbook descriptions on this topic are
found in Reed and Simon (1978), Section XIII.12.
5Usually Γ(S) is considered only for the case where S is a contraction operator and
there are cases where Γ(S) is called the second quantization of S (e.g., Mayer, 1995,
Section 4.1). But, in the present book, we use the word “second quantization” only for
dΓ(·). In Arai (2000a), Γ(S) is called the second quantization of the second kind.

We ﬁrst note the following fact:
Proposition 4.12. Let S and T be densely deﬁned closed operators from
H to K . If Γ(S) = Γ(T ), then S = T .
Proof. We need only to apply Proposition 4.3.
□
Remark 4.4. The correspondence Γ(·) : S →Γ(S) deﬁnes a mapping
from the set of densely deﬁned closed operators from H to K to the set of
densely deﬁned closed operators from F(H ) to F(K ). Proposition 4.12
shows that this mapping is injective.
With regard to boundedness or unboundedness of a Γ-operator, the fol-
lowing theorem holds. Note the diﬀerence from those of the second quanti-
zation dΓ(·).
Theorem 4.10. Let S be a densely deﬁned closable operator from H to K .
(i) If S is unbounded or bounded with ∥S∥> 1, then Γ(S) is unbounded.
(ii) If S is a contraction operator, then so is Γ(S).
Proof. (i) Let S be unbounded. Then ⊗1S = S is unbounded. Hence, by
Proposition 4.6, Γ(S) is unbounded.
Next let S be bounded with ∥S∥> 1. Then ⊗nS is bounded for all
n ≥1 with
∥⊗n S∥= ∥S∥n.
(4.52)
The present assumption ∥S∥> 1 implies that supn≥1 ∥S∥n = ∞. Hence
supn≥1 ∥⊗n S∥= ∞. Thus, by Proposition 4.5, Γ(S) is unbounded.
(ii) If ∥S∥≤1, then, by (4.52), ∥⊗n S∥≤1. Hence, by Proposition 4.5,
∥Γ(S)∥≤1.
□

(i) If H = K and S is self-adjoint, then Γ(S) is self-adjoint.

Proof. (i) Under the present assumption, ⊗nS is self-adjoint. Hence, by

contraction operator. It is easy to see that (4.53) holds on Fﬁn(H ). By

Theorem 4.12 tells us that the operator Γ(U) with U : H →K unitary
is a natural isomorphism between F(H ) and F(K ).
4.10
Anti-Unitary Γ-Operators
A mapping W : H →K is called an anti-unitary operator if W is
anti-linear, RanW = K and ∥Wψ∥= ∥ψ∥, for all ψ ∈H .
Let W : H →K be anti-unitary. Then, using the polarization identity,
one can show that
⟨Wψ, Wφ⟩= ⟨φ, ψ⟩,
ψ, φ ∈H .
In the same way as in the case of bounded linear operators, one can show
that, for each n ∈N, there exists a unique anti-unitary operator ⊗nW from
⊗nH to ⊗nK such that
(⊗nW)(⊗n
j=1ψj) = ⊗n
j=1Wψj,
ψj ∈H , j = 1, . . . , n.
We call ⊗nW the n-fold tensor product of W.
Let JC : C →C be the complex conjugation:
JCz := z∗,
z ∈C
and
Γ(W) := JC ⊕(⊕∞
n=1 ⊗n W).
Then, it is easy to see that Γ(W) is an anti-unitary operator from F(H )
to F(K ).

4.11
Representations of Unitary Groups and Semi-Groups
Let U(H ) be the set of all unitary operators on a Hilbert space H . Then,
it is easy to see that U(H ) is a group with respect to the product operation
of operators. The group U(H ) is called the unitary group on H .
Theorem 4.13. Let U0 be a subgroup of U(H ). Then, the mapping Γ(·):
U0 ∋U →Γ(U) ∈U(F(H )) gives a faithful unitary representation of U0
on F(H ).
In particular, if U0 is closed in the strong topology, then Γ(·) is strongly
continuous.
Proof. The ﬁrst half of this theorem follows from Theorem 4.12(ii), (iii)
and Remark 4.4. The second half is due to Theorem 4.12(iv).
□
Theorem 4.13 is used for the unitary representations of groups appearing
in quantum ﬁeld theory in the following form.
Corollary 4.3. Let G be a group and ρ : G →U(H ) be a unitary represen-
tation. Then, {Γ(ρ(g))|g ∈G} is a unitary representation of G on F(H ).
In particular, if G is a topological space and ρ is strongly continuous, then
{Γ(ρ(g))|g ∈G} is a strongly continuous unitary representation.
Proof. We need only to apply Theorem 4.13 to the case where U0 =
{ρ(g)|g ∈G}.
□
For a Hilbert space H , we denote by Con(H ) the set of all contrac-
tion operators on H . It is easy to see that Con(H ) is a semi-group (see
Section 2.9.2), with the unit element being IH .
Theorem 4.14. Let B be a subsemi-group of Con(H ). Then, {Γ(C)|
C ∈B} is a subsemi-group of Con(F(H )).
Proof. Let C1, C2 ∈B. Then, by Theorem 4.12 (ii), Γ(Cj) (j = 1, 2) is a
contraction operator and Γ(C1C2) = Γ(C1)Γ(C2). Thus, the desired result
follows.
□

Theorem 4.15. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H .
(i) For all t ∈R,
Γ(eitT ) = eitdΓ(T ).
(4.56)
(ii) If T ≥0, then dΓ(T ) ≥0 and, for all z ∈C+ (see (1.77)),
Γ(e−zT ) = e−zdΓ(T ).
(4.57)

Remark 4.5. See Problem 9 for some aspects of Theorem 4.15.
One has the following theorem on the transformation law of dΓ(T ) under
the unitary operator Γ(U), with U : H →K being unitary.
Theorem 4.16. Let U be a unitary operator from H to K and T be a
self-adjoint operator on H . Then,
Γ(U)dΓ(T )Γ(U)−1 = dΓ(UT U −1).
(4.58)
Proof. Since Γ(U) is unitary, Γ(U)dΓ(T )Γ(U)−1 is a self-adjoint operator
on F(K ). Let t ∈R be arbitrary. Then, using the unitary covariance of

functional calculus (Theorem 1.32) and (4.56) and the product law of the
Γ-operation, we can proceed as follows:
eitΓ(U)dΓ(T )Γ(U)−1 = Γ(U)eitdΓ(T )Γ(U)−1 = Γ(UeitT U −1) = Γ(eitUT U−1)
= eitdΓ(UT U−1).
Hence, (4.58) holds.

Remark 4.6. For Hilbert spaces H and K , we denote by Con(H , K )
the set of all contraction operators from H to K . Let H be a class of all
Hilbert spaces and C := {S ∈Con(H , K )|H , K ∈H}, the class of all
contraction operators from one Hilbert space to another. Then, the pair
Hilbert(C) := (H, C) forms a category whose class of objects and arrows
(morphisms) are H and C, respectively.6 One can also consider the category
whose objects and arrows are, respectively, full Fock spaces and contraction
operators from a full Fock space to a full Fock space. We denote it by
Fock(C). Then, it follows from Theorem 4.12(ii) that the correspondence
Γ : Hilbert(C) →Fock(C), deﬁned by
Γ(H , S) := (F(H ), Γ(S)),
(H , S) ∈Hilbert(C),
is a covariant functor. Hence, the Γ-operator Γ(·) in its extended form Γ(·)
is a covariant functor from a Hilbert space category Hilbert(C) to a full
Fock space category Fock(C).
By Theorem 4.15, the operator family {Γ(eitT )}t∈R with a self-adjoint
operator T is equal to the strongly continuous one-parameter unitary group
{eitdΓ(T )}t∈R generated by dΓ(T ). Hence, Γ(eitT ) is an integrated form of
the second quantization dΓ(T ) in the sense that, for all Ψ ∈D(dΓ(T )),
Ψ(t) = Γ(eitT )Ψ is a unique solution to the strong diﬀerential equation
dΨ(t)
dt
= idΓ(T )Ψ(t).
In this sense, it may be possible to regard Γ(eitT ) as a bounded operator
version of the second quantization of T . Thus, conceptually, the second
quantization may be understood as the functor Γ(·), with arrows restricted
to {eitT |t ∈R, T being a self-adjoint operator on a Hilbert space}.
Theorem 4.16 extends to the case where T is a densely deﬁned closable
operator.
6An introduction to category theory is found, for example, in Mac Lane (1986),
Section 11.9, and Awodey (2010).

To acquire a meaning of commutation relation (4.61), we recall some
algebraic concepts. Let K be R or C. A vector space g over K is called a
Lie algebra over K if there is a mapping [ , ] : g×g →g ((X, Y ) ∈g×g →
[X, Y ] ∈g) satisfying the following (i)–(iii):
(i) (linearity) [aX + bY, Z] = a[X, Z] + b[Y, Z], X, Y ∈g, a, b ∈K,
(ii) (anti-symmetry) [X, Y ] = −[Y, X], X, Y ∈g.
(iii) (Jacobi identity) [X, [Y, Z]] + [Y, [Z, X]] + [Z, [X, Y ]] = 0, X, Y, Z ∈g.
If K = R (resp., C), then g is called a real (resp., complex) Lie algebra.
The mapping [ , ] : g×g →g is called a bracket product, or Lie bracket.
A subset h of a Lie algebra g is called a subalgebra of g if it is a vector
subspace of g and, for all X, Y ∈h, [X, Y ] ∈h. In that case, h is a Lie
algebra.
Example 4.5. For a vector space V over K, we denote by gl(V ) the set of
all everywhere deﬁned linear operators on V (note that gl(V ) ⊂L(V )). It
is easy to see that gl(V ) is a Lie algebra over K, with the bracket product
given by the commutator [X, Y ] := XY −Y X, X, Y ∈gl(V ).
Full Fock Spaces and Second Quantization Operators
231
In particular, for a Hilbert space H , the set B(H ) of all everywhere
deﬁned bounded linear operators on H is a Lie algebra, with the bracket
product being the commutator. This Lie algebra is a subalgebra of the Lie
algebra gl(H ).
For Lie algebras g and h over K, a linear operator f : g →h is called a
homomorphism from g to h if, for all X, Y ∈g, f([X, Y ]) = [f(X), f(Y )]
(i.e., f preserves the Lie algebraic structure). A bijective homomorphism
f : g →h is called an isomorphism. The Lie algebras g and h are said to
be isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism f : g →h.
A homomorphism ϱ from a Lie algebra g to gl(V ) (i.e., for all X, Y ∈
g, a, b ∈K, ϱ(X) ∈gl(V ), ϱ(aX + bY ) = aϱ(X) + bϱ(Y ) and ϱ([X, Y ]) =
[ϱ(X), ϱ(Y )]) is called a representation of g on V . In this case, V is called
the representation space of g.
If V is a subspace of a Hilbert space H , then ϱ is called a Hilbert
space representation of g in H . If, for all X ∈g, ϱ(X) is bounded,
then ϱ is called a bounded representation of g in H . A Hilbert space
representation of g which is not bounded is said to be unbounded.
Now, let us return to Theorem 4.18. Note that, for all S ∈B(H ),
dΓ(S) can be regarded as an everywhere deﬁned linear operator on the
vector space Fﬁn(H ). Namely, dΓ(S) ∈gl(Fﬁn(H )). Therefore, Theorem
4.18 means that the mapping dΓ(·) : B(H ) →gl(Fﬁn(H )) gives a Hilbert
space representation of the Lie algebra B(H ) on Fﬁn(H ). By Theorem
4.8(ii), this representation is unbounded.

In the case where S and T are self-adjoint, dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ) are self-
adjoint (Theorem 4.9). Hence, one can ask when they commute strongly.
One should be careful about the following point: by Corollary 4.4, if S and
T commute, then dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ) commute on Fﬁn(D([S, T ])). But dΓ(S)
and dΓ(T ) do not necessarily strongly commute.
With regard to the strong commutativity of dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ), the fol-
lowing beautiful fact exists.
Theorem 4.19. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on H . Then, the
self-adjoint operators dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ) strongly commute if and only if S
and T strongly commute.
Proof. Let s, t ∈R be arbitrarily ﬁxed. Then, by (4.56) and (4.53), we
have
eis dΓ(S)eit dΓ(T ) = Γ(eisSeitT ),
s, t ∈R.
(4.65)
Suppose that dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ) strongly commute. Then, by Proposition
1.48, for all s, t ∈R, eis dΓ(S) and eit dΓ(T ) commute. By this fact and (4.65),
Γ

eisSeitT 
= Γ

eitT eisS
. Restricting this equation to H as a closed
subspace of F(H ), we obtain eisSeitT = eitT eisS. Hence, by Proposition
1.48 again, we conclude that S and T strongly commute.
Conversely, suppose that S and T strongly commute. Then, by Proposi-
tion 1.48 and (4.65), eis dΓ(S) and eit dΓ(T ) commute. Hence, by Proposition
1.48 again, dΓ(S) and dΓ(T ) strongly commute.
