Chapter 5
Boson Fock Spaces
There is an important closed subspace of the full Fock space F(H ) over a Hilbert
space H , called the boson Fock space over H . In this chapter, we describe
basic aspects of the theory of boson Fock spaces. This theory is a basis for
mathematically rigorous constructions of models in a class of quantum ﬁelds called
Bose ﬁelds.
5.1
Introduction: Some Physical Backgrounds
A
big
diﬀerence
between classical particles and quantum particles
(elementary particles, atoms, molecules, ions, etc.) is that identical quantum
particles (e.g., two electrons) are indistinguishable (e.g., Dirac, 1958, Chap-
ter IX). This fact is called the principle of indistinguishability. It places
some restrictions on the form of states of a many-body system consisting
of identical quantum particles.
To be concrete, let us consider a system S of N identical quantum
particles with N ≥2 (e.g., N electrons). Then, one can show (e.g., Arai
and Ezawa, 1999b, Section 4.1) that the principle of indistinguishability
implies the following alternative on the states of the system: any state of
the system S is either symmetric or anti-symmetric for all permutations
of the N identical quantum particles. A quantum particle is said to obey
the Bose–Einstein (resp., Fermi–Dirac) statistics if its many-particle
systems allow only symmetric (resp., anti-symmetric) states, called a boson
(resp., fermion). Thus, there are two classes of quantum particles in nature.
For example, electrons and protons are fermions, while photons and mesons
are bosons.
239
240
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
As is easily inferred, a Hilbert space of states for the system S may take
a diﬀerent form according to whether the quantum particles are identical
bosons or fermions. If a Hilbert space of states for a one-boson (resp., one-
fermion) system is H , then a natural Hilbert space of states for a system
of N identical bosons (resp., fermions) is given by the symmetric tensor
product ⊗N
s H
(resp., the anti-symmetric tensor product ∧N(H )) (see
Section 2.9.4 for the deﬁnition of these Hilbert spaces).
As is well known, elementary particles can be created or annihilated
through interactions. A quantum ﬁeld is supposed to be an object with
which one kind of elementary particles (quanta) is associated and that has
the function creating or annihilating the associated elementary particles
without restriction on their number. Hence, in the particle picture, the sys-
tem of a quantum ﬁeld is essentially an inﬁnite particle system. Therefore,
a Hilbert space of states for a quantum ﬁeld system must contain vectors
representing states of n identical elementary particles with n ≥0 arbitrary.
A quantum ﬁeld whose quanta are bosons (resp., fermions) is called a
Bose (resp., Fermi) ﬁeld. A boson Fock space, the main object in this
chapter, is used to describe a Hilbert space of states for the system of a
Bose ﬁeld. On the other hand, a Hilbert space of states for the system of
a Fermi ﬁeld is given by a fermion Fock space, discussed in the following
chapter.
In connection with these facts, we want to mention the following aspect:
a quantum particle carries a physical quantity called a spin angular
momentum s = (s1, s2, s3), where s1, s2 and s3 are linear operators on a
Hilbert space. This quantity is related to an internal degree of freedom.1
From a physical perspective, the spin angular momentum of a quantum
particle is supposed to be the angular momentum of “internal rotation.”
The total angular momentum of a quantum particle is given by the sum of
the spin angular momentum and the orbital angular momentum.
A number s ∈{n/2 | n ∈Z+}—an integer (0, 1, 2, . . .) or a half-integer
(1/2, 3/2, . . .)—is associated with each quantum particle in such a way that
the eigenvalue of s2 is equal to s(s + 1)ℏ2, where ℏis the reduced Planck
constant. The number s is called the spin of the quantum particle under
consideration. In this case, the quantum particle is said to have spin s.
For example, an electron and a proton have spin 1/2. The spin of a
photon is 1. A π meson and a K meson have spin 0.
If the mass of a quantum particle with spin s is positive, then
the quantum particle has exactly (2s + 1) spin eigenstates, which are
1A degree of freedom independent of external (spatial) degrees of freedom.
Boson Fock Spaces
241
represented by eigenvectors of sj with eigenvalues −sℏ, (−s + 1)ℏ, . . . ,
(s −1)ℏ, sℏ. However, for elementary particles with mass zero, this is not
true. For example, a photon, whose spin is 1, has only two spin eigenstates
with eigenvalues ±ℏ; theoretically, this is due to relativistic and gauge
invariance (see, for example, Takeda and Miyazawa, 1974, Section 6.1 for
details).
In general, a quantum particle with an integer spin obeys the Bose–
Einstein statistics, i.e., it is a boson, while a quantum particle with a half-
integer spin obeys the Fermi–Dirac statistics, i.e., it is a fermion. This
experimentally established fact is called the relation of spin and statis-
tics. Theoretically, this can be derived from an axiomatic relativistic quan-
tum ﬁeld theory (e.g., Bogoliubov et al., 1975; Haag, 1996).

5.3.2
Boson second quantization operators and their basic
properties
We are now ready to state and prove some facts on the reduction of a second
quantization operator dΓ(·) to the boson Fock space Fb(H ).
Theorem 5.1. Let T be a densely deﬁned closable operator on H .
(i) The second quantization dΓ(T ) is reduced by the boson Fock space
Fb(H ).
(ii) Let dΓb(T ) be the reduced part of dΓ(T ) to Fb(H ) (see Section 1.9) :
dΓb(T ) := dΓ(T )Fb(H ).
(5.9)
Then,

(5.10)
(iii) dΓb(T ∗) ⊂dΓb(T )∗.

Proof. (i) Let Ψ ∈D(dΓ(T )) and, for each N ∈N, deﬁne the vec-

The operator dΓb(T ) is called the boson second quantization

Theorem 5.2. Let T be self-adjoint.
(i) dΓb(T ) is self-adjoint.
(ii) If T ≥0, then dΓb(T ) ≥0.
(iii) If σ(T ) ∩(−∞, 0) ̸= ∅, then dΓb(T ) is not bounded from below.
(iv) If D ⊂H is a core for T p with some p ∈N, then Fb,ﬁn(D) is a core
for dΓb(T )p.
Proof. (i) This follows from Theorem 1.47(ix).
(ii) This follows from Theorem 4.8(iv).

5.3.4
eitdΓb(T )-invariant vectors
Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H . Then, by an application of Theorem
1.29(v), we have
{Ψ ∈Fb(H )|eitdΓb(T )Ψ = Ψ, t ∈R} = ker dΓb(T ).
(5.17)
By (5.12), ΩH ∈ker(dΓb(T )). Hence,
eitdΓb(T )ΩH = ΩH ,
t ∈R,
i.e., ΩH is an eitdΓb(T )-invariant vector.
Concerning the uniqueness of eitdΓb(T )-invariant vectors, the following
theorem holds.
Theorem 5.4. Let T be a non-negative self-adjoint operator on H such
that ker T = {0}. Then, if a vector Ψ ∈Fb(H ) satisﬁes eitdΓb(T )Ψ = Ψ
for all t ∈R, then Ψ = λΩH for some constant λ ∈C.
Proof. By (5.17), we need only to show that, under the present
assumption, ker dΓb(T ) = {λΩH |λ ∈C}.
Let Ψ ∈ker dΓb(T ). Then, dΓb(T )Ψ = 0. This implies that, for all
n ∈N, T (n)
b
Ψ (n) = 0. Since T ≥0 with ker T = {0}, it follows from Theorem
3.9 that, for all n ∈N, ker T (n)
b
= 0. Hence, Ψ = {Ψ (0), 0, 0, . . .} = λΩH
with λ = Ψ (0).
□
Remark 5.1. With regard to ker dΓb(T ) in the case where ker T ̸= {0},
see Theorem 7.7 in Chapter 7 in this book.

5.3.6
Commutation properties
In this section, we describe commutation properties of boson second
quantization operators.
Theorem 5.5. Let S and T be densely deﬁned closable operators on H
such that D([S, T ]) is dense and [S, T ] is closable. Then, Fb,ﬁn(D([S, T ])) ⊂
D([dΓb(S), dΓb(T )]) and, for all Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D([S, T ])),
[dΓb(S), dΓb(T )]Ψ = dΓb([S, T ])Ψ
Proof. This follows from Theorem 4.18 and the reducibility of dΓ(·) to
Fb(H ).
□
As a corollary to Theorem 5.5, we have the following fact.
Corollary 5.1. Let T be a densely deﬁned closable operator on H . Then,
Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) ⊂D([Nb, dΓb(T )]) and, for all Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D(T )),
[Nb, dΓb(T )]Ψ = 0.
In the case where S and T are self-adjoint, it is natural to ask when
dΓb(S) and dΓb(T ) strongly commute.
252
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Lemma 5.1. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H . Then, for all z ∈C,
eizdΓ(T ) is reduced by Fb(H ) and
(eizdΓ(T ))Fb(H ) = eizdΓb(T ).
Proof. We need only to apply Theorem 1.49 with M = Fb(H ), f(λ) =
eizλ and A = dΓ(T ).
□
Remark 5.2. The operators eizdΓ(T ) and eizdΓb(T ) are not necessarily
bounded.
The following proposition gives an answer to the above question.
Proposition 5.5. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on H .
(i) dΓb(S) and dΓb(T ) strongly commute if and only if S and T strongly
commute.
(ii) Nb and dΓb(T ) strongly commute.
Proof. (i) Suppose that dΓb(S) and dΓb(T ) strongly commute. Then,
eis dΓb(S)eit dΓb(T ) = eit dΓb(T )eis dΓb(S),
s, t ∈R.
(5.33)
Restricting this equation to the one-particle space ⊗1
sH = H , we have
eisSeitT = eitT eisS. Hence, S and T strongly commute.
Conversely suppose that S and T
strongly commute. Then, by
Theorem 4.19, eis dΓ(S) and eit dΓ(T ) strongly commute for all s, t ∈R.
Hence,
eis dΓ(S)eit dΓ(T ) = eit dΓ(T )eis dΓ(S),
s, t ∈R.
By Lemma 5.1, this implies (5.33). Hence, dΓb(S) and dΓb(T ) strongly
commute.
(ii) It is obvious that S = I and T strongly commute. Hence, by part (i),
Nb and dΓb(T ) strongly commute.
□

We next derive some basic properties of the reduced Γ-operator Γb(·).
Theorem 5.6. Let T be a densely deﬁned closable operator from H to K .
(i) If T is unbounded or bounded with ∥T ∥> 1, then Γb(T ) is unbounded.
(ii) Γb(T ∗) ⊂Γb(T )∗.
254
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(iii) If T is a contraction operator, then Γb(T ) is a contraction operator
and
Γb(T )∗= Γb(T ∗).
(5.37)
(iv) If D is a core for T, then Fb,ﬁn(D) is a core for Γb(T ).
Proof. (i) Let T be unbounded. Then, (⊗1T )b = T is unbounded. Hence,
by Proposition 4.6, Γb(T ) is unbounded. Next, let T be bounded with
∥T ∥> 1. Then, there exist a constant c > 0 and a unit vector f ∈H
such that ∥T f∥≥1 + c. Hence,
∥(⊗nT )b∥≥∥(⊗nT ) ⊗n f∥= ∥T f∥n ≥(1 + c)n.
Hence, supn≥1 ∥(⊗nT )b∥= ∞. Therefore, by Proposition 4.5, Γb(T ) is
unbounded.
(ii) This follows from Theorem 4.11(i) and Proposition 1.51(iv).
(iii) By Theorem 4.10(ii), Γ(T ) is a contraction operator. Hence,
∥Γb(T )∥≤∥Γ(T )∥≤1. Equality (5.37) follows from Theorem 4.11(ii).
(iv) This follows from Theorem 4.11(iii).
□
Theorem 5.7. Let H , K and X be Hilbert spaces.

Γb(U)−1 = Γb(U −1).

Γb(U)Fb,ﬁn(H ) = Fb,ﬁn(K ).

operators. Then,
Γb(T )Γb(S) = Γb(T S).

Boson Fock Spaces

Proof. These follow from Theorem 4.12 and the theory of reduction of

The basic relations between the boson second quantization operator
dΓb(T ) and the boson Γ-operator Γb(T ) are given by the following theorem.
Theorem 5.8. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H .
(i) For all t ∈R,
Γb(eitT ) = eitdΓb(T ).
(ii) If T ≥0, then dΓb(T ) ≥0 and, for all z ∈C+,
Γb(e−zT ) = e−zdΓb(T ).
Proof. This theorem follows from Theorems 4.15 and 1.49.
□
Theorem 5.9. Let U : H →K (a Hilbert space) be a unitary operator
and T be a densely deﬁned closable operator on H . Then,
Γb(U)dΓb(T )Γb(U)−1 = dΓb(UT U −1).
(5.38)
Proof. This follows from Theorem 4.17 and Proposition 1.54.
□
Theorem 4.13 and Corollary 4.3 immediately yield the following results
on unitary representations of a group on Fb(H ).
Theorem 5.10. Let U0 be a subgroup of U(H ) which is closed in the strong
topology. Then, the mapping Γb(·): U0 ∋U →Γb(U) ∈U(Fb(H )) gives a
faithful strongly continuous unitary representation of U0 on Fb(H ).
Corollary 5.2. Let G be a group and ρ : G →U(H ) be a unitary represen-
tation. Then, {Γb(ρ(g))|g ∈G} is a unitary representation of G on Fb(H ).
In particular, if G is a topological space and ρ is strongly continuous, then
{Γb(ρ(g))|g ∈G} is a strongly continuous unitary representation.

5.7.3
Irreducibility
In this section, we prove another important property of the operator set
{A(f), A(f)∗|f ∈H }. For this purpose, we ﬁrst introduce a concept on a
set of linear operators on a Hilbert space.
Let X be a Hilbert space and L be a set of (not necessarily bounded)
linear operators on X : L ⊂L(X ).
272
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Deﬁnition 5.2.
(i) Let M be a closed subspace of X . Then, M is said to reduce L if
each A ∈L is reduced by M . In this case, M is called a reducing
subspace of L.
Remark. Obviously, {0} and X reduce L. These spaces are called the
trivial reducing subspaces.
(ii) The set L is said to be reducible if it has a non-trivial reducing
subspace (i.e., there exists a closed subspace M ̸= {0}, X reducing L).
(iii) The set L is said to be irreducible if it is not reducible (i.e., L has
no non-trivial reducing subspaces).
Remark 5.7. In the case where L ⊂B(X ), it is easy to see that a closed
subspace M is a reducing subspace of L if and only if L leaves M and M ⊥
invariant (i.e., for all A ∈L, AM ⊂M and AM ⊥⊂M ⊥).
We ﬁrst want to show that reducibility and irreducibility are unitarily
invariant concepts.
Let X and Y be Hilbert spaces and L ⊂L(X ) and B ⊂L(Y ). The
operator set L is said to be unitarily equivalent to B if there exists a
unitary operator U : X →Y such that B = {UAU −1|A ∈L}.
It follows that L is unitarily equivalent to B if and only if B is unitarily
equivalent to L (so the above deﬁnition is well-deﬁned).
Proposition 5.10. Let L ⊂L(X ) and B ⊂L(Y ) and suppose that L is
unitarily equivalent to B. Then, L is reducible (resp., irreducible) if and
only if B is reducible (resp., irreducible).
Proof. Under the present assumption, there exists a unitary operator U :
X →Y such that B = {UAU −1|A ∈L}. Suppose that L is reducible.
Then, there exists a closed subspace M ⊂X such that M ̸= {0}, X and
each A ∈L is reduced by M . Let N := UM . Then, N is a closed subspace
of Y and N ̸= {0}, Y . Each B ∈B is written B = UAU −1, with some
A ∈L. By Proposition 1.54, B is reduced by N . Thus, B is reducible.
Conversely, if B is reducible, then, by symmetry (one needs only to
replace (X , U, A) by (Y , U −1, B) in the above argument), one can conclude
that L is reducible.
□
Boson Fock Spaces
273
To characterize the irreducibility of L, we introduce a subset of B(X ) by
L′ := {T ∈B(X ) | T A ⊂AT, A ∈L},
(5.68)
which is called the commutant of L. It is easy to see that L′ is a subspace
of B(X ).
Lemma 5.8. Let L, M ⊂L(X ) and L ⊂M. Then, M′ ⊂L′.
Proof. An easy exercise.
□
The set L is said to be ∗-invariant if each element A in L is densely
deﬁned closed and A∗∈L. In this case, A∗is densely deﬁned and A∗∗= A.
We denote by CI the set of scalar operators on X :
CI := {cI | c ∈C}.
Proposition 5.11. Let L ⊂L(X ).
(i) If L′ = CI, then L is irreducible.
(ii) Let L be ∗-invariant and irreducible. Then, L′ = CI.
Proof. (i) Let M be a reducing subspace of L and P be the orthogonal
projection onto M . Then, for each A ∈L, PA ⊂AP. Hence, P ∈L′. Hence,
under the present assumption, P = cI for some c ∈C. Since P = P ∗and
P 2 = P, it follows that c = 0, 1, i.e., P = 0 or I. This means that M = {0}
or X . Thus, L is irreducible.
(ii) Let T ∈L′. Then, for all A ∈L, T A ⊂AT . Hence, (AT )∗⊂(T A)∗.
We have (AT )∗⊃T ∗A∗and (T A)∗= A∗T ∗(by the boundedness of T ).
Hence, T ∗A∗⊂A∗T ∗. By the ∗-invariance of L, A∗∈L. Hence, taking
A∗instead of A and using the fact that (A∗)∗= A, we obtain T ∗A ⊂
AT ∗. Hence, T ∗∈L′. Therefore, the bounded self-adjoint operators S+ :=
(T +T ∗)/2 and S−:= (T −T ∗)/2i are in L′. Let E(·) be the spectral measure
of S+. Then, using Stone’s formula, E(B)A ⊂AE(B) for all Borel sets B ⊂
R and A ∈L. This means that RanE(B) reduces L. By the irreducibility of
L, RanE(B) = {0} or X . Let a = inf supp E. Then, a ∈σ(S+). Hence, for
all ε > 0, E([a, a + ε]) ̸= 0. Therefore, RanE([a, a + ε]) = X . Considering
the limit ε ↓0, we obtain RanE({a}) = X . Hence, E({a}) = I, which
implies that S+ = aI. Similarly, one can show that S−= bI, for some
b ∈R. Therefore, T = S+ + iS−= cI (c = a + ib). Thus, L′ = CI.
□
Now, we are ready to prove a basic fact about the set of the boson
creation and annihilation operators:
274
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Theorem 5.15. Let D be a dense subspace of H . Then,
{A(f), A(f)∗| f ∈D}′ = CI.
(5.69)
In particular, it is irreducible.
Proof. Let T ∈{A(f), A(f)∗| f ∈D}′. Then, for all f ∈D, T A(f)# ⊂
A(f)#T . By this relation with A(f)#
= A(f) and (5.54), we have
A(f)T ΩH = 0, f ∈D. Hence, by Proposition 5.7, there exists a number
c ∈C such that T ΩH = cΩH . The relation T A(f)∗⊂A(f)∗T (f ∈D)
implies that, for all n ∈N and f1, . . . , fn ∈D,
T A(f1)∗· · · A(fn)∗ΩH = A(f1)∗· · · A(fn)∗T ΩH
= cA(f1)∗· · · A(fn)∗ΩH .
Hence, for all Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D), T Ψ = cΨ. Since T is bounded with D(T ) =
Fb(H ) and Fb,ﬁn(D) is dense in Fb(H ), it follows that T = cI. Thus,
(5.69) holds.
□
5.7.4
Reduction of creation and annihilation operators
Let M be a closed subspace of H and PM be the orthogonal projection
onto M .
Theorem 5.16. Let f ∈M . Then, A(f)# is reduced by Fb(M ).
Proof. By Theorem 5.7(v), Q := Γb(PM ) is the orthogonal projection onto
Fb(M ). Let Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(H ). Then, A(f)∗QΨ = QA(f)∗Ψ. Since Fb,ﬁn(H )
is a core for A(f)∗, it follows from a limiting argument that QA(f)∗⊂
A(f)∗Q. Hence, Fb(M ) reduces A(f)∗. Therefore, Fb(M ) reduces A(f)
too.
□

5.9
Relations among the Creation and Annihilation
Operators and the Second Quantization Operators
So far, we have treated the second quantization operators and the creation
and annihilation operators separately. But they should have some non-
trivial relations because the creation and annihilation operators are non-
diagonal ones. This section is devoted to studies on this aspect.
5.9.1
Relative boundedness of the creation and annihilation
operators with respect to second quantization
operators
The following theorem, which is the main result in this section, plays a
basic role in the analysis on boson Fock spaces.
Theorem 5.17. Let T be a non-negative and injective self-adjoint operator
on H . Then, for all f ∈D(T −1/2),
D(dΓb(T )1/2) ⊂D(A(f)) ∩D(A(f)∗)
and, for all Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T )1/2),
∥A(f)Ψ∥≤∥T −1/2f∥∥dΓb(T )1/2Ψ∥,
(5.74)
∥A(f)∗Ψ∥2 ≤∥T −1/2f∥2 ∥dΓb(T )1/2Ψ∥2 + ∥f∥2∥Ψ∥2.
(5.75)

5.9.2
Commutation relations among dΓb(T ) and A(f)#
We next consider the commutation properties of the boson second quanti-
zation operators with the creation and annihilation operators.
Proposition 5.14. Let T be a densely deﬁned closable operator on H .
(i) For all f ∈D(T ),
Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) ⊂D([dΓb(T ), A(f)∗])
and
[dΓb(T ), A(f)∗] = A(T f)∗
on Fb,ﬁn(D(T )).
(ii) For all f ∈D(T ∗),
Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) ⊂D([dΓb(T ), A(f)])
and
[dΓb(T ), A(f)] = −A(T ∗f)
on Fb,ﬁn(D(T )).
Boson Fock Spaces
283
Proof. (i) Let Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D(T )). Then, by (5.58), each Ψ (n) with n ≥1
is a linear combination of vectors of the form A(f1)∗· · · A(fn)∗ΩH , with
fj ∈D(T ), j = 1, . . . , n. Hence, by Proposition 5.8, Ψ, A(f)∗Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T ))
(f ∈D(T )) and
dΓb(T )A(f)∗Ψ = A(T f)∗Ψ + A(f)∗dΓb(T )Ψ.
Hence, (5.14) holds.
(ii) Let f ∈D(T ∗) and Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D(T )). Then, by (5.67), we see, as in
(i), that Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T ), A(f)]) and [dΓb(T ), A(f)]Ψ = −A(T ∗f)Ψ. Thus,
the desired result follows.
□
In the case where T
is self-adjoint, non-negative and injective,
Proposition 5.14 can be reﬁned further as follows.
Theorem 5.18. Let T be a non-negative and injective self-adjoint operator
on H .
(i) For all Ψ, Φ ∈D(dΓb(T )) and f ∈D(T ) ∩D(T −1/2),
⟨dΓb(T )Ψ, A(f)Φ⟩−⟨A(f)∗Ψ, dΓb(T )Φ⟩= −⟨Ψ, A(T f)Φ⟩.
(5.88)
(ii) For each f
∈
D(T ) ∩D(T −1/2), A(f)# maps D(dΓb(T )3/2) to
D(dΓb(T )) and satisﬁes commutation relations
[dΓb(T ), A(f)∗] = A(T f)∗,
[dΓb(T ), A(f)] = −A(T f)
on D(dΓb(T )3/2).
Proof. (i) By Proposition 5.14, for all Ψ
∈Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) and Φ ∈
D(dΓb(T )), (5.88) holds. Since Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) is a core for dΓb(T ), for any
Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T )), there exists a sequence {Ψn}n ⊂Fb,ﬁn(D(T )) such that
Ψn →Ψ and dΓb(T )Ψn →dΓb(T )Ψ (n →∞). Hence,
⟨dΓb(T )Ψn, A(f)Φ⟩−⟨A(f)∗Ψn, dΓb(T )Φ⟩= −⟨Ψn, A(T f)Φ⟩.
By (5.86), A(f)∗Ψn →A(f)∗Ψ (n →∞). Hence, taking the limit n →∞
in the above equation, we obtain (5.88)
284
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(ii) Let Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T )3/2) and Φ ∈D(dΓb(T )). Then, dΓb(T )Ψ ∈
D(dΓb(T )1/2). Hence, by (i),
⟨(A(f)∗dΓb(T ) + A(T f)∗) Ψ, Φ⟩= ⟨A(f)∗Ψ, dΓb(T )Φ⟩.
This means that A(f)∗Ψ ∈D(dΓb(T )) and
dΓb(T )A(f)∗Ψ = (A(f)∗dΓb(T ) + A(T f)∗) Ψ.
Hence, the statement on A(f)∗is proved. Similarly, one can prove the state-
ment on A(f).

5.9.3
Relative boundedness of A(f)#A(g)# with respect
to dΓb(T )
Let T be a nonnegative and injective self-adjoint operator on H . As an
application of Theorem 5.18, we show that, for all f, g in a subspace of H ,

bijective, with (H + 1)−1 being bounded and ∥(H + 1)−1∥= 1. We remark
that, for each f ∈H ,

Proof. By Theorem 5.18(ii), we have
(H + 1)A(f) −A(f)(H + 1) = −A(T f)
on D(H3/2). Since D(H) ⊂D(H3/2) and A(f) is H1/2-bounded (Theorem

Lemma 5.12. Let f ∈D(T −1/2) ∩D(T ). Then, for all Ψ ∈D(H), Ψ ∈

D(T −1/2)), D(H) ⊂D(A(f)#A(g)#) and, for all Ψ ∈D(H),
∥A(f)A(g)Ψ∥≤∥T −1/2f∥∥H1/2A(g)Ψ∥≤∥T −1/2∥dT (g)∥(H + 1)Ψ∥.
Hence, (5.93) holds. As for (5.94), we proceed as follows:
∥A(f)∗A(g)Ψ∥≤∥T −1/2f∥∥H1/2A(g)Ψ∥+ ∥f∥∥A(g)Ψ∥
≤∥T −1/2f∥dT (g)∥(H + 1)Ψ∥+ ∥f∥∥T −1/2g∥∥H1/2Ψ∥.
We note that
∥H1/2Ψ∥= ∥H1/2(H + 1)−1(H + 1)Ψ∥
≤∥H1/2(H + 1)−1∥∥(H + 1)Ψ∥
= 1
2∥(H + 1)Ψ∥.
Thus, (5.94) holds. In the same way, (5.95) and (5.96) can be proved.
□
Thus, we see that A(f)#A(g)# with f, g
∈D(T −1/2) ∩D(T ) is
H-bounded.

5.10
The Segal Field Operator
Operators made from the boson creation and annihilation operators are the
main objects of analysis on the boson Fock space. Among those operators,
a simple and natural one may be A(f) + A(f)∗with f ∈H . It is obvious
that Fb,0(H ) ⊂D(A(f) + A(f)∗) and A(f) + A(f)∗is symmetric. Hence,
one can deﬁne a closed symmetric operator
ΦS(f) :=
1
√
2
(A(f) + A(f)∗),
f ∈H ,
(5.107)
where the constant 1/
√
2 is just for convenience. The operator ΦS(f) is
called the Segal ﬁeld operator with test vector f, which plays a funda-
mental role in applications to Bose ﬁeld theory. The purpose of this section
is to investigate the properties of the Segal ﬁeld operator.

dominating operator being the boson number operator Nb.
5.10.3
Irreducibility of Segal ﬁeld operators
We next consider the irreducibility of the Segal ﬁeld operators.
Theorem 5.24. For any dense subspace D of H , {ΦS(f)|f ∈D} is
irreducible.
Proof. Let T ∈{ΦS(f)|f ∈D}′. Then, for all f ∈D, T ΦS(f) ⊂ΦS(f)T .
Let Df
:= D(A(f)∗) = D(A(f)) (see Corollary 5.6). Hence, for all
Boson Fock Spaces
301
Ψ, Φ ∈Df,
⟨Ψ, T (A(f)∗+ A(f))Φ⟩= ⟨(A(f) + A(f)∗)Ψ, T Φ⟩.
Replacing f by if, one has
⟨Ψ, T (A(f)∗−A(f))Φ⟩= ⟨(A(f) −A(f)∗)Ψ, T Φ⟩.
From these two equations, one obtains
⟨Ψ, T A(f)∗Φ⟩= ⟨A(f)Ψ, T Φ⟩,
⟨Ψ, T A(f)Φ⟩= ⟨A(f)∗Ψ, T Φ⟩.
The ﬁrst equation implies that T Φ ∈D(A(f)∗) and T A(f)∗Φ = A(f)∗T Φ,
i.e., T A(f)∗⊂A(f)∗T . Similarly, the second equation implies that T A(f) ⊂
A(f)T . Hence, T ∈{A(f), A(f)∗|f ∈D}′ = CI (by Theorem 5.15), i.e.,
T = cI, for some c ∈C. Thus, {ΦS(f)|f ∈D} is irreducible.
□

We say that a linear operator A on X (i.e., A ∈L(X )) strongly
commutes with a bounded linear operator C ∈B(X ) if CA ⊂AC.
Lemma 5.14. Let A ∈L(X ) and C ∈B(X ) such that CA ⊂AC (i.e.,
A strongly commutes with C). Then:
(i) E1(A + C) = E1(A) and
exp(A + C)Ψ = (exp C)(exp A)Ψ,
Ψ ∈E1(A).
(5.131)
(ii) If A is closed, then (exp C)E1(A) ⊂E1(A) and
exp(A + C)Ψ = (exp A)(exp C)Ψ,
Ψ ∈E1(A).

5.11.1
Commutation relations
In this section, we consider a pair (A, B) of linear operators on X which
has the following property:
(AB) There exist a subspace D ⊂D(A) ∩D(B) and a bounded operator
C ∈B(X ) satisfying the following conditions:
(i) The operators A and B leave D invariant: AD
⊂D and
BD ⊂D.
(ii) [A, B] = C on D (hence CD ⊂D by (i)) and CA = AC and
CB = BC on D.
Remark 5.15. Let Dc be a dense subspace of X such that Dc ⊂D(AB) ∩
D(BA). Suppose that there exists a bijective operator Z ∈B(X ) such that
Boson Fock Spaces
309
(i) [A, B] = Z on Dc; (ii) ZDc ⊂D(A) ∩D(B) and AZ = ZA, BZ =
ZB on Dc. Then, at least one of A and B is unbounded. This proposition
can be easily proved by applying a well-known theorem in the theory of
commutation relations (see, for example, Putnam, 1967, Theorem 1.2.2).
Thus, for a pair (A, B) obeying (AB), at least one of A and B is unbounded
if D is dense and C is bijective.
Lemma 5.16. Assume (AB). Suppose that B is closed and D ⊂D(exp A).
Then, (exp A)D ⊂D(B) and, for all Ψ ∈D,
(exp A)BΨ = (B + C)(exp A)Ψ.

5.12
Exponential Operators for Segal Field Operators
Now, we come back to the boson Fock space Fb(H ). We have seen that,
for each f ∈H , ΦS(f) is self-adjoint. Hence, for all t ∈R, eitΦS(f) is a
unitary operator on Fb(H ). The unitary operator eitΦS(f) is called the
Weyl operator with f. However, for a non-zero complex number z which
is not purely imaginary, ezΦS(f) with f ̸= 0 being unbounded.
Boson Fock Spaces
313
Proposition 5.24. Let f ∈H and f ̸= 0.
(i) For all t ∈R \ {0}, etΦS(f) is an unbounded non-negative self-adjoint
operator and injective with (etΦS(f))−1 = e−tΦS(f).
(ii) For all z = a + ib ∈C with a, b ∈R, a ̸= 0, ezΦS(f) is a densely deﬁned
unbounded closed operator and (ezΦS(f))∗= ez∗ΦS(f) and injective with
(ezΦS(f))−1 = e−zΦS(f).
Proof. (i) The function R ∋λ →etλ is strictly positive and continuous.
Hence, by Corollary 1.4(ii), etΦS is a non-negative injective self-adjoint oper-
ator, with (etΦS(f))−1 = e−tΦS(f). By Proposition 5.17, ΦS(f) is neither
bounded from below nor bounded from above. Hence, by an application of
Proposition 1.46(ii), etΦS(f) is unbounded for all t ∈R \ {0}.
(ii) The function R ∋λ →ezλ is continuous and |ezλ| = eaλ > 0, λ ∈
R. Hence, by the functional calculus, ezΦS(f) is a densely deﬁned closed
operator and (ezΦS(f))∗= ez∗ΦS(f) since (ezλ)∗= ez∗λ. The injectivity of
ezΦS(f) follows from an application of Corollary 1.4(i).
Using functional calculus, we have ezΦS(f) = eibΦS(f)eaΦS(f). Hence, for
all Ψ ∈D(ezΦS(f)) = D(eaΦS), ∥ezΦS(f)Ψ∥= ∥eaΦS(f)Ψ∥. This implies that,
if ezΦS(f) is bounded, then so is eaΦS(f). But, by (i), eaΦS(f) is unbounded.
Thus, ezΦS(f) is unbounded.
□

Commutation property (5.149) for the Weyl operators eiΦS(f) and eiΦS(g)
is called the Weyl relation for ΦS(f) and ΦS(g). This implies an important
result.
Corollary 5.11 (Strong commutativity). Let f, g ∈H . Then, ΦS(f)
and ΦS(g) strongly commute if and only if Im ⟨f, g⟩= 0.
Proof. Suppose that ΦS(f) and ΦS(g) strongly commute. Then, by Propo-
sition 1.48, for all s, t ∈R, eitΦS(f)eisΦS(g) = eisΦS(g)eitΦS(f). Hence, by
(5.149), e−itsIm ⟨f,g⟩= 1, for all s, t ∈R. Hence, Im ⟨f, g⟩= 0.
Conversely, suppose that Im ⟨f, g⟩= 0. Then, Im ⟨tf, sg⟩= 0, s, t ∈
R. Using the real linearity of ΦS(f) in f
and (5.149), we obtain
Boson Fock Spaces
319
eitΦS(f)eisΦS(g) = eisΦS(g)eitΦS(f). Hence, by Proposition 1.48 again, ΦS(f)
and ΦS(g) strongly commute.

5.13
Decomposition of the Segal Field Operator
Let C be a conjugation on H , i.e., C is anti-linear mapping from H to
H satisfying (i) C2 = I and (ii) (norm preserving) ∥Cf∥= ∥f∥, f ∈H .10
Then, it is easy to see that
⟨Cf, Cg⟩= ⟨g, f⟩,
f, g ∈H
and
HC := {f ∈H | Cf = f}
becomes a real Hilbert space with the inner product induced from that
of H . Note also that each f ∈H is uniquely written as
f = f1 + if2,
with f1, f2 ∈HC (explicitly f1 = 1
2(f + Cf), f2 = 1
2i(f −Cf)). The vector
f1 (resp., f2) is called the real (resp., imaginary) part of f with respect to
C and written as f1 = Re f and f2 = Im f.
For a subspace V of H , we deﬁne VC by
VC := V ∩HC.
(5.151)
It follows that, if V is dense in H and CV ⊂V , then VC is dense in HC.
For each f ∈H , we introduce operators φF(f) and πF(f) by
φF(f) :=
1
√
2
(A(f)∗+ A(Cf)),
(5.152)
πF(f) :=
i
√
2(A(f)∗−A(Cf)).
(5.153)
Note that φF(f) and πF(f) on Fb,0(H ) are complex linear in f, but not
symmetric unless Cf = f. The operators φF(f) and πF(f) depend on the
choice of C; however, for notational simplicity, we suppress C.
10A simple example of C is given as follows: Let {en}∞
n=1 be a CONS of H . Then,
any ψ ∈H has the expansion ψ = ∞
n=1 ⟨en, ψ⟩en. One can deﬁne C : H →H by
Cψ := ∞
n=1 ⟨ψ, en⟩en. It is easy to see that C is a conjugation on H .

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
It follows from Theorem 5.14 that, for all f, g ∈H , the following com-
mutation relations hold on Fb,0(H ):
[φF(f), πF(g)] = i ⟨Cf, g⟩,
(5.154)
[φF(f), φF(g)] = 0,
[πF(f), πF(g)] = 0.
(5.155)
We call the mapping f →φF(f) the canonical ﬁeld over (H , C) and the
mapping f →πF(f) the canonical conjugate momentum over (H , C).
Remark 5.18. In applications to quantum ﬁeld theory, φF(·) and πF(·)
are used to represent a canonical pair of quantum ﬁelds at time zero (i.e.,
time-zero quantum ﬁelds)(see Chapter 10). The names for φF(·) and πF(·)
are taken from this context.
The operators φF(f) and πF(f) are written in terms of the Segal ﬁeld
operator:
φF(f) = ΦS(f),
πF(f) = ΦS(if)
(f ∈HC).
(5.156)
But note that φF(f) ̸= ΦS(f) ↾D(A(f)) ∩D(A(f)∗) ∩D(A(Cf)) if
Im f ̸= 0. Hence, for all f ∈H ,
φF(f) = ΦS(Re f) + iΦS(Im f),
(5.157)
πF(f) = ΦS(iRe f) + iΦS(iIm f)
(5.158)
on D(A(Re f)) ∩D(A(Re f)∗) ∩D(A(Im f)) ∩D(A(Im f)∗).
The Segal ﬁeld operator is recovered from φF(·) and πF(·) in the follow-
ing form: for all f ∈H ,
ΦS(f) = φF(Re f) + πF(Im f)
on Fb,0(H ). By (5.148), we have
eiΦS(f) = ei⟨Re f,Im f⟩/2eiφF(Re f)eiπF(Im f).
Proposition 5.18(i) and Theorems 5.23, 5.24 and 5.27 immediately yield
the following theorem.
Theorem 5.28.
(i) For all f ∈HC, φF(f) and πF(f) are self-adjoint and essentially
self-adjoint on Fb,0(H ), leaving Fb,0(H ) invariant.
Boson Fock Spaces
321
(ii) For all f, g ∈HC, the commutation relations
[φF(f), πF(g)] = i ⟨f, g⟩,
(5.159)
[φF(f), φF(g)] = 0,
[πF(f), πF(g)] = 0,
(5.160)
hold on Fb,0(H ).
(iii) For any dense subspace D
⊂HC, {eiφF(f), eiπF(f) | f
∈D} is
irreducible.
(iv) For any dense subspace D ⊂HC, {φF(f), πF(f)| f ∈D} is irreducible.
(v) For all f, g ∈HC,
eiφF(f+g) = eiφF(f)eiφF(g),
eiπF(f+g) = eiπF(f)eiπF(g),
eiφF(f)eiπF(g) = e−i⟨f,g⟩eiπF(g)eiφF(f),
eiφF(f)eiφF(g) = eiφF(g)eiφF(f), eiπF(f)eiπF(g) = eiπF(g)eiπF(f).
In particular, {φF(f) | f ∈HC} (resp., {πF(f) | f ∈HC}) is a family
of strongly commuting self-adjoint operators.
Commutation relations (5.159) and (5.160) may be regarded as a gener-
alization of Heisenberg CCR with ﬁnite degrees of freedom (see Remark on
Problem 5 in Chapter 3). Indeed, if dim H = n ∈N and we take a CONS
{ej}n
j=1 of HC, then the operators Qj := ℏsφF(ej) and Pj := ℏ1−sπF(ej)
(s ∈[0, 1], j = 1, . . . , n) satisfy
[Qj, Pk] = iℏδjk, [Qj, Qk] = 0, [Pj, Pk] = 0 (j, k = 1, . . . , n)
on Fb,0(H ).
We call commutation relations (5.159) and (5.160) the Heisenberg
CCR over HC to distinguish them from the CCR satisﬁed by A(·)#’s.11
In particular, if H is inﬁnite dimensional, then the Heisenberg CCR over
HC is said to be a Heisenberg CCR with inﬁnite degrees of freedom.

a unitary operator. Let A1 and A2 be closed operators on H1 and H2,

Φ ∈D2,

Ψ ∈D1.

UA1U −1 = A2
(5.166)
holds.
Proof. Equation (5.164) implies that A2 ↾D2 ⊂UA1U −1. Since UA1U −1

that A1 ⊂U −1A2U. Hence, UA1U −1 ⊂A2. Thus, (5.166) holds.

5.15
Spectrum of Segal Field Operators
We next identify the spectrum of ΦS(f).
Theorem 5.31. Let f ∈H , f ̸= 0.
(i) σ(ΦS(f)) = R.
(ii) If H is separable, then σp(ΦS(f)) = ∅.
13Another proof is given by applying the following general fact: for any densely deﬁned
closed operator A on a Hilbert space H and any unitary operator U : H →K (K is a
Hilbert space), the operator equality (UAU−1)∗= UA∗U−1 holds.
14For any closable operator A on a Hilbert space H and any unitary unitary operator
U : H →K (a Hilbert space), UAU−1 is closable and UAU−1 = U ¯
AU−1.
Boson Fock Spaces
325
Proof. Let t ∈R and take g = itf in (5.169). Then,
eiΦS(itf)ΦS(f)e−iΦS(itf) = ΦS(f) + t∥f∥2.
Since eiΦS(itf) is unitary, it follows that
σ#(ΦS(f)) = σ#(ΦS(f) + t∥f∥2) = {λ + t∥f∥2|λ ∈σ#(ΦS(f))},
where σ#(·) is either σ(·) or σp(·).
(i) By the self-adjointness of ΦS(f), σ(ΦS(f)) ̸= ∅. Hence, there exists
a λ0 ∈σ(ΦS(f)). Therefore, σ(ΦS(F)) ⊃∪t∈R{λ0 + t∥f∥2} = R. Thus, the
desired result follows.
(ii) Suppose that σp(ΦS(f)) ̸= ∅and λ ∈σp(ΦS(f)). Then, for all t ∈R,
λ + t∥f∥2 ∈σp(ΦS(f)). Hence, σp(ΦS(f)) is an uncountable set. If H
is separable, then Fb(H ) is separable. In general, the cardinality of the
point spectrum of a closed Hermitian operator on a separable Hilbert space
is at most countable.15 Hence, we are led to a contradiction. Thus, σp
(ΦS(f)) = ∅.
□
5.16
Transformation Laws of Creation and Annihilation
Operators with Respect to Γ-Operators
Let H and K be Hilbert spaces. Let U : H →K be unitary. Then, the
boson Γ-operator Γb(U) : Fb(H ) →Fb(K ) is unitary (Theorem 5.7(ii)).
For deﬁniteness, we write the annihilation operator A(·) on Fb(H )
as AH (·).
Theorem 5.32. For all f ∈H , the following operator equalities hold:
Γb(U)AH (f)Γb(U)−1 = AK (Uf),
(5.171)
Γb(U)AH (f)∗Γb(U)−1 = AK (Uf)∗.
(5.172)
In particular,
Γb(U)ΦS,H (f)Γb(U)−1 = ΦS,K (Uf),
(5.173)
where ΦS,H (·) is the Segal ﬁeld operator on Fb(H ).
15This can be proved as follows. Let X be a separable inﬁnite-dimensional Hilbert space
and H be a closed Hermitian operator on X . Suppose that H had an uncountable set
{λα}α∈Λ ⊂R (λα ̸= λβ for α ̸= β) of eigenvalues, where Λ is an uncountable index
set. Then, ⊕α∈Λ ker(H −λα) ⊂X is a non-separable Hilbert space. But this is a
contradiction because a separable Hilbert space includes no non-separable Hilbert space.
Hence, the cardinality of σp(H) is at most countable.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Proof. For all Ψ ∈Fb,0(H ), f ∈H and n ∈N,

Fb,0(H ) is a core for AH (·)∗, an application of Lemma 5.20 gives (5.172).
Taking the adjoint of (5.172), we obtain (5.171).

Corollary 5.12.

□
Formulae (5.174)–(5.176) show that the correspondences: A(f)# →
−A(f)# and ΦS(f) →−ΦS(f) are unitarily implementable. These facts
play important roles in applications to quantum ﬁeld theory.
5.17
Time Development of Segal Field Operators
and Field Equations
In general, for a self-adjoint operator H on a Hilbert space X and a linear
operator A on X , the operator
AH(t) := eitH/ℏAe−itH/ℏ
(t ∈R)
(5.177)
is called the Heisenberg operator of A with respect to H. In the context
of quantum physics where H denotes a quantum Hamiltonian, A is a phys-
ical quantity and t denotes time, AH(t) is interpreted as the operator
describing the time development of A. This way of looking at the time
development of a quantum system is called the Heisenberg picture. On
Boson Fock Spaces
327
the other hand, there is another picture, called the Schr¨odinger picture,
in which the time development of a quantum system is grasped as that of
state vectors in such a way that, if Ψ ∈X is an initial state vector (i.e., a
state vector at t = 0), then the state vector at time t is given by e−itH/ℏΨ.
Let T be a self-adjoint operator on H . Then, as we have seen, the
boson second quantization dΓb(T ) of T is self-adjoint. In applications
to quantum ﬁeld theory, if T denotes the Hamiltonian of a boson, then
dΓb(T ) represents the Hamiltonian of a free Bose ﬁeld whose quanta con-
sist of non-interacting identical bosons. In that case, the unitary operator
e−itdΓb(T )/ℏdescribes the time development of state vectors of the sys-
tem under consideration. It is also important to consider the Heisenberg
operator eitdΓb(T )/ℏAe−itdΓb(T )/ℏof a linear operator A on Fb(H ) with
respect to dΓb(T ).
Let us consider the case A = ΦS(f) with f ∈H . Then, the time
development of the Segal ﬁeld operator ΦS(f) with respect to dΓb(T ) is
given by
ΦS(t, f) := eitdΓb(T )ΦS(f)e−itdΓb(T ),
where, for notational simplicity, we replace t/ℏby t.
The purpose of this section is to study the strong diﬀerentiability of
ΦS(t, f) in t and to ﬁnd the diﬀerential equations it obeys.
Lemma 5.21. For all t ∈R and f ∈H , the operator equalities
eitdΓb(T )A(f)#e−itdΓb(T ) = A(eitT f)#,
(5.178)
ΦS(t, f) = ΦS(eitT f)
(5.179)
hold.
Proof. We need only to apply Theorem 5.32 to U
= eitT and use
Theorem 5.8(i).

t of the operator ΦS(eitT f) for the purpose mentioned above.

5.18
Abstract Free Bose Fields
In this section, we construct an abstract quantum ﬁeld model. Let HC
be as in Section 5.13 and T be an injective and non-negative self-adjoint
operator on H such that CT ⊂T C (i.e., for all f ∈D(T ), Cf ∈D(T ) and
T Cf = CT f, in particular, T (D(T ) ∩HC) ⊂HC). Then, it is easy to see
that CT C = T . Hence, using Stone’s formula, we obtain
ET (·) = CET (·)C.
Therefore, it follows that, for all Borel measurable functions G : R →C,
G(T ) = CG∗(T )C. In particular, for all real-valued Borel measurable func-
tions F, F(T ) = CF(T )C. Hence, for all f ∈D(F(T )), Cf ∈D(F(T )) and
F(T )Cf = CF(T )f. Hence,
F(T )(D(F(T )) ∩HC) ⊂HC.

f ∈D(T a) ∩HC), T af ∈HC.

5.20
Coherent Vectors
5.20.1
Deﬁnition and basic properties
By Lemma 5.18(i), for all f ∈H , the Fock vacuum ΩH is an entire analytic

It is obvious that exp 0 = ΩH . If f ̸= 0, then exp f ̸= ΩH . A coherent
vector exp f is said to be non-trivial if f ̸= 0.
Remark 5.21. In the context of quantum ﬁeld theory, a coherent vector
multiplied by a non-zero complex number is called a coherent state. A
non-trivial coherent state is a quantum state whose n-particle component
(n ∈Z+) is of the form αA(f)∗nΩH /n! ̸= 0, with f ∈H \ {0} and a
complex number α ̸= 0.

5.22
The Boson Fock Space over a Direct Sum
Hilbert Space
Let H and K be Hilbert spaces. Then, it is natural to consider the boson
Fock space Fb(H ⊕K ) over the direct sum Hilbert space
H ⊕K := {(f, g)|f ∈H , g ∈K }.
This boson Fock space is important not only purely theoretically but also
in applications.
We denote the annihilation operator on Fb(H ) by AH (·).

We call the isomorphism U in Theorem 5.40 the natural isomorphism

Example 5.6. We give an important example of the natural isomorphism
established above, which is useful in applications to quantum ﬁeld theory.
We consider the boson Fock space Fb(L2(Rd)) over L2(Rd) (d ∈N). Let σ
and κ be constants satisfying 0 ≤σ < κ and A := {p ∈Rd | σ ≤|p| ≤κ}.
Then, each element f ∈L2(Rd) has a unique orthogonal decomposition
f = f1 + f2 with f1 ∈L2(A) and f2 ∈L2(Ac) (explicitly, f1 = χAf, f2 =
χAcf). Hence,
L2(Rd) = L2(A) ⊕L2(Ac).
Therefore, by Theorem 5.40,
Fb(L2(Rd)) ∼= Fb(L2(A)) ⊗Fb(L2(Ac)).
(5.221)
Remark 5.22. As is easily seen, isomorphism (5.221) holds for any Borel
set A ∈Bd.

Example 5.7. In Example 5.6, let F : Rd →R be a Borel measurable

5.23
Representations of CCR
In this section, we study some representation theoretical aspects underlying
boson Fock spaces.
5.24
Representation of CCR over a Vector Space
As we have seen in Section 5.7, the boson creation and annihilation
operators A(·)# on the boson Fock space Fb(H ) obey CCR, a set of
characteristic commutation relations, and the Fock vacuum ΩH is a cyclic
vector, for {A(f)∗|f ∈D}, with D being a dense subspace of H (Propo-
sition 5.9). Moreover, various operators on the boson Fock space Fb(H )
can be made from A(·)#’s. One of them is the Segal ﬁeld operator ΦS(f)
(f ∈H ), which is a simple linear combination of the creation operator
A(f)∗and the annihilation one A(f), and it has interesting properties.
Boson Fock Spaces
347
Noting these aspects and taking an algebraic point of view, one may
regard the boson Fock space Fb(H ) as a Hilbert space, in which algebraic
objects obeying CCR are realized as A(f)#’s (f ∈H ).
This point of view leads one to introduce a representation theoretical
concept of CCR.
Deﬁnition 5.3. Let F be a Hilbert space and D be a dense subspace in F.
Let V be a dense subspace of a Hilbert space H and C : V →L(F); V ∋
f →C(f) ∈L(F) such that, for all f ∈V , C(f) is densely deﬁned
and closed. The triplet (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) (or (F, D, {C(f), C(f)∗|f ∈
V })) is called a representation of the CCR over V if it has the following
properties:
(C.1) For all f ∈V , D ⊂D(C(f)) ∩D(C(f)∗) and C(f)D ⊂D, C(f)∗
D ⊂D.
(C.2) (anti-linearity in test vectors) For all f, g ∈V and α, β ∈C, C(αf +
βg) = α∗C(f) + β∗C(g) on D.
(C.3) (CCR) For all f, g ∈V ,
[C(f), C(g)∗] = ⟨f, g⟩H ,
(5.225)
[C(f), C(g)] = 0,
[C(f)∗, C(g)∗] = 0
(5.226)
on D.
The Hilbert space F is called the representation space of the present
representation of the CCR over V .
If {C(f), C(f)∗| f ∈V } is irreducible (resp., reducible), then the
representation (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) is said to be irreducible (resp.,
reducible).
Remark 5.23. Property (C.2) implies the linearity of C(f)∗in f: for all
f, g ∈V and α, β ∈C, C(αf + βg)∗= αC(f)∗+ βC(g)∗on D.
Remark 5.24. The subspace D is not necessarily unique.
Remark 5.25. By Remark 5.15, (5.225) with g = f implies that, for f ̸= 0,
at least one of C(f) and C(f)∗is unbounded. Hence, by Proposition 1.10,
both C(f) and C(f)∗are unbounded.

Example 5.9. The triplet
ρF(V ) := (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ), {A(f)|f ∈V })
is an irreducible representation of the CCR over V (the irreducibility is due
to Theorem 5.15). This representation is called the Fock representation
of the CCR over V .
Example 5.10. Let L : V →C be a linear functional and
CL(f) := A(f) + L(f)∗.
Then, (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ), {CL(f)|f ∈V }) is an irreducible representation
of the CCR over V .
Example 5.11. Let W : H →H be an isometry (i.e., W is linear and
∥Wf∥= ∥f∥, f ∈H ) such that WV ⊂V and
CW (f) := A(Wf).
Then, (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ), {CW (f)|f ∈V }) is a representation of the CCR
over V . With regard to the irreducibility of this representation, see Prob-
lem 10.
Example 5.12. Let (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) be a representation of the
CCR over V and U : F →F ′ (F ′ is a Hilbert space) be a unitary
operator. Then, (F ′, UD, {UC(f)U −1 | f ∈V }) is a representation of the
CCR over V .
As suggested by Examples 5.10 and 5.11, there are inﬁnitely many
representations of the CCR over V , which are not necessarily of the type
as described in Example 5.12. Thus, we are led toward a concept to classify
the representations of CCR, as follows.
Deﬁnition 5.4. Let (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) and (F ′, D′, {C′(f)|f ∈V })
be two representations of the CCR over V . They are said to be equivalent
if there exists a unitary operator U : F →F ′ such that, for all f ∈V ,
C′(f) = UC(f)U −1 (operator equality). In that case, we often say simply
that {C(f)|f ∈V } is equivalent to {C′(f)|f ∈V }.
Remark 5.26. The operator equality C′(f) = UC(f)U −1 implies that
C′(f)∗= UC(f)∗U −1.
Boson Fock Spaces
349
Remark 5.27. Suppose that ρ := (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) is equivalent to
ρ′ := (F ′, D′, {C′(f)|f ∈V }). Then, by Proposition 5.10, ρ is reducible
(resp., irreducible) if and only if ρ′ is reducible (resp., irreducible). Hence,
if ρ is reducible and ρ′ is irreducible, then ρ is inequivalent to ρ′. But this
type of inequivalence is a trivial inequivalence. Non-trivial inequivalences
may occur among irreducible representations.
Example 5.13. Let us consider the representation (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ),
{CW (f)|f ∈V }) in Example 5.11. Suppose that W is unitary. Then, UW :=
Γb(W) is a unitary operator on Fb(H ) and, by Theorem 5.32,
UW A(f)U −1

f ∈V .
Hence, (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ), {CW (f)|f ∈V }) is equivalent to the Fock rep-

5.25
Second Quantization Associated with
a Representation of CCR
As we have seen in Proposition 5.14 and Theorem 5.18, the operators
dΓb(T ) and A(f)# (f ∈D(T ) ∩D(T ∗)) obey characteristic commutation
relations. It is natural to consider an abstract form of them so that
{dΓb(T ), A(f), A(f)∗|f ∈D(T ) ∩D(T ∗)} may be regarded as a concrete
realization of a set of abstract commutation relations.
Deﬁnition 5.6. Let (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) be a representation of the CCR
over V ⊂H and T be a densely deﬁned closed operator on H . A densely
deﬁned closed operator H on F is called a second quantization operator
352

(or simply a second quantization) of T associated with (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈
V }) if there exists a dense subspace D0 ⊂D such that
[H, C(f)] = −C(T ∗f),

[H, C(f)∗] = C(T f)∗,
f ∈D(T ) ∩D(T ∗)
(5.228)
on D0.18
Remark 5.28. It is obvious that, if H is a second quantization of T
associated with (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }), then so is H +L, for all linear oper-
ators L on F, such that H +L is a densely deﬁned closed operator and, for
all f ∈V and Ψ ∈D0, [L, C(f)#]Ψ = 0. In particular, for all constants c,
H + c is a second quantization of T associated with (F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }).
The operator H, up to constant additions, is not necessarily unique (i.e.,
there may be an operator L which satisﬁes the above property and is not
a constant operator).

5.26
Bosonic Diagonalization
In relation to second quantizations associated with the representations of
CCR, we introduce the following notion.
Deﬁnition 5.7. A self-adjoint operator H on a Hilbert space F is said
to be bosonically diagonalizable if H is unitarily equivalent to a boson
second quantization up to a constant addition, i.e., if there exist a self-
adjoint operator T on a Hilbert space H , a real constant E0 and a unitary
transformation U from F to the boson Fock space Fb(H ) such that
UHU −1 = dΓb(T ) + E0.
(5.230)
As seen from (5.230), the analysis of a bosonically diagonalizable oper-
ator can be reduced to that of a boson second quantization operator. For
example, with regard to the spectra of a bosonically diagonalizable opera-
tor H satisfying (5.230), we have σ(H) = σ(dΓb(T )) + E0 and σ#(H) =
σ#(dΓb(T )) + E0 (# =c, d, ess, p).19 Moreover, by the unitary covariance of
functional calculus, for all Borel measurable functions f on R, Uf(H)U −1 =
f(dΓb(T ) + E0). In particular, eitH = U −1eitdΓb(T )UeitE0, ∀t ∈R.
19For a subset D of R and a real constant a, D + a := {x + a|x ∈D} ⊂R.
356
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
The following theorem is concerned with the bosonic diagonalization of
a second quantization associated with a representation of CCR.

holds, i.e., H is bosonically diagonalizable.
Proof. By (5.231) and (5.54), we have C(f)Ω = 0, f ∈VT . Hence,

5.27
Representation of Heisenberg CCR
The set of operators {φF(f), πF(f) |, f ∈HC} introduced in Section 5.13
suggests a general concept of representations of the Heisenberg CCR over
a real inner product space.
Deﬁnition 5.8. Let K be a real Hilbert space and W be a dense subspace
of K . Let F be a Hilbert space and D be a dense subspace of F. Sup-
pose that, for each f ∈W , there exist symmetric operators φ(f) and π(f)
satisfying the following conditions:
(i) D ⊂∩f∈W D(φ(f)) ∩D(π(f)) and φ(f)D ⊂D, π(f)D ⊂D, f ∈W .
(ii) For all f, g ∈W and a, b ∈R, φ(af + bg) = aφ(f) + bφ(g) and π(af +
bg) = aπ(f) + bπ(g) on D.
(iii) For all f, g ∈W ,
[φ(f), π(g)] = i ⟨f, g⟩,
[φ(f), φ(g)] = 0,
[π(f), π(g)] = 0
on D.
Then, (F, D, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) is called a representation of the
Heisenberg CCR over W .
Two representations (F, D, {φ(f), π(f) | f
∈
W }) and (F ′, D′,
{φ′(f), π′(f) | f ∈W }) of the Heisenberg CCR over W are said to be
equivalent if there exists a unitary operator U : F →F ′ such that,
for all f ∈W , Uφ(f)U −1 = φ′(f) and Uπ(f)U −1 = π′(f).
The representation (F, D, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) is said to be irre-
ducible (resp., reducible) if {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W } is irreducible (resp.,
reducible).
Remark 5.29. In this deﬁnition, the self-adjointness of φ(f) and π(f) are
not required and the subspace D is not necessarily unique.
Remark 5.30. By Remark 5.15 and Deﬁnition 5.8(iii), if f ̸= 0, then at
least one of φ(f) and π(f) is unbounded.
358
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Remark 5.31. Remark 5.27 also applies to the representations of the
Heisenberg CCR.
Example 5.18. Let φF(f) and πF(f) (f ∈HC) be deﬁned by (5.156)
and W be any dense subspace of H such that CW ⊂W . Then, by Theo-
rem 5.28(iv), (Fb(H ), Fb,0(H ), {φF(f), πF(f) | f ∈WC}) is an irreducible
representation of the Heisenberg CCR over WC. This representation is called
the Fock representation of the Heisenberg CCR over WC.
The following proposition shows that a representation of the CCR over
a complex inner product space with an additional condition yields a repre-
sentation of the Heisenberg CCR over a real inner product space.
Proposition 5.26. Let H be a complex Hilbert space and V be a dense
subspace of H . Let J be a conjugation on H such that JV ⊂V . Sup-
pose that there exists a representation (F, D, {C(f) | f ∈V }) of the CCR

To consider the converse of Proposition 5.26, we recall a basic concept
in Hilbert space theory. Let K be a real Hilbert space with inner product
⟨, ⟩K . Then, the product space K × K := {(f, g) | f, g ∈K } becomes a
complex vector space with the following operation of addition and scalar
Boson Fock Spaces
359
multiplication: for all (f, g), (f ′, g′) ∈K ×K and α = a+ib ∈C (a, b ∈R),
(f, g) + (f ′, g′) := (f + g, f ′ + g′),
α(f, g) := (af −bg, ag + bf).
This complex vector space is called the complexiﬁcation of K
and
denoted by KC.
Note that ψ := (f, g) = (f, 0) + i(g, 0) (f, g ∈K ). Hence, identifying
(f, 0) with f, we have ψ = f + ig. The vector f (resp., g) is called the real
(resp., imaginary) part of ψ and written as f = Re ψ (resp., g = Im ψ).
A natural inner product is introduced in KC by
⟨f + ig, f ′ + ig′⟩KC := ⟨f, f ′⟩K + ⟨g, g′⟩K −i ⟨g, f ′⟩K + i ⟨f, g′⟩K
(f, f ′, g, g′ ∈K ). Then, the inner product space (KC, ⟨, ⟩KC) becomes a
complex Hilbert space. This Hilbert space is called the complexiﬁcation of
the real Hilbert space K and denoted by the same symbol KC for simplicity.
Henceforth, the subscript KC in ⟨, ⟩KC is omitted, provided that there
would be no danger of confusion.
We deﬁne a mapping CK : KC →KC by
CK (f + ig) := f −ig,
f, g ∈K .
Then, it is easy to see that CK is a conjugation. This conjugation is called
the complex conjugation on KC. It immediately follows that
K = (KC)CK .
Example 5.20. Let H be a complex Hilbert space and C be a conjugation
on H . Then, (HC)C ∼= H .

Propositions 5.26 and 5.27 show that considering a representation of the

to considering a representation of the CCR over WC.
Remark 5.32. Noting commutation relation (5.234), one can deﬁne a
generalized concept of the representation of a Heisenberg CCR in the
following alternative manner. Let X be a complex Hilbert space and Y be
a dense subspace of X . Let ω be a mapping from Y × Y to R, satisfying
the following (i)–(iii):
(i) (real bi-linearity) For all f, g, h ∈Y and a, b ∈R,
ω(af + bg, h) = a ω(f, h) + b ω(g, h),
ω(h, af + bg) = a ω(h, f) + b ω(h, g).
(ii) (anti-symmetry) For all f, g ∈Y , ω(f, g) = −ω(g, f).
(iii) (non-degeneracy) {f ∈Y |ω(f, g) = 0, g ∈Y } = {0}.
The mapping ω is called a real symplectic form on Y .
Suppose that a set {Φ(f)|f ∈Y } of symmetric (not necessarily self-
adjoint) operators on a Hilbert space F is given and D is a dense sub-
space of F left invariant by each Φ(f), f ∈Y . Then, the quadruple
(F, D, {Φ(f)|f ∈Y }, ω) is called a representation of the generalized
Heisenberg CCR over (Y , ω) if, for all f, g ∈Y and a, b ∈R,
Φ(af + bg) = a Φ(f) + b Φ(g)
on D and
[Φ(f), Φ(g)]Ψ = iω(f, g)Ψ.
(5.235)
Boson Fock Spaces
361
Example 5.21.
(i) ω(f, g) = Im ⟨f, g⟩X , f, g ∈Y .
(ii) ω(f, g) = Im ⟨f, T g⟩X , f, g ∈Y , where T ∈B(X ) is any injective
self-adjoint operator.
5.28
Weyl Representations of CCR
5.28.1
Deﬁnition and remarks
The representations of CCR and Heisenberg CCR considered so far
are unbounded in the sense that operators realizing them are unbounded
(see Remark 5.25). However, with regard to Heisenberg CCR, there is a
scheme to translate them into commutation relations of unitary operators
which are heuristically (informally) equivalent but, in reality, not necessar-
ily equivalent.20
Deﬁnition 5.9. Let K be a real Hilbert space, W be a dense subspace
of K
and F be a complex Hilbert space. Suppose that, for each f ∈
W , two self-adjoint operators φ(f) and π(f) on F are deﬁned. The pair
(F, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) is called a Weyl representation of the CCR
over W on F if the following (i) and (ii) hold:
(i) For all f, g ∈W and t ∈R,
φ(tf) = tφ(f),
π(tf) = tπ(f),
φ(f) + φ(g) ⊂φ(f + g),
π(f) + π(g) ⊂π(f + g).
(ii) (Weyl relations over W ) For all f, g ∈W and t ∈R
eiφ(f)eiπ(g) = e−i⟨f,g⟩eiπ(g)eiφ(f),
(5.236)
eiφ(f)eiφ(g) = eiφ(g)eiφ(f),
(5.237)
eiπ(f)eiπ(g) = eiπ(g)eiπ(f).
(5.238)
The Weyl representation (F, {φ(f), π(f) | f
∈W }) is said to be
irreducible (resp., reducible) if {eiφ(f), eiπ(f) | f ∈W } is irreducible
(resp., reducible).
20For a heuristic argument, see, for example, Putnam (1967), Section 4.2, where the case
of the Heisenberg CCR with one degree of freedom is discussed.
362
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Two Weyl representations (F, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) and (F ′, {φ′(f),
π′(f) | f ∈W }) are said to be equivalent if there exists a unitary operator
U : F →F ′ such that, for all f ∈W , Uφ(f)U −1 = φ′(f) and Uπ(f)U −1 =
π′(f).
If dim W = ∞, then (F, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) is said to be a Weyl
representation with inﬁnite degrees of freedom.
Remark 5.33. Relations (5.237) and (5.238) imply that {φ(f) | f ∈W }
(resp., {π(f) | f ∈W }) is a family of strongly commuting self-adjoint oper-
ators on F. Hence, for all f, g, φ(f) + φ(g) is essentially self-adjoint and
φ(f +g) = φ(f) + φ(g). Similarly, we have π(f +g) = π(f) + π(g). It follows
that
eiφ(f+g) = eiφ(f)eiφ(g),
eiπ(f+g) = eiπ(f)eiπ(g).
Remark 5.34. Remark 5.27 also applies to the Weyl representations of
CCR.
Remark 5.35. Deﬁnition 5.9 includes, as a special case, the concept of
Weyl representation of the CCR with N degrees of freedom (N ∈N), which
is deﬁned as follows. Let Qn and Pn (n = 1, . . . , N) be self-adjoint operators
on a Hilbert space F. Then, (F, {Qn, Pn | n = 1, . . . , N}) is called a Weyl
representation of the CCR with N degrees of freedom if it satisﬁes the
following relations (the Weyl relations with N degrees of freedom): for all
s, t ∈R and n, m = 1, . . . , N,
eitQneisPm = e−iδnmtseisPmeitQn,
(5.239)
eitQneisQm = eisQmeitQn,
eitPneisPm = eitPmeisPn.
(5.240)
Indeed, if one takes an ONS {en}N
n=1 with en ∈W in Deﬁnition 5.9 and
deﬁnes Qn := φ(en) and Pn := π(en) (n ∈N), then these operators obey
(5.239) and (5.240).
It is shown that a Weyl representation (F, {Qn, Pn | n = 1, . . . , N})
is a representation of the Heisenberg CCR with N degrees of freedom
(Problem 5 in Chapter 3). For a proof of this fact, see Proposition 5.28
and Theorem 5.48. But the converse is not true. Namely, a representation
of the Heisenberg CCR with ﬁnite degrees of freedom is not necessarily a
Weyl representation. We have seen this in Problem 21 in Chapter 1.
Remark 5.36. As is well known, any irreducible Weyl representation
(F, {Qn, Pn|n = 1, . . . , N}) with N degrees of freedom on a separable
Boson Fock Spaces
363
Hilbert space F is equivalent to the Schr¨odinger representation
π(N)
S
:= (L2(RN), C∞
0 (RN), {qn, pn|n = 1, . . . , N})
of the Heisenberg CCR with N
degrees of freedom, where qn
is
the multiplication operator by the nth coordinate function xn(x
=
(x1, . . . , xN) ∈RN) and
pn := −iDxn,
with Dxn being the generalized partial diﬀerential operator in the variable
xn acting in L2(RN). Namely, there exists a unitary operator U : F →
L2(RN) such that, for all n = 1, . . . , N and t ∈R, UeitQnU −1 = eitqn
and UeitPnU −1 = eitpn, which are equivalent to that, for n = 1, . . . , N,
UQnU −1 = qn and UPnU −1 = pn This is the celebrated von Neumann
uniqueness theorem on the representation of CCRs (von Neumann, 1931)
(cf. also, for example, Putnam, 1967, Sections 4.3 and 4.11; Arai, 2006b,
Chapter 3). It should be noted, however, that, as for the non-Weyl rep-
resentations of Heisenberg CCRs, the uniqueness theorem does not hold
even if the degrees of freedom are ﬁnite. We want to emphasize this aspect
since there are textbooks and literature with the misunderstanding that, for
each N ∈N, every irreducible representation of the Heisenberg CCR with
N degrees of freedom is equivalent to the Schr¨odinger representation π(N)
S
.
Indeed, there is an example, (H , D, {q, p}), of irreducible representations
of the Heisenberg CCR with one degree of freedom in which both q and
p are unbounded self-adjoint operators and which is inequivalent to π(1)
S
(Fuglede, 1967). Physically interesting examples of irreducible representa-
tions of CCRs with two degrees of freedom inequivalent to the Schr¨odinger
representation π(2)
S
appear in gauge quantum mechanics in connection with
the so-called Aharonov–Bohm eﬀect (see Arai, 1998 and references therein).
Remark 5.37. In contrast to the case of Weyl representations with ﬁnite
degrees of freedom, for Weyl representations with inﬁnite degrees of free-
dom, a uniqueness theorem similar to the von Neumann uniqueness theorem
mentioned above does not hold any more. We shall see this in Section 5.29.

5.28.3
General properties
We now turn to the general aspects of the Weyl representations of CCR.
We ﬁrst prove two lemmas, which are important in themselves.
Lemma 5.24. Let H be a self-adjoint operator and T be a closed operator
on a Hilbert space satisfying the operator equality
eitHT e−itH = T + ct,
t ∈R,
(5.242)
where c ∈C is a constant. Then:
(i) D(H) ∩D(HT ) ⊂D(T H) and
[T, H]Ψ = icΨ,
Ψ ∈D(H) ∩D(HT )
(5.243)
(ii) (spectrum of T ) If T is self-adjoint and c ̸= 0, then σ(T ) = R.
Proof. (i) Let Ψ ∈D(H) ∩D(HT ). Then, we have, for all t ∈R,
T e−itHΨ = e−itHT Ψ + cte−itHΨ.
Since Ψ is in D(H) ∩D(HT ), the right-hand side is strongly diﬀerentiable
in t, and its strong derivative is −ie−itHHT Ψ + ce−itHΨ −icte−itHHΨ.
Hence, the left-hand side is strongly diﬀerentiable in t. This fact and the
closedness of T imply that −ie−itHHΨ ∈D(T ) and d(T e−itHΨ)/dt =
−iT e−itHHΨ. Therefore, taking t = 0, we see that Ψ ∈D(T H) and (5.243)
holds.
(ii) Let T be self-adjoint. Then, it is easy to see that c ∈R \ {0}.
By the unitary invariance of the spectrum of a linear operator, we have
σ(T ) = σ(T + ct) = {λ + ct|λ ∈σ(T )} for all t ∈R. Since σ(T ) ̸= ∅, there
is a λ0 ∈σ(T ). Hence, for all t ∈R, λ0 + ct ∈σ(T ). Therefore, σ(T ) = R.
□
Remark 5.39. If H represents a quantum Hamiltonian, then a (closed)
symmetric operator T satisfying (5.242) with c = 1 is called a strong
time operator with respect to H (Arai, 2005).21
Remark 5.40. Concerning the spectrum of H, one has the following fact:
if H is self-adjoint and T is a symmetric operator satisfying (5.242) with
c ̸= 0, then H is absolutely continuous.22 For a proof of this fact, see Arai
(2005), Theorem 6.7, and Schm¨udgen (1983a), Corollary 2.
21For the physical aspects of the time operator, see, for example, Muga et al. (2008) and
Muga et al. (2009).
22For the deﬁnition of absolute continuity of a self-adjoint operator, see Appendix C.
366

Lemma 5.25. Let Q and P be self-adjoint operators on a Hilbert space
obeying the Weyl relation
eisQeitP = e−icsteitP eisQ,
s, t ∈R,
where c ∈R \ {0} is a constant. Then,
eitP Qe−itP = Q + ct,
t ∈R.
In particular,
[Q, P] = ic on D(QP) ∩D(PQ).
Moreover,
σ(P) = σ(Q) = R.
(5.244)
Proof. The Weyl relation is equivalent to
eitP eisQe−itP = eicsteisQ,
s, t ∈R.
By the unitary covariance of functional calculus, we have
eis(eitP Qe−itP ) = eis(Q+ct).
Hence, eitP Qe−itP = Q + ct, t ∈R. Hence, the commutation relation of
Q and P follows from an application of Lemma 5.24(i). An application of
Lemma 5.24(ii) yields that σ(Q) = R. Exchanging the role of Q and P, one
has σ(P) = R.
□
Remark 5.41. Suppose that the assumption of Lemma 5.25 holds. Then,
by symmetry between Q and P, we have eitQPe−itQ = P −ct for all
t ∈R. Hence, by Remark 5.40, Q and P are absolutely continuous with
σ(Q) = σac(Q) = R and σ(P) = σac(P) = R. Thus, we see that the Weyl
relations are so strong that they determine the spectral properties of the
operators involved.
In view of Lemma 5.25, relation (5.242) is called the weak Weyl rela-
tion for (H, T ).
Lemma 5.25 immediately yields the following proposition.
Proposition 5.28. Let (F, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) be a Weyl representation
of the CCR over W on a Hilbert space F. Then, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W } obeys
the Heisenberg CCR over W in the following sense:
[φ(f), π(g)] = i ⟨f, g⟩
on D([φ(f), π(g)]) ,
(5.245)
[φ(f), φ(g)] = 0
on D([φ(f), φ(g)]),
(5.246)
[π(f), π(g)] = 0
on D([π(f), π(g)]).
(5.247)

Theorem 5.48. Let (F, {φ(f), π(f) | f ∈W }) be a Weyl representation of

by eiφ(fj), eiπ(gj), φ(fj) and π(gj) (j = 1, . . . , n) and, for j, k = 1, . . . , n,
[φ(fj), π(gk)] = i ⟨fj, gk⟩,
[φ(fj), φ(fk)] = 0,
[π(gj), π(gk)] = 0
on DFn.
(ii) For all f ∈WC, the operator Φ(f) deﬁned by (5.233) is essentially
self-adjoint and
eiΦ(f) = ei⟨Re f,Im f⟩/2eiφ(Re f)eiπ(Im f).
(5.250)
Moreover,
eiΦ(f+g) = eiIm ⟨f,g⟩/2eiΦ(f)eiΦ(g), f, g ∈WC.
(5.251)
Proof. (i) As a natural generalization of the subspace D0 in Lemma 5.26,

(ii) By (5.236), we can apply Lemma 5.26 to the case where A = φ(Re f)

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(5.250) and using the strong commutativity of {φ(Re f), φ(Re g)} (resp.,

Remark
5.44. It is not so diﬃcult to show that (5.251) implies
(5.236)–(5.238). Hence, (5.236)–(5.238) are equivalent to (5.251). From
this point view, one can generalize the concept of Weyl representation
of CCR. Let X be a Hilbert space and Y be a dense subspace of X .
Let {Φ(f) | f ∈Y } be a set of self-adjoint operators on a Hilbert space
F and ω be a real symplectic form on Y
(see Remark 5.32). Then,
(F, {Φ(f) | f ∈Y }, ω) is called a Weyl representation of the gen-
eralized CCR over (Y , ω) if
eiΦ(f+g) = eiω(f,g)/2eiΦ(f)eiΦ(g),
f, g ∈Y .
5.29
A Class of Representations of CCR
In this section, we construct a class of representations of CCR from the Fock
representation of CCR. To understand the idea behind the construction, we
ﬁrst recall a geometric concept.
5.29.1
Symplectic group on a Hilbert space
Let H be a Hilbert space with conjugation C (see Section 5.13). As a
natural generalization of the standard symplectic form on R2n (n ∈N), we
can deﬁne a mapping ω : (H ⊕H ) × (H ⊕H ) →C by
ω((f, g), (f ′, g′)) := ⟨Cf, g′⟩−⟨Cg, f ′⟩, (f, g), (f ′, g′) ∈H ⊕H .
The following properties of ω are easily proved:
(i) (complex bi-linearity) For all ψ, φ, χ ∈H ⊕H and α, β ∈C,
ω(α ψ + β φ, χ) = α ω(ψ, h) + β ω(φ, χ),
ω(χ, α ψ + β φ) = α ω(χ, ψ) + β ω(χ, φ).
(ii) (anti-symmetry) ω(ψ, φ) = −ω(φ, ψ), ψ, φ ∈H ⊕H .
Boson Fock Spaces
371
(iii) (conjugation covariance) For all ψ, φ
∈
H ⊕H , ω(ψ, φ)∗
=
ω(Cψ, Cφ), where
C(f, g) := (Cf, Cg),
(f, g) ∈H ⊕H .
(iv) (non-degeneracy) Any vector ψ ∈H ⊕H satisfying ω(ψ, φ) = 0 for
all φ ∈H ⊕H is equal to the zero vector 0 in H ⊕H .
We call ω the standard symplectic form on H ⊕H with respect to C.
Note that this depends on C. In what follows, we ﬁx the conjugation C.
Let A be a bounded linear operator on H ⊕H (i.e., A ∈B(H ⊕H )).
Then, for all (f, g) ∈H ⊕H , ∥A(f, g)∥≤∥A∥

5.29.2
Bogoliubov transformations
Now, we are ready to construct a class of representations of CCR.
Let S ∈SpC(H ) be given by (5.258) and V be a dense subspace of H
such that
CV ⊂V ,
S1V ⊂V ,
S2V ⊂V .
Then, it is easy to see that SjV ⊂V (j = 1, 2).
Boson Fock Spaces
375
Let L : V →C be a linear functional. For all f ∈V , the operator
A(S1f) + A(CS2f)∗is densely deﬁned and closable. Hence, one can deﬁne
a densely deﬁned closed operator B(f) on Fb(H ) by
B(f) := A(S1f) + A(CS2f)∗+ L(f)∗
(5.262)
It follows that
B(f)∗= (A(S1f) + A(CS2f)∗)∗+ L(f) ⊃A(S1f)∗+ A(CS2f) + L(f).
Lemma 5.29. The triplet (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ), {B(f) | f ∈V }) is a repre-
sentation of the CCR over V .
Proof. The anti-linearity of B(f) ↾Fb,ﬁn(V ) in f is easily seen. It is
easy to see that, for all f ∈V , B(f)#Fb,ﬁn(V ) ⊂Fb,ﬁn(V ) and, for all
Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(V ),
[B(f), B(g)∗]Ψ = [A(S1f) + A(CS2f)∗, A(S1g)∗+ A(CS2g)]Ψ
= (⟨S1f, S1g⟩−⟨CS2g, CS2f⟩)Ψ
= ⟨f, (S∗
1S1 −S∗
2S2)g⟩Ψ = ⟨f, g⟩Ψ,
where we have used the ﬁrst equation in (5.259). Similarly, using the second
equation in (5.259), we can show that [B(f), B(g)]Ψ = 0.
□
The correspondence {A(f), A(f)∗}f∈V →{B(f), B(f)∗}f∈V is called
the Bogoliubov transformation associated with (S, L). We also write it
as (A(·), A(·)∗) →(B(·), B(·)∗).
In particular, the Bogoliubov transformation associated with (I, L)
(S1 = I and S2 = 0) is called the Bogoliubov translation with respect
to the linear functional L. In this case, B(f) takes the form
BL(f) := A(f) + L(f)∗,
f ∈V ,
(5.263)
which appeared in Example 5.10. In this context, L is called the trans-
lation functional. As mentioned in Example 5.10, (Fb(H ), Fb,ﬁn(V ),
{BL(f)|f ∈V }) is an irreducible representation of the CCR over V .
Remark 5.45. The concept of Bogoliubov transformation can be extended
to the case where {A(f)|f
∈V } is replaced by any representation
(F, D, {C(f)|f ∈V }) of the CCR over V .
376
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
It is interesting to investigate the conditions for {B(f) | f ∈V } to be
equivalent or inequivalent to {A(f) | f ∈V }. From this point of view, we
introduce the following deﬁnition:
Deﬁnition 5.10. The Bogoliubov transformation {A(f), A(f)∗}f∈V →
{B(f), B(f)∗}f∈V is said to be proper (resp., improper) if{B(f) | f ∈V }
is equivalent (resp., inequivalent) to {A(f) | f ∈V }.
Remark 5.46. In addition to the above classes of Bogoliubov transforma-
tions, there is another class, called non-invertible Bogoliubov transforma-
tions (Arai, 1991a). This class may have physically interesting applications,
but we do not discuss it in this book.
Let
us
consider
the
case
where
the
Bogoliubov transformation
{A(f), A(f)∗}f∈V →{B(f), B(f)∗}f∈V is proper. In this case, there exists
a unitary operator U on Fb(H ) such that UB(f)U −1 = A(f), f ∈V .
Hence, by Theorem 5.45, under suitable conditions, a second quantization
associated with {B(f)|f ∈V } is bosonically diagonalizable. This structure
has been used to bosonically diagonalize a class of Bose ﬁeld Hamiltonians;
the point is to ﬁnd a representation of CCRs which is obtained as a proper
Bogoliubov transformation and whose second quantization is the Bose ﬁeld
Hamiltonian in question (see, for example, Ruijsenaars, 1977, 1978 and
references therein). For recent advances on bosonic diagonalizations, see
Matsuzawa et al. (2021) and references therein.
Remark 5.47. It is known that some improper Bogoliubov transfor-
mations are associated with “characteristic” quantum phenomena (e.g.,
superﬂuidity, Bose–Einstein condensation). In this sense too, improper
Bogoliubov transformations are also interesting. See Arai (2020) for details
on this respect.
We ﬁrst discuss Bogoliubov translations in the following section. As
for general Bogoliubov transformations, however, we give only a partial
analysis.

f ∈D
is a linear functional. It is easy to see that there exists a vector h ∈H
such that LT (f) = ⟨h, f⟩, f ∈D if and only if g ∈D(T ∗) and, in that case,
h = T ∗g. Thus, by Theorem 5.49, we obtain the following fact.
(i) The Bogoliubov translation
{A(f), A(f)∗}f∈D →{BLT (f), BLT (f)∗}f∈D
is proper (resp., improper) if and only if g ∈D(T ∗) (resp., g ̸∈D(T ∗)).
(ii) The Weyl representation (Fb(H ), {φLT (f), πLT (f)|f ∈DC}) is equiv-
alent (resp., inequivalent) to the Fock representation (Fb(H ), {φF(f),
πF(f)|f ∈DC}) if and only if g ∈D(T ∗) (resp., g ̸∈D(T ∗)).
5.29.4
A general case of Bogoliubov transformations
Let us return to the original Bogoliubov transformation (5.262). In this
case, letting CS(f) := B(f) −L(f)∗(f ∈V ), we have
B(f) = CS(f) + L(f)∗,
CS(f) = A(S1f) + A(CS2f)∗.
Note that B(·) is a Bogoliubov translation of CS(·) in the extended sense
(Remark 5.45). Hence, it may be enough to consider the Bogoliubov trans-
formation {A(f), A(f)∗}f∈V →{CS(f), CS(f)∗}f∈V .

5.30

5.30.5
Lp-integrability of φ(f)
To prove the Lp-integrability of φ(f), we recall a basic fact. Let (M, B, ν) be
a probability space and X : M →R∪{±∞} (M ∋m →X(m) ∈R∪{±∞})

(M, B)). Then, the characteristic function CX of X is deﬁned by

$

eitX(m)dν(m),

P X(B) := ν({m ∈M|X(m) ∈B}),
B ∈B1,
is called the probability distribution of X. Indeed, it is easy to see that P X
is a probability measure on (R, B1) and
CX(t) =
$
R
eitxdP X(x).
(5.281)

As a special case of Proposition 5.32, we have
ˆπn = π(en)
on P0,
where ˆπn is deﬁned by (5.274). Hence, the representation (L2( ˙R∞, dμ),
DW, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈H }) includes the representation (L2( ˙R∞, dμ), P0,
{ˆqn, ˆπn|n ∈N}). We also note that φ(f) is a multiplication operator.
Hence, (L2( ˙R∞, dμ), DW, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈H }) may be interpreted as a
representation in a functional form corresponding to the Schr¨odinger rep-
resentations of CCR with ﬁnite degrees of freedom. For this reason, we call
it a functional Schr¨odinger representation of the Heisenberg CCR
over H .
5.31
Concluding Remarks
The theory developed in Section 5.30 is, in fact, a special case of the the-
ory of Gaussian random process over a real Hilbert space. This concept is
deﬁned as follows.
Deﬁnition 5.11. Let H be a separable real Hilbert space and {φH (f)|f ∈
H } be a set of random variables on a probability space (QH , ΣH , μH )
(i.e., φH (f) : QH →R ∪{±∞}, ΣH -measurable and φH (f)(q) is ﬁnite
for μH -a.e. q ∈QH ). The mapping φH : f →φH (f) is called a Gaussian
random process over H if the following (i)–(iii) hold:
(i) (linearity) For all f, g ∈H and a, b ∈R, φH (af + bg) = aφH (f) +
bφH (g), μH -a.e.
(ii) (fullness) {φH (f)|f ∈H } is full.
(iii) (Gaussian)
:
QH eiφH (f)dν = e−∥f∥2/4, f ∈H .
Remark
5.50. Part
(iii)
in
Deﬁnition
5.11
can
be
replaced
by
:
QH eiφH (f)dν = e−λ∥f∥2 (f ∈H ) with λ > 0. However, if we deﬁne a new
random variable ;φH (f) by ;φH (f) := φH (f)/2
√
λ, then
:
QH eiφH (f)dν =
e−∥f∥2/4. Hence, the choice of λ is not essential.
Boson Fock Spaces
405
The content of Section 5.30 shows that, for any separable real Hilbert
space H , there exists a Gaussian random process over H .
The lemmas, propositions and theorems concerning φ(·) in Section 5.30
hold with ( ˙R∞, Σ∞, μ) and φ(·) replaced by (QH , ΣH , μH ) and φH (·),
respectively. In particular, the boson Fock space Fb(HC) is isomorphic
to L2(QH , dμH ) in quite the same way as in the case of L2( ˙R∞, dμ)
(cf. (5.291)). The Hilbert space L2(QH , dμH ) is sometimes called the Q-
space representation of the boson Fock space Fb(HC).
Generally, the integration of a function on an inﬁnite-dimensional space
with respect to an inﬁnite-dimensional measure is called a functional inte-
gration. The integration with respect to the measure μH on QH is a basic
example of functional integration appearing in mathematical quantum ﬁeld
theory.
The natural isomorphism between Fb(HC) and L2(QH , dμH ) is a fun-
damental structure of the boson Fock space Fb(HC). This structure is
shown to be very useful in studying quantum ﬁeld models because, under
the isomorphism, the time-zero ﬁeld φF(f) (f ∈H ) becomes a multiplica-
tion operator by the function φH (f) on QH , and one can use the functional
integration with respect to μH to study functions on QH . For more details,
see, for example, Arai (2010), Ezawa and Arai (2023), Derezi´nski and
G´erard (2013), Glimm and Jaﬀe (1987), L¨orinczi et al. (2020), Hiroshima
and L¨orinczi (2020), and Simon (1974, 1979).

Chapter 6
Fermion Fock Spaces
The fundamental aspects of the theory of fermion Fock spaces, which form the
basis for the construction of Fermi ﬁelds, are described.
6.1
Deﬁnitions and Basic Properties
Let K be a complex Hilbert space and, for each p ∈N, ∧p(K ) be the
p-fold anti-symmetric tensor product of K
(see Section 2.9.4). We set
∧0(K ) := C. The inﬁnite direct sum Hilbert space
Ff(K ) =
∞

p=0
∧p(K )
is called the fermion Fock space over K , or the anti-symmetric Fock
space over K . It is obvious that Ff(K ) is a closed subspace of the full
Fock space F(K ) over K .
If K
is ﬁnite dimensional with m = dim K , then, for all p > m,
∧p(K ) = {0} (see Remark 2.13). Hence, Ff(K ) = ⊕m
p=0∧p(K ). Therefore,
Ff(K ) is ﬁnite dimensional with dim Ff(K ) = m
p=0 dim ∧p(K ) = 2m.
Hence, in this case, the analysis of Ff(K ) is reduced to ﬁnite-dimensional
analysis. This is a big diﬀerence from the case of boson Fock spaces.
Based on the fact mentioned in the preceding paragraph, throughout
this chapter, we assume that K is inﬁnite dimensional, unless otherwise
stated.
In the context of concrete quantum ﬁeld models, K represents the state
vector space of a fermion, called the one-particle space of a fermion, or
the one-fermion space, and the Hilbert space ∧p(K ) with p ≥2 is a
closed subspace of Ff(K ) that represents the state vector space consisting
of p identical fermions. For this reason, ∧p(K ) is called the p-particle
space of fermions.

6.2

In the same manner as in the case of second quantization operators on
a boson Fock space, one can deﬁne second quantization operators on the
fermion Fock space Ff(K ).

6.3
Fermion Γ-Operators
In this section, we consider the reduction of Γ-operators on the full Fock
space F(K ) (see Section 4.9) to the fermion Fock space Ff(K ).
Let H be a complex Hilbert space and S be a densely deﬁned clos-
able operator from H to K . Then, in the same way as in the proof of
Proposition 5.2, one can show that, for all p ≥2,
Ap ⊗p S ⊂(⊗pS)Ap.
Hence, one can deﬁne a linear operator ∧pS from ∧p(H ) to ∧p(K ) as
follows:
D(∧pS) := D(⊗pS) ∩(⊗pH ),
(∧pS)Ψ := (⊗pS)Ψ,
Ψ ∈D(∧p(S)).
Note that, in the case of H = K , ∧p(K ) reduces ⊗pS, and the oper-
ator ∧pS is the reduced part.
For p = 0, 1, we set ∧0S := 1, ∧1S := S.
The symbol ∧p(S) may be used instead of ∧pS: ∧p(S) = ∧pS.
The following lemma is proved in the same way as we proved Lemma 5.2.
Lemma 6.1. Let S be a densely deﬁned closable operator from a complex
Hilbert space H to K and Γ(S) be the Γ-operator from F(H ) to F(K )
deﬁned by (4.51). Then, Pf(K )Γ(S) ⊂Γ(S)Pf(H ).
By this lemma, we can deﬁne a linear operator Γf(S) from Ff(H ) to
Ff(K ) by
D(Γf(S)) := D(Γ(S)) ∩Ff(H ),
Γf(S)Ψ := Γ(S)Ψ,
Ψ ∈D(Γf(S)).
The operator Γf(S) is called the fermion Γ-operator
associated
with S.

It follows that
Γf(S) = ⊕∞
p=0 ∧p S.
We have
Γf(S)ΩK = ΩK .
Hence,
1 ∈σp(Γf(S)).
(6.4)
The proof of the following theorem can be obtained in quite the same
manner as that of Theorem 5.6.
Theorem 6.2. Let S be a densely deﬁned closable operator from H to K .
(i) If S is unbounded, then Γf(S) is unbounded.
(ii) Γf(S∗) ⊂Γf(S)∗.
(iii) If S is a contraction operator, then Γf(S) is a contraction operator,
and
Γf(S)∗= Γf(S∗).
(iv) If D is a core for S, then ∧ﬁn(D) is a core for Γf(S).

(ii) If U : H →K is unitary, then so is Γf(U) : Ff(H ) →Ff(K ), and
Γf(U)−1 = Γf(U −1).

The following theorem gives the relations between the fermion second
quantization operator and the fermion Γ-operator.
Theorem 6.4. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on K .
(i) For all t ∈R,
Γf(eitT ) = eitdΓf(T ).
(ii) If T ≥0, then dΓf(T ) ≥0, and for all z ∈C+,
Γf(e−zT ) = e−zdΓf(T ).

6.4
Commutation Properties of Fermion Second Quantization
Operators
Proposition 6.2. Let S and T be densely deﬁned closable operators on K
such that D([S, T ]) = D(ST ) ∩D(T S) is dense and [S, T ] is closable. Then,
∧ﬁn(D([S, T ])) ⊂D([dΓf(S), dΓf(T )]) and, for all Ψ ∈∧ﬁn(D([S, T ])),
[dΓf(S), dΓf(T )]Ψ = dΓf([S, T ])Ψ.
Proof. Similar to the proof of Theorem 4.18.
□
The operator
Nf := dΓf(I)
is called the fermion number operator on Ff(K ).
Applying Proposition 6.2 to the case of S = I, we obtain the following
result.
Proposition 6.3. Let T be a densely deﬁned closable operator on K . Then,
∧ﬁn(D(T )) ⊂D([Nf, dΓf(T )]) and, for all Ψ ∈∧ﬁn(D(T )),
[Nf, dΓf(T )]Ψ = 0.
With regard to the strong commutativity of dΓf(T ) and dΓf(S) in the
case where T and S are self-adjoint, the following theorem holds.
Theorem 6.5. Let S and T be self-adjoint operators on K . Then, the self-
adjoint operators dΓf(S) and dΓf(T ) strongly commute if and only if S and
T strongly commute.
Fermion Fock Spaces
419
Proof. Similar to the proof of Theorem 4.19.
□
A simple application of this theorem to the case of S = I gives the
following result.
Corollary 6.1. Let T be a self-adjoint operator on K . Then, Nf and
dΓf(T ) strongly commute.

6.7
Canonical Anti-Commutation Relations
For two linear operators A and B acting in a Hilbert space X , one can
deﬁne a linear operator {A, B} on X by
{A, B} := AB + BA.
By the deﬁnition of the sum of two linear operators, D({A, B}) = D(AB)∩
D(BA). The operator {A, B} is called the anti-commutator of A and B.
