In a physical picture, a vacuum is supposed to be a state in which there
exist no observed elementary particles or no visible matters in the space-
time. In such a state, every point in the space-time would be on an equal
footing. Therefore, a vacuum should be a state invariant under all proper
Poincar´e transformations. This requirement is (U.3).
The joint spectrum σJ(P) of P is interpreted as the set of measured
values of the energy–momentum P. In the special theory of relativity, an
energy–momentum vector of a “normal” motion (time-like motion) is time-
like and the energy component is non-negative. Hence, (8.50) is a natural
condition.
In the special theory of relativity, space-like separated points are
causally independent. Hence, ﬁeld measurements should be mutually
independent if they are made at those points. On the other hand, the
independence of quantum mechanical observables is expressed as their com-
mutativity. This is a physical meaning of property (GW.4).
Physically, a quantum ﬁeld is supposed to have the function that creates
elementary particles from the vacuum or annihilates them into the vacuum.
Each state may be described by a conﬁguration of elementary particles
whose number is ﬁnite, and such a state may be given by a ﬁnite linear
combination of the vacuum Ψ0 and vectors of the form φ(f1) · · · φ(fn)Ψ0
(n ∈N, fj ∈S (R1+d), j = 1, . . . , n). This is a physical picture behind
property (GW.5).
Let us see some consequences of (GW.1)–(GW.5).

μ = 0, 1, . . . , d.

eitPμΨ0 = Ψ0.
By considering the strong diﬀerentiation of both sides at t = 0, one sees
that Ψ0 ∈D(Pμ) and PμΨ0 = 0.

8.11.2
Angular momentum
In this section, we show how the concept of angular momentum appears in
the framework of the G˚arding–Wightman axioms. For each Λ ∈L ↑
+, we set
U0(Λ) := U(0, Λ).
Then, U0 : L ↑

L ↑
+.

For 1 ≤j, k ≤d, j ̸= k, and θ ∈R, a mapping Rjk(θ) on M1+d is
deﬁned by
(Rjk(θ)x)μ := xμ,
μ ̸= j, k,
(Rjk(θ)x)j := xj cos θ −xk sin θ,
(Rjk(θ)x)k := xj sin θ + xk cos θ,
x ∈M1+d.
It is easy to see that Rjk(θ) ∈L ↑
+. Geometrically, Rjk(θ) means the
Euclidean rotation of angle θ around the origin in the xj-xk plane.
Also, we deﬁne R0j(θ) ∈L ↑
+ (j = 1, . . . , d) by

μ ̸= 0, j,

(R0j(θ)x)j := x0 sinh θ + xj cosh θ.
Geometrically, R0j(θ) means the Lorentz rotation of angle θ around the
origin in the x0-xj plane. Also, we introduce Rj0(θ) ∈L ↑

θ ∈R.

of the quantum ﬁeld φ. In particular, we call (M jk)1≤j<k≤d the orbital
angular momentum.

8.11.3
The Wightman axioms
Let (H , U, φ, D, Ψ0) be a neutral quantum scalar ﬁeld theory on M1+d.
Then, by a general theory in Section 8.5, for each n ∈N, there exists a
568
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
unique tempered distribution Wn on (R1+d)n such that, for all f1, . . . , fn ∈
S (R1+d),
Wn(f1 × · · · × fn) = ⟨Ψ0, φ(f1) · · · φ(fn)Ψ0⟩.
(8.70)
The
tempered
distribution
Wn
is
called
the
n-point
Wightman
distribution for the quantum ﬁeld φ. The distribution kernel of Wn is
denoted Wn(x1, . . . , xn):
Wn(f) =

Wn(x1, . . . , xn)f(x1, . . . , xn)dx1 · · · dxn.
In terms of the operator-valued distribution kernel φ(x) of the quantum
ﬁeld φ, Wn(x1, . . . , xn) is written as
Wn(x1, . . . , xn) = ⟨Ψ0, φ(x1) · · · φ(xn)Ψ0⟩
as a symbolical expression for (8.70).
One can characterize a QFT in terms of the Wightman distributions
instead of using a Hilbert space and operators acting in it. This approach
leads one to the following axioms (Wightman, 1956; Streater and Wight-
man, 1964).
A neutral quantum scalar ﬁeld theory is a sequence {Wn ∈
S ′(R(1+d)n)}∞
n=0
(W0 := 1) of tempered distributions satisfying the fol-

(W.1) (Hermiticity) For all f ∈S (R(1+d)n),
Wn(f)∗= Wn(f †),
n ≥1,
where f † is the function deﬁned by
f †(x1, . . . , xn) := f(xn, xn−1, . . . , x1)∗
(8.71)
for all (x1, . . . , xn) ∈(R1+d)n.
(W.2) (relativistic invariance) For all (a, Λ) ∈P↑
+ and f ∈S (R(1+d)n),
Wn(f) = Wn(f(a,Λ)),
n ≥1,
where
f(a,Λ)(x1, . . . , xn) := f(Λ−1(x1 −a), . . . , Λ−1(xn −a)).

(W.3) (positivity) For all N

Remark 8.10. In general, a tempered distribution T ∈S ′(R(1+d)n) is said
to be Poincar´e (resp., Lorentz) invariant if, for all f ∈S (R(1+d)n) and
(a, Λ) ∈P↑

In terms of distribution kernel T (x1, . . . , xn) of T , the Poincar´e invariance
of T is symbolically expressed as
T (Λx1 + a, . . . , Λxn + a) = T (x1, . . . , xn).
The case a = 0 in this equation gives the symbolical expression of the
Lorentz invariance of T . Axiom (W.2) is rephrased as follows: for all n ≥1,
Wn is Poincar´e invariant.

8.11.4
The Osterwalder–Schrader axioms
The theory of functions of complex variables tells us that the essence of a
function may become apparent only after all its possible analytic contin-
uations are found. This idea may be applicable to tempered distributions
too. From this point of view, one is naturally led to consider the analytic
continuations of the Wightman distributions and may expect to obtain a
set of axioms for a QFT in terms of objects diﬀerent from the Wightman
distributions. In the following, we describe how this procedure is done and
what kind of axioms appear.
One can show by using the relativistic invariance, the spectral condition
and the locality in the Wightman axioms that each Wightman distribution
Wn can be analytically continued to a function on the subset
{((it1, x1), . . . , (itn, xn))|tj ∈R, xj ∈Rd, (itj, xj) ̸= (itk, xk)
j ̸= k, j, k = 1, . . . , n}
in C(1+d)n := C1+d×· · ·×C1+d (the n direct product of C1+d).25 This subset
is called the non-coincident Euclidean region. As is seen, the analytic
continuation makes the time components of space-time points purely imag-
inary ones. For this reason, it is called the analytic continuation to purely
imaginary times. On the level of the space-time, this analytic continua-
tion changes the Minkowski space-time metric to the Euclidean one. In
this sense, the analytic continuation is called the Euclideanization of the
Wightman distributions. Let us denote the analytic continuation of Wn by
the same symbol Wn and introduce a sequence {Sn}∞
n=0 of functions as
follows: S0 := 1 and
Sn((t1, x1), . . . (tn, xn)) := Wn((it1, x1), . . . , (itn, xn))
It is shown that, for all n ∈N, Sn is a real analytic function on the domain
En := {(y1, . . . , yn) ∈R(1+d)n|yj ̸= yk, j ̸= k, j, k = 1, . . . , n}.
(8.73)
The function Sn is called the n-point Schwinger function or n-point
Euclidean Green’s function.
25For the details, see, for example, Ezawa and Arai (2023), Chapter 2, Osterwalder and
Schrader (1973, 1975), and Simon (1974).

and hence, in the symbolical sense, “xE and yE are space-like separated.”
Therefore, applying schematically (heuristically) the microscopic causality
to this case, one has that [φr(xE), φr′(yE)] = 0 (r, r′ = 1, . . . , s). Thus, if
a ﬁeld (φr,E)s
r=1 on the Euclidean space R1+d exists, then it is expected
that they form a set of commuting operators. Needless to say, commutative
operators may be more tractable than non-commutative ones.
8.12
Euclidean Quantum Fields
As remarked in a heuristic way at the end of the previous section, it
is expected that, in the analytic continuation of the G˚arding–Wightman
theory to the non-coincident Euclidean region, a quantum ﬁeld on the
Minkowski space-time may metamorphose into an operator-valued distribu-
tion whose values are mutually commutative. One may call such a commu-
tative operator-valued distribution a Euclidean quantum ﬁeld if it exists.
576
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
In this connection, the vacuum in the G˚arding–Wightman theory should
have a corresponding non-zero vector in the Hilbert space in which the
Euclidean quantum ﬁeld acts. If such a vector exists, we call it a Euclidean
vacuum. In this scheme, it is expected that the Schwinger functions are
generated by the expectation values of the Euclidean quantum ﬁelds with
respect to a Euclidean vacuum. At least it is natural as a working hypoth-
esis to suppose that such a class of Schwinger functions may exist. These
heuristic considerations leads one to the following deﬁnition.
Deﬁnition 8.4. Let H be a Hilbert space. A Euclidean quantum ﬁeld
(or a Euclidean ﬁeld simply) on R1+d is an operator-valued distribution
ϕE on R1+d with values in L(H ) and common domain D, satisfying the
following (EF.1)–(EF.3):
(EF.1) (cyclicity) There exists a unit vector Φ0 in D such that, for all n ∈N
and fj ∈S (R1+d) (j = 1, . . . , n), Φ0 ∈D(ϕE(f1) · · · ϕE(fn)) and
the subspace
D0 := span
(
Φ0, ϕE(f1) · · · ϕE(fn)Φ0|n ∈N, fj ∈S (R1+d),
j = 1, . . . , n
)
is dense in H and D0 ⊂D.
(EF.2) (commutativity) For all f, g ∈S (R1+d), [ϕE(f), ϕE(g)] = 0 on D0.
(EF.3) (Euclidean invariance) Let n ∈N and fj ∈S (R1+d) (j = 1, . . . , n).
Then, for all (a, R) ∈R1+d × SO(1 + d),

Φ0, ϕE(f1(a,R)) · · · ϕE(fn(a,R))Φ0

= ⟨Φ0, ϕE(f1) · · · ϕE(fn)Φ0⟩,
where fj(a,R)(x) := fj(R−1(x −a)), x ∈R1+d.
The vector Φ0 is called a Euclidean vacuum.
Let ϕE be a Euclidean ﬁeld on R1+d as above. Then, by the Schwartz
nuclear theorem, for each n ∈N, there exists a unique tempered distribution
Sn ∈S ′(R1+d) such that
Sn(f1×· · ·×fn) = ⟨Φ0, ϕE(f1) · · · ϕE(fn)Φ0⟩,
fj ∈S (R1+d), j = 1, . . . , n.
We call Sn’s the Schwinger distributions of the Euclidean ﬁeld ϕE.
General Theory of Quantum Fields
577
Since a Euclidean ﬁeld is commutative in the sense of (EF.2), there
may be the case where H = L2(X, dμ) with a probability measure space
(X, Σ, μ), ϕE(f) (f ∈SR(R1+d)) is a random variable on (X, Σ, μ) and
Φ0 = 1. In this case, ϕE is an example of a generalized random process,
or a random distribution, on R1+d. Nelson formulated a set of axioms for
such a Euclidean quantum ﬁeld from which an RQFT on the Minkowski
space-time is reconstructed. These axioms are called the Nelson axioms.
For the details, see Nelson (1973) and Simon (1974).
8.13
PCT Theorem
Concerning space-time symmetries, we have so far considered only
continuous symmetries, i.e., symmetries deﬁned by continuous groups, such
as time- translation, space translations, space rotations and proper Lorentz
transformations. However, besides continuous symmetries, there are phys-
ically important discrete symmetries which are described by ﬁnite groups
consisting of transformations on the space-time. In this section, we brieﬂy
describe them and give a remark on an important theorem.
We deﬁne the mappings I0 and Is on R1+d as follows:
I0(x) := (−x0, x),
(8.75)
Is(x) := (x0, −x),
x = (x0, x) ∈R1+d.
(8.76)
The mappings I0 and Is are, respectively, called the time reversal (or
time inversion) and the space inversion. Note that
(I0Is)(x) = −x = (IsI0)(x),
x ∈R1+d.
Hence,
I0Is = IsI0
and I0Is gives the space-time inversion: R1+d ∋x →−x. It is easy to
see that I0 and Is are bijective linear mappings with
I2

s = I.
In particular,

s
= Is.
Hence,
{I, I0}, {I, Is}
and
{I, I0, Is, I0Is}
become
discrete
(ﬁnite)
groups.

8.14
Haag’s Theorem
In this section, we describe an important theorem in axiomatic QFT. We
denote by O(3) the three-dimensional orthogonal group (see Appendix F,
Example F.1(iii)). The direct product
E (3) := R3 × O(3) := {(a, R)|a ∈R3, R ∈O(3)}
of R3 and O(3) becomes a topological group with product topology and the
product operation deﬁned by
(a2, R2)(a1, R1) := (a2 + R2a1, R2R1),
a1, a2 ∈R3, R1, R2 ∈O(3).
The unit element of E (3) is (0, I) and the inverse element of (a, R) ∈E (3) is
(−R−1a, R−1). The group E (3) is called the three-dimensional Euclidean
group.
The direct product
E (3)
+
:= R3 × SO(3)
of R3 and the three-dimensional rotation group SO(3) (see Appendix F,
Example F.1(iv)) forms a subgroup of E (3). It is called the three-
dimensional restricted Euclidean group.
For each (a, R) ∈E (3)
+ , one can deﬁne an operator v(a, R) on L2(R3) by
(v(a, R)f)(x) := f(a,R)(x) := f(R−1(x −a)),
a.e. x ∈R3.
(8.78)

mapping v : E (3)

unitary representation of E (3)

Euclidean symmetry.

{c(a, I)|a ∈R3} is a one-dimensional unitary representation of the trans-
lation group R3, it follows that, for all a, b ∈R3, w(|a|)w(|b|) = w(|a+b|).
Taking b = −a, we obtain w(|a|)2 = 1. Hence, c(a, I) = ±1. Since c(a, I)
is continuous on R3 and R3 is connected, it follows that c(a, I) = 1 for all
a ∈R3 or c(a, I) = −1 for all a ∈R3. But the latter is excluded because

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
of (8.81). Hence, U(a, R)ΩL2(R3) = c0ΩL2(R3). Since U(0, I) = I, it follows
that c0 = 1. Thus, U(a, R)ΩL2(R3) = ΩL2(R3). Then, by condition (iv),
ΩL2(R3) = λΨ0 for some constant λ ∈C (|λ| = 1). Letting γ = 1/λ, we
obtain the desired result.

Theorem 8.9 has an important implication in constructing a non-trivial
QFT model. Let (Fb(L2(R3)), D, H, {ϕ(t, ·), π(t, ·)}t∈R) be as in Theorem
8.9 and H0 be deﬁned by (8.24) with d = 3. By (5.190), the Fock vacuum
Ω0 := ΩL2(R3) is a ground state of H0. Suppose that H ̸= H0 and
H = H0 + HI
with a symmetric operator HI on Fb(L2(R3)). This means that H is
obtained by a perturbation of H0. Physically, the perturbation operator
General Theory of Quantum Fields
583
HI is expected to describe an interaction of the quantum ﬁeld ϕ(t, f). But
it follows from the conclusion of Theorem 8.9 that HI does not change
the ground state Ω0 of the unperturbed system. In general, an interaction
of a quantum ﬁeld is expected to change the ground state of a quantum
ﬁeld system. From this point of view, the result just mentioned indicates
the ineﬀectiveness of the interaction HI. Indeed, we have for all t ∈R and
f1, . . . , fm, g1, . . . , gn ∈SR(R3) (m, n ∈N),
⟨Ψ0, ϕ(t, f1) · · · ϕ(t, fm)π(t, g1) · · · π(t, gn)Ψ0⟩
= ⟨Ψ0, ϕ(0, f1) · · · ϕ(0, fm))π(0, g1) · · · π(0, gn)Ψ0⟩
=

Ω0, φF(T −1/2f1) · · · φF(T −1/2fm)πF(T 1/2g1) · · · πF(T 1/2gn)Ω0

= ⟨Ω0, ϕfree(t, f1) · · · ϕfree(t, fm)πfree(t, g1) · · · πfree(t, gn)Ω0⟩.
where ϕfree(t, f) and πfree(t, g) (f, g ∈SR(R3)) are the free quantum ﬁelds
deﬁned in Section 8.7 with d = 3. The formula shows that the VEVs of
products of time-t quantum ﬁelds ϕ(t, ·) and π(t, ·) coincide with those of
time-t free quantum ﬁelds ϕfree(t, ·) and πfree(t, ·) (but this may not be the
case for the VEVs of the products of unequal-time quantum ﬁelds).
As is seen from the proof of Theorem 8.9, the problem comes
from the choice of the time-zero ﬁelds, i.e., the Fock representation
{φF(T −1/2f), πF(T 1/2f)|f ∈SR(R3)} of Heisenberg CCR is chosen. There-
fore, Theorem 8.9 suggests that, in constructing a non-trivial model with
Euclidean symmetry in the sense of (i)–(iv) in Theorem 8.9, one should
use as the time-zero ﬁelds a representation of Heisenberg CCR inequiva-
lent to the Fock one. In fact, representations of CCR inequivalent to Fock
ones appear in many places in quantum ﬁeld theory to describe physically
interesting situations. We shall discuss an example of such a structure in
Chapter 13 (see also Arai, 2020).
Remark 8.12. If the quantum ﬁeld ϕ in Theorem 8.9 is a relativistic scalar
ﬁeld and T = L1/2
m , then it follows from an application of a general theorem
(Streater and Wightman, 1964, Theorem 4-15) that ϕ is a free ﬁeld of mass
m (see Chapter 10). There is a relativistic version of Theorem 8.9, which is
also called Haag’s theorem and implies that, in relativistic QFT, the so-
called interaction picture is impossible, i.e., the total Hamiltonian cannot
be written as the sum of the free (unperturbed) part and the interaction
584
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(perturbation) part. Hence, the Dyson perturbation expansion in relativis-
tic QFT, which is based on the interaction picture, becomes being mathe-
matically in question in an essential sense. For the details, see, for exam-
ple, Streater and Wightman (1964), Theorem 4-16 and Strocchi (2013),
Theorem 5.1.
8.15
Scattering Theory and Spectral Analysis
8.15.1
Introduction
In an axiomatic QFT in which the basic concept is a quantum ﬁeld (e.g.,
the G˚arding–Wightman axioms), no particle picture is given in advance.
Hence, one needs to derive a particle picture from the axioms. Physically,
one has a particle picture by observing free elementary particles. In scat-
tering phenomena of elementary particles, free elementary particles coming
from a long distance at time t ≈−∞are scattered by a target and then
ﬂy away into the distance at t ≈+∞, appearing as free elementary parti-
cles again.29 From these experimental facts, one infers that there exists an
asymptotic ﬁeld φin(t, x) (resp., φout(t, x)) describing free particles, which is
formally deﬁned as an asymptotic limit (in a suitable sense) limt→−∞φ(t, x)
(resp., limt→+∞φ(t, x)) of an interacting quantum ﬁeld φ(t, x), satisfying
φin/out(t, x) = eitH/ℏφin/out(0, x)e−itH/ℏ, where H is the Hamiltonian of
the quantum system under consideration, and the free Klein–Gordon
equation

□+ m2
ℏ2

φin/out(t, x) = 0
in the sense of operator-valued distribution if φ(t, x) is a quantum scalar
ﬁeld, with m ≥0 being a constant.30 The quantum ﬁelds φin/out are called
free quantum Klein–Gordon ﬁelds, and it is shown that they describe free
particles of mass m indeed (the details will be given in Chapter 10). How-
ever, in the case of the asymptotic ﬁelds φin/out, m has to be identiﬁed with
the observed mass of a particle (not the “bare mass”31). With this particle
29In the intermediate space-time where the interactions among the elementary particles
and the target occur, a particle picture makes no sense.
30We continue to use the physical unit system where c = 1, unless otherwise stated.
31A “bare mass” means the mass of a particle before being in the interaction with
quantum ﬁelds (it may be somewhat a ﬁctitious notion). In the conventional picture
in physical QFT, the bare mass of a particle may change through an interaction with
a quantum ﬁeld to give an observed mass. It is known, however, that in some models
General Theory of Quantum Fields
585
picture, one can ask the transition probability of an initial particle state
(in-state) at t = −∞to a ﬁnal particle state (out-state) at t = +∞, which
may be compared with experiments on scattering phenomena of elementary
particles. Such transition probabilities can be described in a uniﬁed way by
a unitary operator called a scattering operator, or a scattering matrix.
A scattering theory in the framework of the G˚arding–Wightman axioms
is established and called the Haag–Ruelle scattering theory. Concern-
ing this theory, we refer the reader to textbooks on mathematical QFT
(e.g., Araki, 1993, Chapter 4; Bogoliubov et al., 1975, Chapter 4; Glimm
and Jaﬀe, 1987, Chapters 13–14; Haag, 1996, Section II.4; Reed and Simon,
1979, Chapter XI, Section 16). See also Buchholz (1978). In this section, we
present another type of scattering theory which can be applied to models
in non-relativistic QFT, including those in relativistic QFT with cutoﬀs
(see Chapter 14). From a mathematical point of view, it gives a method for
the spectral analysis of a class of self-adjoint operators on Hilbert spaces of
Fock space type.

8.15.5
Scattering operator
We assume the following (H.3) and (H.4) in addition to (H.1) and (H.2):
(H.3) (existence of a ground state) H has a ground state Ψ0:
HΨ0 = E0Ψ0,
∥Ψ0∥= 1.
(H.4) The operator T is absolutely continuous.
Under these assumptions, we have by Theorem 8.10
A±(f)Ψ0 = 0,
f ∈D(T −1/2).
Since Ψ0 ∈C∞(H), it follows from Lemma 8.10 that, for all n ∈N
and fj ∈DT (j = 1, . . . , n), Ψ0 ∈D(A±(f1)# · · · A±(fn)#). Hence, we can
deﬁne vectors
Ψ±(f1, . . . , fn) := A±(f1)∗· · · A±(fn)∗Ψ0.
Physically, the vector Ψ−(f1, . . . , fn) (resp., Ψ+(f1, . . . , fn)) is interpreted as
an asymptotically observed n particle state at t = −∞(resp., +∞), called
an in-state (resp., out-state). In this way, a particle picture emerges in
the interacting system under consideration.

If Fin = Fout = Fb(H ), then the quantum system is said to be
asymptotically complete. In this case, S is a unitary operator on
Fb(H ).
If F∞:= Fin = Fout, then the quantum system is said to have weak
asymptotic completeness. In this case, S is a unitary operator on F∞.
Since, for each in-state Ψ ∈F∞with ∥Ψ∥= 1, SΨ is a state vector at
t = +∞(an out-state) determined causally under no measurements in
the meantime, | ⟨Φ, SΨ⟩|2 is interpreted as the transition probability from
Ψ at t = −∞to Φ at t = +∞(i.e., the probability that the state Φ is
found under a measurement at t = +∞). In particular, | ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 gives the
probability that the system is found to be in the same state Ψ as the initial
one under a measurement at t = +∞. Based on this, one says that there is
no scattering with respect to the asymptotic initial state Ψ at t = −∞if
| ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 = 1. We say that there is no scattering if, for all unit vectors
Ψ ∈F∞, | ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 = 1. Hence, if | ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 < 1 for some unit vector
Ψ ∈F∞, then there is a scattering. “No scattering” is characterized as
follows.
Proposition 8.12. There is no scattering if and only if S = eiθ for some
θ ∈R.
Proof. The “if part” is obvious. So, we prove the “only if part.” Sup-
pose that there is no scattering. Then, for all unit vectors Ψ ∈F∞,
| ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 = 1. Let Ψ ∈F∞with ∥Ψ∥= 1 and P be the orthogonal
projection onto the one-dimensional space HΨ := {αΨ|α ∈C}. Then, we
have SΨ = ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩Ψ + (1 −P)SΨ. Hence,
∥SΨ∥2 = | ⟨Ψ, SΨ⟩|2 + ∥(1 −P)SΨ∥2 = 1 + ∥(1 −P))SΨ∥2.
Since S is unitary, ∥SΨ∥2 = ∥Ψ∥2 = 1. Hence, ∥(1 −P)SΨ∥2 = 0. This
implies that SΨ ∈HΨ. Hence, SΨ = α(Ψ)Ψ with a constant α(Ψ) such that
|α(Ψ)| = 1. It follows that, for all non-zero vectors Φ ∈F∞, SΦ = β(Φ)Φ
with β := α(Φ/∥Φ∥). Using the linearity of S, one can show that β(Φ) is
independent of Φ. Hence, there exists a constant θ ∈R such that β(Φ) = eiθ.
Thus, S = eiθ.
□

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields

Theorem 8.14. Assume (H.1)–(H.4). Then,
(i) σ(Hin/out) = σ(H0) + E0.
(ii) σ(H0) + E0 ⊂σ(H).
(iii) If Fin = Fb(H ) or Fout = Fb(H ), then σ(H) = σ(H0) + E0 and
the ground state of H is unique.
General Theory of Quantum Fields
597
Proof. (i) By the preceding lemma and the unitary invariance of spectrum,
we have σ(Hin/out −E0) = σ(H0). Hence, the desired result follows.
(ii) Since H is a direct sum operator, we have
σ(H) = σ(Hin/out) ∪σ(H⊥
in/out).
Hence, σ(H) ⊃σ(Hin/out) = σ(H0) + E0.
(iii) Let Fin = Fb(H ). Then, F ⊥
in = {0} and hence Hin = H. Thus,
by (ii), σ(H) = σ(H0) + E0. Suppose that Φ0 ̸= 0 were a ground state
of H. Without loss of generality, we can assume that Ψ0 ⊥Φ0. Then, by
A−(f)Φ0 = 0 for all f ∈D(T −1/2), we have ⟨Ψ−(f1, . . . , fn), Φ0⟩= 0 for all
fj ∈DT (j = 1, . . . , n, n ∈N). Hence, Φ0 ∈D⊥
0,−= {0}. Thus Φ0 = 0. But
this is a contradiction, Thus, the ground state of H is unique. Similarly,
one can prove the stated fact in the case Fout = Fb(H ) too.

Remark 8.13. Theorem 8.14(iii) shows that, if σ(H0) + E0 ⫋σ(H), then
Fin/out ̸= Fb(H ). Physically, an eigenvector of H with an eigenvalue in
σ(H) \ (σ(H0) + E0) is interpreted as a bound state of H.
Let us consider a typical case of T appearing in quantum scalar ﬁeld
models.
Corollary 8.3. Let H be separable and assume (H.1)–(H.4). Suppose that
T is absolutely continuous and
σ(T ) = σac(T ) = [m, ∞)
(8.107)
with a constant m ≥0. Then:
(i)
σ(Hin/out) = {E0}∪[E0 +m, ∞),
σp(Hin/out) = {E0}.
(8.108)
(ii) {E0} ∪[E0 + m, ∞) ⊂σ(H).
(iii) If m = 0, then σ(H) = [E0, ∞).
(iv) If Fin = Fb(H ) or Fout = Fb(H ), then σ(H) = {E0}∪[E0 +m, ∞)
and the ground state of H is unique.
Proof. (i) By Theorem 5.3 and (8.107), we have
σ(H0) = {0} ∪[m, ∞).
By this fact and Theorem 8.14(i), we obtain (8.108).
Part (ii) follows from (i) and Theorem 8.14(ii).
(iii) Let m = 0. Then, by (ii), [E0, ∞) ⊂σ(H). But it is obvious that
σ(H) ⊂[E0, ∞).
Part (iv) follows from (i) and Theorem 8.14(iii).

8.16
Concluding Remarks
In this chapter, we have discussed mainly Wightman’s approach to
axiomatic QFT. As is seen, this approach is operator-theoretical and
“analytic,” so to speak; a quantum ﬁeld is given by an (unbounded)
operator-valued distribution acting in a Hilbert space and the VEVs of
the products of the quantum ﬁeld yield tempered distributions (Wightman
distributions).
Another approach to axiomatic QFT was proposed and developed by
Haag, Kastler and Araki in the 1960s (Haag and Kastler, 1964; Araki, 1964).
In this approach, a central role is played by a C∗-algebra34 of local observ-
ables (observables associated with open subsets in the space-time), which
are represented by bounded operators in contrast to the case of Wightman
quantum ﬁelds. This type of QFT is called algebraic quantum ﬁeld
theory (AQFT). AQFT is beyond the scope of this book, but we shall
use the ideas of AQFT partially in Chapter 15, where a mathematical the-
ory of spontaneous symmetry breaking in QFT is described. For details of
AQFT, see, for example, Araki (1993), Emch (1972, 2009), and Haag (1996)
(a brief introduction to algebraic approach to QFT is presented in Bogoli-
ubov et al., 1975, Appendix A). A pedagogical introduction to AQFT is
found in Fewster and Rejzner (2020).

Chapter 9
Non-Relativistic QFT
Mathematically rigorous constructions of basic models in non-relativistic QFT
are given.
9.1
Introduction
In this chapter, we begin by showing the existence of models of QFT by
constructing them in a mathematically rigorous way. We ﬁrst discuss the
models in non-relativistic QFT since they are easier to treat than those
in relativistic QFT. A non-relativistic QFT has two further categories:
a bosonic one and a fermionic one (see Section 5.1). We ﬁrst construct a
model of a non-relativistic Bose ﬁeld and then a model of a non-relativistic
Fermi ﬁeld. But, for the reader’s convenience, we begin with a brief descrip-
tion of a corresponding classical ﬁeld theory.
9.2
Classical Field Theory
According to de Broglie (1923), associated with a non-relativistic free parti-
cle (e.g., a non-relativistic electron) in the d-dimensional space Rd = {x =
(x1, . . . , xd)|xj ∈R, j = 1, . . . , d} (d ∈N; physically, d = 3) is a matter-
wave u : R × Rd →C; R × Rd ∋(t, x) →u(t, x) ∈C obeying the partial
diﬀerential equation
i∂u(t, x)
∂t
= −1
2mf
Δu(t, x),
(9.1)
609
610
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
where mf
> 0 is a constant and Δ is the d-dimensional generalized
Laplacian.1 The function u is called the classical free de Broglie ﬁeld.
We call (9.1) the free de Broglie equation.
One may note that (9.1) is same in form as a Schr¨odinger equation in
quantum mechanics. But the physical meaning of the de Broglie equation
is totally diﬀerent from that of the Schr¨odinger equation as an equation
in quantum mechanics because the former is an equation of motion for a
classical ﬁeld describing a matter-wave, while the latter is an equation for
the probability amplitude of a quantum state.2 For this reason, we do not
use the name “Schr¨odinger equation” for (9.1) in the context of matter-
wave theory.3 Of course, from a purely mathematical point of view, it does
not matter how (9.1) is called.
A classical de Broglie ﬁeld may have a self-interaction (a nonlinear inter-
action) and an interaction with an external ﬁeld (potential) V : R1+d →R.
An equation in which such interactions are incorporated is given by
i∂u(t, x)
∂t
= −1
2mf

+ U(|u(t, x)|)u(t, x),
(9.2)
where U : [0, ∞) →R is a given function. It is obvious that the case where
V = 0 and U = 0 in (9.2) reduces to (9.1).
The time reversal utr of de Broglie ﬁeld u is deﬁned by

9.3
Heuristic Arguments toward Construction of QFT
By substituting (9.6) for (9.2), one obtains an equation which a quantum
de Broglie ﬁeld should obey. Hence, a quantum ﬁeld ψ corresponding to
4Physically, this equation is supposed to describe approximately a classical matter

612
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
the classical free de Broglie ﬁeld u if it exists should be an operator-valued
distribution on R1+d acting in a suitable Hilbert space F and satisfying
the ﬁeld equation
iℏD0ψ(x) = −ℏ2
2mΔψ(x)
(9.7)
in the sense of operator-valued distribution (x0 = t), i.e.,
ψ(−iℏD0f) = −ℏ2

(9.8)
on a dense subspace in F.
Remark 9.1. In the case of a classical self-interacting de Broglie ﬁeld
u obeying (9.2), a diﬃculty immediately arises in considering a quantum
ﬁeld ψ as an operator-valued distribution corresponding to it because the
products of ψ(x)#, such as ψ(x)∗ψ(x)ψ(x), are mathematically meaningless
unless ψ(x) is an operator-valued function with a suitable property (but,
in the conventional scheme of ﬁeld quantization, ψ(x) is not an operator-
valued function even in the free ﬁeld case). This applies to other models in
QFT too. In fact, the ill-deﬁnedness of the products of a quantum ﬁeld at
each space-time point is an origin of the so-called “divergence problems” in
QFT and makes it diﬃcult to construct an interacting quantum ﬁeld model
with space-time symmetries.
If one follows the canonical quantization formalism,5 then ψ should be
constructed from a sharp-time quantum ﬁeld ψ(t, ·), and for any ﬁxed time
t ∈R, ψ(t, ·) should satisfy canonical commutation relations (a bosonic
case) or canonical anti-commutations relations (a fermionic case)6:
[ψ(t, x), ψ(t, y)∗] = δ(x −y),
[ψ(t, x), ψ(t, y)] = 0,
[ψ(t, x)∗, ψ(t, y)∗] = 0
5For a classical ﬁeld φ(t, x) which has a Lagrangian, the momentum conjugate π(t, x)
to φ(t, x) is deﬁned from the Lagrangian density L (φ, ˙φ) ( ˙φ(t, x) := ∂φ(t, x)/∂t)

The operator

9.4.5
Galilean symmetry
In this section, we discuss the symmetry properties of the free bosonic quan-
tum de Broglie ﬁeld. For this purpose, we ﬁrst introduce a transformation
group which acts on a non-relativistic space-time.
We denote by Md(R) the set of d × d real matrices. The set
O(d) := {R ∈Md(R)|tRR = I}
(9.51)
of d × d orthogonal matrices forms a group with the product operation
of matrices, called the d-dimensional orthogonal group. We introduce the
direct product of O(d), Rd and R1+d:
G1+d := O(d) × Rd × R1+d
= {(R, v, a)|R ∈O(d), v ∈Rd, a ∈R1+d}.
Each (R, v, a) ∈G1+d deﬁnes a mapping on R1+d by
(R, v, a)(x) := (t + a0, Rx + vt + a),
x = (t, x) ∈R1+d,
where a = (a0, a) ∈R × Rd. The mapping (R, v, a) is called a Galilei
transformation on R1+d. Note that the motion R ∋t →Rx + vt is a
uniform motion with velocity v and the initial position being Rx.
It is obvious that
(Id, 0, 0) = I
(identity),
where Id is the d×d unit matrix. It is easy to see that each (R, v, a) ∈G1+d
is a bijection with
(R, v, a)−1 = (R−1, −R−1v, (−a0, −R−1(a −a0v))) ∈G1+d.
(9.52)
Moreover, for all (R, v, a), (T, u, b) ∈G1+d,
(T, u, b)(R, v, a) = (T R, T v + u, (b0 + a0, T a + b + a0u)) ∈G1+d.
Hence, G1+d is a transformation group on R1+d. The transformation group
G1+d is called the (1 + d)-dimensional Galilei group. For g ∈G1+d and
x ∈R1+d, we sometimes write g(x) = gx.
The subset
G hom
1+d := {(R, v, 0)|R ∈O(d), v ∈Rd}
of G1+d forms a subgroup of G1+d. The subgroup G hom
1+d is called the (1 + d)-
dimensional homogeneous Galilei group.
Non-Relativistic QFT
629
A function u : R1+d →C is said to be Galilei invariant (resp.,
homogeneously Galilei invariant) if, for all g ∈G1+d (resp., G hom
1+d ),
u(gx) = u(x), x = (t, x) ∈R1+d.
For each u : R1+d →C, g = (R, v, a) ∈G1+d and a constant C ∈R, one
can deﬁne u(g,C) : R1+d →C by
u(g,C)(t, x) := e−iCθ(t,x,v)u(g(t, x)),
(t, x) ∈R1+d,
where
θ(t, x, v) := v · Rx + 1
2v2t.
The function u(g,C) is called the Galilei transformation of u associated
with (g, C).
We denote by SV,dB the space of solutions to the nonlinear de Broglie
equation (9.2):
SV,dB := {u : R1+d →C|u satisﬁes (9.2)}.
The following theorem tells us how the space SV,dB is transformed under
Galilei transformations.

of the nonlinear de Broglie equation (9.2). In particular, this symmetry
holds in the case of V = 0.

9.4.6
Interaction with an external ﬁeld
In this section, we consider a bosonic quantum de Broglie ﬁeld interacting
with an external ﬁeld. An external scalar ﬁeld is a real-valued Borel mea-
surable function V on Rd such that V (x) is ﬁnite for a.e. x ∈Rd. Then,
the one-boson Hamiltonian is given by the Schr¨odinger operator
hV := −ℏ2
2mΔ + V
acting in L2(Rd). We assume that hV is essentially self-adjoint.8 Then, the
self-adjoint operator hV (the closure of hV ) generates the strongly contin-
uous one-parameter unitary group {eithV /ℏ}t∈R. So as a natural extension
of the free bosonic quantum de Broglie ﬁeld, we deﬁne an operator ψV (t, f)
(t ∈R, f ∈L2(Rd)) by
ψV (t, f) := ψ(eithV /ℏf ∗)
In the same way as in Lemma 9.2, one can prove the following lemma.
Lemma 9.11. For each t ∈R, the mapping S (Rd) ∋f →ψV (t, f) ∈
L(Fb(L2(Rd)) is an operator-valued distribution, with D(N 1/2
b
) being a
common domain.
The boson second quantization operator
HdB(V ) := dΓb(hV )
(9.61)
of hV is self-adjoint. In the same way as in the proof of Theorem 9.1, one
can show that, for all t ∈R and f ∈L2(Rd),
eitHdB(V )/ℏψV (0, f)e−itHdB(V )/ℏ= ψV (t, f)
8For classes of V satisfying this assumption, see, for example, Reed and Simon (1975),
Chapter X.
Non-Relativistic QFT
635
on D(N 1/2
b
). Thus, (Fb(L2(Rd)), D(N 1/2
b
), HdB(V ), {ψV (t, ·)}t∈R) is a
sharp-time QFT.
It follows from the general properties of a boson second quantization
operator that 0 is an eigenvalue of HdB(V ) with the Fock vacuum ΩL2(Rd)
being its eigenvector:
HdB(V )ΩL2(Rd) = 0.
(9.62)
But we note that ΩL2(Rd) is not necessarily a ground state of HdB(V )
because HdB(V ) is not necessarily non-negative.
Proposition 9.2.
(i) If hV ≥0, then HdB(V ) ≥0 and the Fock vacuum ΩL2(Rd) is a ground
state of HdB(V ), with the ground state energy being zero.
(ii) If σ(hV ) ∩(−∞, 0) ̸= ∅, then HdB(V ) is not bounded from below.
Proof. The non-negativity of HdB(V ) in (i) and the unboundedness from
below of HdB(V ) in (ii) follow from an application of Theorem 5.2. The
statement on the ground state of HdB(V ) in (i) follows from (9.62).
□
The ﬁeld equation of ψV (t, f) is formulated in the following theorem.

Proof. Similar to the proof of Theorem 9.2.
□
Remark 9.3. Consider the case where V is continuous except at a ﬁnite
number of points in Rd and not a constant function. Then, ˆpj does not
strongly commute with V .9 Hence, hV and ˆpj do not strongly commute.
Physically, this means that, in the one-boson system under consideration,
the momentum ˆpj (j = 1, 2, . . . , d) is not a conserved quantity. An appli-
cation of Proposition 5.5 yields that each Pb,j does not strongly com-
mute with HdB(V ). Hence, in this quantum system, the joint spectrum
of (HdB(V ), Pb,1, . . . , Pb,d) makes no sense.

jth
t , 0, . . . , 0), t ∈R.

9.5
The Operator-Valued Distribution Kernel of the Boson
Annihilation Operator
In this section, we show that the operator-valued distribution kernel of
the boson annihilation operator ψ(f ∗) (f ∈S (Rd)) on Fb(L2(Rd)) has
meaning as an operator-valued function, and we discuss related topics.
We denote by C((Rd)n) the set of continuous functions on (Rd)n and
introduce a subspace:
DC := {Ψ ∈Fb,0(L2(Rd))|Ψ (n) ∈C((Rd)n), n ≥1},
which is dense in Fb(L2(Rd)). For each x ∈Rd, we deﬁne a linear operator
ψ(x) on Fb(L2(Rd)) as follows:
D(ψ(x)) := DC,
(9.63)
(ψ(x)Ψ)(n)(x1, . . . , xn) :=
√
n + 1Ψ (n+1)(x, x1, . . . , xn),
Ψ ∈D(ψ(x)),
n ≥0,
(9.64)
We call ψ(x) the boson annihilation operator at the point x.
We remark that the domain of ψ(x) is independent of x and, in the
deﬁnition of D(ψ(x)), the condition of continuity of each component Ψ (n)
of Ψ ∈D(ψ(x)) is necessary because the right-hand side of (9.64) has to be
uniquely determined as an equivalence class for each x.10
It is easy to see that ψ(x) is densely deﬁned and leaves DC invariant.
But, as the following proposition shows, the operator ψ(x) is somewhat
singular.

Remark 9.5. Since ψ(x)ψ(y) = ψ(y)ψ(x) on DS for all x, y ∈Rd,
the object ψ(xm)∗. . . ψ(x1)∗(resp., ψ(y1) . . . ψ(yn)) in the above expres-
sions can be replaced by ψ(xσ(1))∗. . . ψ(xσ(m))∗with any σ ∈Sm (resp.,
ψ(yσ(1)) . . . ψ(yσ(n)) with any σ ∈Sn).
We here recall a concept concerning sesquilinear forms on a Hilbert
space. Let H be a Hilbert space and D be a subspace of H . A sesquilinear
form q : D × D →C on D is said to be equal to a linear operator T on
D if D ⊂D(T ) and ⟨ψ, T φ⟩= q(ψ, φ), ψ, φ ∈D. In this case, we write
T = q on D.
In this case, q is said to have an operator representation T .

that the Hamiltonian HdB(V, U) gives a uniﬁcation of the standard
Hamiltonians (Schr¨odinger Hamiltonians) of many-body quantum systems
in non-relativistic quantum mechanics. In this sense, for each n ∈N, the
quantum theory of the n-body system can be viewed as a part of a quantum
de Broglie ﬁeld theory.
Remark 9.7. The ﬁnite volume version of the Hamiltonian HdB(V, U) with
d = 3, V = 0 and a δ-type interaction U(x, y) = gδ(x −y) (g > 0) is used
as a Hamiltonian for superﬂuidity in the physics literature. But, in this
case, HdB(V, U) is not deﬁned as an operator on Fb(L2(VL)), where VL :=
[−L/2, L/2]3 ⊂R3 (L > 0) is the ﬁnite volume set under consideration (see
Section 9.9.1). A way to avoid this diﬃculty is to replace gδ(x −y) with a
suitable function gW(x −y) (see Section 14.2.3) and then to take a limit
W(x) →δ(x) in a suitable sense (e.g., in terms of vacuum expectation
values of the quantum ﬁelds under consideration) to construct a quantum
ﬁeld theory with the δ-type interaction.
Remark 9.8. One can consider the formal Heisenberg ﬁeld operator ψ(t, x)
( (t, x) ∈R1+d) of ψ(x) with respect to HdB(V, U):

9.9
QFT on a Bounded Space Region
So far, we have considered quantum de Broglie ﬁelds on the inﬁnitely
extended space-time R1+d = R × Rd. But one can also consider those on a
bounded space region. In fact, most of the physics literature on QFT begin
Non-Relativistic QFT
657
with a QFT on a ﬁnite box in space and then take the inﬁnite volume limit
to obtain a QFT on R1+d. One of the reasons for adopting such a proce-
dure is that a QFT on R × M, with M ⊂Rd being bounded, may be less
singular, more tractable and also serve as a ﬁnite volume approximation
to a QFT on R × Rd. From a mathematical physics point of view, it may
be interesting to compare a QFT on a bounded space region with that on
R1+d. Taking into account these points of view, we describe in this section
the basic elements of a ﬁnite volume QFT.
9.9.1
QFT on a cubic box
For simplicity, we take as a bounded space region the d-dimensional cubic
box
VL :=

−L
2 , L
2
d
,
(9.87)
with L > 0 being the length of each edge. A Hilbert space of state vec-
tors of a one-particle system on VL with r internal degrees of freedom
(r ∈N) is taken to be L2(VL; Cr). The Fock space Fb(L2(VL; Cr)) (resp.,
Ff(L2(VL; Cr))) gives a framework describing bosonic (resp., fermionic)
QFT models on VL. To avoid unnecessary complexities, we consider a Bose
ﬁeld on VL with r = 1. Moreover, it turns out that it is convenient to
work with the momentum representation, which is deﬁned as follows. The
momentum space dual to VL is given by

Lemma 9.19. Let f ∈C(Rd). Then, for all p ∈Rd, limL→∞fL(p) =
f(p).

ε > 0, there exists a constant δ > 0 such that, if p′ ∈Rd, |p′ −p| < δ,

√

Thus, limL→∞fL(p) = f(p).

as L →∞.
(13) Prove that ˆH(L)

as L →∞.

10.3
Representation Theoretic Aspects
Theorem 10.1 implies in particular that, for each (t, f) ∈R×SR(Rd), φ(t, f)
and π(t, f) are essentially self-adjoint. We denote their closure by φ(t, f)
and π(t, f), respectively, which are self-adjoint. For each t ∈R, we set
ρt := (Fb(L2(Rd)), {φ(t, f), π(t, f)|f ∈SR(Rd)}).
Theorem 10.5.
(i) For each t ∈R, ρt is an irreducible Weyl representation of the CCR
over SR(Rd).
(ii) For each pair (t, s) ∈R × R, ρt is equivalent to ρs.
Proof. (i) We ﬁrst show that ρ0 (the case t = 0) is an irreducible Weyl
representation of the CCR over SR(Rd). Let ˆCd : L2(Rd
k) →L2(Rd
k) be
deﬁned by
( ˆCd ˆf)(k) := ˆf(−k)∗,
ˆf ∈L2(Rd
k).
Then, it is easy to see that ˆCd is a conjugation and Dd := { ˆf|f ∈SR(Rd)}
is a dense subspace of H ˆ
Cd := { ˆf ∈L2(Rd
k)| ˆCd ˆf = ˆf}. Obviously, the
Relativistic Free Quantum Scalar Fields
689
multiplication operator T := √ω is reduced by H ˆ
Cd. We have
φ(0, f) = φF(T −1 ˆf),
π(0, f) = πF(T ˆf).
Moreover, T Dd and T −1Dd are dense in H ˆ
Cd. Thus, we can apply Theorem
5.47 to conclude that ρ0 is an irreducible Weyl representation of the CCR
over SR(Rd).
Theorem 10.2 implies that {eiφ(t,f), eiπ(t,f)|f ∈SR(Rd)} is unitarily
equivalent to {eiφ(0,f), eiπ(0,f)|f ∈SR(Rd)}. By this fact and Proposition
5.10, ρt is an irreducible Weyl representation of the CCR over SR(Rd),
which is equivalent to ρ0.
(ii) By the proof of (i), ρt ∼= ρ0 ∼= ρs (∼= means “equivalent”).
□
Remark 10.1. To make explicit the dependence of ρ0 on the mass m ≥0,
we write ρ(m) := ρ0. It is proved that, if m1 ̸= m2 (m1, m2 ≥0), then ρ(m1)
is inequivalent to ρ(m2) (see Reed and Simon, 1975, Theorem X.46 for the
case of d = 3 and m1, m2 > 0 and Arai, 2016a for the general case; in Arai,
2016a, a general structure behind the fact is clariﬁed). Thus, {ρ(m)}m≥0
is a family of mutually inequivalent irreducible Weyl representations and
the boson masses form its index set. This is an very interesting fact which
clariﬁes the meaning of boson masses.

The results obtained so far on the quantum ﬁeld φ show that the

Theorem 10.11 shows that (GW.5) holds in the present model.
10.10
Commutation Relations and Microscopic Causality
In this section, we prove that, in the case of the 4-dimensional space-time
(d = 3), the free neutral quantum KG ﬁeld φ satisﬁes the microscopic
causality (GW.4) in the G˚arding–Wightman axioms. In this way, it is shown
that the present model with d = 3 satisﬁes all of the G˚arding–Wightman
axioms. In fact, this holds in any dimensional space-time (d ≥2 in the
massless case m = 0). We will touch on this point in the following section.

Example 10.2. It is easy to see that

Remark 10.6. The divergence seen in the above example is an elementary
example of the so-called ultraviolet divergences in QFT. This kind of
divergence comes from treating a mathematically meaningless object, such
as φ(x)n (n ≥2), which is used to “deﬁne” an interaction of a quantum ﬁeld
at the space-time point x. The problem of ultraviolet divergences in QFT is
not yet solved mathematically with full generality, although algorithms to
obtain ﬁnite results in QFT models in terms of formal perturbation theory
have been established as “renormalization theory.” To construct in a non-
perturbative way a non-trivial model of relativistic QFT without ultraviolet
cutoﬀs in the four-dimensional Minkowski space-time is still one of the most
important challenges in modern mathematical physics.

10.16
Charged Quantum Scalar Field
In this section, we describe an outline of a method to construct a quantum
ﬁeld version of a complex scalar ﬁeld (a classical ﬁeld with values in C) φcl
satisfying the free KG equation (10.1). For the basic aspects of a complex
scalar ﬁeld theory, see Problem 14 (this may be helpful to understand the
method described as follows).
10.16.1
Heuristic arguments
A general form of a complex scalar ﬁeld φcl(x) satisfying (10.1) is given by
φcl(x) =

Rd dk
1

2(2π)dω(k)

acl
−(k)
∗eiω(k)t−ik·x + acl
+(k)e−iω(k)t+ik·x
,
(10.86)
where acl
± are functions with suitable properties. Note that, in contrast to
the case of the real scalar ﬁeld, two independent functions, acl
±, appear here.
To obtain a quantum version of the complex ﬁeld φcl, one needs only to
replace the functions acl
± by the operator-valued distributions a±(k) satis-
fying the CCR
[a±(k), a±(k′)∗] = δ(k −k′),
[a±(k), a±(k′)] = 0,
[a+(k), a−(k′)∗] = 0,
[a+(k), a−(k′)] = 0.
Hence, two kinds of annihilation operators, a±(k), are needed. Therefore, a
quantum ﬁeld corresponding to the classical ﬁeld φcl is supposed to describe
two kinds of elementary particles. It turns out that these two kinds of ele-
mentary particles are interpreted as charged particles which have the same
mass but diﬀerent signs of charge.9 As is well known, to each elementary
9For detailed physical discussions, see, for example, Bjorken and Drell (1965),
Section 12.5.
Relativistic Free Quantum Scalar Fields
731
particle, there corresponds an elementary particle, called its anti-particle,
which has the same mass, the same spin and the same life time but a dif-
ferent sign as for electromagnetic properties. Therefore, the quantum ﬁeld
corresponding to the complex classical ﬁeld φcl is interpreted to describe a
charged particle and its anti-particle with spin 0.
Let H+ be a Hilbert space of state vectors of a charged particle with
spin 0 and H−be that of its anti-particle. From a quantum ﬁeld theoretical
point of view, a particle and its anti-particle are not separated but two
appearances of one entity. This one entity is nothing but a pair of a particle
and an anti-particle. Hence, it is natural to take the direct sum Hilbert space
H1 = H+ ⊕H−
as a one-particle Hilbert space of the quantum ﬁeld to be constructed. Then,
it is expected that the theory of the boson Fock space Fb(H1) over H1 can
be used to construct the desired quantum ﬁeld theory.
10.16.2
Outline of a mathematically rigorous construction
Based on the heuristic arguments in the preceding section, we now give an
outline of a mathematically rigorous construction of a charged quantum
scalar ﬁeld.
(1) Creation and annihilation operators
The choice of the Hilbert spaces H+ and H−may be arbitrary in an
abstract level. However, to be parallel to the theory of the free neutral
quantum KG ﬁeld, we take H± = L2(Rd
k) so that
H1 = L2(Rd
k) ⊕L2(Rd
k) = {(f, g)|f, g ∈L2(Rd
k)}.
We denote by a(f, g) the annihilation operator on the boson Fock space
Fb(H1) with test vector (f, g) ∈H1. This operator yields two operators:
a+(f) := a(f, 0),
a−(f) := a(0, f),
f ∈L2(Rd
k).
We call a+(f) (resp., a−(f)) the annihilation operator of the particle
(resp., anti-particle) with test vector f. The adjoint a+(f)∗(resp.,
a−(f)∗) is called the creation
operator
of
the
particle (resp.,
anti-particle) with test vector f. As is easily seen, the following

commutation relations hold on Fb,0(H1): for all f, g ∈L2(Rd

[a±(f), a±(g)∗] = ⟨f, g⟩,
[a±(f), a±(g)] = 0,
(10.87)
[a+(f), a−(g)] = 0,
, [a+(f), a−(g)∗] = 0.
(10.88)
We denote by Nb the number operator on Hb(H1).

(5) The total charge operator
In the theory of a charged quantum ﬁeld, a new object, called a charge
operator, appears.10 Let q ∈R \ {0} be the charge of the quantum particle
10For the classical counterpart, see Problem 14.
734
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
under consideration. Then, the operator qI ⊕(−qI) on H1 satisﬁes
qI ⊕(−qI)(f, 0) = q(f, 0),
f ∈H+,
qI ⊕(−qI)(0, g) = −q(0, g),
g ∈H−.
Hence, H+ is the eigenspace of qI ⊕(−qI) with eigenvalue +q and H−is
the eigenspace of qI ⊕(−qI) with eigenvalue −q (the charge of the anti-
particle). For this reason, qI ⊕(−qI) is called the charge operator on
the one-particle space H1.
The second quantization
Q := dΓb(qI ⊕(−qI)) = q dΓb(I ⊕(−I))
of the charge operator qI ⊕(−qI) is called the total charge operator on
Fb(H1). We have
QΩH1 = 0,
where ΩH1 = {1, 0, 0, . . .} is the Fock vacuum in Fb(H1).
It is easy to see that
Q = qdΓb(I ⊕0) −qdΓb(0 ⊕I).
on Fb,0(H1). Hence, by Theorem 5.18, the following commutation relations
hold on Fb,0(H1):
[Q, a+(f)∗] = qa+(f)∗,
[Q, a−(f)∗] = −qa−(f)∗,
f ∈L2(Rd
k).
Therefore, for all vectors of the form
Ψn+,n−:= a+(f1)∗· · · a+(fn+)∗a−(g1)∗· · · a−(gn−)∗ΩH1
(n± ∈Z+, fj ∈H+, gi ∈H−), which represents a state vector consisting
of n+ particles and n−anti-particles, we have
QΨn+,n−= (n+ −n−)qΨn+,n−.
Note that (n+ −n−)q is the total charge of the state Ψn+,n−.
Let
N+ := dΓb(I ⊕0),
N−:= dΓb(0 ⊕I).
Then,
Nb = N+ + N−.

10.17
Finite Volume Approximations and Inﬁnite

It is easily seen that, even in the case of the free quantum KG ﬁeld theories
studied in this chapter, the methods of the ﬁnite volume approximations
discussed in Section 9.9 are valid without essential changes; only the one-
particle Hamiltonian takes a diﬀerent form from that of the one-particle
Hamiltonian ENR (in the momentum representation) of the free quantum
de Broglie ﬁeld. In this section, we only give a result on the inﬁnite volume
limit of the Hamiltonian of the free neutral quantum KG ﬁeld in the ﬁnite
volume approximation.

Chapter 11
Quantum Theory of

11.1
Classical Theory of Electromagnetic Fields
11.1.1
The Maxwell equations and gauge invariance
As is well known, most macroscopic electromagnetic phenomena are
explained by the theory of electromagnetism established by Maxwell.
A basic object in this theory is the pair (E, B) of an electric ﬁeld E =
(E1, E2, E3) : M4 →R3 and a magnetic ﬁeld B = (B1, B2, B3) : M4 →R3
on the four-dimensional Minkowski space-time M4 = {x = (ct, x)|t ∈R,
x ∈R3} (where c is the speed of light in a vacuum), obeying the Maxwell
equations:
(M.1)
div E = ϱ
ε0
,
(M.2)
rot E = −∂tB,
(M.3)
div B = 0,
(M.4)
rot B =
j
c2ε0
+ 1
c2 ∂tE,
where div u := 3
j=1 ∂juj (the spatial divergence of u = (u1, u2, u3) :
M4 →R3), rot u := (∂2u3 −∂3u2, ∂3u1 −∂1u3, ∂1u2 −∂2u1) (the spatial
rotation of u), j = (j1, j2, j3) : M4 →R3 denotes a current density, ϱ :
M4 →R denotes a charge density and ε0 is the dielectric constant in the
vacuum. Here, we use the MKSA unit system.
Henceforth, we move to the unit system with c = 1. It follows from a
basic theorem in vector analysis (the Poincar´e lemma) that (M.3) implies
the existence of a vector ﬁeld A = (A1, A2, A3) : M4 →R3 such that
B = rot A.
(11.1)
747
748
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
The vector ﬁeld A is called a vector potential. Substituting (11.1) for
(M.2), we have rot (E + ∂tA) = 0. Hence, there exists a scalar ﬁeld φ :
M4 →R such that E + ∂tA = −∇φ, i.e.,
E = −∂tA −∇φ,
(11.2)
where ∇:= (∂1, ∂2, ∂3). The scalar ﬁeld φ is called a scalar potential.
The pair
A := (φ, A)
is called an electromagnetic potential, or a gauge potential.1
We have from (11.2) and (M.1) that
−Δφ(x) −div ∂tA(x) = ϱ(x)
ε0
,
(11.3)
where Δ := div ∇= 3
j=1 ∂2
j (a three-dimensional Laplacian). On the
other hand, (11.1), (11.2), and (M.4) give
□A(x) + ∇(∂tφ(x) + div A(x)) = j(x)
ε0
,
(11.4)
where □:= ∂2
t −Δ (a four-dimensional d’Alembertian).
Conversely, for any vector ﬁeld A = (φ, A) : M4 →M4 satisfying (11.3)
and (11.4), the vector ﬁelds B and E deﬁned by (11.1) and (11.2) satisfy
the Maxwell equations (M.1)–(M.4).
Thus, the electromagnetic theory is essentially equivalent to the theory
on vector ﬁelds A obeying (11.3) and (11.4).
11.1.2
A diﬃculty in constructing a quantum
electromagnetic ﬁeld
In constructing a quantum version of the classical electromagnetic theory,
i.e., a quantum electromagnetic ﬁeld theory, one encounters some diﬃculty
in contrast to the case of a de Broglie ﬁeld or a scalar ﬁeld. One of the
reasons is that the components of the electromagnetic ﬁeld (E, B) are not
independent, being mutually related through the Maxwell equations, even
in the case of j = 0 and ϱ = 0 (where there exist no currents and no
charges). So, it may be natural to try to ﬁnd a quantum version (or a
“quantized” version) of the electromagnetic potential A rather than the
electromagnetic ﬁeld (E, B). If this can be done, then one may automati-
cally obtain a quantum version of (E, B) through (11.1) and (11.2).
1In strict terms, A is the 1-form φdx0 + 3
j=1 Ajdxj.
Quantum Theory of Electromagnetic Fields
749
As is seen from (11.3) and (11.4), the components of A are not indepen-
dent mutually. However, by making use of some invariance in the theory,
the dependence among the components of the electromagnetic potential A
can be expressed in a simple form, as shown in the following. This invari-
ance is associated with the non-uniqueness of electromagnetic potentials
which yield the same electromagnetic ﬁeld (E, B). Indeed, it is easy to see
that, for any diﬀerentiable function Λ on M4, the electromagnetic potential
A′ = (φ′, A′) deﬁned by
A′ = A + ∇Λ,
φ′ = φ −∂tΛ
(11.5)
gives the same electromagnetic ﬁeld (E, B) as that derived from A and
obeys (11.3) and (11.4), with A replaced by A′.
The correspondence
GΛ : A →A′,
A′ := GΛ(A)
is called the gauge transformation associated with Λ. The function Λ,
which deﬁnes this transformation, is called a gauge function, or simply
a gauge. Thus, the electromagnetic theory is invariant under gauge trans-
formations. This property is called gauge invariance.
By a gauge transformation, the ﬁeld equations (11.3) and (11.4) may
be converted into simpler forms. Specifying a gauge is called gauge ﬁxing.
Here, we give two examples.
(A) Coulomb gauge
Let us ﬁnd a gauge function Λ0 such that A′ = GΛ0(A) and div A′ = 0.
This condition is equivalent to
ΔΛ0 = −div A.
(11.6)
Hence, for each t ∈R, Λ0(t, ·) should be a solution to a three-dimensional
Poisson equation. By Example D.15 in Appendix D,
Λ0(t, x) :=

R3
div A(t, y)
4π|x −y| dy,
(t, x) ∈M4
is a solution to (11.6) under a suitable condition for div A. Thus, for such a
vector potential A, we have div A′ = 0, i.e., A′ is divergence-free. Thus, we
have seen that, for a suitable class of vector potentials, it is always possible,
through a gauge transformation, to bring any element in the class to a vector
potential which is divergence-free. In the case where a vector potential is
750
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
divergence-free, one says that the Coulomb gauge, or radiation gauge,
is taken.
(B) Lorenz gauge
One can also consider an electromagnetic potential A satisfying the Lorenz
condition2
∂tφ + div A = 0
(see Problem 1). In this case, one says that the Lorenz gauge is taken. In
relativistic notation, this condition is written as
∂μ Aμ = 0,
where A = ( Aμ)3
μ=0 := (φ, −A1, −A2, −A3) (hence, Aj = Aj, j = 1, 2, 3).
Hence, the Lorenz condition is relativistically invariant.

11.3
Quantum Radiation Field
We are now ready to construct a quantum version of an electromagnetic
vector potential in the Coulomb gauge. The construction can be done in
the same way as in the case of a free de Broglie ﬁeld or a free KG ﬁeld.
Namely, we deﬁne an operator-valued distribution a(r)(f ∗) (f ∈S (R3),
r = 1, 2) acting in a Hilbert space H such that its operator-valued distri-

[a(r)(k), a(s)(k′)∗] = δrsδ(k −k′),

11.6
Quantum Electromagnetic Fields
In correspondence to formulae (11.1) and (11.2) in the classical theory, it is
natural to deﬁne a quantum electric ﬁeld E(f) = (E1(f), E2(f), E3(f))
and a quantum magnetic ﬁeld B(f) = (B1(f), B2(f), B3(f)) with f ∈
S (R1+d) as follows:
Ej(f) := Aj(∂tf),
B1(f) := A2(∂3f) −A3(∂2f),
B2(f) := A3(∂1f) −A1(∂3f),
B3(f) := A1(∂2f) −A2(∂1f),
where (11.11) is taken into account to deﬁne Ej(f). According to
Theorem 11.1(iv), we have
Ej(□f) = 0,
Bj(□f) = 0
(j = 1, 2, 3)
on D(N 1/2
rad ). Namely, Ej and Bj obey the d’Alembert equation in the sense
of distribution. Moreover, Theorem 11.1(v) implies that
3

Ej(∂jf) = 0
on D(N 1/2
rad ).

11.8
Canonical Conjugate Field
In the classical theory of electromagnetic ﬁelds, the canonical conjugate
momentum (ﬁeld) of the electromagnetic vector potential is given by its
time derivative. Hence, in quantum theory too, it may be natural to
deﬁne the canonical conjugate momentum operator as the time derivative
of the sharp-time free quantum radiation ﬁeld. Noting (11.33), we deﬁne
the canonical conjugate ﬁeld, or canonical conjugate momentum,

11.9
Hamiltonian and Momentum Operator
The function ωph gives the self-adjoint operator
hrad := ⊕d−1ωph
acting in E (the right-hand side is a direct sum operator). The boson second
quantization
Hrad := dΓb(hrad)
(11.34)
of hrad is called the Hamiltonian of the free quantum radiation ﬁeld.
Indeed, we have the following theorem.

The momentum operator of the free quantum radiation ﬁeld
(Prad,1, . . . , Prad,d) is deﬁned by

Prad := (Hrad, Prad,1, . . . , Prad,d)

Applying Theorem 5.3, we obtain the following results on the spectra
of Hrad and Prad,j:
σ(Hrad) = [0, ∞),
σp(Hrad) = {0},
σ(Prad,j) = R,
σp(Prad,j) = {0}, j = 1, . . . , d,
where ker Hrad = ker Prad,j = {αΩE |α ∈C}. In particular, the ground state
of Hrad is unique, with the ground-state energy being zero.
Note that the eigenvalue 0 of Hrad is an embedded eigenvalue (an eigen-
value embedded in the continuous spectrum). This comes from the fact that
the mass of a photon is zero.
The energy–momentum spectrum of the free quantum radiation ﬁeld
(the joint spectrum of Prad) is found to be
σJ(Prad) = V +.
The method of proof is similar to that of Theorem 10.9.

Chapter 12
Free Quantum Dirac Field
As a basic example of fermionic relativistic quantum ﬁelds, we describe a quantum
ﬁeld of a free relativistic charged particle with spin 1/2.
12.1
Classical Theory of the Free Dirac Field
A relativistic charged particle with spin 1/2 (e.g., electron, proton, . . .)
is called a Dirac particle. In this chapter, we describe a mathematical
construction of the quantum ﬁeld whose quanta are free identical Dirac
particles. This quantum ﬁeld is called the free quantum Dirac ﬁeld. But
we ﬁrst discuss the classical free Dirac ﬁeld.
12.1.1

A set {γμ ∈M4(C)|μ = 0, 1, 2, 3} of 4 × 4 complex matrices is called a
representation of the gamma (γ)-matrices associated with M4 if they
satisfy anti-commutation relations
{γμ, γν} = 2gμνI4, μ, ν = 0, 1, 2, 3,
(12.1)
where {X, Y } := XY + Y X, and (γ0)∗= γ0 (Hermiteness), (γj)∗= −γj,
j = 1, 2, 3 (anti-Hermiteness).
Remark 12.1. The algebra generated by elements θμ, μ = 0, 1, 2, 3, with
unit element I satisfying {θμ, θν} = 2gμνI (μ, ν = 0, 1, 2, 3) is called the
Cliﬀord algebra associated with M4. Precisely, {γμ ∈M4(C)|μ = 0,
1, 2, 3} should be called a representation of the algebra. But we follow the
convention in the physics literature.

A non-zero solution ψ : M4 →C4 to (12.7) (ψ ̸= 0) is called a free
classical Dirac ﬁeld, or a free Dirac spinor. This physically describes
a classical matter ﬁeld (matter wave) associated with a free Dirac particle
of mass M. A free classical Dirac ﬁeld with M > 0 (resp., M = 0) is said
to be massive (resp., massless).

12.1.3
Discrete symmetries in the free Dirac equation
As is shown later (Section 12.1.5), the free Dirac equation has a relativistic
symmetry. But, before discussing it, it may be instructive to study discrete
symmetries of the free Dirac equation with respect to space inversion, charge
conjugation and time reversal.
Let I0 and Is be the time reversal and space inversion on R1+3, respec-
tively (see (8.75) and (8.76)) and C be a 4 × 4-matrix satisfying
CγμC−1 = −γμ,
μ = 0, 1, 2, 3,
(12.12)
where, for a matrix T , T denotes the complex conjugate of T . In the Weyl
representation of the γ-matrices, a choice of C is given by
C = −iγ2.
We also need a matrix
γ5 := iγ0γ1γ2γ3
(12.13)
to deﬁne a transformation of a C4-valued function on M4. The matrix γ5
is called the chiral operator in the context of the theory of Dirac ﬁelds.

γ5 = −iα1α2α3.
(12.14)

R4 →C4 as follows:

ψs(x) := γ0ψ(Isx),
(12.15)

Theorem 12.1 (P, C, T symmetries). Suppose that ψ is a solution to
the free Dirac equation (12.7). Then, for # = s, c, t, ψ# is a solution to the
free Dirac equation.
Proof. We have
∂0ψs(x) = γ0(∂0ψ)(Isx), ∂jψs(x) = −γ0(∂jψ)(Isx).
Hence, using γjγ0 = −γ0γj, we have
iγμ∂μψs(x) = γ0(iγμ∂μψ)(Isx) = γ0Mψ(Isx) = Mψs(x).
Therefore, ψs satisﬁes (12.7).

{γ5, γμ} = 0,

(12.18)

12.1.4
The special linear group SL(2, C) and the
four-dimensional proper Lorentz group
A free Dirac ﬁeld has a kind of relativistic covariance. This section is devoted
to a preliminary to formulate it.
We denote by SL(2, C) the set of 2 × 2 complex matrices whose deter-
minant is 1:
SL(2, C) := {A ∈M2(C)| det A = 1}.
It is easy to see that SL(2, C) forms a group with the operation of matrix
multiplication (see Appendix F). This group is called the complex special
linear group of degree 2. A vector in a two-dimensional representation
space of SL(2, C) is called a spinor.
For matrices T, S ∈M2(C), we deﬁne ⟨T, S⟩∈C by
⟨T, S⟩:= Tr (T ∗S),
where Tr denotes a trace. It is easy to check that this ⟨· , · ⟩is an inner
product of M2(C) and M2(C) becomes a four-dimensional complex Hilbert
space with the inner product. For notational simplicity, we denote this
Hilbert space by the same symbol M2(C) again.
Free Quantum Dirac Field
783
Lemma 12.3.
Tr (σμσν) = 2δμν,
μ, ν = 0, 1, 2, 3.
(12.19)
Proof. Since σμσμ = σ0, for each μ, Tr (σμσμ) = 2. Hence, (12.19) holds
for μ = ν.
In the case where μ = 0 and ν ̸= 0, we have Tr (σμσν) = Tr σν = 0.
In the case where j ̸= k, j, k = 1, 2, 3, using the anti-commutation rela-
tions {σj, σk} = 0, we have Tr (σjσk) = −Tr (σkσj). By the symmetry of
trace, the right-hand side is equal to −Tr (σjσk). Hence, Tr (σjσk) = 0.
□
Relation (12.19) shows that {σμ/

2(Λ(A)x)μ = xνTr (σμAσνA∗).
This holds for all x ∈M4. Hence,
Λ(A)μ
ν = 1
2Tr (σμAσνA∗), μ, ν = 0, 1, 2, 3.
(12.25)
It follows from (12.25) that Λ(A) is a continuous function of A. Note
that
Λ(I2) = I4.
(12.26)
On the other hand, SL(2, C) is simply connected (see, for example,
Yamanouchi and Sugiura, 1960, p. 142, Example 1). Hence, Λ(A) is an
element of L ↑
+, the four-dimensional proper Lorentz group. Thus, the cor-
respondence A 	→Λ(A) deﬁnes a mapping Λ(·) from SL(2, C) to L ↑
+. This
mapping has interesting properties.
Lemma 12.5.
(i) (homomorphism) For all A, B ∈SL(2, C).
Λ(AB) = Λ(A)Λ(B).
(12.27)
(ii) Let A, B ∈SL(2, C). Then, Λ(A) = Λ(B) if and only if A = B or
A = −B.
Free Quantum Dirac Field
785
Proof. (i) For all x ∈M4,
h(Λ(AB)x) = ABh(x)B∗A∗= Ah(Λ(B)x)A∗= h(Λ(A)Λ(B)x).
By this fact and the injectivity of h, Λ(AB)x = Λ(A)Λ(B)x, which implies
(12.27).
(ii) Suppose that Λ(A) = Λ(B). Then, for all x ∈M4, Ah(x)A∗=
Bh(x)B∗. This means that AσμA∗= BσμB∗, μ = 0, 1, 2, 3. Hence, the
matrix T := A−1B, which is in SL(2, C), satisﬁes T σμT ∗= σμ. This equa-
tion with μ = 0 implies that T is unitary. Hence, it follows that T σj = σjT ,
j = 1, 2, 3. It is easy to see that such a matrix T is a scalar matrix, i.e.,
T = λI2, for some constant λ ∈C. Since det T = 1, it follows that λ = ±1.
Hence, A = B or A = −B.
Conversely, suppose that A = ±B. Then, it immediately follows from
the deﬁnition of Λ(·) that Λ(A) = Λ(B).
□
Lemma 12.5(i) and (12.25) show that Λ : SL(2, C) →L ↑
+ is a continuous
representation of SL(2, C) on M4 (for terminologies in group theory, see
Section 2.9.2). Lemma 12.5(ii) means that N(Λ), the kernel of Λ, is {±I2}.
Namely, Λ is a two to one homomorphism from SL(2, C) to L ↑
+. Moreover,
the following fact is found.
Lemma 12.6. The homomorphism Λ is surjective: Λ(SL(2, C)) = L ↑
+.
Proof. Let sl(2, C) be the Lie algebra of SL(2, C) (see Example F.2 in
Appendix F) and g = l↑
+ be the Lie algebra of L ↑
+ (see Section 8.10.4). Then,
the diﬀerential representation dΛ of Λ (see Section F.2 in Appendix F) is a
homomorphism from sl(2, C) to g. Since N(Λ) = {±I2}, it follows that the
Lie algebra of N(Λ) is {0}. Hence, by Theorem F.2, ker dΛ = {0}. Hence,
dΛ is injective. It is easy to see that, as a real vector space, sl(2, C) is six-
dimensional. Also, dim g = 6 (apply Proposition 8.6 to the case d = 3).
Hence, dΛ is a bijection.
On the other hand, since L ↑
+ is connected, it follows from Theorem F.1
that any L ∈L ↑
+ is written in the form L = eX1 · · · eXN, with Xj ∈g.
So, taking Yj ∈sl(2, C) such that Xj = dΛ(Yj), we have L = Λ(A) with
A := eY1 · · · eYN ∈SL(2, C). Thus, Λ is surjective.
□
Remark 12.2. Another (direct) proof of Lemma 12.6 may be given by
showing that, for any Λ ∈L ↑
+, there exists an A ∈SL(2, C) satisfying
Λμ
ν = 1
2Tr (σμAσνA∗),
μ, ν = 0, 1, 2, 3.
(12.28)
786
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
See (12.25). Equation (12.28) is equivalent to a system of equations for the
matrix elements of A, which is explicitly solved.
Remark 12.3. A continuous mapping f from an arc-wise connected
topological space 
X onto a topological space X is called a covering map
if, for each point x ∈X , there exists an open neighborhood Vx such that
f is a homeomorphism from each connected component of f −1(Vx) onto
Vx. If such a mapping f exists, then 
X is called a covering space of X .
If X and 
X are topological groups and f is a homomorphism, then 
X is
called a covering group of X . In particular, if the group 
X is simply
connected, then 
X is called a universal covering group of X .
In terms of these concepts, the above results show that the mapping
Λ : SL(2, C) →L ↑
+ is a covering map and SL(2, C) is a universal covering
group of L ↑
+.
By Lemma 12.5, for any representation (λ, V ) of L ↑
+ (V
is a
representation space), there exists a representation (ρ, V ) of SL(2, C)
such that
ρ(A) = λ(Λ(A)),
A ∈SL(2, C).
But this representation is not faithful because ρ(A) = ρ(−A), for all A ∈
SL(2, C).
Conversely, suppose that a representation (ρ, V ) of SL(2, C) is given
with ρ(−I2) = IV . By Lemma 12.6, for each g ∈L ↑
+, there exists an Ag ∈
SL(2, C) such that Λ(±Ag) = g. We have ρ(−Ag) = ρ(−I2)ρ(Ag) = ρ(Ag).
Hence, one can deﬁne λ : L ↑
+ →GL(V ) by
λ(g) := ρ(Ag),
g ∈L ↑
+.
It follows that (λ, V ) is a representation of L ↑
+. Thus, the analysis of
representations of L ↑
+ can be reduced to the analysis of those of SL(2, C).
In this sense, SL(2, C) may be a more fundamental group.
Remark 12.4. In the case where ρ(−I2) ̸= IV , ρ(−Ag) ̸= ρ(Ag). Hence,
in this case, there is a correspondence: g 	→ρ(Ag) or ρ(−Ag). This
correspondence is called the double-valued representation of L ↑
+.

12.2
Parities and a Massless Dirac Field
In this section, we want to add a remark on the matrix γ5. We denote by
Map(M4, C4) the set of mappings from M4 to C4.
12.2.1
A space-inversion operator
Let ψs be the space inversion of ψ ∈Map(M4, C4) (see (12.15)), and deﬁne
a mapping Vs on Map(M4, C4) by
Vsψ := ψs.
Then,
V 2
s = I,
Vs ̸= ±I.
Hence, Vs has eigenvalues ±1, with
ker(Vs ∓1) = {ψ ∈Map(M4, C4)|γ0ψ(Isx) = ±ψ(x), ∀x ∈M4}.
For any ψ ∈Map(M4, C4), one has
ψ = ψ+ + ψ−,
with ψ± := (1 ± Vs)ψ/2 ∈ker(Vs ∓1). Hence,
Map(M4, C4) = ker(Vs −1) ⊕ker(Vs + 1).
We call Vs the space-inversion operator on Map(M4, C4).
The eigenvalue 1 (resp., −1) of Vs is called the even (resp., odd) parity.
An element of ker(Vs −1) (resp., ker(Vs + 1)) is said to have even (resp.,
odd) parity. Since {γ5, γ0} = 0, it follows that
γ5Vs = −Vsγ5.
(12.107)
This means that γ5 ker(Vs ±1) = ker(Vs ∓1), i.e., γ5 transforms a ﬁeld with
even (resp., odd) parity to a ﬁeld with odd (resp., even) parity.
12.2.2
Left-handed and right-handed ﬁelds
Let
PL := 1 −γ5
2
,
PR := 1 + γ5
2
.
Then, it is easy to see that PL and PR are orthogonal projections onto
ker(γ5 + 1) and ker(γ5 −1), respectively, and
PL + PR = I.
Free Quantum Dirac Field
805
Hence, each ψ : M4 →C4 can be decomposed as
ψ = ψL + ψR,
with ψL := PLψ and ψR := PRψ.
By (12.107), one has
VsPL = PRVs.
This means that the role of PL and PR exchanges under the transformation
by the space-inversion operator Vs. For this reason, ψL (resp., ψR) is called
the left-handed (resp., right-handed) component of ψ.2
A non-zero mapping ψ ∈Map(M4, C4) is said to be left-handed (resp.,
right-handed) if ψR = 0 (resp., ψL = 0).
Proposition 12.2. Suppose that ψ is a free Dirac ﬁeld. Then,
iγμ∂μψL −MψR = 0,
iγμ∂μψR −MψL = 0.
(12.108)
Proof. By (12.18), γ5ψ obeys the equation
iγμ∂μγ5ψ + Mγ5ψ = 0.
By subtracting (resp., adding) this equation from (resp., to) (12.7), we
obtain the ﬁrst (resp., second) equation in (12.108).
□
This proposition implies an interesting fact.
Corollary 12.2. There is no left-handed or right-handed massive free Dirac
ﬁeld.
Proof. Let ψ be a massive free Dirac ﬁeld such that ψR = 0. Then, by
the second equation of (12.108), MψL = 0. Since M > 0, ψL = 0. Hence,
ψ = 0. Therefore, there is no left-handed massive free Dirac ﬁeld. Similarly,
one can show that, if ψL = 0, then ψ = 0.
□
By this corollary, left-handed or right-handed free Dirac ﬁelds can exist
only in the massless case, M = 0. Hence, we next consider the massless
case.

12.3.2
Heuristic arguments
If one replaces the functions bcl

−(−k, s)) in the classical free
Dirac ﬁeld ψcl(t, x), given by (12.106), with an operator-valued distribution

{b(k, s), b(k′, s′)∗} = δss′δ(k −k′),
(12.110)
{d(k, s), d(k′, s′)∗} = δss′δ(k −k′),
(12.111)
{b(k, s), b(k′, s′)} = {d(k, s), d(k′, s′)} = 0,
(12.112)
{b(k, s), d(k′, s′)} = {b(k, s), d(k′, s′)∗} = 0,
(12.113)
in the sense of operator-valued distributions (k, k′ ∈R3, s, s′ = ±1/2),
then one has heuristically an object

s=±1/2

which may be expected to be the operator-valued distribution kernel of
a free quantum Dirac ﬁeld. Indeed, it is easily seen that ψ(t, x) formally
satisﬁes the above properties (D.1) and (D.2). With this scheme of heuris-
tics, we show in the following that there certainly exists an operator-valued
distribution whose kernel has the form ψ(t, x) given by (12.114).

12.5
Total Charge Operator
Corresponding to the classical total charge Qcl given by (12.56), the total

It is obvious that QD is self-adjoint and strongly commutes with HD and
PD,j (j = 1, 2, 3).

N−:= dΓf(0 ⊕I),
(12.152)
we have

(12.153)
on D(N+) ∩D(N−).
Let n, m ≥0, fj, gℓ∈L2(R3), sj, tℓ= ±1/2 (j = 1, . . . , n, ℓ= 1, . . . , m)
and

N−Ψ (n,m) = mΨ (n,m).
Hence,
QDΨ (n,m) = q(n −m)Ψ (n,m).
Free Quantum Dirac Field
821
Therefore, Ψ (n,m) can be interpreted as a state vector consisting of
n Dirac particles and m anti-Dirac particles (note that the charge of an
anti-Dirac particle is −q). The operator N+ (resp., N−) counts the number
of Dirac (resp., anti-Dirac) particles in the state Ψ (n,m). Hence, N+ (resp.,
N−) is called the number operator for Dirac (resp., anti-Dirac) particles.
The one-particle space

statement of the charge conservation law in the system of the free quantum
Dirac ﬁeld.

Chapter 13
Van Hove–Miyatake Model
A model of a quantum scalar ﬁeld interacting with a ﬁxed external source is
analyzed in detail.
13.1
Introduction
We have constructed a free quantum scalar ﬁeld in Chapter 10. But this
model does not describe any interactions of elementary particles. In this
chapter, we construct a model of a quantum scalar ﬁeld interacting with a
ﬁxed external ﬁeld (source). This model is one of the simplest interacting
models in QFT, but it serves as a prototypical model in QFT in the sense
that it exhibits interesting features of models in QFT. For a comprehen-
sive understanding of the model, we ﬁrst look at its classical ﬁeld version.
Throughout this chapter, we use the physical unit system where c = 1
and ℏ= 1.
Let ϱ be a real tempered distribution on Rd, and consider the partial
diﬀerential equation
(□+ m2)ϕ(x) = ϱ(x),
x = (t, x) ∈R × Rd,
(13.1)
for a real scalar ﬁeld ϕ : R1+d →R. Physically, the distribution ϱ is inter-
preted as a given static source or static external ﬁeld (“static” means “time
independent”) and ϕ is a scalar ﬁeld generated by ϱ obeying (13.1). The
case d = 3 is the physical case in the conventional sense.
The Lagrangian which leads to the ﬁeld equation is given by
Lcl = 1
2

Rd dx

(∂tϕ(x))2 −|∇ϕ(x)|2 −m2ϕ(x)2

+

Rd dxϱ(x)ϕ(x).
835

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Hence, the classical Hamiltonian takes the form
Hcl(t) = 1
2

Rd dx

π(t, x)2 + |∇ϕ(t, x)|2 + m2ϕ(t, x)2

−


(13.2)
where π = ∂tϕ. As is easily seen, Hcl is independent of t (Problem 2).
Namely, the total energy of the ﬁeld is conserved. Hence, Hcl is written in
terms of the time-zero ﬁelds ϕ(0, x) and π(0, x):
Hcl(t) = Hcl(0)
= 1

(13.3)
This model describes an interaction between a classical scalar ﬁeld and
a classical source. But it has no relativistic symmetry, i.e., it is a non-
relativistic model (Problem 1).
The quantum ﬁeld theoretical version of the above classical ﬁeld model
with ϱ ̸= 0 is called the ﬁxed source model, or the van Hove–Miyatake
(vHM) model, with mass m and source ϱ van Hove (1952) and Miyatake
(1952a, 1952b) (usually, this model is called the van Hove model).
In the context of classical ﬁeld theory with d = 3, the tempered distri-
bution ϱ denotes the density of the distribution of nucleons in the space R3,
and ϕ is the ﬁeld of the nuclear force that ϱ generates. According to the
meson theory by Hideki Yukawa, the nuclear force comes from the exchange
of mesons. Hence, in quantum theory, the ﬁeld of nuclear force is described
by the quantum meson ﬁeld.

13.2
A Realization of the vHM Model
As mentioned above, the classical Hamiltonian Hcl(t) is independent of
time t. Hence, the Hamiltonian of the corresponding quantum ﬁeld model
may be deﬁned by replacing ϕ(0, x) and π(0, x) in Hcl(0) with the time-
zero ﬁelds of the free neutral quantum KG ﬁeld. This is a basic idea for the
construction of the vHM model given as follows.
We take the boson Fock space Fb(L2(Rd
k)) over L2(Rd
k) as the Hilbert
space for the vHM model to be constructed. We assume that the real tem-
pered distribution ϱ satisﬁes the condition
ϱ ∈H−1/2
ω,R (Rd)
(13.6)
(see (10.9)) and deﬁne the Hamiltonian of the model by
Hϱ := H0 −φ0(ϱ),
(13.7)
where
H0 := Hb = dΓb(ω),
the Hamiltonian of the free neutral quantum KG ﬁeld (see Section 10.2 and
(10.14)), and φ0(·) is deﬁned by (10.15).1 As suggested above, the time-zero
1By the reality of ϱ, φ0(ϱ) is essentially self-adjoint on Fb,0(L2(Rd

ﬁeld and its conjugate momentum in the formulation under consideration
are taken, respectively, to be φ0(f) (f ∈SR(Rd)) and π0(f), deﬁned by
(10.16). We call (Hϱ, {φ0(f), π0(f)|f ∈SR(Rd)}), with ϱ ̸= 0, the concrete
vHM model based on the representation {φ0(f), π0(f)|f ∈SR(Rd)} of
