As is seen, Hϱ is an example of an operator, which is obtained by per-
turbing a boson second quantization operator by a Segal ﬁeld operator.
Hence, Hϱ has an abstract version.
Generally, in the case where a physical concrete model has an abstract
version, it is better to consider the abstract version. This approach makes it
possible to understand what are general and what are special in the model
and hence may bring a deeper and wider cognition for the model under
consideration. With this philosophy, in what follows, we deﬁne the abstract
version of the concrete vHM model and analyze it in detail. The properties
of the concrete vHM model are derived as simple applications of theorems
on the abstract vHM model.
Before giving the deﬁnition of the abstract vHM model, we ﬁrst intro-
duce a general concept of abstract Bose ﬁeld models.
13.3
Abstract Form of Bose Field Models in the Canonical
Formalism in QFT
In general, an abstract Bose ﬁeld model in the canonical formalism in
QFT is deﬁned by a triple M = (F, H, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W }) consisting
of a self-adjoint operator H on a Hilbert space F and a representation
(F, D, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W }) (on F) of the Heisenberg CCR over a real
inner product space W , with the interpretation that H is the Hamiltonian
of the model, φ(f) is the time-zero ﬁeld and π(f) is the time-zero conjugate
momentum. The time-t ﬁelds (t ∈R) are deﬁned by
φ(t, f) := eitHφ(f)e−itH,
π(t, f) := eitHπ(f)e−itH.
The model M is an abstract form of the model discussed in Section 8.6.
Remark 13.1. An abstract Fermi ﬁeld model in the canonical formalism
in QFT is deﬁned by replacing {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W } by a representation of
CAR over a complex inner product space.
Van Hove–Miyatake Model
839
There may exist many Bose ﬁeld models based on the representations of
the Heisenberg CCR over a real inner product space W . Hence, it is natural
to classify them into equivalent and inequivalent ones. For this purpose, we
introduce a concept of equivalence of Bose ﬁeld models.
Deﬁnition 13.1. Two Bose ﬁeld models M := (F, H, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W })
and M′ := (F ′, H′, {φ′(f), π′(f)|f ∈W }) are said to be equivalent if
there exist a unitary operator U : F →F ′ and a real constant E such that
UHU −1 = H′ + E (cf. Proposition 8.1) and
Uφ(f)U −1 = φ′(f),
Uπ(f)U −1 = π′(f),
f ∈W .
In this case, we write M ∼= M′.
Remark 13.2. It is obvious that M ∼= M and that, if M ∼= M′, then M′ ∼= M.
Moreover, it is easy to see that if three Bose ﬁeld models M1, M2 and M3
satisfy M1 ∼= M2 and M2 ∼= M3, then M1 ∼= M3. Therefore, the relation ∼=
in the set of Bose ﬁeld models is certainly an equivalence relation. Thus,
the above deﬁnition is meaningful.
As is seen, the concept of equivalence deﬁned above is stronger than
the equivalence of the two representations (F, D, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W })
and (F ′, D′, {φ′(f), π′(f)|f
∈W }) of the Heisenberg CCR over W .
Also, it should be kept in mind that only the unitary equivalence of
the Hamiltonians up to constant additions does not imply the equivalence
of the models.
A Bose ﬁeld model M = (F, H, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W }) is said to be regu-
lar if H is bounded from below and has a unique ground state Ω (∥Ω∥= 1)
with property Ω ∈∩∞
n=1 ∩(t1,f1),...,(tn,fn)∈R×W D(X(t1, f1) · · · X(tn, fn)),
where X = φ or π.
Proposition 13.1. Let M = (F, H, {φ(f), π(f)|f ∈W }) and M′ =
(F ′, H′, {φ′(f), π′(f)|f
∈W }) be regular Bose ﬁeld models. Suppose
that they are equivalent. Then, for all n ∈N and (tj, fj) ∈R × W
(j = 1, . . . , n),
⟨Ω, X(t1, f1) · · · X(tn, fn)Ω⟩= ⟨Ω′, X′(t1, f1) · · · X′(tn, fn)Ω′⟩,
(13.8)
where Ω′ is a ground state of the model M′, with ∥Ω′∥= 1.
840
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Proof. Under the present assumption, there exist a unitary operator U :
F →F ′ and a real constant E such that UHU −1 = H′ + E · · · (∗) and
Uφ(f)U −1 = φ′(f), Uπ(f)U −1 = π′(f),
f ∈W .
By (∗), E0(H) = E0(H′) + E (recall that E0(A) := inf σ(A) for a self-
adjoint operator A). Since H′Ω′ = E0(H′)Ω′, it follows that HU −1Ω′ =
E0(H)U −1Ω′. Hence, U −1Ω′ is a ground state of H. Hence, U −1Ω′ = αΩ,
for some α ∈C with |α| = 1.
Now, let L be the left-hand side of (13.8). Then,
L =
	
U −1Ω′, X(t1, f1) · · · X(tn, fn)U −1Ω′
=
	
Ω′, (Ueit1HU −1)(UX(f1)U −1)(Uei(t2−t1)HU −1)(UX(f2)U −1) · · ·
× (Uei(tn−tn−1)HU −1)(UX(fn)U −1)(Ue−itnHU −1)Ω′
.
We have UeisHU −1 = eis(H′+E) (s ∈R) and UX(fj)U −1 = X′(fj). Hence,
L is equal to the right-hand side of (13.8).
□
Proposition 13.1 gives a suﬃcient condition for two regular Bose ﬁeld
models to be inequivalent.
Corollary 13.1. Let M and M′ be regular Bose ﬁeld models. Suppose that
there exist an n ∈N and (t1, f1), . . . , (tn, fn) ∈R×W such that (13.8) does
not hold. Then, M is inequivalent to M′.
13.4
Deﬁnition of the Abstract vHM Model
Let H be a complex Hilbert space and Fb(H ) be the boson Fock space
over H (see Chapter 5). We carry over the notation in Chapter 5.
Let T be a non-negative and injective self-adjoint operator on H and,
for each g ∈H \{0}, deﬁne
HT (g) := dΓb(T ) + ΦS(g).
(13.9)
This is an abstract version of Hϱ (the case of HT (g) with H = L2(Rd
k),
T = ω and g = −ϱ/√ω gives Hϱ).
From a perturbation theoretical point of view (see Remark 7.11), HT (g)
is viewed as the perturbation of dΓb(T ) by ΦS(g), and it may be better to
introduce a perturbation parameter λ ∈R by replacing g with λg so
Van Hove–Miyatake Model
841
that HT (g) takes the form
H(λ) := HT (λg) = dΓb(T ) + λΦS(g).
(13.10)
The parameter λ is also called the coupling constant. The reader should
keep in mind this point of view in what follows, although the presentation
is non-perturbative in the sense that no restriction is given to the strength
|λ| of the coupling parameter (in the standard perturbation theory, it is
usual that |λ| must be suﬃciently small).
It is easy to see that HT (g) is a symmetric operator, with D(HT (g)) ⊃
Fb,ﬁn(D(T )). From a quantum theoretical point of view, it should be exam-
ined if HT (g) is self-adjoint or essentially self-adjoint. We ﬁrst consider this
problem.

By Theorem 13.1 and Lemma 13.2, for each g ∈D(T −1/2), we can
deﬁne a Bose ﬁeld model by the triple (Fb(H ), HT (g), {φF(T −1/2f),
πF(T 1/2f)|f ∈D1/2(T )}). We call the model with g ̸= 0 the abstract
vHM model with the pair (T, g).
If g = 0, then HT (g) = dΓb(T ). We call the triple (Fb(H ), dΓb(T ),
{φF(T −1/2f), πF(T 1/2f) |f ∈D1/2(T )}) the abstract free Bose ﬁeld
theory with one-particle Hamiltonian T (see (5.14)).
The following theorem shows that the abstract vHM model is non-
trivial.
Theorem 13.2. The abstract vHM model with the pair (T, g) is inequiva-
lent to the abstract free Bose ﬁeld theory (Fb(H ), dΓb(T ), {φF(T −1/2f),
πF(T 1/2f)|f ∈D1/2(T )}).
Proof. Suppose that they were equivalent. Then, there exist a unitary
operator U on Fb(H ) and a real constant E such that UHT (g)U −1 =
dΓb(T ) + E and, for all f ∈D1/2(T ),
UφF(T −1/2f)U −1 = φF(T −1/2f),
UπF(T 1/2f)U −1 = πF(T 1/2f).
The last two operator equations imply that, for all f ∈D1/2(T ),
UφF(T −1/2f) ⊂φF(T −1/2f)U,
UπF(T 1/2f) ⊂πF(T 1/2f)U.
Hence, by Lemma 13.2, U = cI for some c ∈C. Hence, HT (g) = dΓb(T )+E,
implying that ΦS(g) = E. But, since g ̸= 0, ΦS(g) is not a scalar operator.
Thus, we arrive at a contradiction.
□
In fact, the abstract vHM model is inequivalent to any free Bose ﬁeld
theory under suitable conditions. We prove this later (see Theorem 13.13).

We want to mention some remarks on Theorem 13.4 from a perturbation
theoretical point of view:
(1) We ﬁrst consider the case where T is strictly positive, i.e., T ≥m for
some constant m > 0. In this case, T −1 is a everywhere deﬁned bounded
operator with ∥T −1∥≤1/m. Hence, condition (13.31) is automati-
cally satisﬁed. By Theorem 5.3, inf σ(dΓb(T ))\{0} ≥m > 0. Hence,
0 is a simple isolated eigenvalue of dΓb(T ). As already seen, ΦS(g)
is relatively bounded with respect to dΓb(T ). Hence, one can apply
the analytic perturbation theory (Kato, 1976, Chapter 7; Reed and
Simon, 1978, Chapter XII) to the self-adjoint operator H(λ) deﬁned
by (13.10) to conclude that there exists a constant r0 > 0 such that,
for all |λ| < r0, H(λ) has a simple eigenvalue E(λ) analytic in λ with
E(0) = 0 and there exists an eigenvector Ω(λ) ∈ker(H(λ) −E(λ))
which is analytic in λ. Moreover, it is shown by an application of a gen-
eral theorem (Arai, 2006b, Theorem 5.20) that Ω(λ) is a ground state
of H(λ). Thus, in the case where T is strictly positive, the existence
of a ground state of H(λ) is shown by an application of the standard
analytic perturbation theory; however, the strength |λ| of the coupling
constant λ is restricted. Theorem 13.4(iv) shows that, in fact, H(λ) has
a unique ground state for all λ ∈R, and the ground state is analytic
in λ. We also note that ground state energy, with g replaced by λg,
is given by
ET (λg) = −λ2
2 ∥T −1/2g∥2,
which is obviously analytic in λ.
854
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(2) We next consider the case where T is not strictly positive, i.e., 0 ∈σ(T ).
In this case, 0 is not an isolated point of σ(T )2 and T −1 is unbounded
(Problem 4). Hence, it is non-trivial if g ∈D(T −1). By Theorem 5.3, in
the present case, 0 ∈σp(dΓb(T )) is not an isolated eigenvalue. Hence,
one cannot apply the standard analytic perturbation theory to H(λ) (in
the standard analytic perturbation theory, an eigenvalue of the unper-
turbed operator A in question must be an isolated eigenvalue of A
with a ﬁnite multiplicity). Theorem 13.4(iv) shows that, in this case
too, H(λ) has a ground state analytic in λ ∈R, and the ground state
energy is also analytic in λ ∈R if g ∈D(T −1).
(3) As a typical case of T in (2), let us consider the case where σ(T ) =
[0, ∞). Then, by Theorem 5.3, we have
σ(dΓb(T )) = [0, ∞).
Hence, in this case, the eigenvalue 0 of the unperturbed operator dΓb(T )
is an embedded eigenvalue of dΓb(T ). Generally, it is very subtle if an
embedded eigenvalue is stable under a perturbation. Theorem 13.4(iv)
shows that, if g ∈D(T −1), then 0 ∈σp(dΓb(T )) is stable under the
perturbation ΦS(g). But, if g ̸∈D(T −1), then it is unstable, i.e., it
disappears under the perturbation (see Theorem 13.7).
13.7
Spectral Properties of HT (g) (II): The Case g ̸∈D(T −1)
We next consider the case where (13.31) does not hold:
g ̸∈D(T −1).
(13.39)
In this case, the method of the preceding section cannot be used since
Φ(iT −1g) is not deﬁned. The spectral analysis of HT (g) under condition
(13.39) becomes more complicated as seen in the following.
We ﬁrst remark that situation (13.39) is possible only if the lowest
energy E0(T ) = inf σ(T ) of T is equal to zero:
E0(T ) = 0,
(13.40)
because, if E0(T ) > 0, then 0 ∈ϱ(T ) (recall that σ(T ) ⊂[E0(T ), ∞)), and
hence T −1 is bounded with D(T −1) = H so that g ∈D(T −1) contradicts
(13.39). Moreover, 0 is not an isolated point of σ(T ) (if 0 is an isolated
2If 0 is an isolated point of σ(T), then 0 is an eigenvalue of T, and hence T is not
injective; however, this contradicts the original assumption.
Van Hove–Miyatake Model
855
point of σ(T ), then it is an eigenvalue of T , contradicting the injectivity
of T ). Hence, inf(σ(T )\{0}) = 0.

Remark 13.10. It is well known that, even if the spectrum of a linear
operator A on a Hilbert space coincides with that of a linear operator B
on a Hilbert space, they are not necessarily unitarily equivalent. Theorems
13.7 and 13.5 imply that the pair (HT (g), dΓb(T ) + E(T, g)) is an example

Theorems 13.4 and 13.7 lead one to the following interesting fact.
Theorem 13.8. Assume (13.13) and that T is absolutely continuous. Then,
HT (g) has no ground states if and only if (13.39) holds.
We now consider the physical meaning of the absence of ground states,
as stated in Theorem 13.8. We ﬁrst remark that the property g ∈D(T α), for
some α ∈R, can be interpreted as a regularity condition for g with respect
to T . From this point of view, Theorem 13.8 shows that the existence of
ground states of HT (g) depends on the regularity of g with respect to T .

region because it corresponds to a region of long wavelengths of the quan-
tum particle. With this picture in mind, we deﬁne a notion independently
of whether T is absolutely continuous or not.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
A vector f ∈H is said to be infrared regular with respect to T if
f ∈D(T −1) and infrared singular with respect to T if f ̸∈D(T −1).
Theorem 13.8 is rephrased as follows.
Assume (13.13) and that T is absolutely continuous. Then,
HT (g) has no ground states if and only if g is infrared singular
with respect to T .
As already remarked, infrared singularity with respect to T occurs only
if (13.40) holds. Generally, in a quantum ﬁeld theory with a quantum par-
ticle whose Hamiltonian T satisﬁes (13.40), there may be structures due to
infrared singularity, such as the absence of ground states. Problems related
to infrared singularity are generically called infrared problems.
Example 13.2. Consider the case where H = L2(Rd
k) and T is the mul-
tiplication operator by the function ω(k) =
√
k2 + m2, k ∈Rd (m ≥0).
Then, E0(ω) = m. Hence, the infrared singularity with respect to ω occurs
only if m = 0, i.e., the massless case. Therefore, in relativistic QFT with a
massless quantum ﬁeld, infrared problems can occur (see Theorem 13.9(iv)).
Example 13.3. Consider the case where T is the one-particle Hamiltonian
h0 of the free quantum de Broglie ﬁeld given by (9.9). Then, E0(h0) = 0.
Hence, in a quantum de Broglie ﬁeld with an interaction (e.g., the abstract
vHM model with H = L2(Rd) and T = h0), infrared problems can occur.

13.10
A General Structure behind the Infrared
Catastrophe
In this section, we show that the infrared catastrophe mentioned in the pre-
ceding section can be regarded as a special realization of a general structure
of the abstract vHM model. To describe it, we consider a family {g(κ)}κ>0,
with g(κ) ∈D(T −1). By Theorem 13.4(iv), HT (g(κ)) has a unique ground
state, which is given by ΩT (g(κ)) up to constant multiples. The following
theorem states a general structure of the abstract vHM model.
Theorem 13.11. The weak limit w- limκ→∞ΩT (g(κ)) = 0 if and only if
lim
κ→∞∥T −1g(κ)∥= ∞.
(13.59)
Proof. Similar to the proof of Theorem 13.10 (we need only to replace ga
by g(κ)).
□
We emphasize that, in Theorem 13.11, the existence of limκ→∞g(κ) is
not assumed.
If g ∈H is infrared singular with respect to T , then g(κ) := χ[1/κ,∞)g
satisﬁes (13.59), as already seen.
There is another important case which is related to the behavior of the
model in higher energy regions.
870
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Example 13.4. Suppose that T is unbounded and strictly positive, i.e.,
T ≥γ, for some constant γ > 0. Then, T −1 is bounded with D(T −1) = H .
Hence, g is trivially infrared regular with respect to T . Moreover, we ﬁx a
vector v ∈H such that v ̸∈D(T p), for some p ∈N. Note that χ[0,κ](T )v ∈
C∞(T ), for all κ > 0. Hence, one can deﬁne
g(κ) := T p+1χ[0,κ](T )v,

(13.61)
We note that, in this example, there are no subsequences {κn}n tending
to ∞as n →∞such that w- limn→∞g(κn) exists in H . To see this, suppose
that w- limn→∞g(κn) = g ∈H . Then, by the boundedness of T −(p+1),
w- limn→∞T −(p+1)g(κn) = T −(p+1)g. On the other hand, it follows from the
deﬁnition of g(κ) that T −(p+1)g(κn) →v (n →∞). Hence, v = T −(p+1)g.
Therefore, v ∈D(T p+1) ⊂D(T p). But this is a contradiction.
The fact just shown implies that, for all Ψ ∈Fb,ﬁn(D(T )), {ΦS(g(κ))Ψ}κ
has no subsequences which weakly converge. Hence, HT (g(κ))Ψ has no weak
limit as κ →∞. Thus, in this example, in contrast to the case of the
infrared catastrophe (see (13.58)), it is suggested that a Hamiltonian which
may correspond to κ = ∞cannot be deﬁned as an operator on the boson
Fock space Fb(H ).
As is seen from (13.60), the divergences related to g(κ) as κ →∞
come from higher energy regions, or, in other words, regions of shorter
wave lengths — ultraviolet regions. Hence, this kind of divergences is called
ultraviolet divergence, or ultraviolet catastrophe. The parameter κ
is called an ultraviolet cutoﬀ. Property (13.61) for the present type of
g(κ) is called the ultraviolet van Hove–Miyatake phenomenon in the
abstract sense.3
By abuse of notation, we call the property w- lima→∞Ωa = 0 the
infrared van Hove–Miyatake phenomenon in the abstract sense.
3For the concrete case, see van Hove (1952), Miyatake (1952a, 1952b), and Ezawa
(1963).

Proposition 13.4(i) gives a characterization of the absence of ground

representation theoretical point of view on CCR:
(i) Suppose that T is absolutely continuous. Then, the absence of ground

alent to πF(V ) (see Theorem 13.8).
(ii) The infrared van Hove–Miyatake phenomenon exactly corresponds to
the case where πT,g is inequivalent to πF(V ).
The absence of ground states and the infrared van Hove–Miyatake phe-
nomenon may be singular from a conventional point of view; however, from
another point of view, they may be regarded as characteristic phenomena.
It is very interesting to know that the representation πT,g describes phys-
ically inequivalent phases depending on whether it is equivalent to πF(V )
or not.
13.11.2

In this section, we assume that the self-adjoint operator T is strictly positive

Let n ∈Z+. Then, for any φ ∈H−(n+1)(T ), there exists a sequence
{φj}j in H such that ∥φj −φ∥−(n+1) →0 (j →∞). Hence, {T −(n+1)φj}j

T −1φ := fφ.
Note that, if φ ∈H , then T −1φ = T −1φ.
Since ∥fφ∥−n = ∥φ∥−(n+1), we have
∥T −1φ∥−n = ∥φ∥−(n+1).
Hence, T −1 is an isometry from H−(n+1) to H−n. Moreover, T −1 is surjec-
tive. Thus, T −1 is a unitary operator from H−(n+1) to H−n.

From the analyses performed so far, we see that the representations of
time-zero ﬁelds as those of CCR play important roles:
(1) Even in the case where a quantum ﬁeld model has no ground state
in a representation of time-zero ﬁelds, it may have a ground state in
another representation of time-zero ﬁelds which is inequivalent to the
former one.
(2) In the case where the Hamiltonian of a quantum ﬁeld model, with
the ultraviolet cutoﬀκ > 0, does not converge in a “natural” sense
to an operator within the Hilbert space under consideration in the
limit κ →∞of removing the ultraviolet cutoﬀ, but the VEVs con-
verge as κ →∞, the model without the ultraviolet cutoﬀmay be
constructed in a representation of time-zero ﬁelds inequivalent to the
Fock representation.
It is interesting that, in both cases, the representations of CCR inequivalent
to the Fock representation play essential roles.

The above results may be interpreted as follows. Suppose that the point
sources at x1, . . . , xN are ﬁxed nucleons. Then, as mentioned before, the
concrete vHM model describes a model of bosons (neutral pions) interact-
ing with the ﬁxed nucleons. The interaction generates nuclear forces as a
result of exchanges of pions by nucleons. The ground state energy Eκ up to
constant additions may be interpreted as expressing the potential energy
of the nuclear forces in the ground state. It follows from (13.74) that

the nuclear forces in the ground state. The quantity Sκ diverging to −∞as
κ →∞is interpreted as a self-energy of the ﬁxed nucleons. The prescription
subtracting Sκ from Eκ to obtain a ﬁnite quantity in the limit κ →∞is an
example of the so-called energy renormalization. In this way, a quantum
ﬁeld theoretical derivation of the Yukawa-type potential or the Coulomb-
type potential is done.

Chapter 14
Models in QFT
Some interacting quantum ﬁeld models are described.
14.1
Introduction
The vHM model discussed in the preceding chapter is a simple model in
QFT. Of course, there are other interacting quantum ﬁeld models which
are more complicated and/or more physically realistic. In this chapter, for
further studies, we present a list of interacting quantum ﬁeld models which
have been investigated so far in the ﬁeld of mathematical QFT, although
it is not a complete one.1 Interacting quantum ﬁeld models are mainly
classiﬁed into four categories:
(i) Purely bosonic ﬁeld models.
(ii) Purely fermionic ﬁeld models.
(iii) Boson–fermion interaction models.
(iv) Models of particle–ﬁeld interactions.
Here, models which are neither completely relativistic nor completely
Galilean symmetric are also included. Such models may play roles as
“approximate” versions of “true” models, which are expected to exist, or
phenomenological models, for example, in condensed matter physics. We
explain these categories one by one in the following. But, before doing that,
we remark on a common strategy for constructing quantum ﬁeld models.
To be deﬁnite, let us consider the case of constructing a relativistic
interacting neutral quantum scalar ﬁeld model in the (1 + d)-dimensional
space-time. In this case, a formal Hamiltonian of the model heuristi-
cally given in correspondence to the classical ﬁeld theory is ill-deﬁned
1There exist quantum ﬁeld models other than those mentioned in this chapter.
893
894
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
since a point-wise quantum ﬁeld does not exist as a Hilbert space oper-
ator by Wightman’s theorem (see Remark 8.3(1); see also Example 10.2
and Remark 10.6). To avoid this diﬃculty, one usually proceeds as
follows:
Step 1. One introduces a momentum cutoﬀκ > 0 and a space cutoﬀL > 0
in the formal Hamiltonian to obtain a well-deﬁned operator H(L, κ) acting
in the boson Fock space Fb(L2(Rd
k)) and considers it as an approximate
Hamiltonian of the “true” Hamiltonian to be constructed, where L is a size
such that, only in the cubic box {x ∈Rd| |xj| ≤L/2, j = 1, . . . , d} or in
its neighborhood, the interaction of the quantum ﬁeld under consideration
occurs. Usually the time-zero ﬁelds are taken to be the Fock represen-
tation {φ0(f), π0(f)|f ∈SR(Rd)}. In this way, one ﬁrst deﬁnes a cutoﬀ
model.
Step 2. One shows that H(L, κ) is essentially self-adjoint and bounded from
below. For notational simplicity, here we denote the closure of H(L, κ) by
the same symbol.
Step 3. Suppose that H(L, κ) contains parameters λ(j) ∈R, j = 1, . . . , J
(masses, charges, coupling constants, . . .) and write H(L, κ) = H(s) with
s := (L, κ, λ(1), . . . , λ(J)). Let Hn := H(sn) −En with sn := (Ln, κn, λ(1)
n ,
. . . , λ(J)
n ) and En ∈R (n ∈N). Then, one investigates if there exist a
sequence {(sn, En)}n and a self-adjoint operator H on Fb(L2(Rd
k)) such
that s- limn→∞e−itHn = e−itH, t ∈R.
In this step, one needs to perform detailed operator-theoretical analyses
of H(L, κ). However, in most cases (in particular, in models of relativis-
tic QFT), it is not expected that such a self-adjoint operator H exists.
This is closely related to the fact that, in non-trivial interacting quantum
ﬁeld models without cutoﬀs, inﬁnite renormalizations are necessary on the
level of perturbation theories. The sequence {(sn, En)}n is for a renormal-
ization of H(L, κ) which includes divergences (e.g., usually En →−∞as
n →∞).
Step 4. If a self-adjoint operator H in Step 3 exists, then one deﬁnes a
model without cutoﬀs, whose Hamiltonian is given by H, and investigates
the properties of this model (e.g., the spectral properties of H).
In the case where a self-adjoint operator H in Step 3 does not exist or
H is not expected to exist, one proceeds as follows:
Step

that

a

Models in QFT

SR(Rd). Then, one shows that, for all u ∈S (R) and f ∈S (Rd), the

Similar strategies apply to other types of quantum ﬁeld models. Con-
cerning relativistic models, one can also adopt a strategy, called the
Euclidean strategy (see Section 8.12), whose goal is to construct Schwinger
functions of each model and show that they satisfy the Osterwalder–
Schrader axioms. For this approach, functional integration methods are
very useful (see, for example, Arai et al., 2016; Derezi´nski and G´erard,
2013, Chapter 21; Ezawa and Arai, 2023; Fern´andez et al., 1992; Glimm
and Jaﬀe, 1987; L¨orinczi et al., 2020; Hiroshima and L¨orinczi, 2020; Simon,
1974, 1979). A pedagogical and comprehensive review on mathematical
methods to study quantum ﬁeld models is found in Arai (2002).
With the above remarks, in what follows, we deﬁne only models with
cutoﬀs which form starting points for the construction of models without
cutoﬀs or models with more symmetries.
14.2
Purely Bosonic Field Models
A purely bosonic ﬁeld model is a model which describes only a
self-interaction of a Bose ﬁeld and/or an interaction among Bose ﬁelds
of diﬀerent kinds. In this category, there are two classes: relativistic and
non-relativistic.
2See Appendix E.
896
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
14.2.1
P (φ)1+d model
In the classical ﬁeld theory, one can consider a real scalar ﬁeld φcl :
M1+d →R on the (1 + d)-dimensional Minkowski space-time M1+d sat-
isfying a nonlinear KG equation—a nonlinear perturbation of the free
KG equation:
(□+ m2)φcl(x) = −4λφcl(x)3 −2σφcl(x) + μ,
x = (t, x) ∈M1+d,
(14.1)
where m > 0, λ > 0, σ ∈R and μ ≥0 are parameters. The right-hand side
gives a form of nonlinear self-interactions of the ﬁeld φcl. A model of this
type is called a classical φ4
1+d model.
A generalization of this model is given by a real scalar ﬁeld φcl satisfying
a more general non-linear KG equation
(□+ m2)φcl(x) = −P ′(φcl(x)),
x ∈M1+d,
(14.2)
where P : R →R is a real polynomial of the form
P(φ) =
2p

r=0
arφr,
φ ∈R
(14.3)
with coeﬃcients a2p > 0, ar ∈R, r = 0, 1, . . . , 2p −1 (p ∈N, p ≥2) and P ′
is the derivative of P. Note that P is bounded from below (Problem 2(i)).
This model is called the classical P(φ)1+d model.
It is easy to see that the Lagrangian density for (14.2) is given by
LP(x) := 1

The operator Vκ,g is a regularized quantum version corresponding to the

Vκ,g =

The function g is called a space cutoﬀ, or a volume cutoﬀ.
Let g ∈L1(Rd) and g ≥0. Then, the Hamiltonian of a quantum ﬁeld
model corresponding to the classical theory described by (14.2) is deﬁned by
Hκ,g := Hb + Vκ,g.
(14.8)
It is easy to see that Fb,ﬁn(D(ω)) ∩Fb,0(L2(Rd
k)) is a subset of D(Hκ,g) =
D(Hb) ∩D(Vκ,g). Hence, Hκ,g is densely deﬁned. Moreover, Vκ,g is a
symmetric operator and bounded from below (Problem 2(ii)–(iii)). Thus, we
Models in QFT
899
see that Hκ,g is a symmetric operator and bounded from below. The
quantum ﬁeld model with the Hamiltonian Hκ,g is called the P(φ)1+d
model with momentum cutoﬀκ and space cutoﬀg (or, simply, a
cutoﬀP(φ)1+d model). This model is not fully relativistic and only “approx-
imately” relativistic because it has cutoﬀs. The analysis of this model should
be regarded as a ﬁrst step toward the construction of a P(φ)1+d model with-
out cutoﬀs, which is expected to be a completely relativistic P(φ)1+d model.
With regard to the cutoﬀP(φ)1+d model, functional integral methods are
useful, in addition to operator-theoretical methods.
The goal of the analysis of the cutoﬀmodel Hκ,g is to show that the
cutoﬀtheory has a limit in a suitable sense as κ →∞(the removal of
the ultraviolet cutoﬀ) and g(x) →1 (the removal of the space cutoﬀ) and
to prove that the limiting theory is non-trivial (i.e., inequivalent to a free
QFT), satisfying the axioms of relativistic QFT. But it turns out that this
is a very diﬃcult problem. So far, the following results are known (only
rough statements are given; for more exact statements, see the references
cited5):
(1) In the case of d = 1 (i.e., the case of the two-dimensional space-time),
a P(φ)2 model without cutoﬀs exists and is non-trivial, satisfying the
Wightman axioms (Glimm and Jaﬀe, 1985, 1987; Simon, 1974).
(2) In the case of d = 2, a φ4
3 model without cutoﬀs exists and is non-trivial,
satisfying the Wightman axioms (Brydges et al., 1983; Fern´andez et al.,
1992; Glimm and Jaﬀe, 1985, 1987).
(3) In the case of d ≥4, a construction of φ4
d model without cutoﬀs using
a lattice approximation gives a trivial theory (Aizenman, 1981, 1982;
Ezawa and Arai, 2023; Fern´andez et al., 1992; Fr¨ohlich, 1982; Arai
et al., 2016, Chapter 3). Recently, a complete proof of the triviality of
φ4
4 model has been presented in Aizenman and Copin (2021).
The result (3) with d = 4 (the most interesting case) may discourage one
because it suggests the absence of non-trivial φ4
4 theories without cutoﬀs
in its conventional form. But one can also consider it as a suggestion that
a completely new approach may be needed to construct a non-trivial rela-
tivistic QFT in the four-dimensional space-time with a possible change in
the conventional notion of the quantum ﬁeld. The problem of constructing
a non-trivial relativistic QFT in the four-dimensional space-time as well
5The literature on P (φ)1+d models is extensive, and hence we mainly cite books in
which detailed reviews on the studies of the models are given.
900
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
as a φ4
4 theory is still open. This problem is closely related to one of the
millennium problems — to prove the existence of the quantum Yang–Mills
theory and a mass gap (Jaﬀe and Witten, 2000).
14.2.2
Scalar quantum electrodynamics
Charged spin-zero particles (e.g., π± mesons) interact with the quantum
radiation ﬁeld. The quantum ﬁeld of charged spin-zero particles is given
by a charged quantum scalar ﬁeld (see Section 10.16). Therefore, one is
led to consider a model of a charged quantum scalar ﬁeld interacting with
the quantum radiation ﬁeld. This class of QFT is called scalar quantum
electrodynamics, or the (abelian) Higgs–Kibble model, in the context
of the electro-weak part in the standard model of particle physics.
See, for example, Itzykson and Zuber (1980), 6-1-4 for heuristic physical
arguments and Arai (1991b) for a rigorous deﬁnition of the Hamiltonian of
a scalar quantum electrodynamics with momentum and space cutoﬀs.
14.2.3

14.3
Purely Fermionic Field Models
A purely fermionic ﬁeld model is a model which describes only a
self-interaction of a Fermi ﬁeld and/or an interaction among Fermi ﬁelds
of diﬀerent kinds. As in the case of purely bosonic ﬁeld models, purely
fermionic ﬁeld models are also classiﬁed into relativistic and non-relativistic
ones.
904
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
14.3.1
A model of a self-interacting quantum Dirac ﬁeld
In Chapter 12, we considered a free quantum Dirac ﬁeld on the four-
dimensional space-time. As in the case of quantum scalar ﬁelds, one can
consider models of a self-interacting quantum Dirac ﬁeld. Here, we consider
only one model whose classical ﬁeld equation is given by a nonlinear Dirac
equation
(iγμ∂μ −M)ψ(x) = λ[ψ(x)γμψ(x)]γμψ(x)
for ψ : M4 →C4, where λ ∈R denotes a coupling constant. A Lagrangian

ψ(x)(iγμ∂μ −M)ψ(x) −λ

It follows that the interaction part in the classical Hamiltonian is

this quantity makes no sense unless a momentum cutoﬀand a space cut-
oﬀare introduced. Hence, in what follows, we ﬁrst deﬁne a quantum ﬁeld
Hamiltonian with cutoﬀs.
Let ψg(t, x) be given by (12.169) and, for each κ > 0,
Ψκ(x) := ψχκ(0, x),
(14.19)

quantum Dirac ﬁeld with momentum cutoﬀκ. It follows that Ψκ(x)

(see also Problem 4). By (12.171), we have

one sees that Ψκ(x)γμΨκ(x) is a bounded self-adjoint operator. Hence, it fol-

describes a self-interaction of a quantum Dirac ﬁeld with cutoﬀs. Let HD be
the Hamiltonian of the free quantum Dirac ﬁeld of mass M (see (12.145)).
Then, the Hamiltonian of the quantum ﬁeld model with cutoﬀs correspond-
ing to the above classical model is deﬁned by
Hg,κ := HD + HI(g, κ).
Since HI(g, κ) is bounded, it follows from the Kato–Rellich theorem that
Hg,κ is a self-adjoint operator on FD and bounded from below.
Remark 14.1. There is a two-dimensional space-time version of the above
model, called the Thirring model (Thirring, 1958). The massless Thirring
model (the case of M = 0) without cutoﬀs is exactly soluble in a sense and
has been extensively studied in both the physics and mathematical physics
literatures (e.g., Carey et al., 1985; Ruijsenaars, 1982 for mathematically
rigorous analyses). Also, the massive Thirring model (the case of M > 0)
without cutoﬀs has interesting structures (see, for example, Benfatto et al.,
2009 for a recent mathematical study).
14.3.2
A non-relativistic self-interacting Fermi ﬁeld model:
The BCS model

The Hamiltonian HBCS is called the Bardeen–Cooper–Schriefer (BCS)

metal vanishes below a critical temperature. The mathematical analyses

An earlier important contribution to the mathematical analysis of the BCS
model was presented by Kato (1965). For recent studies, see, for example,
Hainzl and Seiringer (2016) and references therein.
14.4
Models of Bose Fields Interacting with Fermi Fields
14.4.1
Yukawa model
We consider a model of a quantum Dirac ﬁeld interacting with a quantum
scalar ﬁeld in the four-dimensional space-time. One can take as the Hilbert

The quantum ﬁeld model whose Hamiltonian is Hχ,κ is called a Yukawa
model with momentum and space cutoﬀs.
The two-dimensional space-time version of the Yukawa model, denoted
Yukawa2, was extensively studied, and the existence of a Yukawa2 model
without cutoﬀs which satisﬁes the Wightman axioms was shown. For a
review, see Glimm and Jaﬀe (1987), Section 23.4. For recent studies of
Yukawa models with cutoﬀs, see, for example, Aschbacher et al. (2011),
Barbaroux and Guillot (2009), and Takaesu (2011).
14.4.2
Quantum electrodynamics
The quantum theory describing the interaction of a quantum Dirac
ﬁeld (typically, the relativistic quantum electron ﬁeld) with the quantum
radiation ﬁeld is called quantum electrodynamics (QED). The QED
of the quantum electron ﬁeld, as a physical theory, predicts quantum
electromagnetic phenomena with surprisingly high precision (Kinoshita,
1990), although the predictions are based on formal perturbations theo-
ries with renormalization procedures (e.g., Scharf, 1989; Steinmann, 2000).
Despite the success of QED as a physical theory, it still remains to show the
existence of QED in the four-dimensional space-time as a mathematically
well-deﬁned theory. This is one of the most important (but most diﬃcult)
problems in mathematical physics. An axiomatic treatment of QED is found
in Strocchi (2013).
As is mentioned in Remark 11.1, one needs an indeﬁnite metric space to
construct a model of QED in a manifestly covariant way. Here, for simplic-
ity, we present the Hamiltonian of a cutoﬀmodel of QED in the Coulomb

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
gauge, which is deﬁned as a self-adjoint operator on the tensor product
Hilbert space
FQED := FD ⊗Frad
of the fermion Fock space FD (see (12.116)) for the quantum Dirac ﬁeld
and the boson Fock space Frad with d = 3 (see (11.17)) for the quantum
radiation ﬁeld in the Coulomb gauge.
Let Ψκ(x) (x ∈R3) be the time-zero quantum Dirac ﬁeld with momen-

For further analyses of the model and related ones, see, for example, Wakita
(1976), Barbarroux et al. (2004), and Takaesu (2009, 2018).
Remark 14.2. There is a two-dimensional space-time version of QED,
called the Schwinger model (Schwinger, 1962). This model can be solved
exactly (e.g., the quantum ﬁelds involved are explicitly represented) and
is used as a simpliﬁed model for the original QED or other more com-
plex interacting quantum ﬁeld models. The Schwinger model is interest-
ing in that it exhibits characteristic phenomena, such as conﬁnement of
the fermions, spontaneous symmetry breaking of the U(1) symmetry (see
Chapter 15) and the Higgs mechanism (a photon becomes massive), and
has been extensively studied (hence there are many articles on the model).
We only refer the reader to Ito (1977), Strocchi (2013), Section 8.3 and
references therein.
14.4.3
Supersymmetric quantum ﬁelds
In Section 7.14, we mentioned supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld theory
(SQFT) as supersymmetric quantum mechanics with inﬁnite degrees of
freedom and constructed an abstract supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld model
(F(H , K ), Γ, QS, dΓ(S∗S, SS∗)) (see Remark 7.9). This abstract model
produces concrete supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld models according to the
choice of (H , K , S) (see, for example, Arai, 1993b, 2022). A feature of
912
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld models is that they may be less singular
than non-supersymmetric ones in the sense that, in supersymmetric quan-
tum ﬁeld models, some cancellations of ultraviolet divergences may occur.
Supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld models in the two-dimensional space-time
without ultraviolet cutoﬀ(but with space cutoﬀ) have been constructed
(see, for example, Jaﬀe et al., 1988 and references therein). It seems, how-
ever, that no completely relativistic supersymmetric quantum ﬁeld mod-
els with interactions have been constructed even in the two-dimensional
space-time.
14.5
Particle–Field Interaction Models
There are models which describe interactions of quantum particles with
a quantum ﬁeld (mainly a Bose ﬁeld). One of the most important
classes of models in this category is non-relativistic QED, which is
the quantum theory describing non-relativistic charged particles (typically,
non-relativistic electrons) interacting with the quantum radiation ﬁeld,
explaining with relatively high precision electromagnetic phenomena in
“non-relativistic regions” (for the physics of non-relativistic QED, see, for
example, Barut, 1980; Healy, 1982 and, for mathematically rigorous theo-
ries, see, for example, Spohn, 2004).
For simplicity, let us consider the case where the quantum ﬁeld under
consideration is a Bose ﬁeld. The Hilbert space of state vectors of a model
of this type is taken to be of the form
Fpb := Hp ⊗Fb(H ),
where Hp is a Hilbert space for the particle system and H is a one-particle
Hilbert space for the Bose ﬁeld. A general form of the Hamiltonian of such
a model is given by
Hpb := Hp ⊗I + I ⊗dΓb(hb) + Hint,
where Hp is a self-adjoint operator on Hp, denoting the Hamiltonian of
the particle system, dΓb(hb) is the boson second quantization operator of
a non-negative injective self-adjoint operator hb on H (the one-particle
Hamiltonian of the Bose ﬁeld) and Hint is a symmetric operator, denoting
an interaction of the particle system with the Bose ﬁeld.
Remark 14.3. From a more general point of view, the Hilbert space
Hp can be a Hilbert space of state vectors of any quantum system (not
Models in QFT
913
necessarily a quantum-particle system in its concrete realization). For exam-
ple, Hp may be taken to be H ′ ⊗Ff(K ), the tensor product of a Hilbert
space H ′ and the fermion Fock space over a Hilbert space K , so that
Fpb = H ′ ⊗Ff(K ) ⊗Fb(H ). As is seen, this Hilbert space may be the
most general Hilbert space in the sense that it gives a framework for a
quantum theory describing an interaction of a quantum system (associated
with H ′) with a Bose ﬁeld and a Fermi ﬁeld.
Before discussing concrete models in the category under consideration,
we make a remark on a general feature concerning the spectral analysis
of Hpb. To be deﬁnite, we consider the case where Hp and hb have the
following spectral structures:
σd(Hp) = {En}N
n=1,
E1 < E2 < · · · < En < En+1 < · · · < Σ,
σess(Hp) = [Σ, ∞),
σ(hb) = σc(hb) = [m, ∞)
with N < ∞or N = ∞(we use the convention that σess(Hp) = ∅⇐⇒Σ =
∞, the case where the spectrum of Hp is purely discrete) and m ≥0. In
this case, we have by an application of Theorem 5.3
σp(dΓb(hb)) = {0},
σc(dΓb(hb)) = [m, ∞),
where the eigenvalue 0 is simple and its eigenvector is the Fock vacuum ΩH
up to constant multiples. Hence, by the spectral theory of tensor products
of self-adjoint operators (see Theorems 3.8 and 3.13), the spectrum of the
unperturbed Hamiltonian
Hpb,0 := Hp ⊗I + I ⊗dΓb(hb)
is identiﬁed as follows (Fig. 14.1):
σp(Hpb,0) = {En}N
n=1,
σc(Hpb,0) = [E1 + m, ∞).
As is seen, any eigenvalue Ej more than or equal to E1 +m is embedded
in the continuous spectrum of Hpb,0, i.e., it is an embedded eigenvalue of
Hpb,0. In particular, if m = 0 (the massless case), then all the eigenvalues
of Hpb,0 are embedded ones. Hence, the spectral analysis of Hpb includes
the perturbation problem of embedded eigenvalues, which are diﬃcult to
treat in general because, in this case, the method of the standard analytic
(regular) perturbation theory (e.g., Kato, 1976; Reed and Simon, 1978) is
914
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Fig. 14.1
The spectrum of Hpb,0 (the case m < Σ −E1).
not valid any more. One must seek essentially new methods to solve the
perturbation problem of embedded eigenvalues in quantum ﬁeld theory.6
In the late 1990s, breakthroughs in this problem have been made by Arai
and Hirokawa (1997) and Bach et al. (1998a, 1998b). For a review on this
aspect, we refer the reader to Hiroshima (2005b, 2019).
We now describe some models.
14.5.1

In the vHM model in the context of nuclear physics, the ﬁxed sources are

Nelson (1964) proved that, in the case where m > 0, d = 3 and V = 0,
the ultraviolet cutoﬀκ can be removed in the following sense: there exist
a constant Eκ ∈R (this is explicitly given) and a self-adjoint operator H∞
on

(14.22)
This is a surprising result because it shows that the removal of the
ultraviolet cutoﬀκ can be carried out within the same Hilbert space, while,
in a conventional heuristic picture, the removal of the ultraviolet cutoﬀ
may change the Hilbert space of the representation of CCR (recall, for
example, the case of the vHM model discussed in Chapter 13). Nelson’s
result also shows the importance of the topology of convergence for the
nets of (unbounded) operators.8 Note also that (14.22) is equivalent to the
8In the present case, the strong convergence of one-parameter unitary groups. It is easy
to see that, for all f ∈L2((R3)N) with ∥f∥= 1,

f ⊗ΩL2(R3), (HN(κ) −Eκ)f ⊗ΩL2(R3)

= ⟨f, Hpf⟩−Eκ →+∞(κ →∞).
Hence, in the weak topology, {HN(κ) −Eκ}κ does not converge.
Models in QFT
917
strong resolvent convergence of {HN(κ) −Eκ}κ to H∞as κ →∞, i.e.,
limκ→∞(HN(κ) −Eκ −z)−1 = (H∞−z)−1, z ∈C \ R (see, for example,
Reed and Simon, 1980, Theorem VIII.21). A reﬁned analysis of the Nelson
model was given by Cannon (1971).
It is immediately apparent from Nelson’s paper (Nelson, 1964) that
(14.22) also holds in the case where m > 0, d = 1, 2, 3 and V belongs to a
suitable class of functions. For further developments on the removal of the
ultraviolet cutoﬀ(ultraviolet renormalization) in the Nelson model, see, for
example, G´erard et al. (2012), Gubinelli et al. (2014), Miyao (2019), and
Hiroshima and Matte (2022).
As in the case of other models, the existence of a ground state of HN(κ)
has been discussed, mainly in the massless case of m = 0 (Bach et al.,
1998b; G´erard, 2000; Hiroshima and Sasaki, 2008; Spohn, 1998). In the
massive case of m > 0, it is not so diﬃcult to show the existence and
uniqueness of a ground state of HN(κ) under a suitable condition for V
because, in this case, one can employ the method of constructive quantum
ﬁeld theory (Glimm and Jaﬀe, 1968b, 1970, 1985, 1987; Gross, 1972). But,
in the massless case of m = 0, infrared problems may occur, as mentioned
in the case of the massless vHM model in Chapter 13 (for a pioneering
work on this aspect, see Fr¨ohlich, 1973, 1974). In fact, it is shown that, in
the case d = 3 and N = 1, HN(κ) without infrared cutoﬀhas no ground
state (L¨orinczi et al., 2002a). But, if one uses a non-Fock representation for
the time-zero ﬁeld and its canonical conjugate momentum, one can show
that the Hamiltonian without infrared cutoﬀin this representation has a
ground state (Arai, 2001b; L¨orinczi et al., 2002b). This shows that, in the
Nelson model, the existence of a ground state depends on the choice of rep-
resentations of the time-zero ﬁeld and its canonical conjugate momentum
(we have seen this kind of phenomena in the vHM model in Chapter 13).
Sasaki (2005a) extended the result to the case where V is in a more general
class of functions. Also, the existence of a ground state of the renormalized
Hamiltonian H∞without infrared cutoﬀhas been shown in Hirokawa et al.
(2005). For a general mathematical formulation on the absence of ground
states, see Arai et al. (1999).

By using other methods, one can show that, for all q ∈R, HPF is
self-adjoint and bounded from below for a class of V . This result can be
extended to a many-particle system interacting with the quantum radiation
ﬁeld. For the details, see Hiroshima (2000), Hasler and Herbst (2008), and
Falconi (2015).
The Pauli–Fierz-type models have been extensively studied. Blanchard
(1969) may be the ﬁrst who studied the infrared problem of the Pauli–Fierz
model Hdipole in the dipole approximation (i.e., Hdipole is the operator HPF
with ˆAj,κ replaced by Aκ
j (0)). Arai (1983a) gave the ﬁrst complete analysis
of the model Hdipole in the case where d = 3 and V (x) = Mω0x2/2 (a har-
monic oscillator potential; ω0 > 0 is a constant), including the existence of
a ground state without an infrared cutoﬀand of resonances, the identiﬁca-
tion of the spectra of the Hamiltonian, scattering theory and the removal of
the ultraviolet cutoﬀ. See also Arai (1983b), where the Compton scattering
Models in QFT
921
in the dipole approximation is investigated with the need of electron mass
renormalization. A scaling limit on Hdipole is considered in Arai (1990) to
obtain an eﬀective quantum mechanical Hamiltonian. For the model Hdipole
with a general class of V , the asymptotic completeness for Rayleigh scat-
tering was proved by Spohn (1997).
The existence of a ground state of the original Pauli–Fierz model
without infrared cutoﬀwas shown in Griesemer et al. (2001). Related stud-
ies are found in, for example, Hiroshima and Spohn (2001), Hiroshima
(2001), Lieb and Loss (2003), Loss et al. (2007), Hiroshima (2007) and
Hiroshima and L¨orinczi (2008). For reviews on mathematical analysis of
non-relativistic QED and related topics, see, for example, Derezi´nski and
Siedentop (2006) and Hiroshima (2004, 2019). There are semi-relativistic
versions of the Pauli–Fierz model (Miyao and Spohn, 2009; Hiroshima,
2011, 2014; K¨onenberg et al., 2011; Hidaka and Hiroshima, 2016; Hidaka
et al., 2021).
There are investigations of non-relativistic QED using non-Coulomb
gauge and indeﬁnite metric Hilbert space (Suzuki, 2008; Hiroshima and
Suzuki, 2009) (recall Remark 11.1).
An interesting (but diﬃcult) open problem involving the Pauli–Fierz
model is to remove the ultraviolet cutoﬀ, where an inﬁnite mass renormal-
ization may be necessary (see, for example, Hainzl and Seiringer, 2002; Lieb
and Loss, 2002; Hiroshima and Spohn, 2005; Hiroshima and Ito, 2007).
14.5.3
Generalized spin-boson model
One can consider a general quantum system S interacting with a Bose ﬁeld
acting in the abstract boson Fock space Fb(Hb) over a Hilbert space Hb
(a one-particle Hilbert space). The Hilbert space for the composite system
is given by
FGSB := HS ⊗Fb(Hb),
where HS is a Hilbert space for the quantum system S. We denote by HS
the Hamiltonian of the quantum system S which is a self-adjoint operator
on HS and by hb the one-particle Hamiltonian of the Bose ﬁeld which is
a non-negative and injective self-adjoint operator on Hb. We suppose that
the interaction between the quantum system S and the Bose ﬁeld is given
by an operator of the form
HI(B, g) :=
J

(g1, . . . , gJ)). Then, the total Hamiltonian of the interacting system is
given by
HGSB := HS ⊗I + I ⊗dΓb(hb) + HI(B, g).
This model is called a generalized spin-boson (GSB) model (Arai and
Hirokawa, 1997), which covers a range of particle–boson interaction models
(for recent studies on the GSB model, see, for example, Takaesu, 2010;
Teranishi, 2015, 2018; Lonigro, 2022).

It is shown (Arai, 2001a) that, for a class of V , HDM is essentially
self-adjoint but unbounded from above and below. In the sense that it is
not bounded from below, HDM may be unphysical.11 But, for some physical
phenomena such as the Lamb shift (a very ﬁne energy-level shift observed at
the ﬁrst excited state of the hydrogen atom (Kinoshita, 1990), which cannot
be explained in terms of the Dirac operator 3
j=1 αj(−iDj)+βM +V , with
V (x) = −e2/(4πε0|x|) being the Coulomb potential (e > 0 is the funda-

of an electron with a photon), the model explains them to some extent,
although the explanations are based on formal perturbation theories (see,
10Pauli introduced the formal Hamiltonian for HDM with V = 0 in 1933 (Pauli, 1980,
(26.9)). It is cited in Bloch and Nordsieck (1937).
11In the standard picture in quantum theory, the boundedness from below of a Hamil-
tonian H is necessary for the stability of the quantum system described by H.
Models in QFT
925
for example, Nishijima, 1973). On the mathematical side, it is shown that
HDM has a non-relativistic limit in the sense of strong resolvent conver-
gence, which yields the Hamiltonian of the Pauli–Fierz model with spin
1/2 in non-relativistic QED (Arai, 2003, 2006a). These facts suggest that,
in a range of physical phenomena, the model may be physical. Hence, what
is important will be to clarify in what sense or in what range of physi-
cal phenomena the model is physical without invoking formal perturbation
theories.
The operator HDM may be interesting also from a purely operator-
theoretical point of view because HDM is made of objects in a representation
({α1, α2, α3, β}, {ˆqj, ˆpj}3

on HDM, see, for example, Futakuchi and Usui (2014b), Stockmeyer and
Zenk (2008), and Sasaki (2005b, 2014).

Chapter 15
Mathematical Formulation of
Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
We present an introduction to a mathematical theory of spontaneous symmetry
breaking, which is an important subject in QFT.
15.1
∗-Algebras and Representations
An axiomatic approach to symmetry aspects in QFT is given by an alge-
braic formulation of quantum physics. In this formulation, the concept of
∗-algebra plays a fundamental role. For this reason, we ﬁrst review basic
part of the theory of ∗-algebras.
15.1.1
∗-algebras
For each Hilbert space H , one has the Banach space B(H ) of everywhere
deﬁned bounded linear operators on H . It follows that B(H ) becomes an
algebra1 with product operation being the operator product. In addition
to the algebraic operations, B(H ) has another operation which, to each
A ∈B(H ), assigns its adjoint A∗. This operation is called the conjugate
operation and obeys the following laws: for all A, B ∈B(H ) and α, β ∈C,
(A∗)∗= A∗, (αA + βB)∗= α∗A∗+ β∗B∗and (AB)∗= B∗A∗. These
structures of B(H ) are brought into an abstract form to give a general
concept.
Deﬁnition 15.1. A set A is called a ∗-algebra if it is an algebra with a
mapping A ∋A →A∗∈A such that, for all A, B ∈A, α, β ∈C,
(A∗)∗= A,
(αA + βB)∗= α∗A∗+ β∗B∗,
(AB)∗= B∗A∗.
1See footnote right before Lemma 5.17.
929
930
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
The element A∗∈A corresponding to A ∈A is called the conjugate
element of A. The mapping A ∋A →A∗∈A is called the ∗-operation
on A.
A ∗-algebra with unit element is called a unital ∗-algebra.
We say that an element A ∈A is self-adjoint if A∗= A.
Proposition 15.1. Let A be a unital ∗-algebra.
(i) The unit element I ∈A is self-adjoint, i.e., I∗= I.
(ii) For each A ∈A, there exists a unique pair (A1, A2) of self-adjoint
elements in A such that
A = A1 + iA2.
(15.1)
Proof. (i) We have I∗= II∗. Hence, I = (II∗)∗= II∗= I∗.
(ii) Let
A1 := 1
2(A + A∗) ∈A,
A2 := 1
2i(A −A∗) ∈A.
Then, it is easy to see that A1 and A2 are self-adjoint and (15.1) holds.
To prove the uniqueness of (A1, A2) in (15.1), let A = B1 + iB2 with
self-adjoint elements B1 and B2 in A. Then, A1 −B1 = i(B2 −A2). Tak-
ing the ∗-operation on this equation, we have A1 −B1 = −i(B2 −A2).
Hence, it follows that A1 −B1 = 0 and B2 −A2 = 0. Thus, B1 = A1 and
B2 = A2.
□
The self-adjoint element A1 (resp., A2) in (15.1) is called the real
(resp., imaginary) part of A.
Remark 15.1. In general, for a unital algebra A, a mapping ι : A →A is
called an involution on A if ι(I) = I, ι(ι(A)) = A and ι(AB) = ι(B)ι(A),
for all A, B ∈A. The ∗-operation on A is an involution on A.
In what follows, for convenience, we mean by ∗-algebra a unital ∗-algebra
unless otherwise stated.
Example 15.1. As we have seen above, B(H ) is a ∗-algebra, with ∗-
operation being the conjugate operation.
Deﬁnition 15.2. A subset M of a ∗-algebra A is called a ∗-subalgebra
of A if it is a ∗-algebra with the algebraic and the ∗-operations of A.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
931
With regard to existence of ∗-subalgebra, we have the following.
Lemma 15.1. Let D0 be a non-empty subset of a ∗-algebra A. Then, there
exists a unique ∗-subalgebra D such that D0 ⊂D and, if M is a ∗-subalgebra
of A satisfying D0 ⊂M, then D ⊂M.
Proof. Let S be the set of all ∗-subalgebra including D0. Then, since
A ∈S , S is not empty. Hence, D := ∩M∈S M is a non-empty subset of A.
It is easy to check that D is the desired ∗-subalgebra.
□
The ∗-subalgebra D in Lemma 15.1 is the smallest ∗-subalgebra includ-
ing D0. We call D the ∗-algebra generated by D0. The elements of D0
are called the generators of D.
There are some notions of mappings from a ∗-algebra to a ∗-algebra.
Deﬁnition 15.3. Let A and B be ∗-algebras. A mapping φ : A →B is
called a ∗-homomorphism if
φ(αA + βB) = αφ(A) + βφ(B),
φ(AB) = φ(A)φ(B),
φ(A)∗= φ(A∗),
A, B ∈A, α, β ∈C.
A bijective ∗-homomorphism is called a ∗-isomorphism. In particular,
a ∗-isomorphism from A to A is called a ∗-automorphism on A.
As
is
easily
seen,
the
inverse
of
a
∗-automorphism is
also
a
∗-automorphism. Hence, the following deﬁnition has mathematical mean-
ing: two ∗-algebras A and B are said to be ∗-isomorphic if there exists a
∗-isomorphism from A to B.
Let φ1, φ2 : A →A be ∗-automorphisms. Then, it is easy to see that
the product φ1φ2 := φ1 ◦φ2 (the composite mapping2 of φ2 and φ1) is also
a ∗-automorphism on A and the set of all ∗-automorphisms on A forms a
group with this product operation. The group, denoted ∗-Aut(A), is called
the ∗-automorphism group on A.
Proposition 15.2. Let φ be a ∗-automorphism on A. Then, φ(I) = I.
Proof. For all A ∈A, we have φ(A)φ(I) = φ(AI) = φ(A) and φ(I)φ(A) =
φ(IA) = φ(A). Since φ is surjective, this implies that, for all A ∈A,
Aφ(I) = φ(I)A = A. Hence, φ(I) = I.
□
2(φ1 ◦φ2)(A) := φ1(φ2(A)), A ∈A.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
15.1.2
C∗-algebra and von Neumann algebra
The concept of ∗-algebra is purely algebraic. But there exist ∗-algebras
which
have
topological
structures,
such
as
the
∗-algebra
B(H )
(Example 15.1) is a Banach space with respect to operator norm. In this
section, we introduce two topological ∗-algebras.
Deﬁnition 15.4. A ∗-algebra A is called a C∗-algebra if it is a Banach
space with a norm ∥· ∥on A such that, for all A, B ∈A,
(i) ∥AB∥≤∥A∥∥B∥,
(ii) ∥A∗∥= ∥A∥,
(iii) ∥A∗A∥= ∥A∥2.
A ∗-subalgebra M of a C∗-algebra A is called a C∗-subalgebra of A if
M is a C∗-algebra with respect to the norm of A.
Example 15.2. The ∗-algebra B(H ) is a C∗-algebra with operator norm.
A C∗-subalgebra of B(H ) is called a concrete C∗-algebra.
Let H be a Hilbert space and L(H ) be the set of all linear operators
on H as before. Let L be a non-empty subset of L(H ) and L′ be the
commutant of L (see (5.68)).
Lemma 15.2. If L is ∗-invariant,3 then L′ is a ∗-subalgebra of B(H ).
Proof. We need only to prove that, for each B ∈L′, B∗∈L′. Under the
present assumption, for all T ∈L, BT ∗⊂T ∗B. Hence, (T ∗B)∗⊂(BT ∗)∗.
We have (T ∗B)∗⊃B∗T ∗∗= B∗T and (BT ∗)∗= T ∗∗B∗= T B∗(note that
B is bounded). Hence, B∗T ⊂T B∗. Thus, B∗∈L′.
□
Since L′ is a non-empty subset of B(H ) and hence of L(H ), the com-
mutant of L′
L′′ := (L′)′ = {A ∈B(H )|AB = BA, B ∈L′}
(15.2)
is deﬁned. The subalgebra L′′ is called the the double commutant of L.
Let N be a ∗-subalgebra of B(H ). Then, by Lemma 15.2, N′ is a
∗-subalgebra of B(H ). Hence, so is N′′. Therefore, the following deﬁnition
is possible.
Deﬁnition 15.5. A ∗-subalgebra N of B(H ) satisfying N′′ = N is called
a von Neumann algebra.
3See the paragraph right after the proof of Lemma 5.8.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
933
Remark 15.2. Let N be a ∗-subalgebra of B(H ). Then, the following
conditions are equivalent:
(i) N is a von Neumann algebra.
(ii) I ∈N and N is strongly closed, i.e., N is closed in the strong operator
topology on B(H ) (see Remark 1.6 (ii)).
(iii) I ∈N and N is weakly closed, i.e., N is closed in the weak operator
topology on B(H ) (see Remark 1.6 (iii)).
For a proof of this theorem, see Bratteli and Robinson (1979), Theo-
rem 2.4.11. There are authors who use (ii) or (iii) as the deﬁnition of a
von Neumann algebra.
Proposition 15.3. A von Neumann algebra is a C∗-algebra in the operator
norm topology.
Proof. Let N be a von Neumann algebra. We need only to prove the
completeness of N in the uniform topology (operator norm topology). Let
{An}∞
n=1 with An ∈N ⊂B(H ) (n ∈N) be a Cauchy sequence in operator
norm, i.e., ∥An −Am∥→0 (n, m →∞). By the completeness of B(H ),
there exists an operator A ∈B(H ) such that ∥An −A∥→0 (n →∞).
Since An ∈N = N′′, we have AnB = BAn for all B ∈N′. Taking the limit
n →∞in this equation (in the uniform topology), we obtain AB = BA.
Hence, A ∈N′′. Therefore, A ∈N. Thus, N is complete in the uniform
topology.
□
15.1.3
O∗-algebra
For a dense subspace D of H , we deﬁne a subset of L(H ):
L(D) := {X ∈L(H )|D(X) = D, Ran(X) ⊂D}.
Since D is dense in H , each element X in L(D) is densely deﬁned. Hence,
X∗exists. But D(X∗) does not necessarily include D, and even in the
case where D ⊂D(X∗), it does not necessarily hold that Ran(X∗↾D)
⊂D. Taking these matters into account, we introduce the following set of
operators:
L†(D) := {X ∈L(D)|D ⊂D(X∗), X∗D ⊂D}.
(15.3)
For each X ∈L†(D), X∗is densely deﬁned, and hence X is closable.
The set L†(D) becomes a vector space with addition and scalar multipli-
cation for linear operators, where the zero-vector is 0D, the zero-operator
934
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
restricted to D. Moreover, letting X† := X∗↾D for X ∈L†(D), L†(D)
becomes a ∗-algebra, with the ∗-operation deﬁned by X →X† (the restric-
tion ID of the identity on H is the identity in L†(D)). The ∗-algebra L†(D)
is called the O∗-algebra associated with D. For a general theory of
O∗-algebra, see Inoue (1988) and Schm¨udgen (1990).
Remark 15.3. In the case where D = H , each X ∈L†(H ) satisﬁes
D(X) = H and D(X∗) = H , which imply that X = (X∗)∗. Hence, X
is a closed operator. Then, according to the closed graph theorem, X is
bounded. Thus, L†(H ) = B(H ).
15.1.4
States on ∗-algebras
Let A be a ∗-algebra. We denote by A∗the set of linear functionals on A
(the algebraic dual space of A):
A∗:= {φ : A →C|φ is linear}.
The set A∗becomes a complex vector space with addition and scalar mul-
tiplication of linear functionals.
An element ω ∈A∗is called a positive linear functional on A if it
satisﬁes the positivity condition
ω(A∗A) ≥0,
A ∈A.
The basic properties of a positive linear functional are described in the
following proposition.
Proposition 15.4. Let ω be a positive linear functional on A.
(i) For all A ∈A,
ω(A)∗= ω(A∗).
(15.4)
In particular, if A is self-adjoint, then ω(A) is a real number.
(ii) (Schwarz inequality) For all A, B ∈A,
|ω(A∗B)| ≤ω(A∗A)1/2ω(B∗B)1/2.
(15.5)
(iii) If ω ̸= 0, then ω(I) > 0.
Proof. (i) We ﬁrst show that, if A is a self-adjoint element in A, then ω(A)
is a real number. Let A ∈A be self-adjoint. Then, by the positivity of ω,
ω((I + A)∗(I + A)) ≥0. Since A and I are self-adjoint, we have
(I + A)∗(I + A) = (I + A)2 = I + 2A + A2.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
935
Hence, ω(I) + 2ω(A) + ω(A2) ≥0. Note that
ω(I) = ω(I∗I) ≥0
(15.6)
and ω(A2) = ω(A∗A) ≥0. Therefore ω(A) is a real number.
We next consider the case where A is any element in A. Then, by
(15.1), we have ω(A) = ω(A1) + iω(A2). By the preceding result, ω(Aj)∗=
ω(Aj), j = 1, 2. Hence,
ω(A)∗= ω(A1) −iω(A2) = ω(A1 −iA2) = ω(A∗).
Thus, (15.4) holds.
(ii) For all z ∈C, ω((A + zB)∗(A + zB)) ≥0. Hence,
ω(A∗A) + zω(A∗B) + z∗ω(B∗A) + |z|2ω(B∗B) ≥0.
By (15.4), we have ω(B∗A) = ω(A∗B)∗. Using the polar form for complex
numbers, we have ω(A∗B) = |ω(A∗B)|eiθ with some θ ∈R. Take z = xe−iθ
with x ∈R arbitrary. Then, we have
ω(A∗A) + 2x|ω(A∗B)| + x2ω(B∗B) ≥0.
Since x is an arbitrary real number, it follows that
|ω(A∗B)|2 ≤ω(A∗A)ω(B∗B).
Thus, (15.5) holds.
(iii) Since ω ̸= 0, there exists an element A ∈A such that ω(A) ̸= 0.
Then, by (15.4), ω(A∗) ̸= 0. By taking B = I in (15.5), we have 0 <
|ω(A∗)| ≤ω(A∗A)1/2ω(I)1/2. This implies that ω(I) ̸= 0.
□
An important class of positive linear functionals on A is deﬁned as
follows.
Deﬁnition 15.6. A positive linear functional ω on A is called a state on
A if it satisﬁes the normalization condition ω(I) = 1. We denote by EA
the set of all states on A. It is called the state space on A.
By Proposition 15.4 (iii), for each non-zero positive linear functional ω
on A, one can deﬁne a positive linear functional ω on A by
ω :=
1
ω(I)ω.
It is obvious that ω(I) = 1. Hence, ω is a state on A, i.e., ω ∈EA. We call ω
the normalization of ω. Thus, to each non-zero positive linear functional
on A, there corresponds a state on A.
936
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
It is easy to see that, for non-zero positive linear functionals ω1 and
ω2 on A, ω1 = ω2 if and only if there is a constant α > 0 such that
ω1 = αω2.
Proposition 15.5. The set EA is a convex set, i.e., for all ω1, ω2 ∈EA and
λ ∈(0, 1) λω1 + (1 −λ)ω2 ∈EA.
Based on Proposition 15.5, we deﬁne a notion on state: a state ω ∈EA
is called a mixed state if there are two diﬀerent states ω1, ω2 ∈EA and
λ ∈(0, 1) such that ω = λω1 + (1 −λ)ω2. In this case, ω is said to be a
non-trivial mixture of ω1 and ω2. A state is said to be a pure state if
it is not a mixed state.
Example 15.3. Let L†(D) be the O∗-algebra associated with a subspace
D dense in a Hilbert space H (see Section 15.1.3) and M be a ∗-subalgebra
of L†(D) with ID ∈M. For each unit vector Ψ ∈D, a mapping ωΨ : M →C
is deﬁned by
ωΨ(A) := ⟨Ψ, AΨ⟩,
A ∈M.
It is easy to check that ωΨ is a state on M. The state ωΨ is called the vector
state deﬁned by Ψ. A vector state on M is deﬁned to be a state ω on M
such that ω = ωΨ, for some Ψ ∈D.
Let us prove the following fact:
• For all unit vectors Ψ ∈D, the vector state ωΨ on L†(D) is a pure state.
Proof. We prove the assertion by reduction to absurdity. Suppose that ωΨ
is not a pure state. Then, there are two diﬀerent states ω1, ω2 and λ ∈(0, 1)
such that ωΨ = λω1 + (1 −λ)ω2. Hence,
⟨Ψ, AΨ⟩= λω1(A) + (1 −λ)ω2(A),
A ∈L†(D).
(15.7)
Let PΨ be the orthogonal projection onto the one-dimensional subspace
K
:= {αΨ|α ∈C}. Then, for all Φ ∈H , PΨΦ = ⟨Ψ, Φ⟩Ψ. Hence,
PΨD ⊂D. Let P := PΨ ↾D. Then, P ∗= PΨ. Hence, it follows that
P ∈L†(D). The operator QΨ := I −PΨ is the orthogonal projection onto
K ⊥, the orthogonal complement of K . It follows that Q := QΨ ↾D is in
L†(D). Taking A = Q†Q in (15.7), we have
0 = λω1(Q†Q) + (1 −λ)ω2(Q†Q).
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
937
Since each term on the right-hand side is non-negative and 0 < λ < 1,
it follows that ω1(Q†Q) = 0 and ω2(Q†Q) = 0. For all A ∈L†(D), the
Schwarz inequality yields
|ωj(AQ)|2 ≤ωj(AA†)ωj(Q†Q) = 0,
j = 1, 2.
Hence, ωj(AQ) = 0. Similarly, ωj(QA) = 0. We have
PAP = (1 −Q)A(1 −Q) = A −AQ −QA + QAQ.
Hence, ωj(PAP) = ωj(A). On the other hand, one can show that, for
all Φ ∈H , PAPΦ = ωΨ(A)PΦ. Hence, PAP = ωΨ(A)P. Hence, ωj(A) =
ωΨ(A)ωj(P). Taking A = ID, we obtain ωj(P) = 1. Hence, ωj(A) = ωΨ(A).
Since A is an arbitrary element in L†(D), it follows that ωj = ω, j = 1, 2.
But this contradicts the assumption ω1 ̸= ω2. Thus, we arrive at a contra-
diction.
□
It follows from the fact just proved that any non-trivial mixture of two
vector states on L†(D) cannot be a vector state on L†(D).
Remark 15.4. Let M be a ∗-subalgebra of L†(D) with ID ∈M. Then, the
proof above shows that, if PΨ ↾D is an element in M, then ωΨ is a pure
state on M.
We remark that a vector state is not always a pure state; it depends on
the ∗-algebra under consideration.
Example 15.4. Let H1 and H2 be Hilbert spaces and H := H1 ⊕H2 be
the direct sum Hilbert space of H1 and H2. It is easy to see that the direct
sum B(H1) ⊕B(H2) is a ∗-subalgebra of B(H ). Let Ψ = (Ψ1, Ψ2) ∈H
be a unit vector with Ψ1 ̸= 0 and Ψ2 ̸= 0. Then,
∥Ψ1∥2 + ∥Ψ2∥2 = 1,
0 < ∥Ψj∥2 < 1,

Therefore, ωΨ as a vector state on B(H1) ⊕B(H1) is a mixed state of the
vector states ω( ˆΨ1,0) and ω(0, ˆΨ2) on B(H1) ⊕B(H1).
A positive linear functional on a C∗-algebra has strong properties.
Proposition 15.6. Let A be a C∗-algebra with norm ∥· ∥. Then:
(i) Every positive linear functional ω on A satisﬁes
|ω(A)| ≤ω(I)∥A∥,
A ∈A.
(15.8)
In particular, ω is bounded with
∥ω∥= ω(I).
(15.9)
(ii) For all A, B ∈A,
|ω(B∗AB)| ≤∥A∥ω(B∗B).
(15.10)
Proof. (i) For simplicity, we give a proof only in the case where A is a
concrete C∗-algebra, i.e., A is a C∗-subalgebra of B(H ) (see Example
15.2).4
Let A ∈A. Then, ∥A∥2 −A∗A ≥0. Hence, ∥A∥2ω(I) ≥ω(A∗A). By
this fact and Proposition 15.4(ii), we have
|ω(A)| = |ω(I∗A)| ≤ω(I)1/2ω(A∗A)1/2 ≤ω(I)∥A∥.
Hence, (15.8) follows.
By (15.8), we have ∥ω∥≤ω(I). On the other hand, ω(I) ≤∥ω∥∥I∥=
∥ω∥. Hence, (15.9) follows.
(ii) Let B be ﬁxed and deﬁne a mapping η : A →C by η(A) :=
ω(B∗AB). Then, η(A∗A) = ω((AB)∗AB) ≥0. Hence, η is a positive
linear functional on A. Applying (15.8) with ω replaced by η, we have
∥η(A)∥≤η(I)∥A∥. We have η(I) = ω(B∗B). Thus, (15.10) follows.

15.1.5
Representations of ∗-algebras
There is a concept concerning the realizations of a ∗-algebra as a ∗-algebra
consisting of linear operators on a Hilbert space.
4For the abstract C∗-algebra, one can develop a spectral theory in quite a parallel
way to the spectral theory of B(H ) (see, for example, Bratteli and Robinson, 1979,
Section 2.2 or Arai, 2008, Chapter 3). Then, the proof given as follows applies to the
case of the abstract C∗-algebra too.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
939
Deﬁnition 15.7. Let H be a Hilbert space and D be a dense subspace
of H . Let A be a ∗-algebra. A ∗-homomorphism π : A →L†(D) satisfying
π(I) = ID is called a ∗-representation, or simply a representation, of
A on H . We write D = D(π). The Hilbert space H is called a represen-
tation space of A. The triple (H , π, D(π)) is also called a representation
of A.
For a representation (H , π, D(π)) of a ∗-algebra A and a unitary oper-
ator U from H to a Hilbert space K , one can deﬁne
(UπU −1)(A) := Uπ(A)U −1,
A ∈A.
(15.11)
Then, it is easy to see that (K , UπU −1, UD(π)) is a representation of A.
This representation is called the unitary transform of the represen-
tation π by U. Hence, inﬁnitely many representations of A are associated
with a given representation of A.
In the case where D(π) = H in the representation (H , π, D(π)) of A,
it follows from Remark 15.3 that π is a ∗-homomorphism from A to B(H )
and hence, π(A) ∈B(H ), A ∈A. We call this type of representation a
bounded representation of A and write it (H , π).
We note the following fact.
Proposition 15.7. Let (H , π, D(π)) be a representation of a ∗-algebra A.
Suppose that, for each A ∈A, π(A) is bounded (hence, the closure π(A) of
π(A) is an element in B(H )). Deﬁne a mapping ¯π : A →B(H ) by
¯π(A) := π(A),
A ∈A.
Then, ¯π is a bounded representation of A.
Proof. The linearity of ¯π and the property ¯π(AB) = ¯π(A)¯π(B)(A, B ∈A)
are easy to prove.5 For each A ∈A, ¯π(A)∗= π(A)∗= π(A)† = π(A∗) =
¯π(A∗). Thus, ¯π is a ∗-homomorphism from A to B(H ).
□
A concept on equivalence between two representations of a ∗-algebra is
deﬁned as follows.
Deﬁnition 15.8. Let (H1, π1, D(π1)) and (H2, π2, D(π2)) be two represen-
tations of a ∗-algebra A.
5Use the following facts: for densely deﬁned bounded linear operators T and S on a
Hilbert space, αT + βS = α ¯T + β ¯S, α, β ∈C and ST = ¯S ¯T.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
(i) If there exists a unitary transformation U : H1 →H2 such that
Uπ1(A)U −1 = π2(A),
A ∈A,
(15.12)
then π1 is said to be unitarily equivalent (or equivalent) to π2.
(ii) The representation π1 is said to be inequivalent to π2 if π1 is not
unitarily equivalent to π2.
Remark 15.5. Operator equality (15.12) means that each π1(A) is unitar-
ily equivalent to π2(A) under the same unitary transformation U. It follows
that
UD(π1) = D(π2).
(15.13)
In Deﬁnition 5.2, we have introduced the concepts of reducibility and
irreducibility of a set of linear operators on a Hilbert space. They are used to
deﬁne the reducibility and irreducibility of a representation of a ∗-algebra.
Deﬁnition 15.9. A representation π of a ∗-algebra is said to be reducible
(resp., irreducible) if
π(A) := {π(A)|A ∈A}
(15.14)
is reducible (resp., irreducible).
Theorem 15.1. Let π of a representation of a ∗-algebra A such that
π(A)′ = CI. Then, π is irreducible.
Proof. We need only to apply Proposition 5.11(i) to the case where L =
π(A).
□
With regard to bounded representations of a ∗-algebra, we have the
following theorem.
Theorem 15.2. Let π be a bounded representation of a ∗-algebra A. Then,
π is irreducible if and only if π(A)′ = CI.
Proof. Suppose that π is irreducible. Since π is a bounded representation,
π(A)† = π(A)∗. Hence, π(A) is ∗-invariant. By this fact and Proposition
5.11(ii), π(A)′ = CI. The converse follows from Theorem 15.1.
□
Let A be a ∗-algebra and π be a representation of A. Then, for each
∗-automorphism α on A (i.e., α ∈∗-Aut(A)), a composite mapping π ◦α :
A →L†(D(π)) is deﬁned by
(π ◦α)(A) := π(α(A)),
A ∈A.
(15.15)
The following fact is easily proven.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking

Lemma 15.3. The mapping π ◦α is a representation of A with D(π ◦α) =
D(π).
Theorem 15.3. If π(A)′ = CI, then (π ◦α)(A)′ = CI and the representa-
tion π ◦α is irreducible.
Proof. We set η := π ◦α. Let T
∈η(A)′. Then, for all A ∈A,
T η(A) ⊂η(A)T . Hence T π(α(A)) ⊂π(α(A))T . Since α is surjective, this
implies that T ∈π(A)′. Hence, there exists a number λ ∈C such that
T = λI. Therefore, η(A)′ = CI. By Theorem 15.1, this implies that η is
irreducible.

Theorems 15.3 and 15.2 yield the following.
Corollary 15.1. Let π be a bounded irreducible representation of a
∗-algebra A and α ∈∗-Aut(A). Then, so is π ◦α.
15.1.6
GNS representation
In this section, we show that each state of a ∗-algebra A deﬁnes, in a natural
way, a representation of A.
Let H be a Hilbert space and L be a set of linear operators on H
(i.e., L ⊂L(H )). A vector Ψ ∈H is called a cyclic vector for L if
Ψ ∈∩A∈LD(A) and the subspace generated by the set
LΨ := {AΨ|A ∈L}
(15.16)
is dense in H . If there exists a cyclic vector for L, then L is said to have a
cyclic vector.
Let (H , π, D(π)) be a representation of a ∗-algebra A. Then, for each
vector Ψ ∈D(π), π(A)Ψ = {π(A)Ψ|A ∈A} becomes a subspace of H .
If π(A) has a cyclic vector Ω ∈H and D(π) = π(A)Ω, then π is called
a cyclic representation of A with respect to Ω. We write it as (H , π, Ω).
The following theorem tells us that a state on A deﬁnes a cyclic repre-
sentation of A in a natural way.
Theorem 15.4. Let A be a ∗-algebra and ω be a state on A (i.e., ω ∈EA).
Then, there exist a Hilbert space Hω, a unit vector Ωω ∈Hω and a repre-
sentation πω of A on Hω such that (Hω, πω, Ωω) is a cyclic representation
of A and
ω(A) = ⟨Ωω, πω(A)Ωω⟩, A ∈A.
(15.17)
Proof. We divide the proof of this theorem into two steps.
942
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Step 1: Construction of Hω
For A, B ∈A, we deﬁne a complex number ⟨A, B⟩by
⟨A, B⟩:= ω(A∗B).
Then, it is easy to see that the following hold (A, B, B1, B2 ∈A, α1, α2 ∈C):
(a) (positivity) ⟨A, A⟩≥0; (b)(linearity) ⟨A, α1B1 + α2B2⟩= α1 ⟨A, B1⟩+
α2 ⟨A, B2⟩; (c) (Hermitian property) ⟨A, B⟩∗= ⟨B, A⟩. This means that the
mapping A × A ∋(A, B) →⟨A, B⟩is a positive semi-deﬁnite inner product
of A (see Section 2.1.2). Hence, we can apply Problem 1 in Chapter 2 to
construct a Hilbert space. Namely, we deﬁne some objects in the following
order:
(i) (null space)A0 := {A ∈A| ⟨A, A⟩= 0}.
(ii) (equivalence relation) A ∼B
def
⇐⇒A −B ∈A0 (A, B ∈A).
(iii) (equivalence class) [A] := {B ∈A|B ∼A}.
(iv) (quotient vector space)
Dω := A/A0 := {[A]|A ∈A}
(15.18)
with addition [A] + [B] := [A + B] and scalar multiplication α[A] :=
[αA] (A.B ∈A, α ∈C).
(v) (inner product)
⟨[A], [B]⟩:= ⟨A, B⟩,
[A], [B] ∈Dω.
The completion
Hω := Dω
(15.19)
of the inner product space Dω gives the Hilbert space we seek. By construc-
tion, Dω is regarded as a dense subspace of Hω.
Step 2: Construction of a representation
We deﬁne
Ωω := [I] ∈Dω.
Since ⟨[1], [1]⟩= ω(I∗I) = ω(I) = 1, Ωω is a unit vector: ∥Ωω∥= 1. For
each A ∈A, we deﬁne πω(A) : Dω →Dω by
πω(A)[X] := [AX],
[X] ∈Dω.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
943
It is easy to see that, if X ∼Y (X, Y ∈A), then AX ∼AY (use the
Schwarz inequality). Hence, the deﬁnition of πω(A) is well-deﬁned, i.e., it is
independent of the choice of representatives from [X]. It follows that πω(A)
is linear and
πω(A)Ωω = [A].
Hence,
Dω = πω(A)Ωω.
(15.20)
For all A, B ∈A,
πω(AB)[X] = [ABX] = πω(A)[BX] = πω(A)πω(B)[X],
[X] ∈Dω.
Hence,
πω(AB) = πω(A)πω(B).
For all [X], [Y ] ∈Dω, we have
⟨[Y ], πω(A)[X]⟩= ω(Y ∗AX) = ω(X∗A∗Y )∗= ⟨πω(A∗)[Y ], [X]⟩.
Hence, πω(A)∗⊃πω(A∗). Therefore, πω(A)† = πω(A∗). Thus, πω is a repre-
sentation of A. By (15.20), this representation is a cyclic representation with
respect to Ωω. Formula (15.17) immediately follows from the deﬁnitions of
the inner product, Ωω and πω.
□
The cyclic representation (Hω, πω, Ωω) constructed in the proof of The-
orem 15.4 is called the Gel’fand–Naimark–Segal (GNS) representa-
tion, or the canonical cyclic representation of A associated with the
state ω on A. The construction is called the GNS construction.
The GNS representation of a ∗-algebra A associated with a state on A
is unique up to unitary equivalences.
Theorem 15.5 (Uniqueness of GNS representation). Let ω
∈EA
and (Hω, πω, Ωω) be the GNS representation of A associated with ω. Sup-
pose that there exists a cyclic representation (H , π, Ω) of A such that
⟨Ω, π(A)Ω⟩= ω(A),
A ∈A.
(15.21)
Then, there exists a unitary transformation U : H →Hω such that
UΩ = Ωω,
(15.22)
Uπ(A)U −1 = πω(A),
A ∈A,
(15.23)
i.e., π is unitarily equivalent to πω with the correspondence Ω →Ωω for
the cyclic vectors.

Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Proof. Let D := π(A)Ω. Then, a mapping U0 : D →Dω is deﬁned by
U0π(A)Ω := πω(A)Ωω,
A ∈A.
(15.24)
It is easy to see that U0 is linear. We have, for all A, B ∈A,
⟨πω(A)Ωω, πω(B)Ωω⟩= ω(A∗B)
(by (15.17))
= ⟨Ω, π(A∗B)Ω⟩
(by (15.21))
= ⟨π(A)Ω, π(B)Ω⟩.
Hence, ⟨U0π(A)Ω, U0π(B)Ω⟩.
=
⟨π(A)Ω, π(B)Ω⟩. It is obvious that
U0D = Dω. Therefore, by the extension theorem (Theorem 1.3), there exists
a unique unitary transformation U : H →Hω such that U ↾D = U0. Let
Ψ = πω(B)Ωω ∈Dω. Then, U −1Ψ = π(B)Ω. Hence,
Uπ(A)U −1Ψ = πω(AB)Ωω = πω(A)Ψ.
Since UD = Dω, this implies the operator equality (15.23). Equation (15.22)
follows from taking A = I in (15.24).
□
Henceforth, based on Theorem 15.5, we identify any representation
(H , π, Ω) of A as described in Theorem 15.5 with the GNS representation
(Hω, πω, Ωω of A.
With regard to the GNS representation of a C∗-algebra A, it has
boundedness.

∥πω(A)∥≤∥A∥.
(15.25)
Proof. Let Ψ = πω(B)Ωω ∈Dω (B ∈A). Then, for all A ∈A, πω(A)Ψ =

≤∥A∗A∥ω(B∗B)
( by (15.10))

¯πω : A →B(Hω) by

Then, ¯πω is a bounded representation of A with ∥¯πω(A)∥≤∥A∥.
15.1.7
Weyl algebras
In this section, we introduce a speciﬁc class of ∗-algebras which forms a
basis in the mathematical construction of Bose ﬁelds.
Let V be a complex inner product space and V be the Hilbert space
obtained by the completion of V .6 Then, we have the boson Fock space
Fb(V ) over V . For each f ∈V , we deﬁne
WF(f) := eiΦS(f),
(15.26)
where ΦS(f) is the Segal ﬁeld operator on Fb(V ) (see Chapter 5). By
Theorem 5.27, the following hold:
WF(0) = I,
WF(f)∗= WF(−f),
WF(f + g) = eiIm ⟨f,g⟩V /2WF(f)WF(g),
f, g ∈V .
(15.27)
The set {WF(f)|f ∈V } is a subset of the ∗-algebra B(Fb(V )) (the set
of all everywhere deﬁned bounded linear operators on Fb(V )). Hence,
the ∗-algebra generated by {WF(f)|f ∈V } exists. This ∗-algebra has an
abstract form.
Deﬁnition 15.10. The Weyl algebra over V , denoted W(V ), is deﬁned
as the ∗-algebra generated by the elements W(f), f ∈V with relations
W(f)∗= W(−f),
(15.28)
W(f + g) = eiIm ⟨f,g⟩V /2W(f)W(g),
f, g ∈V .
(15.29)
If V
is ﬁnite dimensional, then W(V ) is said to have ﬁnite degrees
of
freedom
and
dim V
is
called
the
degree of
W(V ).
If
V
is
inﬁnite-dimensional, then W(V ) is said to have inﬁnite degrees of
freedom.
Remark 15.6. The notion of the Weyl algebra over V is generalized by
replacing the factor Im ⟨f, g⟩V in (15.29) with a real symplectic form ω(f, g)
(see Remarks 5.32 and 5.44).
6If V is complete, i.e., V is a Hilbert space, then V = V .

We introduce a class of representations of the Weyl algebra W(V ).
A representation (H , π) of W(V ) is said to be regular if each unitary
operator π(W(f)) is weakly continuous in f ∈V (i.e., for all Ψ, Φ ∈H ,
the correspondence f →⟨Ψ, π(W(f))Φ⟩is continuous).
It is easy to see that, if (H , π) is a regular representation of W(V ),
then, for any unitary transformation U : H →K (a Hilbert space), the
representation (K , UπU −1) (see (15.11)) is also regular. Hence, the regu-
larity of representations of the Weyl algebra over an inner product space is
a unitary invariant notion.
It follows that the representations of W(V ) are divided into two classes,
i.e., regular ones and non-regular ones. With regard to the regular repre-
sentations of W(V ), we have the following.

W(V ). Then, π(W(f)) is strongly continuous in f ∈V .

Remark 15.7. In QFT, in addition to Weyl algebra, another ∗-algebra
plays an important role; it is deﬁned as the ∗-algebra generated by elements
ψ(f), ψ(f)∗, f ∈K (a Hilbert space) with relations
ψ(αf + βg) = αψ(f) + βψ(g),
{ψ(f), ψ(g)∗} = ⟨f, g⟩K ,
{ψ(f), ψ(g)} = 0,
{ψ(f)∗, ψ(g)∗} = 0,
f, g ∈K , α, β ∈C,
where {A, B} := AB + BA (anti-commutator). This ∗-algebra is called
the CAR algebra over K and is used to construct Fermi ﬁelds. Sections
6.14 and 6.16 in this book can be rewritten from the point of view of the
representations of CAR algebra.
