15.1.8
Schr¨odinger representation of Weyl algebra with
ﬁnite degrees of freedom and uniqueness theorem
In this section, we consider the representations of a Weyl algebra with
ﬁnite degrees of freedom and show that, under a suitable condition, they
are unique up to unitary equivalences.
We ﬁrst review the basic facts in quantum mechanics in the Schr¨odinger
representation of the CCR with N degrees of freedom (N ∈N) (see Remark
5.36). Let qn and pn (n = 1, . . . , N) be the self-adjoint operators on L2(RN),
as described in Remark 5.36. Then, for all t ∈R, eitqn and eitpn are unitary
operators satisfying the following: for all s, t ∈R and n, m = 1, . . . , N,
eisqneitpm = e−istδnmeitpmeisqn,
(15.34)
eisqneitqm = eitqmeisqn,
eispneitpm = eitpmeispn.
(15.35)
The following fact is well known.
Theorem 15.7. The set {eitqn, eitpn|t ∈R, n = 1, . . . , N} is irreducible.
Proof. See, for example, Arai (2006b), Corollary 3.14.
□
It follows from (15.34) and (15.35) that, for all t = (t1, . . . , tN) ∈RN,
the operators
US(t) := eit1q1eit2q2 · · · eitN qN ,
VS(t) := eit1p1eit2p2 · · · eitN pN
are unitary and, for all s, t ∈RN,
US(s)VS(t) = e−is·tVS(t)US(s),
US(s)US(t) = US(t)US(s),
VS(s)VS(t) = VS(t)VS(s),
where s · t := N
j=1sjtj.
Each element z = (z1, . . . , zN) in CN is uniquely written as z = s + it,
where sj := Re zj, tj := Im zj, j = 1, . . . , N. Using this decomposition of z,
we deﬁne a unitary operator WS(z) on L2(RN) by
WS(z) := eis·t/2US(s)VS(t).
Then, it follows that, for all z, w ∈CN,
WS(0) = I, WS(z)∗= WS(−z),
WS(z + w) = eiIm (z∗·w)/2WS(z)WS(w).
950
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Hence, the ∗-algebra generated by {WS(z)|z ∈CN} has the same algebraic
structure as that of the Weyl algebra A(CN) over CN. Therefore, there
exists a representation πS of A(CN) on L2(RN) such that
πS(W(z)) = WS(z),
z ∈CN.
We call the representation (L2(RN), πS) the Schr¨odinger representation of
W(CN). It follows from Theorem 15.7 that πS is irreducible.
With regard to representations of the Weyl algebra W(CN), the follow-
ing uniqueness theorem holds.
Theorem 15.8. Let (H , π) be a regular and irreducible representation of
W(CN) such that H is separable. Then, there exists a unitary transforma-
tion U : H →L2(RN)such that
Uπ(A)U −1 = πS(A),
A ∈W(CN).
(15.36)
Proof. By the regularity of π and Lemma 15.7, the correspondence RN ∋
s →π(W(s)) is an N-parameter strongly continuous unitary group. Hence,
according to the extended Stone theorem (Theorem 1.46), there exists an
N-tuple (Q1, . . . , QN) of strongly commuting self-adjoint operators on H
such that
π(W(s)) = eis1Q1 · · · eisN QN ,
s ∈RN.
Similarly, there exists an N-tuple (P1, . . . , PN) of strongly commuting self-
adjoint operators on H such that
π(W(it)) = eit1P1 · · · eitN PN ,
s ∈RN.
The set {eitQn, eitPn|n = 1, . . . , N, t ∈R} is irreducible by the irreducibility
of π. Moreover, it is easy to see that (H , {Qn, Pn|n = 1, . . . , N}) is a
Weyl representation of the CCR with N degrees of freedom (see Remark
5.35). Hence, according to von Neumann’s uniqueness theorem (see Remark
5.36), there exists a unitary transformation U : H →L2(RN) such that
UeitQnU −1 = eitqn,
UeitPnU −1 = eitpn, n = 1, . . . , N, t ∈R. It follows
from these equations that Uπ(W(z))U −1 = WS(z), z ∈CN. This and
Lemma 15.4 imply (15.36).
□

15.2
Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
15.2.1
Algebraic symmetry
We now proceed to the consideration of symmetry in quantum physics.
In an algebraic approach to quantum physics, it is assumed that, to each
quantum system Σ, there corresponds a ∗-algebra AΣ called the algebra
of observables. The algebra AΣ itself is not “physical,” but the set of all
representations of AΣ carries the physics of the quantum system Σ. In other
words, quantum phenomena that may occur in the quantum system Σ are
described on the level of representations of AΣ. The variety of quantum
phenomena that the quantum system Σ may have is understood as the
variety of representations of AΣ. In this scheme, the expectation value of
observations of the observable A ∈AΣ in the state ω on AΣ is given by
ω(A). From the point of view which takes the algebra of observables as one
of the fundamental objects in a quantum system, a symmetry in a quantum
system is deﬁned for the algebra of observables.
In what follows, A denotes a ∗-algebra (physically, it represents the
algebra of observables in a quantum system).
Deﬁnition 15.11.
(i) A mapping α : A →A is called an algebraic symmetry of A if it is
a ∗-automorphism on A, i.e., α ∈∗-Aut(A).
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
953
(ii) Two algebraic symmetries α and β of A are said to commute
if αβ = βα.
In addition to a single algebraic symmetry, a family of algebraic symme-
tries which has a group structure is important. Let G be a group. A mapping
ϱ : G →∗-Aut(A) is called a ∗-representation (or simply representation)
of G on A if
ϱ(g1g2) = ϱ(g1)ϱ(g2),
g1, g2 ∈G.
As is easily seen, the range of ϱ, i.e., {ϱ(g)}g∈G is a subgroup of ∗-Aut(A).
The family {ϱ(g)}g∈G is called a group of algebraic symmetries of A
indexed by G.
In particular, If G = Rd (the d-dimensional translation group), then
{ϱ(a)}a∈Rd is called a d-parameter group of algebraic symmetries of A. We
write ϱ(a) = ϱa.
If G is a continuous group, the ∗-algebra A is a topological space and
the mapping g →ϱ(g) is continuous, then the symmetry described by
{ϱ(g)}g∈G is called a continuous symmetry.
In applications to QFT, algebraic symmetries are divided mainly into
two classes: one is about external symmetries, which is concerned with
space-time symmetries (e.g., translations or rotations in space-time), and
the other is about internal symmetries, which may be independent of space-
time (e.g., rotations in spin space or iso-spin space). In axiomatic QFT, it
is usually assumed that external symmetries commute with internal ones.
Let ω be a state on A, i.e., ω ∈EA and α be an algebraic symmetry
of A. Then, the composite mapping ω ◦α : A →C is deﬁned:
(ω ◦α)(A) := ω(α(A)),
A ∈A.
(15.40)
Proposition 15.10. The composite mapping ω ◦α is a state on A.
Proof. The linearity of ω ◦α is easy to prove. For all A ∈A, α(A∗A) =
α(A)∗α(A). Hence, ω(α(A∗A)) ≥0. Therefore, ω ◦α satisﬁes the positivity
condition. By Proposition 15.2, α(I) = I. Hence, (ω◦α)(I) = 1. Thus, ω◦α
is a state on A.
□
Based on Proposition 15.10, we deﬁne the following notion.
Deﬁnition 15.12. A state ω on A is said to be α-invariant if ω ◦α = ω.
Example 15.5. Let H be a Hilbert space and H be a self-adjoint operator
on H having an eigenvalue E0 ∈R. Let Ψ0 ∈ker(H −E0) with ∥Ψ0∥= 1
954
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
and ωΨ0 be the vector state on the ∗-algebra B(H ) associated Ψ0:
ωΨ0(A) := ⟨Ψ0, AΨ0⟩,
A ∈B(H ).
For each t ∈R, we deﬁne αt : B(H ) →B(H ) by
αt(A) := eitHAe−itH, A ∈B(H ).
It is easy to see that αt is an algebraic symmetry on B(H ). Noting that
e−itHΨ0 = e−itE0Ψ0 by Theorem 1.26(i), one can show that ωΨ0 is αt-
invariant.
By Proposition 15.10, for each algebraic symmetry α of A, a mapping
α∗on the state space EA is deﬁned by
α∗(ω) := ω ◦α,
ω ∈EA.
(15.41)
The mapping α∗is called the dual mapping, or the dual, of α. The state
α∗(ω) is called the dual transform of ω by α∗.
It follows that ω is α-invariant if and only if α∗(ω) = ω.
It is easy to see that α∗is an aﬃne mapping, i.e., for all ω1, ω2 ∈EA
and λ ∈(0, 1),
α∗(λω1 + (1 −λ)ω2) = λα∗(ω1) + (1 −λ)α∗(ω2).
Proposition 15.11. For all algebraic symmetries α of A, the dual mapping
α∗is bijective with
(α∗)−1 = (α−1)∗.
(15.42)
Proof. (injectivity) Suppose that, for ω1, ω2 ∈EA, α∗(ω1) = α∗(ω2). Then,
for all A ∈A, ω1(α(A)) = ω2(α(A). Since α is surjective, it follows that,
for all B ∈A, ω1(B) = ω2(B). Hence, ω1 = ω2. Therefore, α∗is injective.
(surjectivity) Let ω ∈EA and set η := ω ◦α−1. Then, η ∈EA and
α∗(η) = ω, Hence, α∗is surjective and (α∗)−1(ω) = η. By the deﬁnition
of η, we have η = (α−1)∗(ω) Hence, (α∗)−1(ω) = (α−1)∗(ω). Since ω is an
arbitrary element in EA, (15.42) follows.
□
Proposition 15.11 means that α∗is a symmetry of EA in the ordinary
sense.7 Based on this fact, the following deﬁnition is possible.
Deﬁnition 15.13. If a subset M of EA satisﬁes α∗(M) = M, then M is
said to be α∗-symmetric.
7For a non-empty set M, a bijection on M is called a symmetry of M.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
955
15.2.2
Deﬁnition of spontaneous symmetry breaking
We consider a quantum system of which algebra of observables is given by
a ∗-algebra A. As we have seen in Section 15.1.6, for each state ω ∈EA, the
GNS representation
Rω := (Hω, πω, Ωω)
(15.43)
of A is associated. As remarked at the beginning of the preceding section,
the family {Rω|ω ∈EA} of representations of A is interpreted as carrying
the physics of the quantum system under consideration. From this point of
view, each representation Rω is called a phase of the quantum system.
Let α be an algebraic symmetry of A and write
α∗ω := α∗(ω),
ω ∈EA.
By (15.40) and (15.41),
α∗ω(A) = ω(α(A)),
A ∈A.
(15.44)
Since α is surjective, it follows that the set of all expectation values of the
state ω coincides with that of the state α∗ω:
{ω(A)|A ∈A} = {α∗ω(A)|A ∈A}.
There exists a natural relation between the two phases Rω and Rα∗ω.
Theorem 15.11. Let ω ∈EA. Then, there exists a unitary transformation
U : Hα∗ω →Hω such that
UΩα∗ω = Ωω,
Uπα∗ω(A)U −1 = πω(α(A)),
A ∈A.
(15.45)
Proof. Let π(A) := πω(α(A)), A ∈A. Then, by Lemma 15.3 and the GNS
construction, (Hω, π, Ωω) is a cyclic representation of A. Moreover, we have
⟨Ωω, π(A)Ωω⟩= ⟨Ωω, πω(α(A))Ωω⟩= α∗ω(A) (by (15.44)).
Hence, by Theorem 15.5, there exists a unitary transformation V : Hω →
Hα∗ω such that V Ωω = Ωα∗ω and V π(A)V −1 = πα∗ω(A). Then, U := V −1
is the desired unitary transformation.
□
Theorem 15.11 shows that the phase Rα∗ω is equivalent to the repre-
sentation (Hω, πω ◦α, Dω). Hence, the relation between the phase Rα∗ω
and the phase Rω can be considered as that between πω and πω ◦α in the
same Hilbert space Hω. Based on this fact, we deﬁne the symmetry with
respect to α in the phase Rω as follows.
956
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Deﬁnition 15.14.
(i) If there exists a unitary transformation V : Hω →Hω such that
πω(α(A)) = V πω(A)V −1, A ∈A,
(15.46)
i.e., πω ◦α is unitarily equivalent to πω, then we say that the quantum
system under consideration is α-symmetric in the phase Rω, or that
the α-symmetry (or the symmetry α) is not broken in the phase Rω.
(ii) If the quantum system under consideration is not α-symmetric, i.e.,
there exists no unitary transformation V as in (i), then we say that
the symmetry α is spontaneously broken (or simply broken) in the
phase Rω.
Remark 15.8. Since D(πω(A)) = Dω = D(πω(α(A)) for all A ∈A, (15.46)
implies that V Dω = Dω.
As is obvious from the deﬁnition above, spontaneous symmetry break-
ing (or simply symmetry breaking) is not a concept concerning the algebra
of observables itself, but it is a concept on the level of representations of
the algebra of observables (physically, on the phenomenal level). Even in
the case where spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs, the original sym-
metry, i.e., the algebraic symmetry itself remains ﬁxed. This distinction is
important to understand clearly spontaneous symmetry breaking.
From the representation theoretical point of view, the spontaneous
breaking of symmetry α in the phase Rω is equivalent to that πω is inequiv-
alent to πω ◦α. Hence, an inequivalent representation of the algebra of
observable is associated with a spontaneous symmetry breaking.8
In QFT and quantum statistical mechanics, spontaneous symmetry
breaking of internal symmetries mainly plays an important role. The states
to be considered are basically vacua (ground states) in QFT and ther-
mal equilibrium states (Kubo–Martin–Schwinger (KMS) states) in quan-
tum statistical mechanics.
We also note the following fact.
Proposition 15.12. Let α be an algebraic symmetry of A and ω ∈EA.
Then, the quantum system under consideration is α-symmetric in the phase
8Generally, inequivalent representations of ∗-algebras, CCR, or CAR play important
roles in quantum physics in the sense that they may be associated with “characteristic”
quantum phenomena (e.g., Bose–Einstein condensation, superconductivity and superﬂu-
idity). See, for example, Arai (2020).
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
957
Rω if and only if there exists a unitary transformation W : Hω →Hα∗ω
such that
Wπω(A)W −1 = πα∗ω(A),
A ∈A.
(15.47)
Proof. Suppose that the quantum system is α-symmetric in the phase Rω.
Let U be the unitary transformation in Theorem 15.11 and V be that in
Deﬁnition 15.14. Then, W := U −1V is a unitary transformation from Hω
to Hα∗ω satisfying (15.47).
Conversely, suppose that there exists a unitary transformation W :
Hω →Hα∗ω such that (15.47) holds. Then, V
:= UW is a unitary
transformation on Hω and (15.46) holds. Hence, the quantum system is
α-symmetric in the phase Rω.
□
15.2.3
Absence of spontaneous symmetry breaking in
quantum systems with ﬁnite degrees of freedom
The following theorem suggests that one cannot expect the existence of
symmetry breaking in “most” quantum systems with ﬁnite degrees of
freedom.
Theorem 15.12. Let V be a d-dimensional inner product space (d ∈N)
and (Hω, πω, Ωω) be the GNS representation of the Weyl algebra W(V )
over V such that Hω is separable, πω is irreducible and regular. Let α
be an algebraic symmetry of W(V ) such that πω ◦α is regular. Then, the
symmetry α is not broken in the phase (Hω, πω, Ωω).
Proof. Under the present assumption, πω(W(V ))′ = CI. Hence, by Theo-
rem 15.3, πω◦α is an irreducible representation of W(V ). Under the present
assumption, this representation is regular. Hence, by Theorem 15.9, there
exists a unitary transformation U : Hω →Hω such that Uπω(A)U −1 =
πω(α(A)), A ∈W(V ).
□
In the case of quantum systems with inﬁnite degrees of freedom, how-
ever, there may exist spontaneous symmetry breaking. We next discuss a
simple example in which spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs.
15.3
Example: A Free Bose Field
In this section, we consider a free Bose ﬁeld from the point of view of
spontaneous symmetry breaking. The symmetry to be considered here is
a symmetry concerning a global translation of the Bose ﬁeld. We shall see
958
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
the following: (i) if the space S on which the Bose ﬁeld exists is of a ﬁnite
volume in such a way that S is a d-dimensional cubic box (d ∈N), then no
spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs; (ii) if S is an inﬁnite volume space
with S = Rd, then spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs. This diﬀerence
is very interesting to note. In what follows, we describe details of these
facts.

15.3.3

Theorem 15.14. Let θ ∈R and ε ∈R \ {0} be arbitrarily ﬁxed. Then, in

0(Rd).

if Ψ ∈Fb(L2(ˆRd)) satisﬁes eia0P0Ψ = Ψ, a0 ∈R, then Ψ = λΨ0 for some

Ψ = λΨ0 for some constant λ ∈C.
It is easy to see that

W(f) ∈W(S (Rd)).
15.4
Order Parameter
We now proceed to formulating conditions for spontaneous symmetry
breaking in a general framework. Let A be a ∗-algebra and α be an algebraic
symmetry of A. We ﬁrst note the following.
Theorem 15.16. If a state ω ∈EA is α-invariant, then the symmetry α is
not broken in the phase Rω = (Hω, πω, Ωω).
Proof. Under the present assumption, ω(α(A)) = ω(A), A ∈A. This
implies that ⟨Ωω, (πω ◦α)(A)Ωω⟩= ω(A). Hence, by the uniqueness of
GNS representation (Theorem 15.5), there exists a unitary transformation
U on Hω such that UΩω = Ωω and Uπω(A)U −1 = πω(α(A)), A ∈A.
Hence, the symmetry α is not broken in Rω.
□
Taking the contraposition of Theorem 15.16 we obtain the following.
Corollary 15.3. Let ω ∈EA. If the symmetry α is spontaneously broken
in Rω, then ω is not α-invariant.10
It follows from the deﬁnition of α-invariance of a state that a state ω on
A is not α-invariant if and only if there exists an element A ∈A such that
ω(α(A)) ̸= ω(A).
(15.105)
The expectation value ω(A) satisfying (15.105) is called an order
parameter with respect to spontaneous symmetry breaking of the sym-
metry α. In terms of this notion, Corollary 15.3 is rephrased as follows:
a necessary condition for a spontaneous symmetry breaking to occur is
that there exists an order parameter. But we remark that an absence of
10We have encountered such a situation in the inﬁnite volume theory of a free Bose ﬁeld
discussed in Section 15.3.3.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
975
order parameter does not necessarily imply spontaneous symmetry break-
ing.11 Keeping this matter in mind, we next consider a suﬃcient condition
for spontaneous symmetry breaking to occur.
Let α be an algebraic symmetry of A, ω be a state on A and G be a
group which has a ∗-representation ϱ on A satisfying the following:
(A.1) (commutativity with α) For all g ∈G, αϱ(g) = ϱ(g)α.
(A.2) (ϱ(g)-invariance of ω) For all g ∈G, ω ◦ϱ(g) = ω.
For the GNS representation Rω := (Hω, πω, Ωω) of A, we assume the
following:
(A.3) For each g ∈G, there exists a unitary transformation U(g) on Hω
such that U(g1)U(g2) = U(g1g2), g1, g2 ∈G (i.e., {U(g)}g∈G is a
unitary representation of the group G on Hω) and the following
(i)–(iii) hold:
(i) (unitary implementability) (πω ◦ϱ(g))(A) = U(g)πω(A)U(g)−1,
g ∈G, A ∈A.
(ii) (U(g)-invariance of the cyclic vector) U(g)Ωω = Ωω, g ∈G.
(iii) (uniqueness of cyclic vector) If a non-zero vector Ψ ∈Hω satis-
ﬁes U(g)Ψ = γgΨ for all g ∈G with γg ∈C, then there exists a
constant λ ∈C such that Ψ = λΩω.
Lemma 15.10. Suppose that πω(A)′ = CI. Let Ψ ∈Hω be a cyclic vector
for πω(A) satisfying
⟨Ψ, (πω ◦ϱ(g))(A)Ψ⟩= ⟨Ψ, πω(A)Ψ⟩,
g ∈G, A ∈A.
(15.106)
Then, there exists a constant λ ∈C such that Ψ = λΩω.
Proof. Let Ψg := U(g)−1Ψ (g ∈G). Then, by (15.106) and (A.3)-(i), we
have ⟨Ψg, πω(A)Ψg⟩= ⟨Ψ, πω(A)Ψ⟩, g ∈G, A ∈A. In the same way as
in the proof of Theorem 15.5, one can show that there exists a unitary
transformation Vg on Hω such that VgΨg = Ψ, Vgπω(A)V −1
g
= πω(A), i.e.,
Vgπω(A) ⊂πω(A)Vg. Hence, Vg ∈πω(A)′. Hence, there exists a constant
γg ∈C such that Vg = γgI. This implies that U(g)Ψ = γgΨ. By this
equation and (A.3)-(iii), we obtain the desired result.
□
11For example, in the ﬁnite volume theory of a Bose ﬁeld in Section 15.3.1, the sym-
metry αε,L is not spontaneously broken; however, for f ∈L2(VL) such that Re ⟨f⟩L ̸∈
{2πn/ε|n ∈Z}, ωL,θ(αε,LW (f))) ̸= ωL,θ(W (f)). Hence, for such a function f ∈L2(VL),
ωL,θ(W (f)) is an order parameter.

Theorem 15.17. Assume (A.1)–(A.3) and suppose that πω(A)′ = CI.
Then, if ω is not α-invariant, the symmetry α is spontaneously broken in
the phase Rω.
Proof. We prove the contraposition. Hence, suppose that the symmetry
α is not broken in Rω. Then, there exists a unitary transformation V on
Hω such that V D(πω) = D(πω) and V πω(A)Ψ = πω(α(A))V Ψ, Ψ ∈D(πω),
A ∈A. Hence, letting η := ω ◦α, we have η(A) =

Ωω, V πω(A)V −1Ωω

.
The vector Ψω := V −1Ωω. is a cyclic vector for πω(A) and η(A) =
⟨Ψω, πω(A)Ψω⟩. On the other hand, it follows from (A.1) and A.2) that
η(ϱ(g)A) = η(A). Hence, (15.106) holds with with Ψ replaced by Ψω.
Therefore, by Lemma 15.10, there exists a constant λ ∈C such that
Ψω = λΩω(|λ| = 1). Hence, η(A) = ω(A), A ∈A, i.e., ω ◦α = ω. Thus, ω is
α-invariant.
□
Corollary 15.3 and Theorem 15.17 yield the following.
Corollary 15.4. Assume (A.1)–(A.3) with πω(A)′ = CI. Then, the sym-
metry α is spontaneously broken in the phase Rω if and only if ω is not
α-invariant.

15.5
Mathematical Form of Nambu–Goldstone Theorem
In this section, we give a mathematically rigorous formulation and a proof
for the statement, called Goldstone’s theorem or the Nabmu–Goldstone the-
orem in the physics literature,12 that “if there exists a spontaneous symme-
try breaking of a continuous symmetry in QFT, then a massless quantum
particle (Nambu–Goldstone particle) should be associated.”
15.5.1
Basic assumptions
Let A be a ∗-algebra and ω be a state on A. We assume that there exists
a ∗-representation {ϱ(a)|a ∈R1+d} of the (1 + d)-dimensional translation
group R1+d(d ∈N) on A and that, for each a ∈R1+d, ω is ϱ(a)-invariant.
For notational simplicity, we denote the GNS representation associated
with ω by (H , π, Ω) and assume that the following are satisﬁed:
(i) The representation π is bounded and irreducible.
(ii) There exists a strongly continuous (1 + d)-parameter unitary group
{U(a)}a∈R1+d on H such that
(π ◦ϱ(a))(A) = U(a)π(A)U(a)−1,
A ∈A, a ∈R1+d,
(15.108)
U(a)Ω = Ω,
a ∈R1+d.
(15.109)
(iii) If a non-zero vector Ψ ∈H satisﬁes U(a)Ψ = Ψ, a ∈R1+d, then
Ψ = λΩ with a constant λ ∈C.
Equation (15.108) means that π ◦ϱ(a) is unitarily implementable. One
can apply the extended Stone theorem (Theorem 1.46) to {U(a)}a∈R1+d to
conclude that there exists a unique (1 + d)-tuple P := (P0, P1, . . . , Pd) of
strongly commuting self-adjoint operators satisfying
U(a) = eia0P0eia1P1eia2P2 · · · eiadPd,
a = (a0, . . . , ad) ∈R1+d.
(15.110)

15.5.2
Heuristic arguments and remarks
Before proceeding to a mathematical formulation of the Nambu–Goldstone
theorem, we brieﬂy look at a description of the Nambu–Goldstone theo-
rem in the physics literature. A basic example of generators of continuous
symmetries in QFT is formally given by the following form:
Q =

Rd j0(t, x)dx,
(15.114)
where t ∈R is the time variable, j0(t, x) denotes the 0th component
(the charge density operator) of the current operator j(t, x) = (j0(t, x),
j1(t, x), . . ., jd(t, x))13 which is derived formally from the existence of a
13Mathematically, each jμ (μ
=
0, . . . , d) is supposed to be an operator-valued
distribution.
Mathematical Formulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
979
continuous symmetry and satisﬁes the continuous equation:
∂tj0(t, x) +
d

ℓ=1
∂ℓjℓ(t, x) = 0
(∂t := ∂/∂t, ∂ℓ:= ∂/∂xℓ). Hence, Q is formally a conserved quantity,
i.e., a quantity independent of time t.14 The operator Q is called a charge
operator. In the physics literature, the symmetry described by Q is said to
be spontaneously broken if there exists an observable T satisfying
⟨[Q, T ]⟩0 ̸= 0
(15.115)
(it is tacitly assumed that Ω ∈D(QT ) ∩D(T Q)). This is due to the follow-
ing reasons: (i) under condition (15.115), the zero-energy state Ω cannot
be an eigenvector of Q, because, if QΩ = λΩ for some λ ∈R, then, by
the formal symmetry of Q, the left-hand side of (15.115) becomes 0, which
is a contradiction; (ii) since eitP0Qe−itP0 = Q, t ∈R (Q is assumed to be
conserved quantum mechanically too), it follows that eitP0QΩ = QΩ. This
implies that P0QΩ = 0. By (15.115), QΩ ̸= 0 and hence QΩ is also a zero-
energy state.15 As is easily seen, {Ω, QΩ} is linearly independent. Hence,
under condition (15.115), Q maps Ω to a diﬀerent zero-energy state QΩ.
This is a form of “symmetry breaking” mentioned in the physics literature.
In particular, the zero-energy state is degenerate. This kind of discussion,
however, is just a matter of formal or heuristic one. In fact, in the ﬁrst
place, the existence of Q is itself dubious. For example, in the inﬁnite vol-
ume theory of a free Bose ﬁeld discussed in Section 15.3.3, the operator
corresponding to Q should be “ limR→∞ΠR .” But such an operator does
not exist (see Proposition 15.20 and Problem 3(i)). Also, in the example, in
each phase, there exists a symmetry breaking, but the zero-energy ground
state is not degenerate. The above heuristic arguments contradicts this
fact. In fact, the degeneracy of the zero-energy state in the above sense
mentioned in the physics literature may be interpreted, in the terminology
of this book, as the existence of multiple phases, and the property that Q
maps a zero-energy state to a diﬀerent zero-energy state may correspond
to the property that the dual of an algebraic symmetry maps a state to a
diﬀerent state.
14For the counterpart in classical ﬁeld theory, see Problem 4 in this chapter, Problem
14 in Chapter 10 and Problem 5 in Chapter 12.
15For all n ∈N and t ∈R, we have eitP0Qne−itP0 = Qn. Hence, if Ω ∈D(Qn), then
eitP0QnΩ = QnΩ, implying that P0QnΩ = 0, i.e., QnΩ is a zero-energy state.

Remark 15.11. In the physics literature, there are cases where, under
the name “Goldstone’s theorem,” or “the Nambu–Goldstone theorem,” the
existence of a massless boson is asserted. But Theorem 15.18 does not imply
such a strong assertion; it only suggests the existence of a massless particle.

988
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
present case to conclude that 0 ∈ˆR1+d is not an isolated point of the
joint spectrum of (P0, P1, . . . , Pd). We remark that, in the present example,
this fact can be derived from (15.100) too.
In a non-trivial relativistic QFT model, condition (j.4) is not expected
to hold because the distribution kernel j0(x) is usually nonlinear in a
point-wise quantum ﬁeld and hence becomes very singular so that j0(x)
itself has no mathematical meaning without regularizations and smearing
with a test function (see Problem 4). Hence, in the relativistic formula-
tions of the Nambu–Goldstone theorem, condition (j.4) has to be replaced
by another (relativistic) condition. For mathematical formulations of the
Nambu–Goldstone theorem in relativistic QFT, see, for example, Ezawa
and Swieca (1967), Strocchi (2021), and Ezawa and Arai (2023). For recent
work, see Brunetti et al. (2021) and references therein.
In this chapter, we have treated only introductory aspects in the math-
ematical theory of symmetry breaking in QFT. For further topics, such
as Higgs mechanism, which forms an essential part of the success of the
standard model of particle physics, we refer the reader to Strocchi (2013,
2021).

Appendix A
Weak Convergence of Vectors and
Strong Convergence of Bounded
Linear Operators in Hilbert Spaces
Let H be a complex Hilbert space with inner product ⟨, ⟩(linear in the
second variable) and norm ∥· ∥. A sequence {ψn}∞
n=1 of vectors ψn ∈H is
said to converge weakly to ψ ∈H if, for all φ ∈H ,
lim
n→∞⟨φ, ψn⟩= ⟨φ, ψ⟩.
(A.1)
In this case, ψ is called the weak limit of {ψn}∞
n=1, and one writes ψ =
w- limn→∞ψn.
In applications, one often meets a problem under what condition a given
sequence of vectors in a Hilbert space converges weakly. One solution to this
problem is given by the following proposition.
Proposition A.1. Let {ψn}∞
n=1 (ψn ∈H , n ∈H ) be bounded, i.e.,
supn∈N ∥ψn∥< ∞. Suppose that there exist a vector ψ ∈H
and a
dense subspace D in H
such that, for all φ ∈D, (A.1) holds. Then,
w- limn→∞ψn = ψ.
Proof. There exists a constant C > 0 such that max{∥ψ∥, supn∈N ∥ψn∥} ≤
C. Let φ ∈H . Then, by the density of D, for each ε > 0, there exists a
vector φε ∈D such that ∥φε −φ∥< ε/(3C). By the assumption on the
convergence of {ψn}n, there exists an n0(ε) ∈N such that, for all n ≥n0(ε),
| ⟨φε, ψn⟩−⟨φε, ψ⟩| < ε/3. Using the identity
⟨φ, ψn⟩−⟨φ, ψ⟩= ⟨φ −φε, ψn⟩+ (⟨φε, ψn⟩−⟨φε, ψ⟩) + ⟨φε −φ, ψ⟩
993
994
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
and the Schwarz inequality, we have for all n ≥n0(ε),
| ⟨φ, ψn⟩−⟨φ, ψ⟩| ≤∥φ −φε∥∥ψn∥+ |⟨φε, ψn⟩−⟨φε, ψ⟩| + ∥φε −φ∥∥ψ∥
< ε
3 + ε
3 + ε
3 = ε.
Hence, (A.1) holds.
□
Remark A.1. The idea of the method used in the proof of Proposition A.1
is called the “ε/3 argument.” It is one of the fundamental techniques in
mathematical analysis.
Proposition A.2. Let K be a Hilbert space and Tn∈B(H , K ) (n ∈N),
with supn∈N ∥Tn∥
<
∞. Suppose that there exist an operator T
∈
B(H , K ), a dense subspace D in H
and a dense subspace F in K
such that, for all ψ ∈D and φ ∈F, limn→∞⟨φ, Tnψ⟩= ⟨φ, T ψ⟩. Then,
w- limn→∞Tn = T .
Proof. For all ψ ∈H , supn∈N ∥Tnψ∥≤(supn∈N ∥Tn∥)∥ψ∥< ∞. Hence,
by Proposition A.1, for all φ ∈K
and ψ ∈F, limn→∞⟨φ, Tnψ⟩=
⟨φ, T ψ⟩, which implies that limn→∞⟨T ∗
nφ, ψ⟩= ⟨T ∗φ, ψ⟩. Using the fact
that ∥T ∗
n∥= ∥Tn∥, we have supn∈N ∥T ∗
nφ∥≤(supn∈N ∥Tn∥)∥φ∥. Hence,
by Proposition A.1 again, w- limn→∞T ∗
nφ = T ∗φ. This is equivalent to
w- limn→∞Tn = T .
□
Proposition A.3. Let K be a Hilbert space and Tn ∈B(H , K ) (n ∈N),
with supn∈N ∥Tn∥< ∞. Suppose that there exist an operator T ∈B(H , K )
and a dense subspace D in H such that, for all ψ ∈D, limn→∞Tnψ = T ψ.
Then, s- limn→∞Tn = T .
Proof. We use the ε/3 argument mentioned in Remark A.1. Let C be a
constant satisfying C > max{supn∈N ∥Tn∥, ∥T ∥}. Let ψ ∈H . Then, for
each ε > 0, there exists a vector ψε ∈D such that ∥ψε −ψ∥< ε/(3C).
The present assumption implies that there exists an n0(ε) ∈N such that
∥Tnψε −T ψε∥< ε/3, n ≥n0(ε). Using the identity
Tnψ −T ψ = Tn(ψ −ψε) + Tnψε −T ψε + T (ψε −ψ)
Weak Convergence of Vectors and Strong Convergence
995
and the triangle inequality, we have for n ≥n0(ε),
∥Tnψ −T ψ∥≤∥Tn∥∥ψ −ψε∥+ ∥Tnψε −T ψε∥+ ∥T ∥∥ψε −ψ∥
< ε
3 + ε
3 + ε
3 = ε.
Hence, the desired result follows.
□

Appendix B
Operators on a Direct
Sum Hilbert Space
Let H1 and H2 be Hilbert spaces and

Appendix C
Absolutely Continuous Spectrum
and Singular Continuous Spectrum
of a Self-Adjoint Operator
In this appendix, we review a classiﬁcation of the spectrum of a self-adjoint
operator.
Let A be a self-adjoint operator on a complex Hilbert space H and EA
be its spectral measure. For any vector Ψ ∈H , the mapping μΨ : B1 →
[0, ∞), deﬁned by
μΨ(B) := ∥EA(B)Ψ∥2,
B ∈B1,
is a bounded measure on (R, B1).
The vector Ψ is said to be absolutely continuous with respect to A
if the measure μΨ is absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue
measure μL on R.
If μΨ is singular with respect to μL, then Ψ is said to be singular with
respect to A.
We denote by Hac(A) (resp., Hs(A)) the set of vectors absolutely con-
tinuous (resp., singular) with respect to A. It is easy to see that Hac(A)
and Hs(A) are subspaces of H . The subspace Hac(A) (resp., Hs(A)) is
called the absolutely continuous (resp., singular) subspace of A.
Theorem C.1.
(i) The subspaces Hac(A) and Hs(A) are mutually orthogonal closed
subspaces, and
H = Hac(A) ⊕Hs(A).
(ii) The operator A is reduced by Hac(A) and Hs(A).
Proof. (i) We ﬁrst show that Hac(A) ⊥Hs(A) · · · (∗).
1001
1002
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Let Ψ ∈Hac(A), Φ ∈Hs(A). By the deﬁnition of a singular vector,
there exists a Borel set S0 such that μL(S0) = 0 and ∥EA(R\S0))Φ∥= 0.
Hence, EA(S0)Φ = Φ. Therefore,
⟨Ψ, Φ⟩= ⟨Ψ, EA(S0)Φ⟩= ⟨EA(S0)Ψ, Φ⟩.
Since Ψ is absolutely continuous with respect to A, ∥EA(S0)Ψ∥= 0, i.e.,
EA(S0)Ψ = 0. Hence, ⟨Ψ, Φ⟩= 0. Thus, (∗) holds.
We next show that H = Hac(A) + Hs(A) · · · (∗∗).1
Let Ξ ∈H . Then, according to Lebesgue’s decomposition theorem,
the measure μΞ is decomposed as μΞ = m1 + m2, where m1 (resp., m2)
is a measure that is absolutely continuous (resp., singular) with respect
to μL. There exists a Borel set B0 such that μL(B0) = 0 and m2(B) =
m2(B ∩B0), B ∈B1.
Put Φ := EA(B0)Ξ, Ψ := Ξ −Φ. Then,
μΦ(B) = ∥EA(B)EA(B0)Ξ∥2 = ∥EA(B ∩B0)Ξ∥2
= μΞ(B ∩B0) = m2(B ∩B0) = m2(B),
where we have used m1(B ∩B0) = 0. Hence, Φ ∈Hs(A). We also have
μΨ(B) = ∥EA(B)(1 −EA(B0))Ξ∥2 = ∥EA(B)Ξ∥2 −∥EA(B ∩B0)Ξ∥2
= μΞ(B) −m2(B) = m1(B).
Hence, Ψ ∈Hac(A). Therefore, Ξ = Ψ + Φ ∈Hac(A) + Hs(A). Thus, (∗∗)
holds.
Now, one can easily show that (∗) and (∗∗) imply the desired result.
(ii) Let P be the orthogonal projection onto Hac(H ). For all Ψ ∈
Hac(A) and B ∈B1, EA(B)Ψ ∈Hac(A). Indeed, if μL(S) = 0 (S ∈B1),
then EA(S)Ψ = 0, and hence EA(S)EA(B)Ψ = EA(B)EA(S)Ψ = 0. Hence,
EA(B)Hac(A) ⊂Hac(A). This fact and (i) imply that EA(B)Hs(A) ⊂
Hs(A). Hence, it follows that, for all B ∈B1, EA(B)P = PEA(B). By this
result and the operational calculus, we see that PA ⊂AP. Hence, Hac(A)
reduces A. By part (i), this implies the reducibility of A by Hs(A).
□
We recall that σp(A) denotes the point spectrum of A (see Section 1.1.2).
We deﬁne
Hp(A) := Ran(EA(σp(A))).
(C.1)
1For two subspaces V1 and V2 of a vector space, V1 + V2 := {v1 + v2|v1 ∈V1, v2 ∈V2}.
Absolutely Continuous Spectrum and Singular Continuous Spectrum
1003
This closed subspace is equal to the closure of the subspace spanned by all
eigenvectors of A if σp(A) ̸= ∅.
Lemma C.1. Hp(A) ⊂Hs(A).
Proof. Let AΨ = λΨ with λ ∈σp(A) and S0 := {λ}. Then, μL(S0) = 0
and ∥EA(R\S0)Ψ∥= 0. Hence, Ψ ∈Hs(A). Since Hs(A) is closed, the
desired result follows.
□
By Lemma C.1, one can deﬁne
Hsc(A) := Hp(A)⊥∩Hs(A) ⊂Hs(A).
This closed subspace is called the singular continuous subspace of A.
By Theorem C.1, H has the orthogonal decomposition
H = Hac(A) ⊕Hsc(A) ⊕Hp(A),
and each closed subspace H#(A) (# =ac, s, p) reduces A. We denote by
A# the reduced part of A to H#(A). Hence, A is written as their direct
sum:
A = Aac ⊕Asc ⊕Ap.
The operator Aac (resp., Asc, Ap) is called the absolutely continuous
part (resp., singular continuous part, point-spectral part) of A.
Thus, introducing
σac(A) := σ(Aac),
σsc(A) := σ(Asc),
σpp(A) := σ(Ap),
we have
σ(A) = σac(A) ∪σsc(A) ∪σpp(A).
(C.2)
The set σac(A) (resp., σsc(A), σpp(A)) is called the absolutely contin-
uous spectrum (resp., singular continuous spectrum, pure point
spectrum) of A.
By (1.13), Theorem 1.14(ii) and (C.2), we have
σc(A) = σac(A) ∪σsc(A).
(C.3)
We also remark that
σpp(A) = σp(A).
1004
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
If H = Hac(A), then A is said to be absolutely continuous, or to
have purely absolutely continuous spectrum.
If H = Hsc(A), then A is said to be a singular continuous, or to
have a purely singular continuous spectrum.
If H = Hp(A), then A is said to be purely point spectral.
The following fact should be kept in mind:

The absolute continuity of a self-adjoint operator is a unitary invariant
property.
Proposition C.1. Let A be an absolutely continuous self-adjoint operator
on H . Then, for any unitary operator U : H →K (a Hilbert space), the
self-adjoint operator UAU −1 on K is absolutely continuous.
Proof. The spectral measure EUAU−1 of UAU −1 is given by EUAU−1(B) =
UEA(B)U −1, B ∈B1. Hence, if the Lebesgue measure of B ∈B1 is zero,
then ∥EUAU−1(B)Φ∥= 0, for all Φ ∈K .
□
For B ∈B1, |B| denotes the Lebesgue measure of B.

Proposition C.2. Suppose that A is absolutely continuous. Then, for
any real-valued continuous function f on R such that |f −1(B)| = 0 if
|B| = 0 (B ∈B1), f(A) is self-adjoint and absolutely continuous.
Proof. The self-adjointness follows from functional calculus. By Theorem
1.27, the spectral measure Ef(A) of f(A) is given by Ef(A)(B)
=
EA(f −1(B)), B ∈B1. Hence, for all ψ ∈H ,
∥Ef(A)(B)ψ∥2 = ∥EA(f −1(B))ψ∥2.
Under the present assumption, if |B| = 0, then |f −1(B)| = 0, and
hence ∥EA(f −1(B))ψ∥2 = 0, implying ∥Ef(A)(B)ψ∥2 = 0. Thus, f(A) is
absolutely continuous.

A continuous linear functional on D(Rd) is called a distribution on

A function in D(Rd) is called a test function in relation to D′(Rd).
The concept of support of a usual function is extended to the case of

as far as locally integrable functions are concerned, the deﬁnition of the sup-

of support of usual functions.

Rd δa(x)f(x)dx = 0. Hence, by du Bois–Reymond’s
lemma, δa(x) = 0 a.e. x ∈Rd. Therefore, for all f ∈C∞
0 (Rd), f(a) = 0. But
this is a contradiction. Thus, δa is a distribution which cannot be regarded
as a function.
Although δa(x) is not a function, as we have seen above, it can be used as
a mere symbol. In that case, there would be no problem unless meaningless
operations such as δa(x)n (n = 1, 2, . . .) are made. The following symbol is
also used:
δa(x) = δ(x −a).
The “visual” notation used for Dirac’s delta distribution can be
extended to other distributions. Namely, for the distributions φ ∈D′(Rd)
and f ∈D(Rd), the following notation with a symbol φ(x) is sometimes
used:

Rd φ(x)f(x)dx := φ(f).
The symbol φ(x) is called the distribution kernel of φ. But one
should keep in mind that, in general, φ(x) is just a symbol which has
no mathematical meaning unless it is a locally integrable function. The
left-hand side of the above equation is just a symbolical expression
which has a mathematical meaning as an integral only if φ(x) is locally
integrable.
We sometimes use the phrase “φ(x) is a distribution on Rd” to mean
that it is the distribution kernel of a distribution φ ∈D′(Rd).
Elements of the Theory of Distributions
1011
For two distributions φ and ψ, the equality φ = ψ in D′(Rd), i.e.,
φ(f) = ψ(f), for all f ∈D(Rd), is sometimes stated as “φ(x) = ψ(x)
in the sense of distribution,” or simply “φ(x) = ψ(x).”
Example D.3. For each a > 0, there exists a mapping φa : D(R) →C
deﬁned by
φa(f) := 1

δ(x2 −a2) = 1

D.1.2
Multiplication by C∞-functions
Let u ∈C∞(Rd). Then, for all f ∈D(Rd), uf ∈D(Rd). Hence, for each
φ ∈D′(Rd), one can deﬁne uφ : D(Rd) →C by
(uφ)(f) := φ(uf),
f ∈D(Rd).
It is easy to see that uφ ∈D′(Rd). The distribution uφ is called the product
of u and φ.

functions f ∈D(Rd), φ(f) ≥0. In this case, we write φ ≥0.
The delta distribution δa on Rd (a ∈Rd) is positive.

D.2
Tempered Distributions
A complex-valued function f on Rd is said to be rapidly decreasing if
f ∈C∞(Rd) and, for all m ∈Z+ and multi-indices α ∈Zd
+,
lim
|x|→∞|x|m∂αf(x) = 0.
We denote by S (Rd) the set of rapidly decreasing functions on Rd. The
set S (Rd) is an inﬁnite-dimensional complex vector space with the usual
operation of addition for two functions and the usual scalar multiplication
for a function. It is obvious that
C∞
0 (Rd) ⊂S (Rd).
Example D.5. For each n ∈N, the function f, deﬁned by f(x) := e−|x|2n,
is in S (Rd), but f ̸∈C∞
0 (Rd).
Let f ∈S (Rd). Then, it is easy to see that, for all m ∈Z+ and any
multi-index α ∈Zd
+,

(D.5)
is ﬁnite, and ∥· ∥m,α is a norm of S (Rd). Hence, (S (Rd), ∥· ∥m,α) is a
normed space.

A sequence {fn}n in S (Rd) (fn ∈S (Rd), n ∈N) is said to converge
to a function f ∈S (Rd) if, for all m ∈Z+ and multi-indices α ∈Zd
+,

The convergence in this sense is written

The space S (Rd) is sometimes called the Schwartz space of rapidly
decreasing functions.
A linear functional φ on S (Rd) is said to be continuous if fn, f ∈
S (Rd), fn
S→f (n →∞), then limn→∞φ(fn) = φ(f).
A continuous linear functional on S (Rd) is called a tempered distri-
bution on Rd. We denote by S ′(Rd) the set of tempered distributions on
Rd. An element f in S (Rd) is called a test function for S ′(Rd).
It follows that
S ′(Rd) ⊂D′(Rd),
(D.6)
i.e., any tempered distribution on Rd is a distribution on Rd.
As in the case of distributions, we mean by the phrase “φ(x) is a
tempered distribution on Rd” that it is the distribution kernel of a tempered
distribution φ ∈S ′(Rd).
The space S ′(Rd) is an inﬁnite-dimensional complex vector space.
Some typical examples of tempered distributions are discussed in the
following section.
A necessary and suﬃcient condition for a linear functional on S (Rd) to
be a tempered distribution on Rd is given by the following theorem.
Theorem D.1. Let φ be a linear functional on S (Rd). Then, φ is in
S ′(Rd) if and only if there exist an n ∈N, mj ∈Z+, α(j) ∈Zd
+ (j =

statement can be proved by a method similar to the one used for proving

D.4.2
Transformations
Let T : Rd →Rd be an injective linear mapping and a ∈Rd. Then, T is
bijective since Rd is a ﬁnite-dimensional vector space. For each function f
on Rd, one can deﬁne a function f(a,T ) on Rd by
f(a,T )(x) := f(T −1(x −a)),
x ∈Rd.
(D.11)
It is easy to see that, if f ∈S (Rd), then f(a,T ) ∈S (Rd). Hence, one
can deﬁne a mapping φ(a,T ) : S (Rd) →C by
φ(a,T )(f) := φ(f(a,T )),
f ∈S (Rd).
It follows that φ(a,T ) ∈S ′(Rd).
Symbolically we have φ(f(a,T )) =

Rd φ(x)f(T −1(x −a))dx. Hence,
heuristically, the change of variable T −1(x −a) →x gives
φ(f(a,T )) =

Rd φ(T x + a)f(x)| det T |dx.
Hence, the distribution kernel of φ(a,T ) is given by | det T |φ(T x+a) in terms
of the distribution kernel φ(x) of φ:
φ(a,T )(x) = | det T |φ(T x + a).
The tempered distribution φ(a,I) (the case of T = I) is called the
translation of φ by the vector a.
If T is a rotation on Rd (i.e., T ∈SO(d)), then φ(0,T ) is called the
rotation of φ with T .
The tempered distribution φ(0,−I) (the case of a = 0, T = −I) is called
the space inversion of φ.
Elements of the Theory of Distributions
1021
Deﬁnition D.1. Let φ ∈S ′(Rd).
(i) The distribution φ is said to be translation invariant if φ(a,I) = φ,
for all a ∈Rd.
(ii) The distribution φ is said to be rotation invariant if φ(0,T ) = φ, for
all T ∈SO(d).
(iii) Let G be a linear transformation group on Rd. Then, φ is said to be
G-invariant if φ(0,T ) = φ, for all T ∈G.
Proposition D.1. If φ ∈S ′(Rd) is translation invariant, then φ is a
constant function.
Remark D.1. The operations described in this section are also deﬁned for
distributions.
D.5
Rd-Translation Invariant Tempered Distributions
For each a ∈Rd and a function f on (Rd)n, we deﬁne a function Ud(a)f on
(Rd)n by
(Ud(a)f)(x1, . . . , xn) = f(x1 −a, x2 −a, . . . , xn −a), (x1, . . . , xn) ∈(Rd)n.
We call Ud(a)f the Rd-translation of f with vector a ∈Rd.
Throughout this section, W ((Rd)n) denotes D((Rd)n) or S ((Rd)n).
It is obvious that, if f ∈W ((Rd)n), then Ud(a)f ∈W ((Rd)n). Hence,
for each φ ∈W ′((Rd)n), one can deﬁne a mapping φa : W ((Rd)n) →C by
φa(f) := φ(Ud(a)f),
f ∈W ((Rd)n).
It is easy to see that φa ∈W ′((Rd)n). We call the distribution φa the
Rd-translation of φ. The distribution kernel of φa is given by φ(x1 +
a, . . . , xn + a):
φa(f) =

(Rd)n φ(x1 + a, . . . , xn + a)f(x1, . . . , xn)dx1 · · · dxn.
A distribution φ ∈W ′((Rd)n) is said to be Rd-translation invariant
if φa = φ, for all a ∈Rd (i.e., φa(f) = φ(f), for all f ∈W ((Rd)n) and
a ∈Rd).

In terms of the distribution kernel φ(x1, . . . , xn) of φ, the Rd-translation
invariance of φ is written
φ(x1 + a, x2 + a, . . . , xn + a) = φ(x1, . . . , xn),
a ∈Rd.
(D.12)
Proposition D.2. Let n ≥2 and φ be an Rd-invariant function on

φ(x1, . . . , xn) = ψ(x2 −x1, x3 −x1, . . . , xn −x1).

Proof. One needs only to take a = −x1 in (D.12) and deﬁne a function
ψ on (Rd)n−1 by ψ(y1, . . . , yn−1) := φ(0, y1, . . . , yn−1), (y1, . . . , yn−1) ∈
(Rd)n−1.
□
The above proposition shows that an Rd-invariant function on (Rd)n
is a function of (n −1) independent diﬀerence variables. This struc-
ture is extended to the case where φ is an Rd-invariant distribution, as
follows.
Theorem D.3. Let n ≥2 and φ ∈W ′((Rd)n) be an Rd-invariant distri-
bution. Then, there exists a distribution ψ ∈W ′((Rd)n−1) such that
φ(f) = ψ(I(f)),
f ∈W ((Rd)n),
(D.14)
where I(f) ∈W ((Rd)n−1) is deﬁned by
I(f)(y1, . . . , yn−1) :=

Rd f(x, y1 + x, . . . , yn−1 + x)dx,
(y1, . . . , yn−1) ∈(Rd)n−1.
Remark D.2. In terms of distribution kernels, (D.14) is written as (D.13).

D.7
The Schwartz Nuclear Theorem
Let n ≥2, dj ∈N, j = 1, . . . , n and F be an n-linear form on the direct
product
S (Rd1) × · · · × S (Rdn)
(see Remark 2.4). Then, F is said to be separately continuous if, for
each j = 1, . . . , n and fk ∈S (Rdk), k ̸= j, the mapping S (Rdj) ∋fj 	→
F(f1, . . . , fj, . . . fn) is continuous in the topology of S (Rdj).
The following theorem is an important theorem, which is an extension
of a separately continuous multi-linear form on S (Rd1) × · · · × S (Rdn) to
a tempered distribution on Rd1+···+dn.
Elements of the Theory of Distributions
1027
Theorem D.5 (the Schwartz nuclear theorem). Let n ≥2 and F be
a separately continuous n-linear form on S (Rd1) × · · · × S (Rdn). Then,
there exists a unique tempered distribution φ ∈S ′(Rd1+···+dn) such that,
for all fj ∈S (Rdj), j = 1, . . . , n,
φ(f1 × · · · × fn) = F(f1, . . . , fn),
where
(f1 × · · · × fn)(x1, . . . , xn) = f1(x1) · · · fn(xn), xj ∈Rdj, j = 1, . . . , n.
For a proof of this theorem, see, for example, Reed and Simon (1980),
Theorem V.1.
Corollary D.1. Let φ, ψ
∈
S ′(Rd1+···+dn) such that, for all fj
∈
S (Rdj), j = 1, . . . , n, φ(f1 × · · · × fn) = ψ(f1 × · · · × fn). Then, φ = ψ.
Proof. This follows from the uniqueness property in the Schwartz nuclear
theorem.
□
Example D.10. Let

Hence, it follows that F is a separately continuous bilinear form on S (Rd)×
S (Rd). Therefore, according to the Schwartz nuclear theorem, there exists a
unique tempered distribution δdiag on R2d such that δdiag(f×g) = F(f, g) =

Rd f(x)g(x)dx, f, g ∈S (Rd). The delta distribution φ0 on R2d discussed
in Section D.3.3 satisﬁes φ0(f × g) =

Rd f(x)g(x)dx, f, g ∈S (Rd). Hence,
δdiag = φ0.

D.9
Convolutions
D.9.1
Convolution of functions in S (Rd)
For functions f, g ∈S (Rd), a function f ∗g on Rd is deﬁned by
(f ∗g)(x) :=

Rd f(x −y)g(y)dy,
x ∈Rd.
The function f ∗g is called the convolution of f and g. It is easy to see
that
f ∗g = g ∗f.
It is not so diﬃcult to prove the following facts5:
(C.1) For each f ∈S (Rd), the mapping g →f ∗g is a continuous linear
operator from S (Rd) to S (Rd).
(C.2) 
fg = (2π)−d/2 ˆf ∗ˆg.
(C.3) 
f ∗g = (2π)d/2 ˆfˆg.
(C.4) For all f, g, h ∈S (Rd), f ∗(g ∗h) = (f ∗g) ∗h.
5See, for example, Reed and Simon (1975), Theorem IX.3.

D.9.2

Example D.13. Let δ be a d-dimensional delta distribution. Then, for all
y ∈Rd and f ∈S (Rd), (δ ∗f)(y) = δ( fy) = f(y), i.e., δ ∗f = f.
D.9.3
Applications: Fundamental solutions for partial
diﬀerential operators
Let P(x) be a polynomial of d real variables x = (x1, . . . , xd) and P(D) be
the partial diﬀerential operator obtained by replacing xj in P(x) with Dj:
P(D) := P(D1, . . . , Dd).
A distribution E
∈
D′(Rd) satisfying the distributional partial
diﬀerential equation
P(D)E = δ
is called a fundamental solution for P(D), where δ is the d-dimensional
delta distribution. Namely, E ∈D′(Rd) is a fundamental solution for P(D)
if, for all f ∈D(Rd),
E(P(−D)f) = f(0),
where P(−D) := P(−D1, . . . , −Dd).
Remark D.6. A fundamental solution for P(D) is not necessarily unique.
For example, if E is a fundamental solution for P(D), then for all u ∈
D′(Rd), satisfying P(D)u = 0, E + u is a fundamental solution for P(D).
See also Example D.14 as follows.
Proposition D.5. Let E ∈S ′(Rd) be a fundamental solution for P(D).
Then, for all f ∈S (Rd), u = E ∗f is a polynomially bounded C∞function
satisfying
P(D)u = f.
Proof. The ﬁrst half of the assertion is due to Theorem D.7(i). Theorem
D.7(i) also implies that
P(D)u = P(D)(E ∗f) = (P(D)E) ∗f = δ ∗f = f.
□
Example D.14. By Example D.4, the Heaviside function θ(x) is a
fundamental solution for the diﬀerential operator D. The function η on
Elements of the Theory of Distributions
1035

η(x) := θ(x) −θ(−x)
2
satisﬁes Dη = δ. Hence, η is also a fundamental solution for D.

Appendix F
Representations of Linear Lie Groups
and Lie Algebras
F.1
A Linear Lie Group and Its Lie Algebra
For a natural number n ∈N, we denote by GL(n, C) the set of all complex
n×n invertible (regular) matrices. This set forms a group with the product
operation of matrices. The group GL(n, C) is called the general linear
group of degree n.
A subgroup G of GL(n, C) is called a linear Lie group of degree n if
it is a closed set in GL(n, C) in the standard topology of the matrix space
Mn(C).
Example F.1. The following sets are linear Lie groups of degree n:
(i) GL(n, R) := {A ∈Mn(R)|A is invertible}.
(ii) SL(n, K) := {A ∈Mn(K)| det A = 1} (K = C or R). This group is
called the special linear group of degree n, or the n-dimensional
special linear group.
(iii) O(n) := {R ∈Mn(R)|tRR = In}, where tR is the transposed matrix
of R and In denotes the n×n identity matrix. This group is called the
orthogonal group of degree n, or the n-dimensional orthogonal
group.
(iv) SO(n) := {R ∈O(n)| det R = 1}. This group is called the special
orthogonal group of degree n, or the n-dimensional rotation
group.
(v) U(n) := {U ∈Mn(C)|U ∗U = In}, where U ∗is the adjoint of U. This
group is called the n-dimensional unitary group.
(vi) SU(n)
:=
{U
∈
U(n)| det U
=
1}. This group is called the
n-dimensional special unitary group.
1043
1044
Analysis on Fock Spaces and Mathematical Theory of Quantum Fields
Let G be a linear Lie group of degree n. Then, it can be shown that
the set
g := {X ∈Mn(C)|etX ∈G, ∀t ∈R}
is a real Lie algebra with commutator bracket.1 This Lie algebra is called
the Lie algebra of G.
Example F.2.
(i) The Lie algebra of GL(n, K) is gl(n, K) := Mn(K).
(ii) The Lie algebra SL(n, K) is sl(n, K) := {X ∈Mn(K)|Tr X = 0}.
(iii) The Lie algebra of O(n) is o(n) := {X ∈Mn(R)|tX = −X}.
(iv) The Lie algebra so(n) of SO(n) is equal to o(n).
(v) The Lie algebra of U(n) is u(n) := {X ∈Mn(C)|X∗= −X}.
(vi) The Lie algebra of SU(n) is su(n) := {X ∈u(n)|Tr X = 0}.
An important relation between a linear Lie group and its Lie algebra is
given by the following theorem.2
Theorem F.1. Let G be a connected linear Lie group and g be its Lie
algebra. Then, for any element g in G, there exist elements X1, . . . , XN ∈g
such that g = eX1eX2 · · · eXN.
F.2
Diﬀerential Representation of Lie Algebras
Let G be a linear Lie group and g be its Lie algebra. Let ρ : G →
GL(V ) be a continuous representation of G (see Section 2.9.2) with V a
ﬁnite-dimensional vector space. Then, it can be shown that, for all X ∈g,
σ(X) := lim
t→0
1
t

ρ(etX) −1

exists, σ(X) ∈gl(V ) (the Lie algebra of everywhere deﬁned linear operators
on V ), and
ρ(etX) = etσ(X),
t ∈R, X ∈g.
1See, for example, Yamanouchi and Sugiura (1960), p. 91, [V].
2For a proof, see, for example, Yamanouchi and Sugiura (1960), p. 104, [V].
Representations of Linear Lie Groups and Lie Algebras
1045
Moreover, the mapping σ : g →gl(V ) is a representation of g (see
Section 4.13). The representation σ is called the diﬀerential represen-
tation of ρ and denoted as σ = dρ.
Since ρ is continuous, it follows that the kernel N(ρ) of ρ is a linear
Lie group. We denote the Lie algebra of N(ρ) by n(ρ). There is a beautiful
relation between n(ρ) and dρ:
Theorem F.2. n(ρ) = {X ∈gl(V )|dρ(X) = 0}(= ker dρ).
For a proof of this theorem, see, for example, Yamanouchi and Sugiura
(1960), p. 118, [VII].
